webTitle: Kennedy acts to curb Lib Dem left

fields.headline: Kennedy acts to curb Lib Dem left
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, has won a key battle against his leftwing activists in a plan to introduce one member, one vote democracy in his party.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, has won a key battle against his leftwing activists in a plan to introduce one member, one vote democracy in his party.

Mr Kennedy won the support of his party executive this week to hold a ballot of the party's 90,000 members on whether the party's key committees should be elected by the entire membership in an annual ballot.

A party executive elected by the membership is thought to be more likely to support some kind of electoral deal with Labour after the next general election. At present, the federal executive and federal policy-making committee are elected by the 2,000 members of the annual party conference.

Leadership sources claim Kennedy is determined to end the dictatorship of "a vanguard of activists" and hand power back to the party membership.

Opponents of the wider franchise claim that only the conference delegates properly know the detailed ability of the candidates. They also argue the cost could be prohibitive.

The ballot on whether to move to one member, one vote democracy will be held in the summer at the same time as the party elects a new party president.

fields.headline: Granada plans separate media listing
fields.trailText: Granada yesterday rolled up its sleeves for the forthcoming fight to take control of the ITV network by disclosing plans for a separate stock market listing of its media division by mid-July.
fields.body:
Granada yesterday rolled up its sleeves for the forthcoming fight to take control of the ITV network by disclosing plans for a separate stock market listing of its media division by mid-July.

The company, which was detailing its £17.5bn merger with the Compass catering group, said it intended to float up to 20% of Granada Media. As well as raising cash, the move would provide more highly valued shares in a pure media group as currency in a bid for either of its ITV rivals.

"This will make very real the underlying value of the media arm which shareholders have felt for some time has been lost," said Granada's chairman, Gerry Robinson. "It will give us a pure media play in the forthcoming bids for United or Carlton and give shareholders a clearer choice."

Granada Media is expected to have a market value of £6bn to £7bn and will be debt free.

Granada said it was minded to bid for either Carlton Communications or United News & Media after being left out in the cold when the pair announced plans to merge last November. The competition commission is due to report on the various combinations by mid-June with trade secretary Stephen Byers expected to give a verdict a month later.

Analysts believe that Granada prefers Carlton over United as a target, not least because it would give the company full control of pay-television business OnDigital.

Mr Robinson, alongside Compass chairman Francis Mackay, expressed regret that the market had reacted adversely to the proposed merger which will see a full decoupling of the hospitality and media parts within 12 months. Compass shares, which fell almost 15% on Monday over disappointment at the lack of a takeover premium, closed another 6.25% lower at 721p while Granada slid 7% to 556p.

"Our share price shouldn't be where it is," Mr Mackay said. "The reaction is related to the unfortunate leak of the deal and we weren't able to talk in detail about the uplift to the hospitality business."

Growth in the combined hospitality business would stay within the 6% to 9% range of the standalone Compass group, he said.

The combined hospitality business will bring cost savings of around £70m a year.

Following the merger, Granada shareholders will own 66.25% of the group and Compass investors 33.75%. Granada shareholders will receive 0.7547 of a Granada Compass share for each one they hold while Compass investors will take a straight one-for-one swap.

What's on the table at TV and catering combine

Granada Media

Produces 6,000 hours of TV programming a year, including Coronation Street, Blind Date and Cold Feet

ITV franchises for Granada, Yorkshire, London Weekend and Tyne Tees

Half share in ONDigital; stakes in Scottish Media Group, ITN and Australia's Seven Network

Pay TV channels including Granada Plus, Men and Motors and MUTV

New media including G-Wizz ISP and stake in Ask Jeeves

Compass Hospitality (including Granada assets)

Contract catering business with revenues of £4.7bn

Food concessions under brands including Upper Crust, Little Chef, Harry Ramsden's, Ritazza and Burger King franchises

Le Meridien, Posthouse, Heritage and Travelodge chains, totalling 58,000 rooms in more than 50 countries

webTitle: Microsoft plea falls on deaf ears

fields.headline: Microsoft plea falls on deaf ears
fields.standfirst: The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: The US government continued to push for Microsoft, the world's largest software company, to be broken up last night in the latest round of the legal battle.
fields.body:
The US government continued to push for Microsoft, the world's largest software company, to be broken up last night in the latest round of the legal battle.

In a 50-page document expected to be filed after stock markets closed in New York, the US justice department rejected the company's plea for far weaker sanctions on its anti-competitive behaviour. Both sides are due to present their arguments to Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in Washington next week.

Last month, Judge Jackson ruled that Microsoft had broken American anti-trust laws by abusing its dominance of the personal computer market. He had indicated a desire to finish the case soon, possibly by this summer. But Microsoft has asked for an extension until December to prepare its case against the government's proposals.

Yesterday's filing was expected to outline the government's view of a prolonged hearing. Separately, official financial records for the US presidential candidates identified George W Bush, the Republican candidate, as a Microsoft shareholder.

The Texas governor has criticised the government's campaign against Microsoft for going beyond laws designed to stamp out predatory pricing.

Dan Bartlett, a spokesman for the governor, said yesterday the shares were in a blind trust and were therefore managed without the governor's knowledge by Northern Trust, a fund management group.

The shares were thought to be worth just over $100,000 at yesterday's stock market price. The financial statement filed earlier this month revealed that Mr Bush's assets include a diversified trust worth more than $1m as well as a 1,500-acre ranch of similar value.

webTitle: Jobs online from Guardian group. It's a work thing

fields.headline: Jobs online from Guardian group. It's a work thing
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Guardian Media Group yesterday accelerated its drive into new media with plans for Workthing.com, an online employment service offering everything from job ads to agony aunt advice on why you failed that interview.
fields.body:
Guardian Media Group yesterday accelerated its drive into new media with plans for Workthing.com, an online employment service offering everything from job ads to agony aunt advice on why you failed that interview.

The website will go live in the summer and aims to operate across all sectors of industry. From the beginning it will carry classified advertising and content from the Guardian newspaper's key franchises in media, education and the public sector. Similar deals are likely to be struck with content providers strong in other employment sectors.

The venture, which has already built a staff of more than 50, aims to become the primary online recruitment service in the UK and will compete head on with servcies such as Monster.com, which launched last year.

Workthing.com addresses key concerns in conventional media companies that classified advertising in particular will migrate online.

The venture claims to have highly sophisticated search engines that will present very specific opportunities for job hunters.

Bob Phillis, chief executive of GMG, which publishes the Guardian, said: "Online recruitment is growing at a phenomenal rate. Workthing.com fits perfectly with GMG's strategy of adapting to markets quickly and professionally, and I am very confident that it will be viewed as an invaluable resource both by employers and people seeking to manage their careers."

The business will make revenues from areas such as job advertising, charging employers to access CV databases and from transactional services such as companies offering employment training.

GMG already runs the family of Guardian Unlimited websites, including Jobs Unlimited, which generates 12m page impressions a month. It also operates Observer.co.uk and the new Learn.co.uk education site.

Workthing.com is headed by Andy Baker, who joined the group from United News & Media, where he was responsible for developing a US-based website for hi-tech professionals.

Carolyn McCall, the managing director-designate of Guardian Newspapers, said the broad-based recruitment service would be complementary to the "vertical" websites run under the Guardian Unlimited brand.

fields.headline: Turfed out for tonsilitis
fields.trailText: 18 May: Can my boss sack me when I'm sick?
fields.body:
The problem

I used to have a part time job working weekends but my boss sacked me when I told him on a Friday that I had tonsillitis. He said I had to bring in a doctor's certificate by the next day but there was no way I could do that because it would have been a Saturday.
Shona Emordy

The solution

It sounds like you have been unfairly dismissed. Insisting on a doctor's note so quickly sounds unreasonable. However, reading between the lines, it seems that your boss did not believe you were ill (or as ill as you claimed) and wanted the note as proof of your condition.

I am puzzled as to how you managed to go into work on the Friday with tonsillitis (which is a somewhat debilitating condition) so perhaps your boss was too. I also wonder whether you could not have got an appointment with your doctor on the Friday (although I do appreciate that many clinics don't provide non-urgent same-day appointments).

The point is that if I have these questions, maybe your boss did too. The real issue, I imagine, is to do with your previous work record. If your level of absenteeism has thus far been very low and you have an impeccable time-keeping record, it seems unreasonable for your boss not to take your word for your sickness or at least give you enough time to get the doctor's certificate. If, on the other hand, your boss has reason to be unhappy with your performance to date, his reaction may not have been so unreasonable.

Only you know whether this matter is worth pursuing. If you think it is, you will need legal advice. Start off at your local Citizen's Advice Bureau or ACAS public enquiry point (see phone book).

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Kenny Garrett
fields.standfirst:
Kenny Garrett
Pizza Express, Dean St, London
***
fields.trailText:
Kenny Garrett
Pizza Express, Dean St, London
***
fields.body:
When people asked Miles Davis where jazz was headed, he said they should go and hear his alto player. That was Kenny Garrett, who was with him from 1986 until Davis's death in 1991. Garrett is at the Dean Street Pizza Express until Sunday with his favourite kind of muscular quartet, playing in a manner that not only gratifies admirers of the expository, dissonant style of the later John Coltrane, but also has enough passion to surprise even the unconverted. In the conservative 90s it was a brave stance that paid off, and it still does.

Garrett has not substantially reshaped the jazz language, being deeply immersed in the transfer of Coltrane's approach to the alto sax. But if that's the last big thing in jazz rather than the next big thing, he continues to reach all kinds of audiences with a predominantly atonal and abstract angle on improvising. This week he is proving that this success comes partly from his steely determination and focus, which cut into the attention of the most distracted audience, and partly from his formidable technique and the selection of consistently thrilling partners. With drummer Marcus Baylor (a young man with much of Elvin Jones's deep, reverberating tom-tom and bass drum sound), plus pianist Carlos McKinney's ability to draw listeners into the subtle implications of repeated rhythmic patterns, and Nat Reeves's softly lyrical bass, Garrett is in scorching form.

He tests the resolve of his audience with a 10-minute howl of free-blasting alto at the outset, reflects on Coltrane's tender side with an atmospheric mid-tempo lament, delivers the classic Giant Steps in a whooping manner that echoes Ornette Coleman as much as Trane, and then shows how amenable he can be with a lighter country-funk theme that reflects the depth of his improvising vocabulary as well as his tonal range on the soprano. Garrett may not yet fully live up to Davis's endorsement, but he has the potential.

webTitle: Boo is first big dot.com casualty

fields.headline: Boo is first big dot.com casualty
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Boo.com
fields.trailText: The UK's internet startup sector last night suffered its first high-profile casualty when Boo.com, the online sportswear retailer, called in liquidators after running out of cash.
fields.body:
The UK's internet startup sector last night suffered its first high-profile casualty when Boo.com, the online sportswear retailer, called in liquidators after running out of cash.

Directors at Boo.com decided to call in liquidators from the accountancy firm KPMG after existing investors refused to add to the estimated £80m they had poured into the firm, which was set up 18 months ago. Boo.com sources indicated it had been looking for an extra £20m to stay afloat.

About 200 staff in London, plus a further 100 in five offices across the world, are likely to learn their fate when they turn up for work this morning.

Boo.com was founded by two 30-year-old Swedes, Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander, and based in London's former fashion hub of Carnaby Street. Technology problems delayed the launch and a raft of senior executives left. In the new year it was forced to cut a quarter of its workforce.

The reverberations are likely to be felt across the domestic internet sector and to be an embarrassment to Boo's heavyweight shareholders, which include the French billionaire owner of the LVMH luxury goods company Bernard Arnault, the Benetton family and US investment banks Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan.

fields.headline: The ripple effect
fields.standfirst:
Random Dance Company
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Random Dance Company
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Wayne McGregor has already made his name as a pioneer of cyberspace, a choreographer whose works are peopled by virtual bodies in extraordinary partnership with dancers of flesh and blood. But in Aeon, McGregor and his design team take us even deeper into the future, with an integration of dance, lighting and graphic animation creating the stuff of science fiction movies.

During the work's prologue the stage is dark except for a single projected image that morphs and dances like some protean life force, spiralling into tentacles, stretching into wisps of plasma and concentrating into a spinal column. Then, startlingly, a new projection lights up the stage, creating the impression that a huge architectural monolith is gliding towards us. Rooms appear within rooms as this craft looms larger and larger. And as our eyes are tricked into a visual tour of its spaces we could almost be revisiting the movie Alien, except that the surprises awaiting us have less to do with extraterrestrial menace than with some of the most beautiful dancing McGregor has yet created.

McGregor doesn't perform in this work and fans may miss his inimitably elongated, flickering virtuosity. But his absence frees the other dancers to look more confidently themselves and also seems to push his own invention in new directions. His trademark stylistic oddities are still there - fish-like ripples of the spine and arms, bird-like movements of the head - but they're now held in tension with a linear, classical dance that is both physically and emotionally more extrovert than his old language.

The dancers move in solos and groups, sometimes half hidden by shadows. Then suddenly the lights switch again and their spacecraft dissolves into a stage that is here and now. The music time travels too, from the ambient sounds of zoviet*france to the baroque music of Corelli, and in response the choreography begins to spin its own more complex variations. McGregor displays a new ambitiousness here, not only in the formal building of his movement but also in its sparking of mood and drama - and it's very exciting to watch. He could easily settle for being the techno boffin of dance, but instead he carries on improving as a choreographer. However technologically literate he is, McGregor's basic inspiration still seems to be the old-fashioned software of human bodies.

fields.headline: Off the beaten track
fields.standfirst:
The Country
Royal Court Downstairs, London
****
fields.trailText:
The Country
Royal Court Downstairs, London
****
fields.body:
Martin Crimp's new play is an assault on the pastoral myth of the country as a place of order, harmony and continuity. What Crimp shows, in this fascinatingly cryptic 90-minute piece, is the fractious disharmony of a deracinated generation less concerned with planting roses than with transferring neu roses from the city to the country.

As in Crimp's last play, Attempts on Her Life, the audience plays the role of detective: we piece together the plot from scattered clues. We deduce that Richard, a doctor, and his wife, Corinne, have moved to the country to start a new life. But the rustic idyll is shattered when we learn that Richard has brought home a young woman he claims to have found lying unconscious by the roadside. Corinne's suspicions, like ours, are instantly aroused: Richard's old drug-habit, his failure to visit a dying patient, the needles in the girl's handbag all become vital pieces of evidence in a tale fraught with deception.

In the past Crimp's plays have attacked urban consumerism. Here he widens his vision to suggest that country life is now filled with transplanted bourgeois desperation. Richard's unseen doctor partner constantly quotes The Georgics; what we get from Crimp is a Pinterish philippic about corrosive deceit and delusion. It works because Crimp artfully withholds information to generate suspense and subtly plays with verbal leitmotifs: the word "track", for instance, constantly recurs, implying both a rural byway and the marks left by a mainlining addict.

The Pinter parallel is reinforced by the use of language as a mask. When Corinne meets Rebecca, the unexpected guest, their encounter is fraught with a semantic nit-picking that conceals mutual hostility: as Rebecca shrewdly remarks, "The more you talk, the less you say." And the last scene between husband and wife is an elaborate verbal dance in which a truth suddenly spoken comes like a blow in the face.

Katie Mitchell's production has the fevered intensity she normally reserves for the classics. Juliet Stevenson's excellent Corinne displays the edginess of someone tiptoeing over eggshells, while Owen Teale as the doctor has the nervous bonhomie of the practised liar and Indira Varma as Rebecca radiates a tetchy sensuality. All contribute to a deeply disturbing play that demolishes Wilde's assertion that "anybody can be good in the country" and adds to the growing catalogue of works charting the bourgeois malaise.

Until June 24. Box office: 020-7565 5000.
fields.bodyText: Martin Crimp's new play is an assault on the pastoral myth of the country as a place of order, harmony and continuity. What Crimp shows, in this fascinatingly cryptic 90-minute piece, is the fractious disharmony of a deracinated generation less concerned with planting roses than with transferring neu roses from the city to the country. As in Crimp's last play, Attempts on Her Life, the audience plays the role of detective: we piece together the plot from scattered clues. We deduce that Richard, a doctor, and his wife, Corinne, have moved to the country to start a new life. But the rustic idyll is shattered when we learn that Richard has brought home a young woman he claims to have found lying unconscious by the roadside. Corinne's suspicions, like ours, are instantly aroused: Richard's old drug-habit, his failure to visit a dying patient, the needles in the girl's handbag all become vital pieces of evidence in a tale fraught with deception. In the past Crimp's plays have attacked urban consumerism. Here he widens his vision to suggest that country life is now filled with transplanted bourgeois desperation. Richard's unseen doctor partner constantly quotes The Georgics; what we get from Crimp is a Pinterish philippic about corrosive deceit and delusion. It works because Crimp artfully withholds information to generate suspense and subtly plays with verbal leitmotifs: the word "track", for instance, constantly recurs, implying both a rural byway and the marks left by a mainlining addict. The Pinter parallel is reinforced by the use of language as a mask. When Corinne meets Rebecca, the unexpected guest, their encounter is fraught with a semantic nit-picking that conceals mutual hostility: as Rebecca shrewdly remarks, "The more you talk, the less you say." And the last scene between husband and wife is an elaborate verbal dance in which a truth suddenly spoken comes like a blow in the face. Katie Mitchell's production has the fevered intensity she normally reserves for the classics. Juliet Stevenson's excellent Corinne displays the edginess of someone tiptoeing over eggshells, while Owen Teale as the doctor has the nervous bonhomie of the practised liar and Indira Varma as Rebecca radiates a tetchy sensuality. All contribute to a deeply disturbing play that demolishes Wilde's assertion that "anybody can be good in the country" and adds to the growing catalogue of works charting the bourgeois malaise. Until June 24. Box office: 020-7565 5000.

webTitle: Deutsche Börse protest over merger that 'puts London on top'

fields.headline: Deutsche Börse protest over merger that 'puts London on top'
fields.standfirst: Costs, currency exposure and exclusion issues threaten exchange deal
fields.trailText: A senior member of the Deutsche Börse board warned yesterday that he would vote against plans to merge the British and German stock exchanges if the deal put London on top.
fields.body:
A senior member of the Deutsche Börse board warned yesterday that he would vote against plans to merge the British and German stock exchanges if the deal put London on top.

The comments from Manfred Zass, the deputy chairman of the Deutsche Börse's supervisory board, underline the difficulties in the way of implementing the merger announced earlier this month.

The Deutsche Börse's board has already voted in favour of the deal in principle but will look at the issue in more detail next week.

Mr Zass, who is also chairman of DGZ Deka Bank, said: "In the event that it transpires that details of the 'merger of equals' clearly indicate domination by London - this could also result from the aggregate impact of the small print - then I will not vote in favour."

Concerns about the detail of the deal have arisen in a number of areas, with members worried about the costs, currency exposure and what will happen to companies which do not qualify for inclusion in either the blue chip or high growth sectors.

The comments by Mr Zass came as officials from the London exchange faced a grilling from MPs about the merger with the Frankfurt exchange.

The officials tried to allay fears that London would lose out as a result of the deal and Don Cruickshank, the chairman designate of both exchanges, insisted that the chances of iX leaving London were "virtually nil".

He also held out some hope of compensation for investors who feel they lost out on April 5, the last day of the tax year when the exchange opened almost eight hours late as a result of a technical breakdown.

Under fire for issuing a statement stressing the "aim" of the merger with the Deutsche Börse was to create trading in euros, Mr Cruickshank was forced to admit that "syntax" had caused some confusion.

The exchange countered concerns that small investors and major pension funds would be forced to buy UK shares in euros but admitted that shares could be quoted in both sterling and euros.

During an often ill-tempered exchange with the MPs, Martin Wheatley, the director of business development, insisted that even if the main listing of a UK firm were no longer in sterling, the exchange would ensure prices in sterling were still available for private investors, newspapers and the calculation of indices.

Mr Cruickshank insisted that any suggestions that the stock exchange had an agenda to encourage the introduction of the euro was an "extraordinarily selective interpretation" of the exchange's attitude.

It would be left to the companies which listed their shares on the market and the investors who bought their shares to decide in which currency they would be traded.

In an attempt to lessen MP's anxieties, the exchange said that less than 1% of UK shares had been traded in euros.

After the "disruption and inconvenience" of the shutdown on April 5, the exchange admitted yesterday that it had taken steps to improve reliability for the future after a report approved by the financial services authority.

fields.headline: Chelsea chairman resigns over charges
fields.trailText: The chairman of Chelsea Building Society has resigned as the accountancy profession's disciplinary body announced yesterday it would be pressing charges against him for his role in the near collapse in the early 1990s of Queens Moat, the hotel group.
fields.body:
The chairman of Chelsea Building Society has resigned as the accountancy profession's disciplinary body announced yesterday it would be pressing charges against him for his role in the near collapse in the early 1990s of Queens Moat, the hotel group.

Mr Hart, the chairman since July 1992, had been due to retire next year.

The joint disciplinary scheme which polices Britain's accountants is laying complaints relating to his role as an auditor of Queens Moat at the time of its 1990 accounts and his subsequent role as a non-executive director at the time of the 1991 accounts.

Both sets of accounts "certainly did not give a true and fair view" of the company's affairs, JDS chief Christopher Dickson said yesterday. Mr Dickson said there were eight complaints in total which broke down into three areas: Mr Hart as an auditor, as a director and as chairman of Queens Moat's audit and remuneration committee.

The tribunal, which has the power to levy unlimited fines and expel an accountant from the profession, will decide if the charges are proven or not.

Queens Moat grew rapidly in the 1980s to become one of Britain's most successful three hotel groups. In the early 1990s the company, which had more than £1bn in debts, was found to have committed accounting irregularities.

fields.headline: Safeway seeks fresh appeal
fields.trailText: Safeway is to give its stores a new look, with greater emphasis on fresh fruit and vegetables, as part of its plan to recover from a 29% drop in annual profits.
fields.body:
Safeway is to give its stores a new look, with greater emphasis on fresh fruit and vegetables, as part of its plan to recover from a 29% drop in annual profits.

New chief executive Carlos Criado-Perez wants to use "market style" fruit and vegetable displays to attract more shoppers into Safeway's 489 supermarkets.

He has also imposed a freeze on new store openings and pledged an end to marketing gimmicks such as "loyalty cards that simply did nothing, rollovers and rollbacks".

Mr Criado-Perez said: "We've got to be a moving target. We want to be unpredictable, so it will be difficult for our competitors to understand what we're doing."

The Argentinian-born chief executive said British supermarkets paid too little attention to presentation - particularly in fresh produce departments.

"It's all process-driven presentation. Boxes from lorries and depots are used to display produce in supermarkets. One of these days they're going to turn the lights off because it's more effective to have no light and spend less money."

The group will refit all its London supermarkets by October with new fresh produce displays, bakery ranges of bread and a new range of high-quality produce. Fresh pasta, meat and fish will get a higher profile and signs and lights will be improved.

Changes since Mr Criado-Perez's appointment include more autonomy for store managers, 323 job cuts at the group's distribution centre in Hayes and local leafleting campaigns to highlight temporary price cuts.

The group's pre-tax profits fell from £334m to £236m, although there were signs of recovery later in the year.

Like for like volume sales rose 9.6% in the second half, against 1% in the first half. The company claimed it was attracting 750,000 more customers a week.

Earlier this month, Safeway became the first large supermarket chain to axe its loyalty card scheme.

Mr Criado-Perez described the ABC cards as "flimsy, worthless pieces of plastic". He said: "There is only one type of customer loyalty, and it's as thin as having the right products at the right price."

Safeway is the country's fourth largest supermarket chain after Tesco, Sainsbury and Asda.

Rather than opening new stores, Mr Criado-Perez wants to catch the rest by increasing the group's sales per square foot from £16 to £21.

One analyst said: "He's certainly confident, but I think people in the City are a bit less confident than him about how easy it's going to be to achieve that target."

However, the analyst - who declined to be named - said that the prospects for the group were gradually improving, and that he had increased his forecast for 2001 profits from £260m to £295m over the past few weeks.

Mr Criado-Perez was appointed following the departure of Colin Smith as chief executive. Safeway has agreed to pay around £1.2m compensation to Mr Smith.

The group said there were no plans at present for chairman David Webster to relinquish his executive role. Mr Webster said he would consider going non-executive "when people stop referring to Safeway as 'struggling'".

Safeway's shares edged up 2.5p to 214.25p, having recovered from a low of 157p in March. The company opened 12 stores last year but will only open two in 2000.

webTitle: Bank set to leave rates on hold

fields.headline: Bank set to leave rates on hold
fields.standfirst: Pound hits low against dollar on mixed signals
fields.trailText: Mixed signals from jobs and earnings data yesterday reinforced the impression that UK interest rates are at or very near their peak, sending the pound crashing to a six-year low against the dollar.
fields.body:
Mixed signals from jobs and earnings data yesterday reinforced the impression that UK interest rates are at or very near their peak, sending the pound crashing to a six-year low against the dollar.

Despite an increase in the pace at which unemployment is falling, earnings growth is starting to ease, according to official data published by the office for national statistics.

City analysts said the favourable combination suggested there was no immediate danger of the labour market overheating, which would probably persuade the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to leave rates on hold again next month.

Minutes of this month's meeting, published yesterday, showed all nine committee members voted for unchanged rates, influenced by the deflationary impact of the strength of sterling against the euro and evidence that economic growth may be slowing down.

The ONS figures showed the jobless total falling on both measures, with the International Labour Organisation definition falling by 20,000 in the past three months to 1,713,000 and the claimant count down by 28,800 in April to a 20-year low of 1,111,800.

The monthly drop of the claimant count was much bigger than the 16,500 average fall over the past three months and suggested that the labour market may be tightening.

However, average earnings growth over the latest three months eased to 5.8%, down 0.2% points from February, as millennium-related payments began to drop out of the data.

ONS officials said the figures were still being distorted by the millennium effect, holding out the prospect of further reductions of earnings growth in the months ahead - although they noted that bonus payments in financial services remained high.

The Treasury warned there was a continued need for responsibility in wage bargaining across the public and private sectors to ensure continued economic stability and growth.

Philip Shaw, of Investec, said the jobs figures should offer some comfort to the MPC but that it was still too early to conclude rates had peaked.

With the pound likely to remain strong against the euro in the short term, the MPC would not be in a "tearing hurry" to move again. Any further increases in borrowing cost would be small, he added.

fields.headline: The sole of Mexico
fields.standfirst:
Titan
Cockpit, Leeds
*****
fields.trailText:
Titan
Cockpit, Leeds
*****
fields.body:
The flyers advertising Mexican band Titan's UK visit proclaim that they're "nothing like you've ever heard before". More than that, they boast a fusion of "Queen, Public Enemy, Chick Corea, jalapenos and David Sole". The initial reaction is to chuckle at the presumably unintentional misprint, but after half an hour of Titan's jawdropping music, only a Starsky & Hutch scriptwriter could refuse to believe that not only is there a David Sole, but he is a major influence on the future course of pop.

Titan (it's pronounced Teet-arn) are very different. The annals of pop aren't bulging with Mexican electronic funk bands, never mind one that looks and plays like characters from a Clint Eastwood spaghetti western. Their image is fabulously preposterous but the glints in their eyes suggest they (and record company Virgin) are well aware of the mileage in selling a gang of wacky, mustachioed banditos to us weirdo-pop starved Brits. But who cares when the "product" is this good?

The Public Enemy and Queen references are misnomers. In fact Titan owe more to the likes of Bootsy Collins, George Clinton, Sergio Mendes, Tito Puente and even the Beastie Boys. And yet, it's impossible to nail them down. Perhaps it's enough to admit that they play the most glorious, spaced-out funky music since Clinton came to earth aboard the Mothership.

A three-piece, they include a mischievous guitarist resembling Spinal Tap's Nigel Tufnell and a frontman/vocalist who could be Joe Strummer reincarnated as a Mexican waiter. On tour, Titan are augmented by a sterling Japanese DJ, who sees no difference in dropping the Chemical Brothers or strange sci-fi music into their narcotic brew.

The real ace in the pack, though, is bassist (and former Mexican child star) Jay de la Cueva. A vision in shades and sideburns with collars the size of small countries, he underpins the sound within gigantic rubbery bass in the same way Bootsy inspired Parliament. Similarly, Titan drop in and out of recognisable forms of music at will, at one point doing things to the Starsky theme that would have David Soul (or Sole) radioing for reinforcements. June's Elevator album and a Rolling Rock advert later in the summer could well see them becoming justifiably massive. In the meantime, they depart the gig in a humble tourbus, when I seriously expected them to ride off on wild horses.

Titan play ULU, London WC1 (020-7344 4444), tomorrow.

fields.headline: Galatasaray 0 - 0 Arsenal
fields.standfirst: Refresh this page for the latest action
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Galatasaray: Taffarel, Penbe, Capone, Popescu, Bulent, K. Suat, Hagi, Davala, Okan, Erdem, Sukur. Subs: Inan, Akyel, Ahmet, Mehmet, Hasan, Hakan, Marcio.

Arsenal: Seaman, Dixon, Silvinho, Keown, Adams, Vieira, Petit, Overmars, Parlour, Bergkamp, Henry. Subs: Lukic, Winterburn, Suker, Grimandi, Malz, Luzhny, Kanu.

Referee: Antonio Nieto (Spain)

1 Henry kicks off for Arsenal with both teams attempting to prove that there is more to the latter stages of this competition than mindless violence off the field by supporters. Henry is looking relaxed and ready to realise the promise of his domestic form.
2 Seaman launches the ball into the Galatasaray half, but only early-doors sparring results
3 Arif has a shot after being played in on the edge of the Arsenal area by Keown.
6 Bergkamp works his way to the edge of the Galatasaray area but there is no one up to assist him and he loses possession.
7 Hagi taks a free-kick from deep on the right flank but directs it straight at Seaman.
8 Overmars plays in Bergkamp from wide on the left: he runs into the area but the ball gets under his feet and runs out.
9 Henry gets away down the left and cuts the ball back from the by-line but is unable to find Parlour 20 yards out from the far post.
10 Overmars charges up from deep in midfield and beats two men but his cross-cum-shot is cleared by Popescu for a corner. Comes to nothing.
12 Galatasaray still awaiting their first meaningful attack.
13 Booking Okan for a foul on Vieira.
14 Keown's free-kick is knocked back for Overmars to shoot high from 25 yards.
15 Hagi lines up for a free-kick 30 yards out, but the ball is played square for Arif to shoot and force Seaman to tip over. Galatasaray's first shot on goal.
17 Overmars plays in Parlour on the edge of the area but Taffarel comes out to save.
18 Booking Bulent for a chop on Parlour.
19 Silvinho makes a great run down the left, cuts inside and crosses into area towards the advancing Henry but Bulent clears well.
20 Galatasaray knock it around at the back before launching a hopeful ball into the Arsenal half. Overmars an ever-present threat on the left for Arsenal.
23 A brief moment of pressure from Galatasaray that calls for discipline in the Arsenal back line when Okan hooks a cross into the area.
24 Booking Vieira for a foul on Okan.
27 Arif centres for Sukur to attempt an overhead kick from just inside the area. Too high.
30 Hagi attempts to inflame things on the pitch by initiating a shove-fest with Parlour, but the Arsenal midfielder is not interested and the referee has a few words.
31 Bergkamp takes a free-kick from deep on the right towards the far post but Adams cannot get behind the ball for a decent header.
35 Arsenal work the ball across the edge of the Galatasaray area; Bergkamp rolls it left and too deep for Overmars, but he recovers and fires in a shot that forces Taffarel to the ground prevent a cheeky goal at the near post.
39 Overmars runs into the area but his shot skims across the face of goal when a cross or knock-back would have been a better option.
41 Booking Keown. The resulting Galatasaray free-kick from deep on the left is played back and Keown provides a timely block when Okan attempts to slide a pass through to Sukur on the edge of the Arsenal 18-yard box.
43 Arsenal wide open at the back as the back four await the offside flag. Suker finds Arif 10 yards out and Arsenal arms go up but his shot flies wide of the far post. A wasted opportunity for Galatasaray.
45 Galatasaray enjoy most possession in the closing moments of the first half as Okan, Sukur and Hagi whip the ball around the fringes of the Arsenal area. Half-time. Arsenal on top during the first half and certainly relaxed about the task in hand, but Galatasaray are beginning to find their range.

46 Galatasaray kick-off and immediately play the ball back for a hoof upfield.
47 Henry rides three challenges 30 yards out before trying to find Overmars on the left.
48 Vieira plays in Parlour on the by-line. He choses to shoot and sees his effort ricochet off the near post. Galatasaray follow up on the break and Sukur comes close to opening the scoring with a right-foot shot that rebounds off the post.
49 All go as Arsenal push up again. Silvinho gets past Hagi on the right and finds Henry. The Frenchman delivers a perfect cross but Keown blows his chance by spooning the ball over the bar from six yards when a tap-in would have sufficed.
52 Galatasaray win a corner, Hagi takes and plays it short but Arsenal clear.
53 Hagi wins another corner under pressure from Keown. Keown slices the ball clear for another corner. Arsenal clear and break with Bergkamp but Galatasaray get back well.
57 Parlour breaks through midfield and plays the ball wide to the right but the move comes to nothing.
59 Bergkamp launches a free-kick deep into the area, but fails to find Vieira and Galatasaray clear. Galatasaray break and Hagi runs merrily around the edge of the Arsenal area, lining up a shot, before finally mis-kicking.
62 Hagi plays the ball wide for Sukur, but his fine cross is cleared well. Galatasaray looking dangerous at the moment and are having the better of the chances so far this half.
64 Kanu starts warming up on the touchline.
65 Henry burgles the ball from Bulent on the edge of the Galatasaray area but his right-foot shot goes wide of the far post.
66 Sukur and Arif looking dangerous for Galatasaray. Sukur plays Arif into the area but he is run off the ball by Arsenal.
67 Arsenal attack on the break but Parlours shot is wide.
68 Henry plays in Overmars, but not well enough and his shot goes wide.
69 Arsenal in the ascendancy now. They win a corner but Taffarel claims.
70 End-to-end stuff as Arif feeds Bulent on the edge of the Arsenal area, but Adams makes the vital challenge before Arif can line up a shot.

webTitle: Politicians who were whiter than white

fields.headline: Politicians who were whiter than white
fields.trailText: Paul Weaver recalls the tales of Westminster politicians who played first-class cricket.
fields.body:
Some prime ministers are remembered for building empires, winning wars or creating the welfare state. John Major is recalled by many for introducing the cones hotline.

This is the man who ran away from the circus to join the bank, the ditherer who put the er in the ERM, the Mr Beanish PM who allegedly tucked his shirt into his Y-fronts and who was so cruelly satirised by that grey puppet in Spitting Image and by the Guardian cartoonist Steve Bell.

The real thing is more substantial than the caricature. The new president of Surrey County Cricket Club is a highly skilled and sometimes ruthless negotiator who should be pressed into service in a game where, in the middle of so many disparate and desperate arguments, the biggest problem is sometimes achieving concensus.

Politicians, tricky and mendacious, can never be entirely trusted. But Major's love and knowledge of the game are deep and genuine, as those of us who witnessed his speech at the Bedser twins' 80th birthday bash will testify.

Beside Lord Home, however, Major was a duffer at cricket. In 1924, as Lord Dunglass, Home made his debut for Middlesex and in 1963 he became the first prime minister with a first-class record. He played 10 matches, scoring 147 runs at 16.33 and taking 12 wickets at 30. He also toured South Africa with an MCC side in 1926-27.

Lord Home of the Hirsel, however, was possibly not the finest cricketer to hole up at No10. Lucy Ridsdale was an outstanding batswoman for the formidable White Heather Club and in 1892, the year she became Mrs Stanley Baldwin, averaged 62. The leading professional batsman that year, Arthur Shrewsbury, averaged 42.

I know this because I've just read it in a little gem of a book called Votes for Cricket, which tells the story of those Westminster politicians who played first-class cricket.

It was pieced together by that most prolific of cricket book writers, the late David Lemmon, and completed after his death by his friend Douglas Smith, the political communications consultant and bon vivant whose infectious laugh has brightened countless gloomy cricket gatherings.

Here, we learn that Clement Attlee described the news ticker tapes at Downing Street as his "cricket machine" since he used it, mostly, for the latest scores.

Here is Canon Edward Lyttelton, of the remarkable Lyttelton family, who could not walk down his nave without wondering whether it would take spin.

And Lord Harris, who captained Kent and England and who appeared in a first-class match at 60 years five months. He was 73 when, as captain of Lords and Commons, he saved the match against MCC by batting for an hour.

Here too is the 5ft 6in George Osbaldeston, known as the Squire of England, steeplechaser, shot (98 pheasants from 100 shots), pugilist, fisherman and cricketer. Osbaldeston represented East Retford for the Liberals from 1812-18 before he gave up Parliament for cricket and became one of the fastest underarm bowlers and most powerful hitters of his day.

A keen gambler, he once took a wager that he could cover 200 miles in 10 hours. Using a fresh horse every four miles he did so with 78 minutes to spare.

Short of temper as well as inches, he was involved in a duel at Wormwood Scrubs in which he and his adversary both missed their targets.

One of the most famous politicians in whites was the third Baron Tennyson, Lionel, grandson of the Poet Laureate. Wounded twice while serving with the Rifle Brigade in the first world war, he went on to captain Hampshire and England with some panache.

Once, while captaining Hampshire, the umpires objected to him shouting to his batsmen at the crease. So he sent instructions by telegram, with the post office messenger boy carrying the envelope out to the wicket.

Lord Tennyson retained the Hampshire wicketkeeper Walter Livsey as his supernumerary in the winter. One dark evening Livsey arrived at the wicket where Tennyson wanted stumps pulled for the day. "What do you think about the light?" he boomed. Livsey replied: "I can hear you, milord, but I can't see you."

Then there was Aidan Crawley, fighter pilot, escaped PoW and documentary film-maker, who played for Oxford, Kent and the Free Foresters. He played for different teams in Parliament too, representing both Labour and the Conservatives.

There is clearly a message in all this. If Tony Blair really intends to win back the hearts of the nation he should hire spinners in place of spin doctors and batsmen in place of whips.

webTitle: Olonga set to dance his way into our hearts

fields.headline: Olonga set to dance his way into our hearts
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe's speed merchant with a smile is music's loss and cricket's gain
fields.trailText: David Foot on why Zimbabwe's speed merchant Henry Olonga is music's loss and cricket's gain.
fields.body:
Henry Olonga is not only Zimbabwe's fastest bowler. He's the team's best dancer - his dainty rhythmic feet approach the wicket more like Gene Kelly than Frank Tyson - the finest singer and, judging from his spectrum of subject matter, probably the most articulate spokesman.

"Hey, H, there's some young guys out there waiting for your autograph." Any suggestion, however, that with his chatty charm, distinctive half-length dreadlocks and intermittently dramatic bowling feats he is in danger of becoming a celebrity, embarrasses him.

Once he was a prize-winner for his singing in school musicals. He has already turned down one opportunity in London for serious tuition. Now, he whispers, there is possible scope for a new future for that tenor voice of his. Could that mean the end of his test cricket, something which would be a minor disaster for his emerging country? He responds enigmatically: "In an ideal world I'd love the two careers to be concurrent."

There is nothing ideal about the lurching economy back home or the farm invasions that dominate the headlines and nag at the consciences of Zimbabwe's players. The team manager Dan Stannard, a former police officer, says: "Our policy is to do our best to concentrate on the cricket and leave others to handle the politics."

Olonga, wise and sensitive beyond his 23 years, says: "We've all got a personal interest in what is happening in Zimbabwe. I think daily of my parents, family, girlfriend, everyone ... The guys must be worried. But it should not distract us from the way we perform. We are professionals, after all."

As the first black Zimbabwean to play for his country, Olonga is conscious of his responsibilities as a role model. He will stand up to speak at a church meeting as fluently as he does when someone engages him in the arts.

That Test debut, against Pakistan five years ago, was a demoralising experience. He was no-balled for throwing, some feared into oblivion. But with the help of Dennis Lillee he reinvented his action. At times he remained wayward, driving his captains to distraction about when to risk him, but he could also produce the occasional ball of exquisite length and unplayable intent. He was, and still is, the speed merchant who could turn a game on its head - as he did with his six for 19 against England in Cape Town in January.

In a team of limited resources and modest budgets for the players, Olonga is typically accessible. There are few obvious egos; too many of the party are currently bereft of confidence in any case. Dave Houghton, their paternal coach, has temporarily left for the more affluent territories of satellite television. The dressing room is regrouping, with Andy Pycroft the new coach.

"There are some new ideas," says Olonga. "We've got a new boss and you can sense signs of excitement. We're a happy dressing room."

Stannard, who is strong on diplomacy, describes his squad as "racially well integrated". The introduction of talented black players is in no way cosmetic. Pommie Mbangwa is there on merit, another amiable young man whose lack of sheer pace is compensated for by his attractive action and the precision you would expect of an older test campaigner.

The diminutive Tatenda Taibu kept wicket against Hampshire at Southampton as if it were a form match at home. He turned 17 on Sunday and is still at school. Seldom can a player at this level have appeared so boyish in appearance. The matronly regulars on the boundary at Northlands Road must have wanted to mother him. In truth he proved, with a performance of quiet, flawless efficiency, that he could look after himself.

Zimbabwe are an engaging rather than intimidating team. Their bowling is mostly medium-paced, or just over, though Mbangwa and Neil Johnson appear none the worse for that. The team chase eagerly in the field, as if striving to enhance their uncertain status. They don't smile a lot but are personable and want to be taken more seriously.

The strike bowler Heath Streak, with 120 wickets from 29 tests, is vital to their prospects in the first test at Lord's starting tomorrow. He has struggled of late with a knee injury but, as a farmer, that is far from his only worry these days.

"When he was unfit it meant a more senior bowling role for me," says Olonga. "I've bowled a lot in the last three months and I think it's probably taken its toll. If anything I've slowed down a little, trying to be more accurate, searching for control as well as pace. Once or twice I've surprised myself by swinging the ball both ways."

And this from an exultant match-winner who, after his sensational three wickets in five balls to beat India by three runs in the World Cup at Grace Road last year, told this reporter: "I've never been length-and-line, you know. They tell me speed is my forte. If I land the ball in the right place then there's a chance of something happening."

Olonga's singing range stretches from opera to R&B and soul. "I like it all and don't know yet which style I'll adopt." That is another facet of his versatility. Like his team-mates, let us hope he is not lost too quickly to the game which he enriches with a face of genuine enjoyment and those restlessly dancing feet.

He has struggled of late with a knee injury but, as a farmer, that is far from his only worry these days. "When he was unfit it meant a more senior bowling role for me," says Olonga. "I've bowled a lot in the last three months and I think it's probably taken its toll. If anything I've slowed down a little, trying to be more accurate, searching for control as well as pace. Once or twice I've surprised myself by swinging the ball both ways." And this from an exultant match-winner who, after his sensational three wickets in five balls to beat India by three runs in the World Cup at Grace Road last year, told this reporter: "I've never been length-and-line, you know. They tell me speed is my forte. If I land the ball in the right place then there's a chance of something happening." Olonga's singing range stretches from opera to R&B and soul. "I like it all and don't know yet which style I'll adopt." That is another facet of his versatility. Like his team-mates, let us hope he is not lost too quickly to the game which he enriches with a face of genuine enjoyment and those restlessly dancing feet.

webTitle: Life at the top holds no fears for reborn Ramprakash

fields.headline: Life at the top holds no fears for reborn Ramprakash
fields.trailText: David Hopps hears Mark Ramprakash expand on his new role as an opening batsman.
fields.body:
Mark Ramprakash's willingness to forgo a family Christmas to act as injury cover in South Africa last winter receives its belated reward in the first Test against Zimbabwe at Lord's tomorrow when he attempts to revive his international career by reinventing himself as an opening batsman.

Although his South African sojourn proved unnecessary and he predictably sat out the tests in Durban and Cape Town, it was then that the idea of his opening the batting first took root in conversations with the captain Nasser Hussain and coach Duncan Fletcher.

"I haven't opened since I was a schoolboy," he said yesterday, "but it provides the potential for making a big score and it's an opportunity I'm eager to take."

He has always possessed a strong team ethic, which became increasingly clear to Fletcher when Ramprakash uncomplainingly accepted an understudy role that others, Graeme Hick among them, had been reluctant to take up.

No one has wanted to succeed more for England than Ramprakash. But his inactive winter provided a chance to reflect on suggestions that his high stress level might have been having a negative effect both on his own game and on those around him.

His assertion yesterday that "I intend to enjoy my cricket more" may simply be telling people what they wanted to hear, but a reappraisal of his occasional tension might be beneficial if he is to accept, at 30, what may be his last chance to fulfil his potential as one of the finest batsmen of his generation.

He has batted at No3 for Middlesex for the best part of a decade, but the failure of the likes of Mark Butcher and Darren Maddy has made a reliable opening partner for Michael Atherton England's priority.

The technical and mental demands of facing the new ball should be far more to Ramprakash's taste than his previous incarnation at No6, when the need to protect England's vulnerable lower order seemed tantamount to an act of cruelty upon so intense a player.

"A lot of good things can come from opening," he said. "And it is a less complicated role than trying to bat with the tail."

webTitle: Spurs smash record as they land £11m Rebrov

fields.headline: Spurs smash record as they land £11m Rebrov
fields.trailText: Alan Sugar's determination to silence his critics took on tangible form yesterday when Tottenham agreed a club-record £11m fee for the Dynamo Kiev striker Sergei Rebrov.
fields.body:
Alan Sugar's determination to silence his critics took on tangible form yesterday when Tottenham agreed a club-record £11m fee for the Dynamo Kiev striker Sergei Rebrov.

It represents a giant leap in transfer dealings for Spurs, who since January 1998 had spent £23m in total on new players.

It also seems to represent a final attempt by the Spurs chairman to counter accusations of stinginess and end his own frustration at failing to make a success of Tottenham on the pitch in the way he has with his other businesses.

The computer millionaire, who once threatened to sell Spurs, now appears to see the purchase of players of the highest quality as the way to win the recognition he craves and the silverware the fans demand. More talent will be purchased over the summer.

Last month David Pleat, Spurs' director of football, promised at least two high-quality signings this summer.

Two Wimbledon players have recently been linked with the Spurs revolution: Scotland's goalkeeper Neil Sullivan and the £6m-rated full-back Ben Thatcher.

Rebrov, who will sign a £25,000-a-week, five-year deal subject to receiving a work permit, represents quite a coup, for he chose Spurs ahead of a possible move to Italy, Arsenal and Rangers despite Tottenham's disappointing season and the prospect of no European football for at least a year.

The 25-year-old also ignored the advice of his fellow Ukraine international Oleg Luzhny, of Arsenal, who said he should "join a bigger and better club".

Rebrov said: "Tottenham managed to find a common language with me." He was unimpressed by Arsenal's decision not to enter talks until after the end of the season.

Spurs, said Rebrov, "have a manager [George Graham] who gets the strikers to run and get the ball. I have played like that all the time."

Rebrov, who as a seasoned international should have no work-permit problems, made his name playing alongside Andrei Shevchenko before his fellow striker's £18m move to Milan last summer. He has scored about 100 league goals for Kiev and 24 in Europe.

"I am looking forward to playing in England," he said. "I like it better than Italian football, although I can't explain why."

Spurs will hope the arrival of such a quality player helps persuade Sol Campbell to stay at the club. But the new signing probably spells the end at Spurs for Chris Armstrong, who has been linked with Leicester, and their previous record signing Les Ferdinand (£6m) as a clear-out begins.

fields.headline: Premiership crowds reach new high
fields.trailText: The Premiership's popularity remains on the up, with figures published yesterday showing an increase in attendances for the eighth season in a row.
fields.body:
The Premiership's popularity remains on the up, with figures published yesterday showing an increase in attendances for the eighth season in a row.

The average crowd was 30,703 and the total number of fans was 11.7m, an increase of 0.4%. The most significant gains were made by Bradford and Watford, whose promotion from the First Division led to rises in gates of 26% and 56% respectively.

Aston Villa were the main exception to the upsurge, with crowds at Villa Park falling by 14%, but Manchester United's average of 58,017 at Old Trafford meant they totalled more than one million fans for Premiership games.

United's Roy Keane and Gary Kelly of Leeds have been ruled out of the Republic of Ireland's summer matches against Scotland, Mexico, the United States and South Africa with hamstring injuries.

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has been put up for sale by Atletico Madrid. The striker, who left Leeds for £12m last summer, scored 24 goals despite Atletico's relegation and has been linked with a move back to the Premiership.

Real Betis, who also dropped out of La Liga, are looking to sell the Brazilian Denilson, who cost them £22m, a world-record fee in 1997.

webTitle: Ipswich and Leeds charged after Wembley ticket inquiry

fields.headline: Ipswich and Leeds charged after Wembley ticket inquiry
fields.trailText: Leeds United and Ipswich Town admitted their culpability last night after being charged with misconduct by the Football Association following an investigation into black-market tickets for England matches at Wembley.
fields.body:
Leeds United and Ipswich Town admitted their culpability last night after being charged with misconduct by the Football Association following an investigation into black-market tickets for England matches at Wembley.

Both clubs have been summoned to Lancaster Gate to explain how an operation involving the Metropolitan Police traced tickets, which were being sold above face value, to their official allocations.

Ten black-market tickets seized before the European Championship qualifying game against Scotland last November had originated at Elland Road, and two tickets for the friendly against Argentina in February had started their shelf life at Portman Road.

"Tickets were found being sold above face value as part of unauthorised corporate hospitality packages. A small number of these tickets were subsequently traced back to the allocations given to Leeds and Ipswich," said the FA spokesman Steve Double.

"Both clubs cooperated fully with the FA inquiry and there is no suggestion that crowd segregation was compromised in either case. They had sold the tickets at face value but under FA rules they remain responsible if the tickets were then sold for higher prices."

The Ipswich chairman David Sheepshanks said: "I am very disappointed that one individual has breached the confidence of the club and it has resulted in the embarrassment of this charge. We know the identity of the person concerned and appropriate action has been taken."

Leeds have also taken disciplinary action against one of their employees. "It was an individual of the club who sold on the tickets at face value," said their chairman Peter Ridsdale. "Even though he made no personal profit, we have taken appropriate action and he will not be receiving tickets again."

fields.headline: English fan stabbed in Copenhagen
fields.trailText: Arsenal have offered supporters on official club trips to tonight's Uefa Cup final a full refund if they do not wish to travel to Copenhagen after an English football fan was stabbed during running battles between Galatasaray and Arsenal supporters.
fields.body:
Arsenal have offered supporters on official club trips to tonight's Uefa Cup final a full refund if they do not wish to travel to Copenhagen after an English football fan was stabbed during running battles between Galatasaray and Arsenal supporters.

The fan was stabbed in the early hours of this morning after a series of clashes outside bars near the City Hall Square. But Copenhagen police spokesman Superintendent Flemming Munch told reporters the wound was not life-threatening. "He has been seriously injured, but he will survive," he said. "We believe he may have been hit in the lung."

Police said that seven people were injured in the trouble, four English and three Turkish, but all - apart from the stab victim - suffered minor injuries.

Arsenal's offer of a refund was made in a handwritten note given to every supporter as they checked in this morning to catch one of their official flights to the Danish capital.

The note, which had been written on Arsenal's headed paper and was handed out by club officials, said: "If any supporter travelling on an official club trip does now not wish to travel to Copenhagen, the club will give a full refund."

Twelve fans opted to stay in England, but the vast majority of the 2,000 supporters scheduled to fly out today decided to attend the game in the Parken Stadium.

Arsenal spokeswoman Amanda Docherty claimed that the club felt it was right to make the offer. She said: "Some people obviously now do not wish to go to the match so therefore it's only right and fair to give them a full refund. The stabbing was an isolated incident and we have been through the city today and the supporters are mixing in the main square and everybody is fine."

Last night's fighting broke out at about 1am when dozens of Turkish fans attacked the Absalom, a disco bar, in which fans of the north London club had been spending much of the evening.

Police in riot gear moved in quickly and the mob began running around the square, approaching another bar, called the Scottish Pub, where one fan hurled a glass at its doors.

When a lull developed in the fighting, the stab victim received extensive treatment on the road in a main thoroughfare leading off the square. Concerned Arsenal fans knelt on the ground around him, using their shirts to staunch the flow of blood, before an ambulance eventually came to take him to hospital.

There followed a further attack on the Absalom, and with the situation still unresolved, a gang of 40 Arsenal fans advanced towards their Turkish rivals and a confrontation quickly broke out.

The fans chased each other across the centre of the square and an attack broke out on a bar and restaurant called Rosie McGee's. All hell broke loose as missiles of all kinds were thrown by Turks at the bar and returned by the English who had rushed to its doors.

Bottles, glasses and bicycles flew through the night air as the battle raged. Again police were quickly on the scene, and officers in full riot gear interposed themselves between the warring factions and officers with dogs finally brought the fighting to an end.

Police said eight men were arrested - four Britons and four Turks - after the scuffles.

Supt Andy Smith, who travelled with the Arsenal fans from north London, said: "I am very sad and distressed to hear of this incident. It has spoiled what had been up until now a very relaxed and good atmosphere."

Later, a Danish police spokesman said: "We had hoped this would not happen but are not shocked that it has, because it was something we had expected more or less. We hope for the best later today."

He also said that despite last night's violence the police would stick to their preparations, and had no plans to close the bars in the city centre.

webTitle: Wealth link to survival with cancer

fields.headline: Wealth link to survival with cancer
fields.standfirst: Survival rates "7% higher" for well off
fields.trailText: People living in the poorer parts of the UK have a significantly lower chance of surviving cancer than those from well-off backgrounds, according to research by the Cancer Research Campaign.
fields.body:
People living in the poorer parts of the UK have a significantly lower chance of surviving cancer than those from well-off backgrounds, according to research by the Cancer Research Campaign.

Survival rates among those in affluent areas suffering the most common cancers are about 7% higher, Gordon McVie, director general of the campaign, said yesterday, adding that social inclusion must go to the top of the government's strategy for tackling cancer.

Professor McVie said 93% of women from affluent areas who had breast cancer survived a year, while in poorer areas the figure was 86%. With bowel cancer, 69% of affluent victims survived a year; in deprived areas 62% survived the period. Similar disparities existed for lung, prostrate and ovarian cancer.

The research showed those from deprived areas often presented for treatment with more advanced cancers. Lack of information and the pressure of child care on a low income might contribute to the disparities.

Derbyshire v Yorkshire

Yorkshire, chasing their third win in as many matches, got an early breakthrough at Derbyshire when Mathew Dowman was caught by Matthew Wood off Paul Hutchison. However the hosts went on to make steady progress off the opening 15 overs to edge the total to 68 for one with Stephen Stubbings (31) and Michael di Venuto (19) the men at the crease.

Leicestershire v Hampshire

Leicestershire made the better start to their First Division clash at home to Hampshire, with Phil DeFreitas taking two early wickets. Jason Laney (eight) and Will Kendall (four) were the men out for Hampshire, who reached 44 for two off 21.3 overs.

Nottinghamshire v Gloucestershire

It proved to be a lucky 13th over of the day for Gloucestershire as Jonathan Lewis grabbed a hat-trick to put winless Nottinghamshire on the back foot in their County Championship Division Two match at Trent Bridge this morning.

Skipper Jason Gallian must have been ruing his decision to elect to bat after winning the toss, as his team lost five wickets in the first 18 overs. Darren Bicknell (two) was run out and then Lewis struck to trap Gallian lbw for 11 and immediately removed Usman Afzaal the same way before having John Morris caught by Thomas Cotterell.

Wayne Noon was then sent back to the pavilion without troubling the scorers as he was adjudged lbw off Michael Smith, to leave the hosts reeling on 40 for five with opener Welton offering some resistance on 30 not out.

webTitle: Suggestion and seduction: the sinister power of Svengali

fields.headline: Suggestion and seduction: the sinister power of Svengali
fields.standfirst: In this exclusive online essay taken from the current edition of the London Review of Books, Adam Phillips wonders whether hypnosis makes a mockery of our ideas of freedom
fields.trailText: Adam Phillips wonders whether hypnosis makes a mockery of our ideas of freedom
fields.body:
Svengali's Web: The Alien Enchanter in Modern Culture by Daniel Pick
Yale, 284 pp., £19.95, 4 May, 0 300 08204 5
Buy it at BOL

First of all we have to imagine a world in which people suffer and have no hope that anything or anyone can make a difference. Then we have to imagine what it would be like to live in a world of people who have no wish to help each other or to feel better. If we don't do this, the history of medicine, and of its country cousin psychiatry, not to mention the history of religion, will hardly seem different from a history of quacks and con-artists ingeniously exploiting the hopelessly vulnerable. The question has always been: what, if anything, can be done? Only when we acknowledge the very real drawbacks of living in a world in which everyone's unhappiness renders everyone else clueless, can we review our contemporary options and their histories with some sense of relief. As unhappiness shows no sign of disappearing - and its staying power makes us look more like fashion victims than truth-seekers in our quest for therapies - we would do better to think of our solutions as inevitably provisional and uncertain, instead of sneering at them. Our misgivings about the available treatments for our contemporary miseries too easily turns into a cover-story for an intolerance of, or impatience with, suffering itself. It was not clear whether (like the psychoanalysis that was born of this tradition) they were solutions, or problems in themselves, or both. Indeed for some people, the fact that these forms of treatment helped the patient was itself the patient's most serious and revealing symptom; and what it revealed was the patient's pathological naivety. People were not being cured through hypnosis, the critics said, they were suffering from being hypnotisable: what they really needed to be cured of was their susceptibility to certain cures. These new treatments, in other words, had ironically disclosed what some feared might be the most terrible, perhaps the most constitutively human problem of all: that people could have considerable influence over each other. That bodies affected each other in daunting and undreamt of ways; that eyes and voices and hands - among other body-parts - were essentially rhetorical organs.

Both as a theatrical spectacle and as a medical treatment, hypnotism made it clear that bodies were persuasive, and that the appetite for persuasion and for being persuaded was exorbitant. It may seem odd, in retrospect, that this should have seemed so shocking. Christianity, after all, was an extravagant acknowledgment of the power of the body; and sexuality, through its various historical formations and deformations, has always been spoken of as a fascination (sex, too, has a reputation for being the problem and the solution). But what the hypnotist exposed, perhaps most devastatingly in such a progressive age as the 19th century, was just how lowbrow people really were. It wasn't truth or goodness they were after: they wanted to be moved. And it wasn't exactly the other person's logic, or their argument, or the information they provided or even their education that was convincing, so much as the look in their eye or their smile. As many commentators - then as now - were quick to point out, this makes politics more volatile than some want it to be, and science much less influential than some think it should be.

The hypnotist and his subject were like a tableau, or a model, of something fundamental and disturbing about human nature. If we are sensual but not that sensible - if we only feel and are barely rational - then hypnotism is not much more than another word for human relations. The question was no longer, could hypnotism be disproved (and therefore discredited), but what was the alternative? What did people do together that wasn't hypnotism, or horribly akin to it? If politics, religion and sexual relations couldn't easily exempt themselves from such a dismaying comparison, why should medicine be able to? Hypnotism was like a terrible cartoon - a secular revelation - of the power people could have over each other, of the enthralled longing to be free from choice. Seeing the amazing things bodies could do to each other - witnessing just how manipulable people's limbs and memories were - made hypnotism as a phenomenon endlessly fascinating, if not actually hypnotic. Since the turn of the last century it has been assumed, or hoped, that a combination of science and history might break its spell. In its sober speculation, and its wealth of often fascinating research, Svengali's Web is in this honourable, but somehow forlorn tradition of lucid and intelligible enquiry into unfathomable craziness.

It is the contention of Pick's book that Du Maurier's once extremely famous novel, Trilby, with its evil, hypnotising Jew, Svengali, was a sensation waiting to happen; and that we have to go back to the beginnings of mesmerism in the 18th century, and forward to the advent of psychoanalysis at the turn of the last century, to understand why. The ground, as Pick shows in impressive detail, had been cleared - or rather, given the many theatrical adaptations of Trilby, the stage had been set - for this particular bestseller. Wittingly or unwittingly, Du Maurier had tuned into the spirit of the age, and turned up the volume.
