fields.headline: Making play pay
fields.standfirst:
New guidelines for teachers mean under-fives may at last to be protected from getting too much too soon.
Curriculum Guidance for the foundation stage, QCA and Dfee. www.qca.org.uk
fields.trailText: New guidelines for teachers mean under-fives may at last to be protected from getting too much too soon.
fields.body:
A little boy wants an apple. "What's the special word?" his mother asks. He pauses, looks anxious, "Full stop?" he ventures tentatively. A funny anecdote or a serious warning? Wendy Scott, chief executive of the British Association of Early Childhood Education, sees it as indicative of the level of anxiety that inappropriate formal learning is creating in our youngest children. For Scott, last week's guidance for the early years, published by the Qualification and Curriculum Authority, with its new emphasis on child-centred learning, is a real victory. "We have the tool we need," she says, "Now it's down to teachers to use it."

When the government published its "learning goals" for three to five year olds last year, there was an outcry. The heads of the nursery schools which the government had itself picked out as "centres of excellence", condemned the goals and said they would; "lower standards, hinder their work, damage development and increase the incidence of special needs by creating failures at five."

Margaret Hodge, the minister responsible, hastily established a consultation exercise and the guidelines were produced in close collaboration with leading practitioners academics and ministers. According to Scott: "If we look back a year it is unrecognisable, unbelievable." Margy Whalley, from Penn Green Centre in Corby, one of those centres of excellence, is equally enthusiastic: "We've won a major battle. We have protected nursery and reception children from getting too much too soon."

And indeed the booklet does seem to have turned the earlier statements of ministers upside down. Back then, Hodge was quoted as saying: "The days of toddlers colouring, cutting and pasting are over." But this document puts playing back at centre stage. As Scott points out: "This is a document about learning and teaching, not teaching and learning. It puts the child first. It is all about how children learn and the role of teachers and adults in observing, responding and extending."

Susan Piers-Mantell and Emma Craigie, were so upset by the imposition of early-learning goals that they set up an organisation called Let The Children Play to protest against it. For them the jury is still out. The guidelines may incorporate good practice but they still suggest that children should be reading by the time they leave reception class - sometimes at barely five years old.

Children like Craigie's daughter who was "mad about stories and pretend writing", but who ran into problems. "I thought school would be a breeze for her," says Craigie, "but she very quickly got the message that she was bad at everything. They said there would be no pressure on her to start reading until she was ready, but she could see that everyone else had a reading books. The children would be comparing progress; they would ask what colour book she was on. And the tables were colour coded too. She was on the 'young ones' table. By the time she was in year one it had become the 'special needs' table. Her teacher said 'she just stares out of the window'. She was just put off. She would say: 'I don't want to go to school, I hate work'."

Teachers using the new guidelines ought to give children a better introduction to learning, but there are still problems. The guidelines leave it to teachers themselves to decide whether or not "to cover the elements of the literacy hour and daily mathematics lesson across the day rather than in a single unit of time".

Teachers with mixed age groups may not always choose the teaching methods most appropriate for the youngest members of the class. But even more worrying is the fact that the early learning goals, which have been widely condemned as inappropriate for young children, are still firmly in place.

English early years specialists are still too excited by what they have won to worry about what they might have conceded, but most are still looking longingly across the Irish sea where the Northern Ireland equivalent of the QCA is consulting on a very different approach to the early years with no early learning goals and the postponement of formal literacy lessons until children are "well over five years old". Says Joyce Hughes, principle officer of the Northern Ireland Council for Curriculum, Examination and Assessment: "We have looked at other countries and we don't know why we are starting so much younger. They start older and they still get there but with far less pain."

Its a shame that those setting the curriculum in England don't appear to be reading from the same text book.

fields.headline: 'Doing' family in Silicon Valley
fields.standfirst: In the epicentre of the New Economy, 'family' is no longer a noun but a verb, a loved child is one who returns home to a voicemail from mom and 'couple time' is spent sitting side by side comparing emails.  Emma Brockes  on what happens to parenting when work is allowed to take over
fields.trailText: In the epicentre of the New Economy, 'family' is no longer a noun but a verb, a loved child is one who returns home to a voicemail from mom and 'couple time' is spent sitting side by side comparing emails. Emma Brockes on what happens to parenting when work is allowed to take over
fields.body:
It is dinnertime in the home of one of Silicon Valley's high powered families and the table is set for five: mom, dad, two kids and a place for one of the family's laptops. Tonight, it is mom's turn to work at the table and she smartly answers emails and builds spreadsheets while her husband reheats the roast chicken he bought on the way home. When they are settled around the table, the kids reel off what after-school activities they're doing tomorrow, and their parents dutifully enter them into their Palm Pilots as if they were meetings with high-level clients. After dinner, the parents kiss them goodnight and promise to page them confirmation by mid-afternoon. Then they return to their screens for a few more hours before bedtime.

The work/life debate, the paternity leave debate, all the negotiations that absorb industrial bodies in Britain today, are, to the families of California's Silicon Valley, like relics from a gentler age that never took hold. Silicon Valley is the company town of the new economy's biggest businesses, Apple, Cisco Systems and Adobe, where people work 12 hours a day and fit "family business" into the gaps between other commitments. As such, it is a useful forecast of what life might be like if we do not reclaim some semblance of a domain outside work; of how we are staring a social revolution in the face.

The most serious impact of the Silicon Valley work model, is on parenting. The dinner table scenario is imagined from research being undertaken by academics at San Jose University. Jan English-Lueck and her team are conducting a two-year study into the lives of 13 middle-class families in the Valley, shadowing them as they go to school, to work or to ballet class, in order to show how technology is changing the way in which families operate. ("Operate" is not a loosely-used term. The discipline with which these test families organise themselves can be as rigorously programmed as a computer operating system.)

One of the causes of this new, highly accelerated pace of parenting, is communications technology. "Work is much more mobile than it used to be," says English-Lueck. "You have a laptop that you can take anywhere, including bed. People have told us that they'll come home in the evening and sit there side by side with their laptops, accessing their email and talking about it with each other. That's what constitutes their couple time." They are never switched off.

Quality time with their children has been effected by the demands of technology. English-Lueck recalls the case of an alienated teenage boy who was tempted back into the family when his mother asked him to explain how a new piece of software worked. "Families in Silicon Valley can use technology to bind them together, or to separate them," says James Freeman, an anthropologist on the San Jose research team.

It is the element of separation that forms the most arresting part of the research, raising as it does the spectre of an environment where children are treated as personnel, where family commitments are scheduled using the principles of management and where it is not unusual for responsible parents to lose track of their kids for a couple of hours, allowing them to slip off the radar because the screen is just too damn crowded. "A child who is five minutes late from hockey practice will throw the parent's whole afternoon schedule off," says Freeman. These families do not operate on a routine, but on a series of last-minute arrangements, re-negotiated as other priorities come up.

There is no room for error in this strictly timetabled world of parenting. Lueck-English recalls an example of how technology is integrated with a tight logistical schedule. "The parent was a little bit late picking up the son from school for a singing lesson. Because she had come directly from work, she did not know whether the lesson had been cancelled or not. So she called her other son, had him check the voicemail at home and call her back on the cell phone, all before she got to the intersection where she had to make the turn off for the teacher's house. And that's the way in which people work out the logistics of their day at a very fast, mobile pace."

A principal barometer of this speed-parenting, is the crossover of language between work and home environments, between managing employees and managing children. "People are using the language of management and technology in the home," says English-Lueck. "There are a lot of technological metaphors. People talk about their 'downtime'; they ask themselves, 'how many cycles do I have to burn?' I once heard somebody say, 'I don't have the bandwidth to take on girl scouts.' When you mix bandwith with girl scouts, clearly there's something going on."

Most revealingly, perhaps, is the way in which the word "family" is slowly turning from a noun, into a verb. Parents in Silicon Valley have been overheard talking about the need for "doing family," as if it were less of a static unit than one of many activities to be fitted around other obligations. When a parent talks about spending "quality time" with his child, it is not a vague reference to hanging out with him or her on the weekend. It is used as a direct oppositional to "quantity time," with the belief that, like everything else in Silicon Valley, if you concentrate hard enough you can achieve just as much in a condensed period as across a longer stretch of time.

If this is the case, then parenting is something you do in short, sharp bursts, dosing your children up with parental lessons, so that they have something to work on in your absence. The distinction between work and home blurs to the extent that they can't be viewed as separate domains. The only way to survive as a parent, is to organise your kids as you would your clients, negotiating a contract with your partner over who takes responsibility for which bits of childcare, in extreme cases, "pitching" for more relaxed duties.

What this means in practical terms is a sort of Palm Pilot parenting. "My interviewees now talk of using their upgraded Palm Pilots to fully integrate home/work divisions of labour," says English-Lueck. "They beam their schedules to each other. Message machines and pagers allow plans to be created, shifted and coordinated in the space of a single afternoon. In such a world, family may partially dissolve as a distinct cultural domain and become yet another site of work, while workplace relationships become assimilated into the rubric of family."

To be a well-cared-for child in one of these families is to return home from school not to the physical presence of a mother or father, but to a text message expressing the hope that they had a good day or some other virtual manifestation of an absent parent. Being in electronic contact with a child is what good parenting is about.

If this all sounds like a mild form of child abuse, the San Jose researchers have raised what they believe to be the positive aspects of the new order. Whereas parents used to keep discussions about work entirely out of the home, children are now invited to take part in them. Work is not a cold, distant environment, hostile to family life, but one that is interweaved into the very fabric of familial relations. Children, particularly those highly atuned to new technologies, can act as informal "consultants" to their parents. Parents meanwhile, will combine caring for their kids with flagrant networking. "Family gatherings and social occasions, can be occasions for work-related discussions," says Lueck-English.

In this context, family is not a constant, a bedrock on which all else rests. It is something that one connects and disconnects with, that appears in the diary as a series of singular events. "We asked people what made them a family. Repeatedly the answer was 'we do things together.' To these interviewees, the family is not a natural unit that simply exists, but one defined by action."

webTitle: Why I'm not quite all there

fields.headline: Why I'm not quite all there
fields.standfirst: The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: "Your problem, Mr Stone, is that you only half exist." No surprises there: I've often had the feeling that I'm not all there. Coming from a solicitor, though, the observation had the paradoxical effect of confirming the full measure of my incompleteness. How nice to find it recognised in law.
fields.body:
"Your problem, Mr Stone, is that you only half exist." No surprises there: I've often had the feeling that I'm not all there. Coming from a solicitor, though, the observation had the paradoxical effect of confirming the full measure of my incompleteness. How nice to find it recognised in law.

The solicitor explained that Dilys, my darling ex, could pursue me for money if she got the urge, but I could do damn all should she move our children Gloria, Jed and Billy to the other end of the country, change their schools, or even change their names. This imbalance does not arise because I am a lunatic, a layabout and a beast: I am, of course, all those things, but that isn't the point. It is that Dilys and I were never married, and unless the government gets around to equalising things, unmarried fathers enjoy no automatic parental rights, even if they share parental care.

"Is that fair?" I inquired, not wanting to be told. I had no wish to go meandering through some moral maze. This drawling member of the legal profession charges £130 an hour. Tick, tick, tick . . .

"That depends on your point of view," he answered. "One supposes it made sense to privilege the unmarried mother because it is usually she who bears the burden of childcare after relationships fail, while the unmarried father frequently disappears. On the other hand, not all unmarried fathers are, as it were, just passing through . . ."

"Or just passed over, as in my case," I cut in, glancing impecuniously at the clock.

Whatever was I doing in his office? Well, it all began when Gloria had one of her headaches: competitive headaches, I call them, due to my suspicion that she cannot bear to be the only girl in her circle without an imaginary ailment. Hence my tenderness when she tries out her Dying Swan act in my presence: "You find an aspirin, I'll fetch a priest."

This last headache, though, may have had some substance. I didn't reach this conclusion simply because Gloria returned from school via her "other house" clutching an explanatory note from Dilys. On the contrary, I find Dilys equally unconvincing in these matters. To her, the kids' most implausible illnesses represent a chance to curry favour. Oh, the cosseting and cooing! Oh, the cold compresses! Oh, the preparation of improbable potions from one of Chris The Pillock's mystic medicine books: Get Well With Gandalf, I expect.

No, the reason I took Gloria more seriously this time was her muttering about Dilys rushing her to a doctor. Oddly, that wasn't mentioned in the note. I called the surgery. Could I speak to the GP who saw my daughter Gloria Stone the other day? Reception could not help me: "We've no one of that name listed here." I persisted: "But she's been with you since she was born. Gloria Stone - 12 years old, turquoise hair, unforgettable in every way." Then I had a hunch: "Try looking under 'Day.'"

Ten seconds later: "Are you Gloria's father?"

"As far as I'm aware."

"We do have a Gloria Day. It looks as if she's been re-filed under her mother's name."

Gotcha!

I spoke to the GP - there was nothing wrong with Gloria that sleep wouldn't put right. But my daughter's health was no longer my main concern. Angrily, I rang Dilys at work.

"Why have you changed Gloria's surname at the doctor's?"

"Oh, is that all you're calling about? I was worried it was something serious."

"Don't piss me about."

"I'm not. I just asked them to list her under my name because it saves confusion."

"What confusion? That is crap."

"Well, listen, Joe," she said, her supercilious tone horribly reminiscent of our final months together, "when was the last time you took any of the children to the doctor when they were ill?"

I hung up. I examined my parental conscience and found it reasonably clear. I leafed through the law firms in the yellow pages. And that's how I came to discover that I only half exist. Still, Mr £130-an-hour seemed to know his stuff. He said I didn't have a legal leg to stand on. I should, therefore, begin by politely inviting Dilys to grant me parental responsibility under the Children Act. She might not want to do it, but if it went to court I'd have an overwhelming case. "After all," he purred, "you're plainly an exemplary father."

His first bill is in the post. It may not be his last.

On the contrary, I find Dilys equally unconvincing in these matters. To her, the kids' most implausible illnesses represent a chance to curry favour. Oh, the cosseting and cooing! Oh, the cold compresses! Oh, the preparation of improbable potions from one of Chris The Pillock's mystic medicine books: Get Well With Gandalf, I expect. No, the reason I took Gloria more seriously this time was her muttering about Dilys rushing her to a doctor. Oddly, that wasn't mentioned in the note. I called the surgery. Could I speak to the GP who saw my daughter Gloria Stone the other day? Reception could not help me: "We've no one of that name listed here." I persisted: "But she's been with you since she was born. Gloria Stone - 12 years old, turquoise hair, unforgettable in every way." Then I had a hunch: "Try looking under 'Day.'" Ten seconds later: "Are you Gloria's father?" "As far as I'm aware." "We do have a Gloria Day. It looks as if she's been re-filed under her mother's name." Gotcha! I spoke to the GP - there was nothing wrong with Gloria that sleep wouldn't put right. But my daughter's health was no longer my main concern. Angrily, I rang Dilys at work. "Why have you changed Gloria's surname at the doctor's?" "Oh, is that all you're calling about? I was worried it was something serious." "Don't piss me about." "I'm not. I just asked them to list her under my name because it saves confusion." "What confusion? That is crap." "Well, listen, Joe," she said, her supercilious tone horribly reminiscent of our final months together, "when was the last time you took any of the children to the doctor when they were ill?" I hung up. I examined my parental conscience and found it reasonably clear. I leafed through the law firms in the yellow pages. And that's how I came to discover that I only half exist. Still, Mr £130-an-hour seemed to know his stuff. He said I didn't have a legal leg to stand on. I should, therefore, begin by politely inviting Dilys to grant me parental responsibility under the Children Act. She might not want to do it, but if it went to court I'd have an overwhelming case. "After all," he purred, "you're plainly an exemplary father." His first bill is in the post. It may not be his last.

fields.headline: How old?
fields.standfirst: It's national breastfeeding week and the message is clear, breast is best. But for how long?  Joanna Moorhead  on life with a toddler who still demands 'booby'
fields.trailText: It's national breastfeeding week and the message is clear, breast is best. But for how long? Joanna Moorhead on life with a toddler who still demands 'booby'
fields.body:
You'd think a Mediterranean beach full of topless sunbathers would have been an uncontroversial place to breastfeed a baby. But no: hardly had I got young Miranda clamped to my boob when a chap I'd been chatting to in the bar the day before sauntered over. "When," he asked, "do you intend to wean her?" A plain enough question, but the meaning was clear. He didn't approve.

I jokily responded with something about how I'd always fed my babies until they were teenagers, but inside my heart sank. Miranda was just one, and I was suddenly remembering how it felt to breastfeed a toddler, and then a child who was more than a toddler. I'd done it twice before, with my older daughters, and now I was embarking once again on what I knew would be a lonely and increasingly isolated path. Because, while it might be generally acknowledged that breastfeeding is best, our society's very clear view is that it isn't best for long. Breastfeed a toddler, as I do, and you soon become aware of the disapproving looks and furrowed brows.

Why so? After all, breastfeeding isn't just for babies. The problem is that our culture, which mistrusts and misunderstands the fundamentals of even early breastfeeding, has failed to get to grips with the fact that it remains a perfectly viable way of supplementing the food - and comfort - of a child of two, three, or even older. Yes, breastfeeding rates may have gone up; and yes, middle-class women may be more likely to start off breastfeeding today than ever: but the first thing many new mothers want to talk about is giving up. For some, it will be in a few weeks, for others, in a few months. But for hardly any will it be in a few years.

I don't know why I didn't put a time limit on breastfeeding, but somehow I never did. It took me more than two months to get to grips with feeding my first baby, Rosie. I remember one night when she was four or five months old and I was having problems with sore nipples my mother-in-law, who bottlefed her children, remarked that I should buy in the formula, because I'd surely be giving up feeding her myself soon anyway. And I was shocked, because as far as I was concerned I'd hardly started.

In fact I fed Rosie right through my second pregnancy: and after Elinor was born, when Rosie was two, I fed my baby on one side and my toddler on the other most afternoons for over a year, during which we all had a much-needed kip. It was blissful: I look back on those times as among the most contented of my life.

Somewhere around the age of three-and-a-half, Rosie had her last breastfeed. I don't recall exactly how it finished, and I certainly don't remember a lump-in-the-throatish final feed: I think she simply decided she was moving on, and I felt neither regrets nor liberation, just that we were entering a new phase. Elinor, who was only 18 months or so, continued to feed until she, too, was at nursery school: and then, like her big sister, she decided to stop.

Then Miranda arrived. With the older two I'd been less confident about following my instincts on introducing solids, but with Miranda I was surer of my ground. She had nothing except breastmilk until she was around seven months old, and my milk was certainly her staple food for the entire first year. After all, mothers did manage to raise their children before baby food manufacturers realised what a wheeze it was to sell them four ounces of pureed carrot ("with no additives") for 60p. It's always seemed logical to me that babies are designed to live on milk until they can feed themselves, which happens anywhere between six and 18 months - which makes you won der why breastfeeding a child of 12 or 13 months seems so controversial.

Even now, at 19 months, Miranda has days when she breastfeeds a lot. She finds it comforting, and I feel I'm her port in a storm if she's a bit under the weather. She certainly seems healthy on it.

Like my older daughters, her first word was "booby", and I know I'll get plenty of disapproving looks as she calls out for it in company in the months and years ahead.

Feeding well beyond babyhood means I've been a breastfeeding mother for seven out of the last eight years. "God - what's it done to your tits?" gasp my friends, and I have to admit that, though the books will tell you it's pregnancy not breastfeeding that changes your breast shape, I know mine are a) considerably smaller and b) considerably droopier than they were when I started out.

Sex is the other thing friends ask about: doesn't a breastfeeding toddler come between you and your partner, they ask. And while I couldn't honestly claim that breastfeeding is good for your sex life (although one study has surprisingly claimed it is, and that women who breastfeed resume sex more quickly after the birth and have more of it), I do wonder whether it's realistic for any of us to talk about "getting back to normal" again. It's not so much breastfeeding as having a baby in the first place that changes your sex life.

Breastfeeding long-term has been easy for me because I work from home, but it can be done even if you work in an office. You don't have to feed your child through the day if you're to feed her at all: some women breastfeed only in the evenings through the week, and then up their feeds to daytimes at weekends. When Elinor was two I left her with my husband and took Rosie away for two days, expecting that Elinor probably wouldn't bother again. I returned to be told she'd been fine, but to my surprise that evening she climbed blithely onto my knee muttering "booby", and we took up where we'd left off.

Many have tried to caution me against long-term breastfeeding: you'll get tired, they say (although I don't), and you'll be feeding them for ever. That's nonsense, of course: even if, like me, you go on feeding for years, in no time at all you'll be looking back from the vantage-point of primary school, as I now do with my older daughters, and it will all be behind you. Breastfeeding, by definition, is never going to be more than a brief spell in the early life of a child: all I'm saying is, it doesn't have to be quite as brief as many mothers make it.

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.trailText: A quick glance at any newsstand in America will reveal the three great passions of American life are getting rich, fashion, and parenting. Correction, make that getting rich, fashion and mothering.
fields.body:
A quick glance at any newsstand in America will reveal the three great passions of American life are getting rich, fashion, and parenting. Correction, make that getting rich, fashion and mothering.

While moms here can spend hours flicking through a glut of magazines designed to give them advice and support, fathers have always been ignored.

Either publishers thought fathers knew it all and didn't need advice, or fathers cared so little about their progeny's development they didn't want any.

But, this month editor Jonathan Scott, 45, proved them wrong. His newly launched Dad's Magazine has flown off newsstands despite predictions to the contrary.

"When I told people I was starting a magazine about fatherhood, they said it would never sell. But with the fathers' rights movement taking hold, with 50% more women working and fathers stepping up to parent, with the Elian Gonzalez case putting fatherhood in the spotlight, I knew the time was right."

Scott, an Illinois-based father of two, said despite parenting magazines purportedly catering to both parents, he always found them "momcentric" and alienating for fathers. "They were just full of articles on breastfeeding and advertising for feminine hygiene products. They never really talked to fathers."

So Scott drew up a prototype that addressed fathering, conducted research, then funded the publication himself.

"What I found was that men did want a magazine, and they wanted it to be a road map for fatherhood. They want advice on how to talk to their kids, what activities to play with them, how to mentor them, and how to address issues when their kids hit adolescence."

The launch issue of Dad's is a mix of reminiscences, humour, and tough talk. Golfer Tiger Woods reveals how his father trained him to be a champion. American comedian Joe Piscopo discusses a bitter custody battle he fought over his son. And there is an article by a son abandoned by his father, which urges fathers to consider the consequences of leaving.

"We want to dispel the notion that if men show too much emotion to their children, they are not being manly."

Website: www.dadsmagazine.com

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: That breastfeeding is best for babies is indisputable. But how do their mothers find it?
fields.trailText: The Question: That breastfeeding is best for babies is indisputable. But how do their mothers find it?
fields.body:
Caroline Watton Mother of Max (7), Louis (5) and Martha and Josie (17 months)

With Max and Louis I went back to work part-time at 12 weeks, and carrying on breastfeeding was my way of getting over the guilt. But I resented having to cut down breastfeeding so early because of work, so I decided I'd stop work before I had my third baby. My third baby, though, was twins, and feeding them together was difficult. I needed help to get them latched on, and emotionally I felt I was kissing two boyfriends at the same time - breastfeeding is an intimate thing. After six weeks I combined breast and bottle so someone else could feed one, and I could concentrate on the other one.
Verdict: Best

Lynne McAllister Mother of Christopher (3) and Sam (1)

I fed both my babies because it was best for them. I wasn't overboard about it - I didn't love the closeness of it, in fact I felt as close to them holding them as feeding them. But it felt natural and I'm glad I did it. My main problem was leaky boobs - it was really grim, there's no way you can feel you're getting back to normal when you're leaking all over the place. I stopped feeding both the boys at five months, and it felt the right thing to do: it opened doors, moved us on. My husband liked feeding them, and it meant he could give them bottles and look after them to give me the occasional break.
Verdict: Grim

Jean Bird Mother of four children born between 1959 and 1966

I enjoyed breastfeeding, and it came easily to me - labour and birth were difficult, but breastfeeding was something I took to and found I could do. I felt very proud of the fact that my body was feeding them, and it's something I still think about occasionally. But breastfeeding was different in my day: you didn't just lift up your T-shirt and give them a quick feed. Then feeds were four-hourly, and the baby had both sides and then that was it for another four hours. You didn't feed in public, no one did. I remember sitting in my car feeding my youngest while my children played.
Verdict: Best

Jas Karlcut Mother of four-week-old Gurpreet

I was keen to breastfeed, but I knew it wasn't easy for everyone. The early days were hard, Gurpreet wanted to feed all the time, and I got very sore. Since the milk came in, though, it's been much easier, especially at night - I don't have to go downstairs to make up bottles or anything. It's a wonderful feeling to be able to spend so much time cuddling her and to look down at this new little person and think how marvellous she is. I find it immensely satisfying. And it's meant my body has returned to normal quite quickly - I'm hungrier than usual because of the extra calories I need for the milk, but my tummy has definitely gone down.
Verdict: Best

Aggie MacKenzie Mother of Rory (8) and Ewan (4)

I'd breastfed a baby before, so I knew they ask for it when they want it. But Ewan didn't ask, and in the days that followed he carried on sleeping a lot and feeding very little. Stupidly I didn't realise how serious it was and at 10 days he ended up malnourished and in hospital. I was devastated: he had to be tube-fed, and he was in for three weeks. I struggled on trying to feed him myself, but couldn't help noticing that when he was given a bottle he guzzled it all down. I felt a failure. I realised I'd judged women who were bottlefeeding, and I now I realised there were good reasons for it. Not everyone can do it.
Verdict: Impossible

Mona Salem Mother of Mohammed (16 months)

Most Arabic women breastfeed if they possibly can, because it says in the Koran that a mother should, and that every drop of milk you give your child is counted by God. I loved feeding Mohammed, but when you breastfeed a toddler in this culture you get stared at, so I've just decided to stop. In my culture when a mother stops breastfeeding she puts bitter herbs on her nipples. I did that three days ago - I felt very sad doing it - but basically I feel I'm doing the right thing in stopping now, so I'm going to persevere. He's had the odd tantrum and I'm really full of milk on one side so it's not easy.
Verdict: Best

fields.headline: On the edge and online
fields.standfirst: Claire Murphy on the increase of email in the work of the Samaritans
fields.trailText: Claire Murphy on the increase of email in the work of the Samaritans
fields.body:
Most people can testify to the cathartic effects of hurling all their frustrations and worries into an email to a friend, particularly when they receive a supportive reply. But for the 25,000 people who emailed the Samaritans last year, those replies were especially crucial. Leo Leibovici, a volunteer at the group's Bracknell branch, says: "I had one email from a clearly suicidal woman saying, 'Waiting for your reply gives me something to hang on for.'"

On Friday the Samaritans will launch their annual awareness week which this year focuses on self-harm and attempted suicide. The problem is becoming more acute among young men - the group that it was originally felt would benefit most from the email facility. "There remains a stigma for young men in talking about their emotions," says Samaritans press officer Emma Charvet. "We're doing a lot of work to encourage men to be more open, and we hope that being able to email us encourages them to get in contact."

Leibovici adds: "Certainly at the start of the service, in 1994, it was generally only young men who were net-literate enough to take advantage of it." These days, although it is difficult to discern gender of most emailers, there is a fairly even split of men and women. However, Leibovici is convinced that there are men who have emailed who would never have phoned.

Simon Armson, Samaritans' chief executive, is in no doubt that email has been helpful to the socially isolated of either gender: "There are people who wouldn't contemplate talking about their feelings, either on the phone or face to face, but who can be highly articulate when using email. It gives them a way to deal with emotions that would otherwise lie within."

There is a far higher proportion of people saying they feel suicidal among emailers than those who phone in, suggesting that the email service is offering a lifeline to the most desperate.

Emails (sent to jo@samaritans.org) are channelled through to one of the 12 branches currently set up to receive them, and replies are sent out within 24 hours. Confidentiality remains as paramount as contacts made via phone: there is a facility for encrypting emails sent in, and emailers do not have to give their name.

"There are obviously differences in style with email," explains Leibovici, who has been answering emails for six of his 10 years as a Samaritan. "There is, for example, no email equivalent of the encouraging noises you make when someone is talking to you on the phone. You have to be that much more obvious about your empathy, perhaps even saying in your reply that you were moved by what they had written."

"There is a certain amount of reading between the lines," adds Armson. "You have to be aware of the significance of what people may not be writing."

Although emails still only represent less than 1% of all approaches to the Samaritans, the service is steadily becoming more popular. In 1997, the organisation received 7,315 emails, a figure that has now shot up by 400%.

Last year, the Samaritans decided to start adding its website address to ads, and attracted another 10,000 emails as a result.

The irony is that as the need for its services increase, numbers of volunteers have fallen to their lowest in 15 years. "It's a big issue for us," explains Charvet. "We haven't actively promoted the email service because we have to be sure we can meet demand." Lottery money has recently financed the addition of a volunteer recruitment officer who will look at new ways of boosting the ranks.

V olunteers are trained to reply to emails as an extra - they continue to take calls, although on separate shifts. Leibovici admits that some volunteers have been nervous of dealing with emails, mainly because of the direct nature of the communication. He says: "With a phone call, people may take half-an-hour to build up to their most pointed emotions. But you can get emails which will start, 'I feel like shit, I want to die', or in two paragraphs will contain the full horror of their situation, both of which can be quite tough to respond to."

The Samaritans' policy is to allow the caller or emailer always to be in control of the exchange, which means that the group will not usually keep sending emails without a response. "Very occasionally we might email someone once, just to ask how they're getting on," Leibovici says. "There have been a few times when I have done this, only to get the email bounced back to me as the account has been closed. Inevitably, you think the worst, but there's no way of knowing what has happened."

Despite its difficulties, Leibovici is an ardent advocate of the Samaritans' use of email. "We didn't start this to be fashionable," he insists. "I feel strongly that we should be available to befriend people in any way they feel most comfortable."

 Volunteer recruitment line: 0990 627282

On Friday the Samaritans will launch their annual awareness week which this year focuses on self-harm and attempted suicide. The problem is becoming more acute among young men - the group that it was originally felt would benefit most from the email facility. "There remains a stigma for young men in talking about their emotions," says Samaritans press officer Emma Charvet. "We're doing a lot of work to encourage men to be more open, and we hope that being able to email us encourages them to get in contact." Leibovici adds: "Certainly at the start of the service, in 1994, it was generally only young men who were net-literate enough to take advantage of it." These days, although it is difficult to discern gender of most emailers, there is a fairly even split of men and women. However, Leibovici is convinced that there are men who have emailed who would never have phoned. Simon Armson, Samaritans' chief executive, is in no doubt that email has been helpful to the socially isolated of either gender: "There are people who wouldn't contemplate talking about their feelings, either on the phone or face to face, but who can be highly articulate when using email. It gives them a way to deal with emotions that would otherwise lie within." There is a far higher proportion of people saying they feel suicidal among emailers than those who phone in, suggesting that the email service is offering a lifeline to the most desperate. Emails (sent to jo@samaritans.org) are channelled through to one of the 12 branches currently set up to receive them, and replies are sent out within 24 hours. Confidentiality remains as paramount as contacts made via phone: there is a facility for encrypting emails sent in, and emailers do not have to give their name. "There are obviously differences in style with email," explains Leibovici, who has been answering emails for six of his 10 years as a Samaritan. "There is, for example, no email equivalent of the encouraging noises you make when someone is talking to you on the phone. You have to be that much more obvious about your empathy, perhaps even saying in your reply that you were moved by what they had written." "There is a certain amount of reading between the lines," adds Armson. "You have to be aware of the significance of what people may not be writing." Although emails still only represent less than 1% of all approaches to the Samaritans, the service is steadily becoming more popular. In 1997, the organisation received 7,315 emails, a figure that has now shot up by 400%. Last year, the Samaritans decided to start adding its website address to ads, and attracted another 10,000 emails as a result. The irony is that as the need for its services increase, numbers of volunteers have fallen to their lowest in 15 years. "It's a big issue for us," explains Charvet. "We haven't actively promoted the email service because we have to be sure we can meet demand." Lottery money has recently financed the addition of a volunteer recruitment officer who will look at new ways of boosting the ranks. V olunteers are trained to reply to emails as an extra - they continue to take calls, although on separate shifts. Leibovici admits that some volunteers have been nervous of dealing with emails, mainly because of the direct nature of the communication. He says: "With a phone call, people may take half-an-hour to build up to their most pointed emotions. But you can get emails which will start, 'I feel like shit, I want to die', or in two paragraphs will contain the full horror of their situation, both of which can be quite tough to respond to." The Samaritans' policy is to allow the caller or emailer always to be in control of the exchange, which means that the group will not usually keep sending emails without a response. "Very occasionally we might email someone once, just to ask how they're getting on," Leibovici says. "There have been a few times when I have done this, only to get the email bounced back to me as the account has been closed. Inevitably, you think the worst, but there's no way of knowing what has happened." Despite its difficulties, Leibovici is an ardent advocate of the Samaritans' use of email. "We didn't start this to be fashionable," he insists. "I feel strongly that we should be available to befriend people in any way they feel most comfortable."  Volunteer recruitment line: 0990 627282

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
Although the story of Atlantic slavery has been told and re-told in any number of books and television documentaries, James Walvin, professor of history at York University, makes no apology for returning to the subject in his latest book, Making the Black Atlantic (Cassell).

He believes something has been missing from the story: the centrality of the slave trade to all aspects of British life in the 17th and 18th centuries and the manner in which slavery generated a set of attitudes towards black people which influenced modern forms of racism. "With a few striking exceptions," he writes, "British historians have tended to regard slavery as a distant issue, of only marginal or passing interest to mainstream Britain."

One reason for such neglect was the relative absence of domestic signs of Atlantic slavery. Walvin remedies this state of affairs by showing how nearly every corner of British life was affected by slavery. Profits from the trade financed the massive 18th-century expansions in the merchant marine, in docks and canals, in agriculture and industry.

But, perhaps most significantly, from the perspective of British economic advancement, was the establishment of a "web of credit" that allowed slave traders to prosper, despite the lengths of time involved in trading from Liverpool to Africa, then to the Americas and thence back home. From this network emerged the financiers, businessmen and manufacturers who were to form the core of early modern industrialists.

Atlantic slavery not only provided the essential conditions for the development of British industrialism, it also created new and unique societies in the Caribbean and North and South America made by the massive importation of enslaved peoples whose sole task was to cultivate commodities for consumption in distant markets. Never before had any society - in the Atlantic world, at least - been so stratified by race.

"From one slave society to another it was the slave's blackness which became a defining characteristic. Slaves were black; only blacks could be slaves."

This, argues Walvin, was slavery's cultural legacy, its contribution to contemporary racism - the abiding belief in black humanity as "deeply and unchangeably inferior".

 Laurie Taylor talks to James Walvin about Britain and the African diaspora on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Too old to care
fields.standfirst: Now even doctors are confirming what elderly people have long suspected - that the NHS is biased against them. Caroline Gilchrist reports on the chilling findings of a new survey
fields.trailText: Now even doctors are confirming what elderly people have long suspected - that the NHS is biased against them. Caroline Gilchrist reports on the chilling findings of a new survey
fields.body:
Half of all GPs say they have concerns about the way in which the NHS may deal with them in old age. This is not exactly what any of us wants to hear, is it? But today's findings from an Age Concern/NOP survey indicate that the issue of ageism in the health service is being confirmed by the profession itself.

Age Concern is still reeling from its findings. Put alongside our large body of evidence of older people's own experiences, they draw a line under the government's insistence that treatment is provided on clinical need alone. Instead, more than three quarters of Britain's 35,000 GPs confirm that age-based rationing does occur. And while nearly all GPs support the principle of priority on the basis of clinical need and no other factor including age, 42% say this is not happening.

The survey provides confirmation of the existence of upper age limits on treatments, from heart bypass operations to the most effective treatment for cancer. Age Concern recently highlighted the case of 65-year-old Leonard Wilson, whose own experience uncovered an apparent policy to refuse heart transplants to anyone over 60. This new survey finds that 63% of GPs are also aware of an upper age limit on heart transplants.

GPs go on to express alarm at the quality of care in hospitals with 43% saying they would have concerns about a frail elderly relative going into their local hospital. One GP commented: "In hospital, you have to be able to feed yourself as the nurses don't do it. If you are frail, you've had it." Another points out: "In our area, we are fortunate to have a good geriatric service, but the attitudes of hospital staff can be a problem. GPs have to apologise for the admission of elderly patients."

This new insight into the NHS comes as part of Age Concern's campaign to tackle the ageism which is inherent at all levels of the service. Over the past year, we have received detailed accounts from over 2,000 older people and their relatives. Many have spoken out with great courage, having suffered appallingly at the hands of the medical profession. Their stories, and the emerging trends in their evidence, were presented in November in a report entitled "Turning your back on us: Older people and the NHS".

Many of these older people ask why they are "fobbed off" by their GPs - often receiving treatment only with the help of an advocate, usually a family member. This new survey begins to provide some answers. It finds that 16% of GPs decide not to make a referral because they suspect that, on account of their age, the older patient won't get treated anyway. One in 10 fail to refer because they know of age barriers. But worryingly, 8% (equivalent to 2,800 GPs) said they thought their patients had already had "a good innings".

Throughout, Age Concern has been left in no doubt as to older people's loyalty to the NHS. Those who speak out against unfair treatment do it because they feel so "let down" by a service they have supported throughout their lives. They are the first to praise good practice, but they also know when they are being denied treatment and the best quality of care.

This point has never been so well highlighted as in the case of 67-year-old Jill Baker, who last month spoke of her horror at finding a "do not resuscitate" (DNR) instruction on her medical notes. Within two days, Age Concern received 100 new cases of resuscitation decisions being made without the involvement of older patients or their relatives.

In a BMJ editorial, Professor Shah Ebrahim asks if there is evidence that DNR orders made with out consent are a barometer for unethical, inadequate care. He concludes: "Our attempts over the past three decades to produce humane doctors and nurses, capable of responding to patients' needs regardless of age, have not been rewarded . . . The first step in making progress is to acknowledge - at the highest level - that stereotyping on the basis of age exists and is unjust."

Today's findings paint a grim picture of a service which is fundamentally stacked against older people. There has never been such a strong case for an inquiry to look at the evidence presented by the public and the growing number of health professionals.

Nearly two-thirds of GPs now support the call for such an inquiry. Here lies an opportunity for progress - and for ministers to prove wrong the GP who believes that the government "knows about it and allows it to go on".

 Caroline Gilchrist is campaigns manager at Age Concern England. A campaign pack is available to the public on 0845-700 9966.

fields.headline: Street wise
fields.standfirst: The government says it wants to encourage us to walk more. But until it improves our urban spaces there's little incentive to do so, says Ben Plowden
fields.trailText: The government says it wants to encourage us to walk more. But until it improves our urban spaces there's little incentive to do so, says Ben Plowden
fields.body:
When the Queen inaugurated the new millennium footbridge over the Thames last week it attracted the sort of attention normally reserved for a major road or tunnel. It would be nice to think this was because London's first-ever bridge for walkers reflected national policies designed to put pedestrians back at the heart of Britain's towns and cities, but the truth is more depressing. In recent months, senior ministers have been backing away from the walking agenda as fast as their legs, or Jags, will carry them.

The most conspicuous casualty of this loss of nerve was the long-awaited national walking strategy. A steering group to draft this document was set up in 1996 by the then transport minister, Steven Norris. Its aim was to identify ways of first stemming and then reversing the historic decline in walking. The draft strategy was handed to ministers early in 1999. Over a year later, the strategy was finally launched in late March. Except it wasn't launched. It was sneaked out via a written parliamentary question. And it wasn't a strategy, having been downgraded to an advice note to local authorities.

Why is New Labour so afraid of pedestrians? The first reason is political. Following the drubbing the government took on transport last autumn, ministers wanted to avoid any suspicion they are promoting walking as a national priority. The deputy prime minister's 200-yard drive at party conference only heightened this paranoia.

This presentational anxiety reflects a deeper problem. Senior Labour ministers and their advisers don't get the point of walking. If they think about it at all, they see it as being like cycling, only more eccentric. Even in transport policy terms, this neglect is unwise. Over a quarter of all British journeys are on foot. This makes walking second only to driving as a form of travel and three times as important as public transport. And nearly all public transport trips involve a walk, making walking the glue in an integrated transport policy.

But the importance of walking in the transport system is the least interesting thing about it. Encouraging walking by creating decent public spaces goes to the heart of New Labour's core concerns. Want to reduce coronary heart disease and obesity at low cost? Then create networks of safe and attractive walking routes so people can walk to work or for pleasure. Keen to tackle social exclusion? Then clean up the streets in the poorest neighbourhoods and reduce traffic speeds so poor children are not five times as likely to be killed by cars as rich ones. Tackle street crime and fear of it by increasing the number of people out and about, particularly after dark.

The government is wrestling with the problems of urban regeneration and out-migration. Richard Rogers' 1999 urban taskforce report identified "poor environmental management and insecurity" as key reasons why so many people have moved away from our towns and cities. Poor environmental management and insecurity mean streets that are full of litter and dog shit, badly lit, poorly maintained, under-policed and deserted after 6pm. Small wonder that those who can escape do so.

Walking matters. It is what people do in the public spaces between houses, shops and offices. It is how they encounter the Galbraithian contrast between private affluence and public squalor. In many ways, the walking environment defines the quality of life in Britain's towns and cites. Improving this environment is fundamental to the New Labour project.

Creating public spaces where people will walk, talk, stop, shop and watch each other is not difficult. We could learn from the owners of shopping centres like Bluewater in Kent, who well understand the economic benefits of a pristine pedestrian environment. But it will take money. We need major capital spending on the physical fabric of our towns and cities. Pedestrianised areas, wider pavements, seating, toilets, public art, trees and better signing all make for a more civilised environment. Contrary to current orthodoxy, spending on these assets is much more useful than devoting cash to new motorways and ever-faster trains.

We also need serious money for maintaining public spaces. Street sweeping, footway repairs, graffiti removal and lighting are all too often cut back in council budgets. These are false economies.

And we need big, high-profile projects like the millennium bridge. Otherwise there is a risk that the walking agenda will seem a little, well, pedestrian.

Above all, we need our elected politicians to stop treating walking as an embarrassment. In an increasingly individualistic world, being pedestrians in public spaces is one of the few things we have in common. As the Bishop of Southwark, the Rt Rev Dr Thomas Butler said in St Paul's Cathedral on Tuesday, projects like the millennium bridge will "help us build the good city". Amen to that.

 Ben Plowden is director of the Pedestrians' Association.

fields.headline: The invisible men
fields.standfirst: Feltham young offenders institution has seen three chiefs come and go in four years. Juliet Lyon on a new man who must now give leadership
fields.trailText: Feltham young offenders institution has seen three chiefs come and go in four years. Juliet Lyon on a new man who must now give leadership
fields.body:
One of our largest and best-known institutions for children and young people has a new leader. William Payne is experienced and well respected in his field, yet his arrival on May 8 went almost unremarked - which is strange because he is the fourth head in four years to lead this institution.

If this institution were a school, particularly a failing school, then another change in leadership would be momentous. But this is Feltham, Britain's largest young offender institution. It contains around 800 of our most vulnerable and volatile boys and young men. The three previous governors didn't resign, they were promoted to senior management positions within the prison service.

Feltham, in Middlesex, is an institution characterised by change. It has a particularly high turnover of staff and managers and a vast catchment area. Half its population is held on remand in a state of uncertainty. Many young men at Feltham will have experienced a disrupted home and school life, poor parental supervision and poverty. They are significantly more likely than other young people to have mental health problems and to have been neglected or abused. It is an institution which, arguably more than most, needs a stable centre and exceptional management.

In 1996, the chief inspector of prisons found Feltham bursting at the seams and functioning as "a gigantic transit camp". Following his unannounced inspection in 1998, Sir David Ramsbotham published a report in 1999 describing conditions as "unacceptable in a civilised country".

A swift response from the then prisons' minister Lord Williams and the director general of prisons Martin Narey led to substantial improvements. Overall numbers have been reduced and a major new building programme is under way. But Home Office records show that the average time out of a cell in 1999 for unsentenced prisoners at Feltham was under three-and- a-half hours per day.

Imprisonment of children and young people should only be used as a last resort. This is clear under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (article 37) and the Home Office guidance on the use of the new detention and training orders. There is no evidence to suggest that prison works for the young. In fact, 88% of the 14 to 16 year olds released in 1995 were reconvicted within two years. Young people growing up in prison will be influenced by their experience. Poor institutions are merely schools for crime.

To have any hope of preventing reoffending, those few young people who should be in prison due to the gravity or persistence of their offending must be held in the best possible institutions with the best possible leadership.

According to the prison service order on regimes for under-18s, drafted by William Payne, the governor "is uniquely placed to influence the culture, ethos and the operation of this estate, thus the custody and care of those young persons held in it".

Governors should be selected and trained specifically to work in young offender institutions. Serving time in them as part of moving up the promotional ladder is not acceptable. They need to understand how to lead institutions full of oppositional young people. They need to show they can look after staff often pushed to the limit. They need to know about applying the principles of authoritative parenting, combining care and control. They must be energetic, visible leaders but, above all, they must like young people and believe in their capacity to change.

I n turn, the prison service has to review its grading and promotional structure, succession planning and management development to make it possible to reward good governors for remaining in post and doing an effective job. This can be done, as shown by two other young offender institutions, Huntercombe and Lancaster Farms.

Staff morale at Feltham has been very low. One manager commented: "Governors come in and make their own changes and none of it is ever sustained." A young prisoner said: "They're the ones in suits. I think the governors only visit. They don't stay in prisons."

Ironically, Feltham's chosen motto is "Challenge and change". The challenge facing Payne is to stay put, to introduce stability and consistency for the first time in years, and by so doing, create a healthy culture in which young people can change and turn their lives around.

 Juliet Lyon is the new director of the Prison Reform Trust.

I n turn, the prison service has to review its grading and promotional structure, succession planning and management development to make it possible to reward good governors for remaining in post and doing an effective job. This can be done, as shown by two other young offender institutions, Huntercombe and Lancaster Farms. Staff morale at Feltham has been very low. One manager commented: "Governors come in and make their own changes and none of it is ever sustained." A young prisoner said: "They're the ones in suits. I think the governors only visit. They don't stay in prisons." Ironically, Feltham's chosen motto is "Challenge and change". The challenge facing Payne is to stay put, to introduce stability and consistency for the first time in years, and by so doing, create a healthy culture in which young people can change and turn their lives around.  Juliet Lyon is the new director of the Prison Reform Trust.

fields.headline: In the line of fire
fields.standfirst: Charities are having a problem attracting trustees due to personal liability for debts. Nicola Hill on advice to potential recruits
fields.trailText: Charities are having a problem attracting trustees due to personal liability for debts. Nicola Hill on advice to potential recruits
fields.body:
Scared off by the daunting prospect of personal liability, charities are finding it increasingly difficult to attract trustees to their board. Treasurers in particular are reluctant to put themselves in the firing line as they are expected to take on key responsibility for ensuring the charity remains solvent.

The list of trustee responsibilities issued by the charity commission runs to 85 points and is quite clear: "If trustees incur liabilities or debts which amount in total to more than the value of the charity's assets they may be sued personally for the difference by the charity's creditors."

Under certain conditions, trustees can take out insurance against personal liability. But to guard against a situation deteriorating to this extent, advice and help is at hand from voluntary sector umbrella bodies and private sector specialists.

The National Council for Voluntary Organisations runs a trustee advice service and board development programme. Tesse Akpeki, head of the development programme, says: "There is a lot of scaremongering about trustees losing their home and car, but if duties are exercised prudently, it can be a fulfilling experience." She advises potential treasurers to find out as much as possible about their responsibilities before taking on the commitment. "A lot of problems are caused by lack of clarity," she says, "but the responsibility is two way: charities should provide a good induction programme for trustees."

NCVO, itself, faces the prospect of finding a new treasurer following the announcement this month of David Taylor's appointment to the charity commission.

Last week, he shared the benefit of his experience with delegates at the charity finance directors' group conference in London. As well as his time at NCVO, his knowledge is built on five years as finance director of WWF-UK and 16 years as a school governor. To avoid being infected by a diseased charity, Taylor told delegates how to diagnose and treat problems before they spread. He recommended that treasurers should be involved in the appraisal of chief executives. "Appraisals can be a good way of finding out if things are going wrong, especially if there is upward or peer appraisal," he said.

Taylor believes treasurers should get to know the finance director and staff and make sure they understand what information is needed from them and why. But as well as being up front with staff, Taylor also told delegates to employ the tactics of a sleuth - advice which may be useful in his new role at the charity watchdog. "Act as a mystery shopper, visit the website to see if it is up to date, telephone in with an inquiry, or try to make a donation," he advised. "It can be quite appalling how donors are treated."

Less surreptitious ways of detecting trouble, he continued, are going on a walkabout around the office and watching the body language of staff who attend the board meeting. Although Taylor admitted no treasurer could do their day job and carry out all his recommendations, he believes even following a little of his advice could help avoid disaster. One of the most important pieces of advice to treasurers was not to let other colleagues on the trustee board opt out of financial responsibility. All trustees are jointly liable for a charity's financial health.

As well as being doctor and sleuth, treasurers were also advised to act like helicopter pilots at the conference. Nigel Scott, finance director of Children's Aid Direct, advised delegates to hover above the day-to- day operations but also to look ahead. "Treasurers are probably going to be there longer than staff, so they should take responsibility for looking three to 10 years ahead."

How far in advance a charity can budget accurately will depend on the certainty of income. At Children's Aid Direct, plans are reviewed every six months. Scott says: "It is not a heinous crime to deviate from the budget, but there needs to be an explanation."

Despite all the advice about avoiding risk, Pesh Framjee, head of the charity unit at accountants Arthur Andersen and Binder Hamlyn, advised treasurers not to be risk averse. "Charities need to take risks to be innovative," he said, but advised treasurers to make sure they are given all the information they need before deciding to take a risk. Once the decision has been made, they should insist on being given information to allow monitoring and evaluation. And, speaking as a treasurer of two charities, Framjee says: "If something does go wrong I want to be woken up at 3am, not read about it in the morning papers."

Kate Kirkland, director of the charity unit at accountants BDO Stoy Hayward, emphasised that it was also the responsibility of charity staff to make sure trustees are able to carry out their duties. "Few charities offer their trustees any training in financial management or even show them how to read the charity's accounts," she said.

When working with boards of charity trustees, Kirkland claims she regularly comes across trustees who cannot tell her the income of their charity, even to the nearest million pounds. "With rising public demand for accountability and the increasing size and complexity of many charities, it is even more important than ever that trustees are in control of the financial management of their charities," she said.

To increase the pool of potential treasurers, the charity finance directors' group is trying to encourage finance directors of large charities to become treasurers of smaller ones. And Pesh Framjee is setting up a group for honorary treasurers to network. Framjee says: "I would certainly encourage friends of mine to become treasurers. We have all become so swallowed up with our jobs, it is a very rewarding experience to put your skills back into the community."

 BDO Stoy Hayward's charity unit provides two trustee development workshops, one for trustees and one for chief executives. Contact Kate Kirkland 020 7486 5888. NCVO's help desk, 0800 2798798; Charity Finance Directors' Group, 020-7247 2112; Pesh Framjee (Binder Hamlyn), 020-7489 9000.

fields.headline: Getting it together
fields.standfirst: Andrew Massey explains how joint partnerships can help charities to reap the benefits
fields.trailText: Andrew Massey explains how joint partnerships can help charities to reap the benefits
fields.body:
Managing voluntary organisations is becoming ever more complex. The National Council for Voluntary Organisations' fourth annual third sector foresight conference, which takes place this Friday in London, seeks to develop the skills of charity chief executives to plan strategically for the future, by discussing the issues currently affecting the voluntary sector, and identifying future areas of concern which could warrant further research and policy development.

The conference will conduct the largest ever survey of voluntary sector senior managers' attitudes, teamed with a wider trend analysis to build a detailed picture of what the sector will be doing over the next 10 years.

One key area identified by the survey was how best to work within a political climate which favours the joint-working or partnership model as the best means of tackling social exclusion and need. This, coupled with a perception among the general public that there are too many charities competing for too few resources.

The overriding message is that each opportunity for joint working must be assessed on its individual merits - both by voluntary organisations and policymakers seeking to work with the sector in tackling social and economic problems.

Within the voluntary sector, there are many examples of high-profile, large organisations working together, such as the disasters emergency committee, the children's promise campaign, and the landmines consortium. But as the large, big brand charities grow in size and smaller organisations find it increasingly difficult to compete, there may be advantages in joint working for smaller organisations.

The national homeless alliance, for example, has announced plans to fundraise for its members under the umbrella campaign "Homeless Direct". There are around 1,000 members of the NHA, all independent charities rather than local branches, and the aim of the new initiative is to promote a new national brand locally and enable people to continue to make donations locally.

Joint working can often be an ideal way to pool resources and risk, reach more users, and increase knowledge and understanding of its client base. But it is not a universal panacea, and policymakers should avoid presenting a general model within which voluntary organisations must sit, whether they like it or not. The voluntary sector thrives on its diversity, and the support it enjoys at a local level, and there is a danger that "tidying up" the sector by encouraging too much joint working could lead to only the largest organisations, which are best able to form partnerships, securing grants and contracts.

Trustees and staff should ask themselves 10 questions when deciding whether or not to work jointly. Is it a legitimate project? Are we optimistic about getting involved? Will there be measurable benefits? Will we be able to demonstrate any "quick wins" to our funders? Will the project demand our full-time attention? Will it have a positive or a negative impact on the relationship we currently enjoy with the prospective partner? Will it help us build coalitions? Are the project aims clear, and is there consensus between the partners over who will run it, and how? Will there be problems with staff feeling an allegiance to their organisation, rather than to the project? Will our organisational structure be hugely affected, and if so, can we deal with this?

It is understandable that some organisations within the sector are wary of working in partnership but if we can learn to see joint working in cooperative, rather than competitive terms, then we will be better equipped to make the right decisions about when, and where, to work together.

 Andrew Passey is head of research at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations.

fields.headline: Delayed sunset
fields.standfirst: The number of British men over 50 forced into early retirement has grown dramatically since the 1980s. Howard Glennerster charts the US experience in which older men are coming back into the workforce
fields.trailText: The number of British men over 50 forced into early retirement has grown dramatically since the 1980s. Howard Glennerster charts the US experience in which older men are coming back into the workforce
fields.body:
Each generation of British men has worked for a shorter period than its predecessor. That is a good thing in so far as it has been a matter of choice, but recently we have seen people forced out of work in their fifties. The difficulty of returning to work, for reasons of health, benefit traps and age discrimination, have kept them out of the labour market. The proportion of men working after the age of 50 has been falling since the 1980s. Of men aged 55-64, less than half are now in the workforce.

Women have been working longer for several decades but their participation, too, has dipped recently for those in their late fifties.

These trends matter not just for the lifestyle, health and self-respect of those concerned but for society's capacity to support a decent life for its older citizens. Whether we finance pensions and health care out of individual savings or taxation, no one will enjoy a great standard of living in old age if we try to fund 80 years of life on incomes earned in only 30 of those years.

This accelerated trend to early retirement is also found in most European countries - indeed, at a higher rate than in the UK. But not so, since the mid-1980s, in the US.

From 1880 through to 1980, the US experienced the same steady fall in labour market participation by older men. Then, in the mid-1980s, American men stopped retiring earlier. US participation rates then rose through the 1990s for men and more sharply for women.

In 1960, the US average retirement age in 1980 was lower than the UK. Now it is a year longer and rising. In the 1990s, the percentage of men in their sixties in the labour force rose by about 0.3% a year and women by about 0.5%. This adds up to a very significant change over the decade.

It is something of a puzzle, but the most obvious explanation is that the American economy has been doing so well that older workers are in big demand. In fact, though, the trend turned long before the present boom. Economists can only explain a part of the change in these cyclical terms. Restructuring and down-sizing have been as prevalent in the US as in the UK.

One difference seems to be that Americans who leave their main job are much more likely to take up new work. Roughly half of all men and women who leave their main job get another "bridging" job. They can take a reduced pension at 62 and work. In the UK, many took incap-acity benefit and never returned to work.

Family incomes in the US stagnated from the 1970s through to the early 1990s. This followed a prolonged post-war rise in incomes. People may have just felt less prosperous. But the trend to longer working lives has gone on after prosperity returned.

There is also a flexible service-based labour market in the US ready to take on older workers. But the UK labour market is also reasonably flexible and service based.

Another possible explanation is the reduced generosity in US public and private pensions that took place in the early 1980s. However, we outdid anything the Americans managed at that point. Our state pensions are smaller and were reduced faster than on the US side of the Atlantic. So that will not do as an explanation either.

Losing health care coverage by your employer before Medicare can be claimed is a major problem for older Americans. But, then, it always has been.

One is forced to conclude that a number of policy changes the Americans made did actually work. The US government made a series of changes to combat age discrimination and remove perverse incentives built into their social security system that encouraged early retirement. These policy changes took place in the 1980s just before the trend changed.

In 1986, Congress passed the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, which prohibited employers from dismissing workers on the basis of age. No contract could specify an end point based on age. Determined employers can find ways round this, but it sends a strong signal.

The 1983 social security amendments raised the normal retirement age at which full pension is drawn from 65 to 67, not immediately, but in full by the second decade of this century. This probably changed people's perception of when it is "normal" to retire. Survey evidence suggests these dates are symbolically important.

Congress also removed the perverse incentive for older people to take their pension as soon as possible. If you waited you lost substantial sums in potential lifetime pension.

The formula changes give Americans a broad age band over which they can retire, receiving reduced pensions if they retire early and much enhanced ones if they retire later. This helps to prevent people in their sixties opting for long-term sickness benefit as the only way to get a benefit. It makes deferred retirement more attractive.

So there are some lessons from the US experience. We should contemplate abolishing age discrimination in labour contracts. We should make sure we eliminate the perverse incentives in the benefit system. We should build on the initiatives already taken to help the older worker back into the labour market. We should think about the impact of the tax regime occupational and private pensions enjoy. The taxpayer subsidises very early retirement in this way. We need to give people a genuine choice about retirement.

 Howard Glennerster, professor of social policy at the London School of Economics, is currently on leave at the National Academy of Social Insurance and the Brookings Institution, Washington DC.
