fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: An Oxfordshire group seeking men to appear in a nude calendar has been inundated with offers from women to vet the candidates
fields.body:
Women's view: An Oxfordshire group seeking men to appear in a nude calendar has been inundated with offers from women to vet the candidates.

Sticky moment: The performance of a play at a Northampton theatre was abandoned during the opening scene when the lead actor's eyes became stuck together because he had used the wrong glue to put on his false eyelashes.

Design fault: The award-winning inventor of a thief-proof lock has had his design records stolen from his house in Bridport, Dorset.

Forehead for business: A regular customer of a takeaway restaurant in Brighton is so impressed with its food that he has had the name and telephone number tattooed on his forehead.

Wailing and gnashing: Staff at Bolton Aquarium, Greater Manchester, held a wake and funeral service in honour of Gnasher the piranha, who had lived to the age of 24.

Seeing red: Tourist officers in West Yorkshire are angry that new signs pointing the way to Brontë country incorporate a red rose.

On the bounce: A jealous boyfriend from Greenfield, Flintshire, was injured when a garden gnome he threw at a window of his former partner's house bounced back and hit him on the head.

Howls of protest: Cheddy the Owl, official mascot of Oldham Athletic football club, has been banned because the head of his new costume is so hideous that it is scaring young fans.

Family viewing: The study of films such as The Godfather trilogy will be included in a module on the mafia as part of a degree course at Coventry University.

Devilish bad luck: Two cars of the same make, colour, age and mileage collided outside The Wizard pub at Alderley Edge, Cheshire, an area associated with witchcraft and the occult.

Noises off: An amateur drama group is auditioning to find a noisy toilet because they want to record the sound of a loud flush for a production in Whitfield, Suffolk.

Birth pains: Organisers of an event in the Tarrant Valley, Dorset, to celebrate the birth of Christ were refused millennium funding because ther project was deemed too religious.

Whether or not? Meteorological experts in Birmingham are unable to say whether this April was the wettest on record because a slug blocked the weather centre's rain gauge.

Mane chance: A hairdressing salon in Thurston, Suffolk, is offering to do hair extensions for balding horses.

fields.headline: Feeding frenzy
fields.standfirst: Biodiversity is second nature to small-scale farmers, the third world's primary food providers. But globalisation is having a devastating and deadly effect on their lives, argues Vandana Shiva
fields.trailText: Biodiversity is second nature to small-scale farmers, the third world's primary food providers. But globalisation is having a devastating and deadly effect on their lives, argues Vandana Shiva
fields.body:
Recently, I was visiting Bhatinda in Punjab because of an epidemic of farmers' suicides. Punjab used to be the most prosperous region in India, but today every farmer is in debt and despair. Vast stretches of land have become waterlogged desert. As an old farmer pointed out, even the trees have stopped bearing fruit because heavy use of pesticides has killed the pollinators - the bees and butterflies.

Punjab is not alone in experiencing this ecological and social disaster. Last year, I was in Warangal, Andhra Pradesh, where farmers have also been committing suicide. Farmers who traditionally grew pulses and millets and paddy have been lured by seed companies to buy hybrid cotton seeds - referred to by the seed merchants as "white gold" - which were supposed to make them millionaires. Instead they became paupers.

Their native seeds have been displaced with new hybrids which cannot be saved and need to be purchased every year at high cost. Hybrids are also vulnerable to pest attacks, and spending on pesticides in Warangal has shot up 2,000% since 1997. Now farmers are consuming the same pesticides as a way of killing themselves so that they can escape permanently from unpayable debt.

Experiences such as these tell me that we are so wrong to be smug about the new global economy. It is time to stop and think about the impact of globalisation on the lives of ordinary people. This is vital to achieve sustainability.

What we are doing in the name of globalisation to the poor is brutal and unforgivable as we witness the unfolding disasters, especially in food and agriculture.

Who feeds the world? It is women and small farmers working with biodiversity who are the primary food providers in the third world. And, contrary to the dominant assumption, their biodiversity-based small farms are more productive than industrial monocultures.

When measured in terms of nutrition per acre, and from the perspective of biodiversity, the "high yields" of industrial agriculture or industrial fisheries do not imply more production of food and nutrition. Planting multiple crops in a mixture will have low yields of individual crops, but will have high total output of food. Research done by the Food and Agriculture Administration has shown that small biodiverse farms can produce thousands of times more food than large, industrial monocultures. And diversity, in addition to giving more food, is the best strategy for preventing drought and desertification.

What the world needs to feed a growing population sustainably is biodiversity intensification, not the chemical intensification or the intensification of genetic engineering. Yet we are repeatedly told that, without genetic engineering and globalisation of agriculture, the world will starve.

This deliberate blindness to diversity, the blindness to nature's production, production by women, production by third world farmers, allows destruction and appropriation to be projected as creation.

Women who produce for their families and communities are treated as "non-productive" and "economically" inactive. The devaluation of women's work, and of work done in sustainable economies, is the natural outcome of a system constructed by capitalist patriarchy. This is how globalisation destroys local economies - and destruction itself is counted as growth.

Because many women in rural and indigenous communities work co-operatively with nature's processes, their work is often contradictory to the dominant market-driven "development" and trade policies. And because work that satisfies needs and ensures sustenance is devalued in general, there is less nurturing of life and life support systems.

Everywhere, food production is becoming a negative economy, with farmers spending more to buy costly inputs for industrial production than the price they receive for their produce. The consequence is rising debts and epidemics of suicides both in poor and rich countries.

Capital-intensive, corporate controlled agriculture is being spread into regions where peasants are poor but, until now, have been self-sufficient in food. The globalisation of non-sustainable industrial agriculture is evaporating the incomes of third world farmers through a combination of devaluation of currencies, increase in costs of production and a collapse in commodity prices.

While farmers earn less, consumers pay more. In India, food prices doubled between 1999 and 2000, and the consumption of food grains in rural areas has dropped by 12%. Increased economic growth through global commerce is based on pseudo surpluses. More food is being traded while the poor are consuming less. When growth increases poverty, when real production becomes a negative economy and speculators are defined as "wealth creators", something has gone seriously wrong.

Global consultants fail to see the 99% food processing done by women at household level, or by the small cottage industry, because it is not controlled by global agribusiness. In India, 99% of agro-processing has been intentionally kept at the small level. Now, under the pressure of globalisation, things are changing.

In August 1998, small-scale local processing of edible oil was devastated in India through a "packaging order" which required all oil to be packaged in plastic or aluminium. This shut down tiny "ghanis", or cold pressed mills. It destroyed the market for our diverse oilseeds - mustard, linseed, sesame, groundnut, coconut.

The takeover of the edible oil industry has affected 10m livelihoods. The takeover of flour, or "atta", by packaged branded flour will cost 100m livelihoods. These millions are being pushed into new poverty, while the forced use of packaging will increase the environmental burden with millions of tonnes of waste.

A global monoculture is being forced on people by defining everything that is fresh, local and handmade as a health hazard. Human hands are being defined as the worst contaminants, and work for human hands is being outlawed, to be replaced by machines and chemicals bought from global corporations. These are not recipes for feeding the world, but stealing livelihoods from the poor to create markets for the powerful.

The US Center for Disease Prevention in Atlanta has calculated that nearly 81m cases of food-borne illnesses occur in the US every year. Most of these infections are caused by factory farmed meat, but now the giant US meat industry wants to dump contaminated meat produced through violent and cruel methods on Indian consumers. The waste of the rich is being dumped on the poor.

Moreover, the wealth of the poor is being violently appropriated through new and clever means like patents on biodiversity and indigenous knowledge. Basmati, neem, pepper, bitter gourd, turmeric . . . every aspect of the innovation embodied in our indigenous food and medicinal systems is now being pirated and patented. The knowledge of the poor is being converted into the property of global corporations, creating a situation where the poor will have to pay for the seeds and medicines they have evolved. Sharing and exchange - the basis of our humanity and of our ecological survival - has been redefined as a crime.

In 1992, when Indian farmers destroyed Cargill's seed plant in Bellary, Karnataka, to protest against seed failure, the Cargill chief executive stated: "We bring Indian farmers smart technologies which prevent bees from usurping the pollen". When I was participating in the UN biosafety negotiations, Monsanto circulated literature to defend its herbicide resistant Roundup Ready crops on grounds that they prevent "weeds from stealing the sunshine". But what Monsanto calls weeds are the green fields that provide Vitamin A rice and prevent blindness in children and anaemia in women.

When giant corporations view small peasants and bees as thieves, and through trade rules and new technologies seek the right to exterminate them, humanity has reached a dangerous threshold. Sustainability, sharing and survival is being economically outlawed in the name of market competitiveness.

In giving food to other beings and species we maintain conditions for our own food security. In feeding earthworms, we feed ourselves; in feeding cows, we feed the soil; and in providing food for the soil, we provide food for humans.

The sustainability challenge for the new millennium is whether global economic man can move out of the world view based on fear and scarcity, monocultures and monopolies, appropriation and dispossession and shift to a view based on abundance and sharing, diversity and decentralisation, and respect and dignity for all beings.

Economic globalisation has become a war against nature and the poor. But the rules of globalisation are not god-given. They can be changed. They must be changed. We can survive as a species only if we live by the rules of the biosphere. As Gandhi had reminded us: "The earth has enough for everyone's needs, but not for some people's greed."

 This is an edited extract of Vandana Shiva's Reith lecture last week. This year's final lecture, by Prince Charles, is on Radio 4 at 8pm tonight.

fields.headline: Breaking free
fields.standfirst: A pioneering drug rehabilitation unit in Norfolk is proving a turning point in the lives of prisoners trying to escape the downward spiral of addiction. Chris Arnot went inside to see how it works
fields.trailText: A pioneering drug rehabilitation unit in Norfolk is proving a turning point in the lives of prisoners trying to escape the downward spiral of addiction. Chris Arnot went inside to see how it works
fields.body:
Sean Oldfield, half way through a four-year sentence for burglary, is sitting in the drug rehabilitation unit at Wayland prison, talking about existentialism. "I'm into Sartre," he confides. "And I've also been reading beat generation writers, like Burroughs and Ginsberg."

Oldfield left school near Sheffield with no qualifications. By 16, he had acquired a heroin habit. By 18, he was sent to prison for the first time for stealing to feed it. Now 24, he's serving his third sentence in six years - and, hopefully, his last. He refuses to accept that the economic devastation of South Yorkshire was any excuse for his previous behaviour. Like Sartre, he now believes in the responsibility of the individual in a seemingly random universe.

The drug rehabilitation unit (DRU) has been "an oasis in a desert, as he put it. "I knew it was time to change, and they've helped me be less impulsive," he says.

The DRU is a small part of Wayland, a category C prison on the edge of Thetford Forest in a sparsely populated part of Norfolk. Near the entrance is a notice with a quaintly old-fashioned tone. Under the 1952 Prison Act, visitors are warned that it is an offence "to convey into the establishment or to an inmate any intoxicating liquor or tobacco". No mention of drugs. Perhaps it goes without saying that bringing in cannabis or heroin is also an offence. Yet the national advisory council for prison visitors believes that half of Britain's 60,000 inmates are users.

"Only yesterday we caught a female visitor passing on heroin from mouth to mouth by kissing," says Rod Cook, drugs strategy co-ordinator at Wayland. "It's a measure of how desperate some of them are. We've invested in CCTV and dogs and that's had a dramatic effect on reducing the supply. But it's a constant battle."

With boredom and temptation so rife in confined spaces, Cook is fully aware there are many offenders who could be dealt with more effectively outside the prison system. "If the resources were available in the community, it would allow the courts more alternatives," he admits.

All the same, Wayland is proud enough of what it's achieving through its unit to allow in not only the Guardian, but also a BBC production team, whose documentary will be broadcast next week.

Senior officer Ellie Griffin comes over as a passionate advocate of the pioneering work that goes on in the DRU. "Prisoners have to want to come in here," she says. "There's not a great clamour to get in because it's not an easy touch.

"In fact, it's seen as totally alien to the normal prison environment. They can't watch telly all day or play snooker. It's a structured community. Everybody gets up early, has breakfast together, goes to the gym and then to meetings together. The system relies on peer support. There's a residents' committee and everyone has to abide by the rules or they're out."

Rule number one is no drugs. Five newcomers were recently expelled after one of them smuggled in cannabis and the others partook. "It happened on a Sunday and they were back in prison by the Monday," says Griffin, who demands honesty from her charges. In return, they are treated "like human beings", called "residents" rather than prisoners or inmates, and given keys to their own rooms. But those rooms are expected to be kept tidy. It's all part of a lengthy process of imposing discipline and personal responsibil ity on to hitherto chaotic lives. Those who stay the course are there for at least nine months.

There are 36 residents altogether, but only 10% of them come from Wayland itself. This was the first unit of its kind when it was set up five years ago and prisoners come from all over the country. But such is the current level of drug-related crime that the government recently invested £72m towards combating abuse in the prison service. By April last year, there were 18 DRUs in England and Wales. By the end of next month, there should be 45.

Wayland is a role model. It employs three full-time key workers, one of whom is Susie Longstaff. "We have to confront them with aspects of their lives that they can be uncomfortable with, so it's not easy for them," she says over lunch in the staff mess. "It's about empowering them to make their own decisions when they leave."

Standing at the serving hatch, dishing up lasagne and chips, is Derek MacDonald, 39, who's doing seven years for robbery, burglary and blackmail. He has just returned from home leave in Leeds, where he stayed with his sister and kept well away from dealers. "It would be difficult to express how disgusted I am with myself and the way I've treated other people," he admits. "I'm not going down that road again. When I first went to prison, it was all cannabis. Then, from about 1992 onwards, there was more heroin about. I got into it and the money just went. The whole prison service should be run like the DRU."

Sean Oldfield would agree. Back in the unit's meeting room, he points to a colourful abstract covering much of one long wall. "That's one of mine," he says. "I modelled it on a Kandinsky." A talented artist then, as well as an existentialist. A would-be editor, too. He has just successfully applied for a grant from the Prince's millennium trust to start his own drug-awareness magazine.

"I want to go to college when I get out of here to study art or psychology," he says. "Probably in Norwich." A fresh start, away from old mates and old haunts in South Yorkshire. But he knows he has two years still to serve. He also knows that the big test will come when he's released.

Will he, as an ex-con with no formal qualifications, be allowed to study? And will he be able, eventually, to earn enough money to fulfil his ambition of travelling around Europe? Above all, can he hold on to the lessons he's learnt in the DRU and stay "clean"?

Everything else could depend on it. He knows that as well.

 Home Ground - The DRU is on BBC2 next Tuesday at 7.30pm.

fields.headline: Movers and shakers
fields.standfirst: Paul Evans  on the questions surrounding translocation as a way of saving woodland from road builders' bulldozers
fields.trailText: Paul Evans on the questions surrounding translocation as a way of saving woodland from road builders' bulldozers
fields.body:
Translocation is an emerging conservation technology which aims to move wildlife from the path of damaging development. Wildflowers, newts and badgers have become ecological refugees, seeking asylum from new roads, airport runways, retail parks and "saved" in special sanctuaries.

One of the most ambitious translocation projects yet is at the M2 widening scheme in Kent which claims to have saved woodland by moving it down the road. The M2 shears through Frith Wood on the eastern slope of the North Downs, south of the Medway towns. An area adjacent to the wood, Cossington Fields, is now a wood in waiting. The soil from the previously arable fields was stripped off and 10,000 tonnes of ancient woodland soil taken from areas affected by road widening was used to replace it; in this 60,000 trees and shrubs were planted and a further 100 hazels were dug from the woods and transplanted here.

As the roads programme rumbles back over the horizon, politicians, developers and ecologists are promoting translocation as a way mitigating, even compensating for, the loss of wildlife habitats. Translocating woodland sounds like a good idea, but is it all it's cracked up to be?

Apart from woodland wildflowers pushing through the mainly bare earth at Cossington Fields, the site looks like any other motorway planting scheme: fences, plastic, straight lines, pernickety design, tidy gardening. Will this really be woodland in 10, 20, 200 years' time? Will it ever make up for real woodland which has been bulldozed, burned and built on?

Against this landscape of loss, translocation is, according to Tony Sangwine, head of horticulture and nature conservation for the highways agency, "the last chance saloon. It can only be used when we're in a tight spot and the road alignment has to go through woodland. We can never claim that translocation can recreate ancient semi-natural woodland, but it gives the best possible chance, for 10 or even 40 years ahead, to have something of ecological quality."

In this respect, translocation has become a tool of environmental pragmatism, but the values involved in employing it require greater public scrutiny.

Stephanie Wray, environmental consultant to the highways agency for the M2 project, says: "There is a lot of confusion and misunderstanding about translocation. This project is one aspect of a mitigation package agreed with English Nature, Kent county council and Kent Wildlife Trust. Ancient woodland is not movable, but translocation is compensation for an area of woodland that has been lost, and it provides nature conservation value."

Carol Hatton, of the World Wide Fund for Nature, insists: "Translocation can never be compensation for the loss of habitat. In our rush to try out a new experiment, we seem to have lost sight of the philosophical issues surrounding translocation which involve an appreciation of the wider landscape, historical and cultural issues."

Mike Townsend, chief executive of the Woodland Trust, says: "The whole concept of ancient woodland is that it has never been cultivated for long periods. The woods may have been managed but the soil has not been moved. The notion that ancient woodland soil can be bulldozed and trucked down the road is untenable."

The character of the woods affected by the M2 widening is very much determined by coppiced sweet chestnut, but because this is not a native tree, Wray would not include it in the translocation plans. "This scheme aims to improve the ecology of what's there to what it would have looked like 400 years ago," she says.

The same appeal to nativeness is applied to dormice. The transplanted hazels are meant to enhance future habitat for dormice, a species protected under EU legislation. Andrew Jones, principal countryside officer for Kent county council, says: "It was only when dormice became protected that we realised they were everywhere. Recent surveys show that dormice seem to prefer new roadside planting to ancient woodland."

This leap in values from translocation as a form of rescue, to compensation for woodland loss, to an ecological improvement on the current condition of the habitat, implies the sort of cultural determinism which still haunts us from the 18th century landscape obsession of improving on nature. Wray denies this and claims that "the different elements of the woodland ecosystem need a scientific understanding of value. It is not about trying to make a faithful copy and not about moving an ancient woodland".

Whatever happens at Cossington Fields, it will not "save" an ancient forest, as the DETR claims. Neither does it represent a "sustainable" way to deliver transport solutions, as the environment minister, Michael Meacher, is quoted as saying.

P eter Buckley, of Wye College, Kent, has been studying translocation projects since the 1980s. "Translocation arises from public inquiries where the treatment of ancient woodland is often cynical," he says. "For scientists, translocation projects are a great playground because you don't know how woodlands work until you mess around with them. What we are trying to do is predict what might happen for a public inquiry. The needs of society and conservation are difficult to reconcile and, in our adversarial public inquiries, truth is often irrelevant."

It would seem, then, that translocation is a misleading term. It is not a facsimile of the original woodland, and yet it arises from the desire to save the original. It is concerned with the conservation value of something which is at least near-natural, and yet it opens opportunities to design and manage in ways which determine what "should" be natural. And in these respects it aims to suit the conscience-salving requirements of mitigation and the aspirations of conservation's management culture.

There is a danger that, as translocation becomes more "successful", it will be a more attractive option for sugaring the pill of environmentally damaging development - a way of getting developers and environmentalists to play the same disingenuous game. fields.bodyText: Translocation is an emerging conservation technology which aims to move wildlife from the path of damaging development. Wildflowers, newts and badgers have become ecological refugees, seeking asylum from new roads, airport runways, retail parks and "saved" in special sanctuaries. One of the most ambitious translocation projects yet is at the M2 widening scheme in Kent which claims to have saved woodland by moving it down the road. The M2 shears through Frith Wood on the eastern slope of the North Downs, south of the Medway towns. An area adjacent to the wood, Cossington Fields, is now a wood in waiting. The soil from the previously arable fields was stripped off and 10,000 tonnes of ancient woodland soil taken from areas affected by road widening was used to replace it; in this 60,000 trees and shrubs were planted and a further 100 hazels were dug from the woods and transplanted here. As the roads programme rumbles back over the horizon, politicians, developers and ecologists are promoting translocation as a way mitigating, even compensating for, the loss of wildlife habitats. Translocating woodland sounds like a good idea, but is it all it's cracked up to be? Apart from woodland wildflowers pushing through the mainly bare earth at Cossington Fields, the site looks like any other motorway planting scheme: fences, plastic, straight lines, pernickety design, tidy gardening. Will this really be woodland in 10, 20, 200 years' time? Will it ever make up for real woodland which has been bulldozed, burned and built on? Against this landscape of loss, translocation is, according to Tony Sangwine, head of horticulture and nature conservation for the highways agency, "the last chance saloon. It can only be used when we're in a tight spot and the road alignment has to go through woodland. We can never claim that translocation can recreate ancient semi-natural woodland, but it gives the best possible chance, for 10 or even 40 years ahead, to have something of ecological quality." In this respect, translocation has become a tool of environmental pragmatism, but the values involved in employing it require greater public scrutiny. Stephanie Wray, environmental consultant to the highways agency for the M2 project, says: "There is a lot of confusion and misunderstanding about translocation. This project is one aspect of a mitigation package agreed with English Nature, Kent county council and Kent Wildlife Trust. Ancient woodland is not movable, but translocation is compensation for an area of woodland that has been lost, and it provides nature conservation value." Carol Hatton, of the World Wide Fund for Nature, insists: "Translocation can never be compensation for the loss of habitat. In our rush to try out a new experiment, we seem to have lost sight of the philosophical issues surrounding translocation which involve an appreciation of the wider landscape, historical and cultural issues." Mike Townsend, chief executive of the Woodland Trust, says: "The whole concept of ancient woodland is that it has never been cultivated for long periods. The woods may have been managed but the soil has not been moved. The notion that ancient woodland soil can be bulldozed and trucked down the road is untenable." The character of the woods affected by the M2 widening is very much determined by coppiced sweet chestnut, but because this is not a native tree, Wray would not include it in the translocation plans. "This scheme aims to improve the ecology of what's there to what it would have looked like 400 years ago," she says. The same appeal to nativeness is applied to dormice. The transplanted hazels are meant to enhance future habitat for dormice, a species protected under EU legislation. Andrew Jones, principal countryside officer for Kent county council, says: "It was only when dormice became protected that we realised they were everywhere. Recent surveys show that dormice seem to prefer new roadside planting to ancient woodland." This leap in values from translocation as a form of rescue, to compensation for woodland loss, to an ecological improvement on the current condition of the habitat, implies the sort of cultural determinism which still haunts us from the 18th century landscape obsession of improving on nature. Wray denies this and claims that "the different elements of the woodland ecosystem need a scientific understanding of value. It is not about trying to make a faithful copy and not about moving an ancient woodland". Whatever happens at Cossington Fields, it will not "save" an ancient forest, as the DETR claims. Neither does it represent a "sustainable" way to deliver transport solutions, as the environment minister, Michael Meacher, is quoted as saying. "Translocation arises from public inquiries where the treatment of ancient woodland is often cynical," he says. "For scientists, translocation projects are a great playground because you don't know how woodlands work until you mess around with them. What we are trying to do is predict what might happen for a public inquiry. The needs of society and conservation are difficult to reconcile and, in our adversarial public inquiries, truth is often irrelevant." It would seem, then, that translocation is a misleading term. fields.headline: Into Africa
fields.standfirst: Nick Wheeler Robinson describes how his village helped a small community in Uganda
fields.trailText: Nick Wheeler Robinson describes how his village helped a small community in Uganda
fields.body:
North Dean is small. Some 75 houses up and down the valley and another dozen on the hills. Most drivers notice only its narrow, winding road as they speed through. No shop, no school, no pub, no church. There is a sloping playing-field and a village hall (first world war barrack hut donated by the then owner of North Dean house) and 18 other listed buildings. Almost twice as many cars as houses. There are a few families with local forebears, but many more have moved in during middle age and stayed on. Good holidays abroad are enjoyed by the comfortably retired. Neighbourhood Watch, and five buses a day.

How should we in North Dean celebrate the millennium? At the village hall committee (first Monday in the month at 8pm) we decided last year on a Domesday photographic survey (now almost complete), an embroidery of the village's comely features (still stitching) and, more recently, an engraved boulder (message to posterity not yet decided) - all to be unveiled at a midsummer party with procession, barbecue and fancy dress.

A few of us felt, however, that as well, we could celebrate the millennium by doing something for a developing country - perhaps small, like us, but less well off. We decided to ask, in principle, whether each household would contribute "whatever you would normally spend on an evening out" to such a scheme. After delivering a flyer to each house, between us we knocked on every door and got a most positive response.

One resident, we found, had particular knowledge and contacts. David had spent many recent years in Uganda in the mission field. At an open meeting he spoke of the fine medical work of a particular group of Ugandan nuns, and all present agreed that this would be our chosen cause. They needed, Sister Ernestine's letter said, a building for their work with HIV and Aids patients. They had had 1,029 new cases in the previous year - from new-born up.

So, another flyer to every home, a small, but profitable, dance and we started collecting for the "North Dean Third World Project". Many households donated £20, £30 or £50. No less valued was the pensioner's fiver - "I don't go out at all now, but I'd like to be involved." Some, of course, gave elsewhere, some could not afford it, a few needed to "ask my husband", one looked sadly at me and wordlessly shook his head. But the great majority (perhaps 85%) contributed generously; £100 came from a musical evening, and our bank balance slowly climbed beyond £3,500.

David was prepared to go out and see to the building, and through another North Deaner, who works for BA, a free flight (thank you BA!) was arranged, which freed up a little more for the project. How much did we need to build what the nuns wanted? Probably £10,000, but a useful, extendable "stage one" would cost £6,000.

As the date of David's departure approached, another flyer asked if anyone in the village would lend another couple of thousand till September (when we shall have a much bigger dance) - and, wonderfully, we had four offers.

So, early in February, David flew out with the £6,310. A ward, 80ft by 30 ft, is up, roofed and the plastering nearly complete. Another North Dean family with medical connections in Uganda recently visited Lowero, saw the work in progress, and may be able to channel help and medicine to the nuns . . . so Lowero may get more than just the North Dean ward.

It may only be a small, incomplete, project from one village, but we've been lucky and we've enjoyed it. And we are (just a little) proud that we have got somewhere. Perhaps, too, another small community might like the idea and . . . if that is taken as a challenge, another developing community would benefit. We would be happy to be outclassed.

webTitle: The sad tale of the spy stuck in Paris

fields.headline: The sad tale of the spy stuck in Paris
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 3.45pm: Paris correspondent Jon Henley on the struggles of former MI5 spy David Shayler to return to Britain to clear his name
fields.body:
In the end, it wasn't quite as dramatic as it was meant to be. David Shayler, the renegade MI5 officer now living in France, had planned to announce his wish to come home from atop an aluminium-and-plastic cross symbolising what he called his "1,000-day crucifixion for telling the truth".

Sadly, for reasons of both security and good taste, French police banned him and his supporters from removing the 10-foot red-and-white construction from the back of their van, and instead Shayler and his mate Thierry rolled up outside the British embassy on a rickety tandem.

"I'd like to go back to England," the ex-spy told a small throng of British reporters and the occasional bemused French shopper on the chic rue du Faubourg St-Honoré. "By Christmas, hopefully. Paris is lovely, but I miss my friends, my family and Middlesborough football team."

Effectively exiled since 1998, when the government failed to persuade a French court to extradite him for an alleged breach of the Official Secrets Act, Shayler said he was now willing to face criminal charges in London - but only if the government goes ahead with the civil proceedings it has brought against him for breach of crown copyright.

"That will be the test," he said. "If the civil case leads to the disclosure of the kind of documents I want to see disclosed, then I will happily face a criminal case and I will subpoena Jack Straw, Robin Cook and Tony Blair and cross-examine them in court. But if those documents remain secret, then there's little point in a criminal case."

Having failed in its extradition attempt, the British government is currently suing Shayler and the Mail on Sunday, the newspaper in which he first accused the British secret services of incompetence and illegal activities, claiming that publication of the portly former spy's revelations had caused "injury to the national interest".

Among other claims, Shayler says some MI5 and MI6 officers - whose names he has passed on to the police - were aware of a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy. "I've nothing to hide, I've always told the truth," he said. "All I'm revealing is where MI5 and MI6 have broken the law and endangered innocent lives."

Shayler, 34, described as "very interesting" news that Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5, planned to publish her memoirs later this year. "She wrote some memoirs five years ago, while I was still with MI5, and they were very heavily censored by the cabinet office," he said. "Now maybe she can be a bit more candid."

Shayler's return home - as well as the publication of Ms Rimington's memoirs - have been made more likely by the fact that the European convention on human rights will become part of British law in October. Many observers believe the Official Secrets Act may breach that convention.

fields.headline: News Corp's satellite web
fields.standfirst:
Chernin negotiating for strategic partners to launch 'media server in the home'

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: News Corporation expects two or three other companies to be involved in its soon-to-be launched satellite internet concern as minority shareholders, Peter Chernin, president of the global media group said yesterday.
fields.body:
News Corporation expects two or three other companies to be involved in its soon-to-be launched satellite internet concern as minority shareholders, Peter Chernin, president of the global media group said yesterday.

Negotiations have focused on strategic partners taking stakes of less than 10% in the new company, dubbed "Platco" by executives at News Corp, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch.

Several of the world's largest companies - including Nokia, the Finnish phone company, Microsoft and Vivendi, the French media conglomerate - are understood to have spoken to News Corp about a possible partnership.

Speaking in New York after a presentation on News Corp's overall internet strategy, Mr Chernin indicated that partnerships with two or three different companies in the hardware, software or content fields would "make most sense".

Negotiations are still continuing for Platco, details of which are expected to be announced within the next two months. Mr Chernin told the audience of Wall Street analysts and investors that Platco was expected to offer web access to 300m households via satellite within the next few years from a base of about 100m today.

The new company will include the media group's controlling stake in BSkyB as well as Star TV in Asia and various operations in Latin America. NDS, the technology company 80% owned by News Corp, and TV Guide, the magazine and television company, will also form part of Platco.

Analysts expect News Corp to offer a slice of the new satellite group to minority shareholders in some of its existing companies. This would mean that Vivendi, for example, would take a stake in exchange for its holding in BSkyB. This sort of structure would allow Platco to act as an operating business rather than as a holding company with investments in different companies. Mr Chernin shrugged off the impact of the recent market correction for high-technology shares in yesterday's presentation.

News Corp announced its intention to spin off its satellite assets earlier this year, before the downturn in internet shares.

Mr Chernin said the new company would "create a currency [that will] enable us to expand our business if the right strategic investment opportunity comes along". His response to a question about the recent market correction was to suggest that if Platco were to be valued less highly than the original target of between $35bn-$50bn (£20bn-£30bn), so would its future acquisition targets.

He outlined a broad strategy in which News Corp would provide a "media server in the home" via a satellite television connection that could link to a wide range of other devices such as mobile phones and personal computers.

In a four-hour presentation, executives explained how they planned to turn the traditional media company into a digital one. James Murdoch, the youngest of Mr Murdoch's sons and an executive vice president, said the three-pronged approach consisted of enhancing distribution networks, improving content and making strategic investments.

The approach is designed to make money from News Corp's existing customers, whether newspaper readers or cinema goers. "The customer relationship is not just one of many factors, it's the holy grail," said Mr Murdoch junior.

 News Corp is to offer its UK newspaper readers its first news service to be delivered via mobile phones within the next two months, said Alisdair MacLeod, managing director of News Network.

webTitle: Communists caught out by net revolution

fields.headline: Communists caught out by net revolution
fields.standfirst:
Chinese struggle to control online boom
Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: The Chinese internet revolution is causing a dilemma for the Communist party, which is torn between trying to spearhead online developments and trying to slow them down.
fields.body:
The Chinese internet revolution is causing a dilemma for the Communist party, which is torn between trying to spearhead online developments and trying to slow them down.

This week the latest stern statements on Taiwan can be seen on the People's Liberation Army's own website. Beijing has also launched a 24-hour news site called One Thousand Dragons which promises to carry one thousand items a day.

With the number of internet users already close to 10m, e-commerce is beginning to boom and websites are exploring everything from online mahjong to fashion advice and gossip on film stars.

The independent sites are more cautious about news coverage. Last week the head of a new government-sponsored Internet Information Management Bureau said that new rules will limit sites to using material from the official press.

"News is a really sensitive area," says one executive from an independent site. "We ask ourselves all the time how we can develop without being shut down. It's like playing a game with no rules. They just come back later to say you can't do it."

The internet explosion is the latest phase in a computer revolution which is little more than five years old. Zhongguancun, in north Beijing, is known as China's Silicon Valley. It has engulfed Haidian, a village of brick and mud houses where street sellers still cry out their wares.

Until the 1980s most of the surrounding land was farmed by peasants. Now Zhongguancun has launched phase two of an expansion plan. Where students from nearby Beijing University used to cycle along paths between the fields, billboards now advertise new internet sites.

Some experts warn that the high growth rate of software companies cannot be maintained but there is still a huge potential demand among China's emerging urban middle class. The number of internet users is expected to double to 20m within the next two to three years.

At lunchtime in Haidian, the Beijing Silicon Valley Computer Plaza is coping with the rush. Outside the five-storey building, touts offer cut-price software while personal computers are loaded onto handcarts and pedicabs.

Increasing demand

"Two years ago, people didn't know what the internet was," says Yu Hongyan, the general manager of the Zhaodaola website. Taxi-drivers would say: 'Internet, is that a new hotel near the airport?'"

Zhaodaola - the name means "I've found it!" - is backed by a US company owned by the rightwing evangelist Pat Robertson. It calls itself a "lifestyle portal" and is now about to launch an e-commerce business.

"A person has to spend much time looking for something, whether it be a job, a friend, a house or a lover," says Ms Yu, who appeared on a recent front cover of the Beijing magazine China Today to illustrate how women's lives have been transformed. "People in China are aiming for a better life. We are entitled to the quality you get in the US and Japan. We are targeting the 20 to 35-year-olds and trying to attract more women. That's why we have a special channel called 'Real Women?' as well as another one called 'Macho Men'."

Across Beijing from Zhaodaola's headquarters is the media monitoring company SinoFile, which scans up to 500 newspapers for mainly commercial clients. It is about to go online. "Bill Gates is the number one hero," says its chief operations officer, Yang Zhi. "Everyone is becoming web aware: it's like a new drug."

Ms Yang's career reflects the rapid shifts in values since the Cultural Revolution, when she was sent to the countryside while her parents - both famous translators of Chinese literature - were imprisoned in Beijing. In the 1980s she studied in the US, returning with a PhD to help set up an institute for the study of ancient civilisations but left academia to found SinoFile in 1992 with her Canadian husband, David Jacobson.

While the new internet revolution gathers pace, the Chinese leadership is divided on whether to tighten or loosen controls.

In January new rules published by the state secrecy bureau imposed tough security checks banning the discussion or transfer of all "secret information" - a term which is very loosely defined.

In the same month, regulations came into force requiring foreign firms to register the type of encryption software which they used, in theory making it possible for the government to monitor all internet transactions. But secrecy checks are now being ignored and encryption requirements have been eased to conform to World Trade Organisation regulations.

After months of conflicting signals, Beijing has finally allowed the first China-based web site to go public overseas. Sina.com, China's most popular site, is now listed on the Nasdaq exchange. Other companies complain that the authorities left it too late for them to cash in on the worldwide hi-tech shares explosion.

Even if the current bubble bursts, the internet tide seems unstoppable. Provincial Communist party bosses now list web development as a top priority - though they often have little idea what it means.

"The party has stayed in power because it is a 'vanguard force'," President Jiang Zemin told this year's National People's Congress. "To continue to be so, senior cadres must equip themselves better by learning internet technology."

"People in China are aiming for a better life. We are entitled to the quality you get in the US and Japan. We are targeting the 20 to 35-year-olds and trying to attract more women. That's why we have a special channel called 'Real Women?' as well as another one called 'Macho Men'." Across Beijing from Zhaodaola's headquarters is the media monitoring company SinoFile, which scans up to 500 newspapers for mainly commercial clients. It is about to go online. "Bill Gates is the number one hero," says its chief operations officer, Yang Zhi. "Everyone is becoming web aware: it's like a new drug." Ms Yang's career reflects the rapid shifts in values since the Cultural Revolution, when she was sent to the countryside while her parents - both famous translators of Chinese literature - were imprisoned in Beijing. In the 1980s she studied in the US, returning with a PhD to help set up an institute for the study of ancient civilisations but left academia to found SinoFile in 1992 with her Canadian husband, David Jacobson. While the new internet revolution gathers pace, the Chinese leadership is divided on whether to tighten or loosen controls. In January new rules published by the state secrecy bureau imposed tough security checks banning the discussion or transfer of all "secret information" - a term which is very loosely defined. In the same month, regulations came into force requiring foreign firms to register the type of encryption software which they used, in theory making it possible for the government to monitor all internet transactions. But secrecy checks are now being ignored and encryption requirements have been eased to conform to World Trade Organisation regulations. After months of conflicting signals, Beijing has finally allowed the first China-based web site to go public overseas. Sina.com, China's most popular site, is now listed on the Nasdaq exchange. Other companies complain that the authorities left it too late for them to cash in on the worldwide hi-tech shares explosion. Even if the current bubble bursts, the internet tide seems unstoppable. Provincial Communist party bosses now list web development as a top priority - though they often have little idea what it means. "The party has stayed in power because it is a 'vanguard force'," President Jiang Zemin told this year's National People's Congress. "To continue to be so, senior cadres must equip themselves better by learning internet technology."

webTitle: Serb opposition TV and radio shut down

fields.headline: Serb opposition TV and radio shut down
fields.standfirst: B2-92
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic continued his clampdown on opposition in Serbia today when his government shut down an independent TV studio and two radio stations.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic continued his clampdown on opposition in Serbia today when his government shut down an independent TV studio and two radio stations.

An official statement, signed by two Serbian deputy prime ministers Milovan Bojic and Vojislav Seselj, read out on the Studio B channel said: "The Serb government has decided to take over all the assets of Studio B."

Its director and editor-in-chief, Dragan Kojadinovic, said B2-92 radio and another independent radio station, both with premises in the same Belgrade building as Studio B, had also been closed.

"I can say that this has no legal or realistic foundations. Studio B has not called for any toppling of legally elected authorities. It only reported on political and other events," Mr Kojadinovic said. "This is the beginning of a state of emergency."

Employees of the leading independent newspaper Blic and the popular student Radio Index also found their offices padlocked this morning.

"The government has imposed an informal state of emergency," opposition leader Vladan Batic said. "This indicates an introduction of a civil war."

Studio B is the most important opposition television outlet in Serbia, although its broadcasts have frequently been jammed. Radio station B2-92 operated on Studio B radio frequencies after its predecessor B92 became a cause celebre when it was forced off air during last year's Kosovo war.

Serb authorities have hit other non-government media with a series of fines, libel charges and arrests over the past few months. A respected Serbian journalist, Miroslav Filipovic, was arrested last week on espionage charges. A freelance correspondent for Agence France Presse, he was released last Friday but could still face charges of "spreading false information" which carry a three-year prison sentence.

Studio B was run by Belgrade city hall, currently controlled by the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), the largest opposition party in Serbia, led by Vuk Draskovic.

At an anti-government rally in Belgrade on Monday, Draskovic told a crowd of around 25,000 people: "We have to rebel against the killers and the terrorists who are ruling Serbia today."

Apparently anticipating protests by opposition supporters, police deployed at least three armoured police vehicles in a downtown park, where the opposition usually gathers before a protest. Dozens of riot police, armed with automatic guns, were seen taking up posts inside government buildings.

fields.headline: Count your lucky stars, ma'am
fields.standfirst:
The Queen Mum's historic duty is to be a focus for pointless outrage

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The government have announced that they are to charge £500 to guests wishing to attend the Queen Mother's 100th birthday party. It's a desperate measure, but it's the only way they could keep Fergie away. Of course £500 is only for starters; guests will be even more out of pocket by the time they're sorted for E's and wizz.
fields.body:
The government have announced that they are to charge £500 to guests wishing to attend the Queen Mother's 100th birthday party. It's a desperate measure, but it's the only way they could keep Fergie away. Of course £500 is only for starters; guests will be even more out of pocket by the time they're sorted for E's and wizz.

The Conservatives are outraged about this vulgar plan to claw back some of the cost of the celebrations; Ann Widdecombe praised the Queen Mother as "a long-established institution", which sounds as if she may have been mixing her up with Strangeways. The royalist right had barely recovered from the Daily Mail front page headline - How dare the BBC snub the Queen Mother - under which a corporation that is usually lambasted for screening dull, unpopular programmes was criticised for not filming a few soldiers marching around Horse Guards Parade being waved at. If it was such a great programme Sky would have bought the rights.

The BBC will be criticised whatever they do. Way back in 1923 the progressives were angry that there was no radio broadcast of Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon's wedding to the then Duke of York. This was refused because it was feared (and I'm not making this up) "that disrespectful people might hear it whilst sitting in public houses with their hats on". God forbid that anything so discourteous should come to pass today, although the Eleven O'Clock Show's photo-montage of the Queen Mum's head on a naked pensioner's body must come close.

In providing a completely pointless thing about which to be outraged, the Queen Mother is fulfilling her historic duty. The reason that she has been built up to untouchable, iconic status is so that Daily Mail readers have something to tut about when we only say she is "lovely" five times over instead of the statutory 27. The BBC is actually spending a million quid covering her 100th birthday. This sounds like plenty and if it's any consolation, somebody might point out to her that they definitely intend to provide live coverage of her funeral. The government is in fact spending £400,000 on the celebrations, which is more than most pensioners have managed to get out of them recently.

But still the Tories are furious at the lack of enthusiasm. This week they criticised British involvement in Sierra Leone on the grounds that the army might not have sufficient manpower to carry out more important duties elsewhere. Now we know to what they were referring. Never mind preventing genocide; we need the army band back here to play Happy Birthday.

All sorts of other festivities are planned. For example, one royal press release announces that on June 2 in St Paul's Cathedral, the Princess Royal "will unveil the bust of the Queen Mother", which is not an image you want to dwell upon. On April 12 she was presented with citizenship of Volgograd (formerly Stalingrad) for her work for that heroic city during the war. Although I have read Antony Beevor's book on the siege of the city, I must have missed the chapter in which she led a Soviet tank division and isolated von Paulus's Sixth Army from the rest of the Third Reich.

Of course the war is the reason why it is outright treason not to love the Queen Mum. As we have been told a thousand times, she opted not to go abroad during the blitz even after her home received a direct hit, only half a mile from her bedroom. To reflect this, her birthday celebrations include an appearance by Dame Vera Lynn and a fly past of second world war aircraft (which will probably then fly over the channel and bomb the headquarters of BMW). This is all part of the attempt to portray her as an ordinary patriotic citizen who toughed it out during Britain's darkest hour with all the other cockneys.

The really popular superstar royals, like the Queen Mother and Diana, are not royals at all but have merely married one - and these icons are served up as one of us. "I mean your Queen Mum, she was just born in an ordinary castle, weren't she, I mean she's not posh like the rest of 'em is she; look at her mum and dad - ordinary working-class geezers, they were, old Lord Claude Bowes-Lyon and Cecilia Cavendish-Bentinck."

What is completely bizarre is that a huge section of the British population still apparently feel such enormous love for someone about whom they know so little. She may have a nice smile and an ability to wave, but then so have the cartoon characters walking round Disneyland. Personally I cannot get excited about an elderly aristocrat's birthday, and if it were down to me the celebrations would be even more low-key. The important thing with old people is not to put them under too much stress. What could be worse than organising a 100th birthday extravaganza and having her die in the middle of it all? Perhaps they should cancel those plans to give her the bumps as well.

webTitle: Sierra Leone debates fate of captured rebel leader

fields.headline: Sierra Leone debates fate of captured rebel leader
fields.standfirst: As Sierra Leoneans spill onto the streets of Freetown to celebrate the capture of RUF leader Foday Sankoh, Simon Tisdall examines the conflicting issues surrounding any decision about his future
fields.trailText: As Sierra Leoneans spill onto the streets of Freetown to celebrate the capture of RUF leader Foday Sankoh, Simon Tisdall examines the conflicting issues surrounding any decision about his future.
fields.body:
The last time Foday Sankoh, the leader of Sierra Leone's Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels, was arrested and charged with treason, he ended up as vice president of the country, in charge of its valuable diamond fields. He is unlikely to be so fortunate on this occasion.

Sankoh was paraded naked through the streets of Freetown today after being captured, reportedly by pro-government soldiers backed by the British intervention force. His re-emergence, 10 days after he disappeared from his heavily guarded Freetown home put an end to speculation that he had been killed, had died of a heart attack, or had fled up-country to join his RUF fighters.

But mystery continued to surround Sankoh's whereabouts during the intervening period. His disappearance closely followed the arrival of British special forces in Sierra Leone and the assertion of overall British direction of the UN and government anti-insurgency effort. Activity near his home by personnel attached to the US embassy in Freetown was also reported around the time he vanished. No explanation has yet emerged about the fate of his numerous bodyguards.

The question now is what to do with Sankoh. People who crowded on to the streets of Freetown to celebrate his capture seemed to be in no doubt. "The masses must decide," one resident was quoted as saying. "He made the people of this country suffer for nine years...He is not fit to exist." Another onlooker said: "We should kill that man today".

The Sierra Leone government to which Sankoh officially belongs may also be tempted to dispose of him as quickly as possible. Sankoh jointly led a coup which deposed President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah in 1998. After West African countries, led by Nigeria, intervened to restore Mr Kabbah, he was arrested, charged with treason and sentenced to death. But under the terms of a peace agreement with the RUF worked out in Togo last July, Sankoh received an amnesty and was invited to join the government. Mr Kabbah and his supporters have no reason to trust him to keep his word a second time and will want to be rid of him.

The British government and its force commanders on the ground may advise a more circumspect approach when it comes to deciding the fate of the RUF leader. The evolving British strategy, as expressed by force commander Brigadier David Richards, seems to be a big push, fronted by the Sierra Leone army and backed by British and UN troops, to seize control of as much rebel-held territory as possible and so force a weakened and defeated RUF to agree to their terms.

While this effort is in progress, the British may well want to keep Sankoh under wraps, pending a future war crimes trial. It may be suggested to him that if he were to collaborate now, this could be taken into consideration later.

The UN special envoy, Oluyemi Adeniji, may take a different view. Mr Adeniji, backed by Liberia's president Charles Taylor (a long-time associate and backer of Sankoh) has been pressing for a ceasefire and return to the Togo peace process (which others believe is effectively defunct). Like it or not, it is argued, Sankoh appears to represent key factions in the civil war. As before, the agreement of these factions is needed if a lasting peace is to be secured.

The UN is also mindful of the fate of the 347 UN personnel who are still being held hostage by RUF forces. Mr Taylor, who has an interest in retaining proxy control of the diamond fields, has warned that the hostages could suffer if the government counter-offensive is pursued. To make matters even more complicated, it remains unclear whether Sankoh actually controls the hostage-takers and whether, now that he has been captured, they will take any further notice of him. One possibility is that Sankoh and other captured rebels could be swapped for the UN hostages.

In terms of international law, it is clear that Sankoh should be forced to answer for his many crimes, the depravity of which has shocked the world. But no international tribunal, such as those set up for Rwanda and the Balkans, currently exists for Sierra Leone. And the new, permanent International Criminal Court has yet to be launched, two years after its founding treaty was signed.

The conflicting objectives, meanwhile, of the various powers-that-be in Freetown seem certain to complicate any decision about Sankoh's fate.

fields.headline: Review: Amores Perros
fields.standfirst: Dog fights on film
fields.trailText: It didn't look as though Cannes was going to have a true controversy this year, or even any film about which to get really hot under the collar. One, however, has turned up in the nick of time, although it is unaccompanied by any press furore, largely because it is hidden away in the small but selective Critics' Week. That's the rather scrappily publicised section that most people get to explore only after they've trawled the Competition, the variable Un Certain Regard section and the Directors' Fortnight - the festival's most public-friendly chunk.
fields.body:
It didn't look as though Cannes was going to have a true controversy this year, or even any film about which to get really hot under the collar. One, however, has turned up in the nick of time, although it is unaccompanied by any press furore, largely because it is hidden away in the small but selective Critics' Week. That's the rather scrappily publicised section that most people get to explore only after they've trawled the Competition, the variable Un Certain Regard section and the Directors' Fortnight - the festival's most public-friendly chunk.

This year's Critics Week hit so far is a Mexican film - Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's debut feature Amores Perros (it could be translated as Dog Love, although the press release goes for Love's A Bitch). It's a film of extreme violence, among both humans and dogs. The first third is set in the sordid, blood-steeped dog-fighting rings of low-life Mexico City, where slavering, snapping hounds hurl themselves at each other in ear-ripping combat. Even though the shots of the dog-fights are mercifully brief and ungloating, they are enough to unsettle you even if you're no dog lover (and after a week trying not to step on the micro-chihuahuas on the Croisette, festival-goers tend not to be).

The dogs form a parallel to human life on the streets of Mexico City, where people all too easily revert to teeth-baring rage. This isn't just a facile dog-eat-dog parable: the canine theme is a cleverly worked-out device for knitting together three stories that intersect in the car crash that starts the film.

In story one, set at the bottom of the poverty ladder, a teenage mother is courted by her hoodlum husband's kid brother. Hoping to buy them a better life, he enters his dog in fights, where it proves to be the bloodiest battler around. In the second story, a model moves into a luxury flat with her middle-aged married lover, but things go horribly wrong when her pampered pooch disappears under the floorboards. And finally, a dog-loving terrorist turned tramp and hitman prepares for his latest mission.

Even at two hours, 33 minutes, there's barely a moment wasted. Inarritu and writer Guillermo Arriaga Jordan are dazzlingly adept storytellers; they've managed to shoehorn three genres coherently into one film.

The first story is hard, low-life realism, shot in lurid colours and edited as a frenetic blur. The model's section is a cruel moral tale of the unexpected, with the tension cranked up mercilessly throughout; it is photographed as a picture of a smooth, upmarket world in which the real troubles go on beneath the surface (under the floorboards, in fact). The third story is pitched as a suspenseful psychological thriller.

The whole is composed according to the Pulp Fiction principle of interlocking lives, all the while looping back and forth in time. Just occasionally you feel the contrivance, but there's never any sense that this is a film wrapped up in its own tentacles or just fiddling around with fancy plot diagrams, like Run Lola Run. It never loses the feel of the everyday. In the dogfights especially, Gonzalez Inarritu could almost be making an edgy, rap-rhythmed documentary, photographed by Rodrigo Prieto so that you can feel the grease, the grime and the panic.

The dog fights mean that the film-makers are in for a hairy time trying to get the film shown in Britain, where the British Board of Film Classification comes down hard on any hint of cruelty to animals. One film that was unreleasable here for that very reason was Claire Denis's film about cockfighting, S'En Fout La Mort, which can be seen at the NFT next month. The fact that Denis's was a sombre art film with a semi-documentary edge could have been regarded as a mitigating factor. It would be harder to argue that case for Amores Perros, which, despite its authentic-looking realism, also has a high-thrills factor. The movie-makers claim that no dogs were hurt during filming, although it's hard to imagine quite how they managed that. The film includes real fighting dogs and, from the look of it, real owners too, every bit as plug-ugly as their pets.

For all its sensationalism, however, this is also a very moral film, with all its characters inexorably heading towards the fates they bring upon themselves - it's a brilliant portrait of the dog beneath the human skin. Amores Perros may also turn out to be the most exciting blast of pure narrative in Cannes this year. It certainly made you look twice at all the trembling Fifis and Fidos on the Croisette.

 www.festival-cannes.fr/
 www.filmunlimited.co.uk

The model's section is a cruel moral tale of the unexpected, with the tension cranked up mercilessly throughout; it is photographed as a picture of a smooth, upmarket world in which the real troubles go on beneath the surface (under the floorboards, in fact). The third story is pitched as a suspenseful psychological thriller. The whole is composed according to the Pulp Fiction principle of interlocking lives, all the while looping back and forth in time. Just occasionally you feel the contrivance, but there's never any sense that this is a film wrapped up in its own tentacles or just fiddling around with fancy plot diagrams, like Run Lola Run. It never loses the feel of the everyday. In the dogfights especially, Gonzalez Inarritu could almost be making an edgy, rap-rhythmed documentary, photographed by Rodrigo Prieto so that you can feel the grease, the grime and the panic. The dog fights mean that the film-makers are in for a hairy time trying to get the film shown in Britain, where the British Board of Film Classification comes down hard on any hint of cruelty to animals. One film that was unreleasable here for that very reason was Claire Denis's film about cockfighting, S'En Fout La Mort, which can be seen at the NFT next month. The fact that Denis's was a sombre art film with a semi-documentary edge could have been regarded as a mitigating factor. It would be harder to argue that case for Amores Perros, which, despite its authentic-looking realism, also has a high-thrills factor. The movie-makers claim that no dogs were hurt during filming, although it's hard to imagine quite how they managed that. The film includes real fighting dogs and, from the look of it, real owners too, every bit as plug-ugly as their pets. For all its sensationalism, however, this is also a very moral film, with all its characters inexorably heading towards the fates they bring upon themselves - it's a brilliant portrait of the dog beneath the human skin. Amores Perros may also turn out to be the most exciting blast of pure narrative in Cannes this year. It certainly made you look twice at all the trembling Fifis and Fidos on the Croisette. fields.headline: Review: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.trailText: If you're not familiar with the pace, grace and elegance of the best of the chop-socky movies, you're likely to be knocked out by Ang Lee's first effort in the genre. It looks a treat, has star performers who know exactly what they are doing and fight sequences that make you gasp and laugh at the same time. There is an occasional tongue-in-cheek quality that never descends into parody, and only the slightly excessive two-hour length (which actually makes it short in relation to this year's Cannes competition) slightly spoils full enjoyment.
fields.body:
If you're not familiar with the pace, grace and elegance of the best of the chop-socky movies, you're likely to be knocked out by Ang Lee's first effort in the genre. It looks a treat, has star performers who know exactly what they are doing and fight sequences that make you gasp and laugh at the same time. There is an occasional tongue-in-cheek quality that never descends into parody, and only the slightly excessive two-hour length (which actually makes it short in relation to this year's Cannes competition) slightly spoils full enjoyment.

Set during the Ching dynasty - and thus a period piece, where costumes and decor matter, and even the scenery becomes important - the film tells its melodramatic story with all the cliches intact, as if Ang Lee were determined to do as well by the genre as he did by Jane Austen in Sense and Sensibility. In other words, he respects the source material while twisting it a little way here and there to allow us to see it in a fresh light.

The story, for instance, is audacious in that it chiefly concerns two women, both dab hands at the fight game. One of them has given up her constrained aristo lifestyle for crime; the other falls in love with a bandit after affirming that justice and honour are all that matter. They are, of course, sisters under the skin, and their destinies lead them to the usual climactic showdown.

Made in China but bankrolled by Warner Brothers, the film gives Ang Lee the chance to let his hair down in a big way after The Ice Storm and Ride With the Devil. But it's not easy to mix it in a genre that requires technique of the highest order. So the film's success is a distinct feather in his cap.

Chow Yun-Fat, Michelle Yeoh, Zheng Pei-Pei and Zhang Zi-Yi are the principals, and you can't do much better than that.

webTitle: British forces kill rebels following leader capture

fields.headline: British forces kill rebels following leader capture
fields.standfirst: Audio: hear Chris McGreal's exclusive report
fields.trailText: British paratroopers have killed three Revolutionary United Front rebels in their first deadly clash since arriving in Sierra Leone - on the day rebel leader Foday                                                         Sankoh has been captured.
fields.body:
British paratroopers have killed three Revolutionary United Front rebels in their first deadly clash since arriving in Sierra Leone - on the day rebel leader Foday Sankoh has been captured.

There were no British casualties, but one woman civilian was injured and was being cared for by British medics, said Prime Minister Tony Blair's official spokesman. The gunfight came at a crucial junction 10 miles east of Lungi airport when the anti-government rebels attacked the paras this morning.

"There was a firefight between about 40 RUF (rebels) and the paras," the spokesman said.

The incident will almost certainly reignite Tory concern that British troops will be sucked into Sierra Leone's civil war, despite the government's assertions that British soldiers will not undertake a combat role. The clash was the day's second moment of high drama. Earlier, Sierra Leone's notorious warlord, Foday Sankoh, endured humiliation as he was stripped naked and paraded through the streets by government troops. Mr Sankoh, leader of the Revolutionary United Front, was brought to Sierra Leone's defence headquarters early this morning, ending a week-long mystery over his whereabouts. At the request of the government, he was whisked to a "secure location" by a British helicopter.

"He is in Sierra Leone government custody, under the auspices of the United Nations," a Foreign Office spokesman said. "His future is a matter for the government of Sierra Leone and the UN." Mr Sankoh, appointed vice-president in the government as part of a controversial peace accord, disappeared last week when demonstrators marched upon his house in protest at the seizure of UN peacekeepers by RUF rebels. RUF gunmen fired on the crowd, killing at least a dozen people.

Since then, there were daily rumours on Mr Sankoh's whereabouts. Some reports said he had fled to rebel strongholds in the interior of the country, others said he had slipped into neighbouring Liberia, or had suffered a heart attack, or was dead. The reappearance of Mr Sankoh, paraded naked through the streets, prompted rejoicing in the capital.

Government soldiers armed with rocket launchers and automatic rifles chased away the crowd and maintained a heavy presence in front of the defence compound. "The masses must decide what to do with him," said SK Shyly, an engineer who drove to the compound. "But I say he is not fit to exist. He made the people of this country suffer for nine years."

RUF rebels acquired notoriety through their practice of hacking limbs off civilians, abducting boys and girls as sex slaves in a campaign of terror. Mr Sankoh was brought into the government and his troops were given a blanket amnesty in a desperate bid to end the 10-year-civil war. But that peace accord unravelled in recent weeks as rebels refused to disarm and seized hundreds of UN peacekeepers. It has become clear that the rebels are in no mood to give up diamond-producing areas under their control. Mr Sankoh's capture may have little bearing on events as his writ may not run over the commanders in the diamond areas in what is an anarchic situation.

Late yesterday, 93 of the former captives were flown from the Liberian capital, Monrovia, to the Freetown airport at nearby Lungi on board a UN aircraft. Oluyemi Adeniji, the UN special representative to Sierra Leone, welcomed them back, saying their contribution to the peacekeeping mission would continue and that the mission would succeed.

Seventy-nine were Zambians and 14 were Kenyans. While one came off the plane on crutches and at least two were bandaged, none appeared to be seriously injured. The remainder of the freed hostages are in the remote Liberian border town of Foya, but were expect to be flown to Monrovia, the Liberian capital, today.

Their release was brokered by Charles Taylor, the Liberian president, who has close ties to the rebels. He is trying to win the release of the remaining 350 UN captives, most of whom are believed to be Zambian.

The Rev. Jesse Jackson, President Clinton's special envoy to Africa, was planning to visit the region this week. But yesterday Sierra Leone's state-run radio announced he was not welcome because of recent statements he made expressing sympathy for the rebels. In Geneva, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees on Tuesday said 600 refugees from western Sierra Leone have fled to neighboring Guinea over the past three days, and aid workers are gearing up to accommodate as many as 25,000 people.
