fields.headline: Charles and God
fields.standfirst: Columnist Madeleine Bunting on how the Prince of Wales has set the cat among the pigeons this time
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 3pm: Columnist Madeleine Bunting on how the Prince of Wales has set the cat among the pigeons this time
fields.body:
Prince Charles' Reith lecture tonight is one of the most astonishing speeches ever delivered by a member of the Royal Family. It is an intensely personal manifesto on the need for a sense of the sacred in our lives; the scope of the speech is enormous, tackling not just sustainable development, scientific rationalism but the way we educate our children into an over-reliance on the mind rather than the intuitive heart.

There will be plenty who will throw up their hands with horror at this final proof of Charles' "fruitcake" tendencies. And they have a point. Charles is a deeply romantic man and his thinking is often incoherent. The slushy metaphors he sometimes uses, and his yearning for "order and harmony" seem to reveal a tortured soul which has found consolation in nature and a fantasy of a lost past.

There is a real danger that his speech will fuel the growing backlash against science. That is very serious because, given enormous global population growth, science will have to play a major role in resolving many of the issues of sustainable development which Charles raises.

By attacking science, the Prince alienated many scientists who could be powerful potential allies; by unnecessarily insisting that reverence for nature must be linked to a belief in a creator, he loses the support of scientists such as Richard Dawkins who have a powerful reverence but no belief in a creator. It is not always scientists who are the problem but the commercial exploitation of their discoveries - a distinction which the Prince ignores.

But for all that, the Prince has used his powerful public position to launch a debate about what constitutes our humanity, our responsibilities to other people and to the natural world. Fumblingly, he makes some very brave, and deeply unfashionable points about the role of the sacred and belief in traditional religion. Sustainable development is primarily a spiritual and moral issue, he claims, echoing the thinking developing amongst many environmentalists; the Netherlands's national environmental strategy explictly addresses a change of spirit, heart as well as mind.

Fascinatingly, the Prince is laying out his stall as to the kind of monarchy he has in mind. He sees his role as an ideological visionary - a re-development of his mother's Christian leadership which is usually very evident in her C hristmas Day speeches. Some will say he is a hypocrite: from his position of privilege, what right has he to pontificate about sustainability?

But on that criteria, what right have I or any Western commentator? His serious interest in all these questions has now lasted over twenty years; he is not a gadfly. But the charge of hypocrisy hits home harder when he talks about the "wisdom of the heart" and one wonders quite how much he knows about that and has been able to put it into practice in his own tragic family; he seems to be the sort of mystic who is much happier communing with the sunset than with human beings.

This obviously tortured, shy man seems, finally, to know what he wants to do with his life and in his job. The only problem is that there appears a disturbing blindness to the constraints his birth has places on this resolve. For example, on the small matter of his future constitutional responsibilities as head of the Church of England.

The Prince dodges the word God, he prefers "creator" or "guiding hand" and he makes a whole speech on the sacred without one reference to Jesus Christ. His gospel reference even attributes a comment to St Matthew rather than Christ. What is blindingly clear is that whatever he does or does not believe, he is not a Christian by any definition understood by the Archbishop of Canterbury.

This is reason for the Church of England to start thinking long and hard about its consitutional position in this country; it is simply ludicrous to suggest that the Church could have as its titular head a divorced pantheist cohabiting with a divorcee. Disestablishment is, surely, preferable to that. Charles really has set the cat amongst the pigeons this time.

webTitle: The books the secret services tried to ban

fields.headline: The books the secret services tried to ban
fields.standfirst: As MI5 awaits a Home Office decision on whether its former head, Stella Rimington, will be permitted to publish her memoirs, Mark Tran takes a look at the books the spymasters wanted kept under wraps
fields.trailText: As MI5 awaits a Home Office decision on whether its former head, Stella Rimington, will be permitted to publish her memoirs, Mark Tran takes a look at the books the spymasters wanted kept under wraps.
fields.body:
Spycatcher. The Thatcher government spent millions in a futile attempt to prevent former MI5 officer Peter Wright from publishing his memoirs. Wright's most sensational claim was that there had been a mole at the heart of MI5 for many years, and that the mole was the director-general himself, Roger Hollis. An entertaining read, he writes of his early years in counter-espionage: "For five years we bugged and burgled our way across London at the state's behest, while pompous bowler-hatted civil servants in Whitehall pretended to look the other way."

Storm command: a personal account of the Gulf war. General Sir Peter de la Billiere, the commander of British troops in the Gulf war, wrote about SAS operations during the 1991 conflict. The book chronicles the war from the allied nerve centre, analyses America's execution of the air and land campaigns and tells how de la Billiere persuaded the US to deploy the SAS in the western desert of Iraq.

Bravo Two Zero by Andy McNab. Another book that did not meet with official approval, this gave an account of McNab's experiences with the SAS, starting as a young soldier in the struggle against the IRA in the streets and fields of South Armagh. McNab went on to command SAS patrols behind enemy lines in Iraq during the Gulf war. The book contains details about the world of surveillance and intelligence-gathering, counter-terrorism and hostage rescue.

Decent Interval. The CIA hated Frank Snepp's classic expose on the collapse of South Vietnam in which he accused the agency of abandoning its agents when the US left Saigon. The CIA sued Snepp because it had not given him clearance to write about his experiences. The resulting court case went all the way to the Supreme Court. Snepp tried to defend himself on first amendment grounds with the help of a then-unknown Harvard lawyer named Alan Dershowitz. He ultimately lost the case, plus his money and the right to publish anything about the CIA without first receiving authorisation. He got his own back, to a certain extent, with Irreparable Harm - which did receive CIA clearance. The book tells of his legal fight and casts light on the nature of bureaucracies and how they defend their turf.

fields.headline: The Duchy of Cornwall
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the Prince of Wales's nice little earner on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the Prince of Wales's nice little earner on the net
fields.body:
1. As if GM foods, the scientific establishment and the horrors of modern architecture were not weighty enough, Prince Charles's Duchy of Cornwall has been landed with a £20bn tax bill.

2. The Cornish Stannary parliament, who sent the bill, says the duchy has claimed an excess tax on tin production in Cornwall for 500 years, and requested payment within 120 days.

3. The parliament takes its names from the Stannary (tin) laws that guaranteed Cornwall's rights and privileges.

4. They argue that their action demonstrates Cornwall was treated separately from the English mainland and should have a special status today. If they get the money, they will spend it on an agency to boost the county's economy.

5. Until the industry collapsed, tin mining made the duchy its money.

6. Its charter was given by Edward III in 1337 to his son, Edward the Black Prince. Henry VI later decreed the monarch's eldest son would be duke.

7. The Duke of Cornwall (aka the Prince of Wales) is in effect a trustee and as he cannot sell off its assets, he would have difficulty paying the bill.

8. Charles does not receive any money from the state. His financial stability comes from the £5m-£6m net surplus generated by the duchy each year.

9. The prince was proclaimed duke at Launceston Castle in 1973. His feudal dues included a pair of white gloves, gilt spurs and greyhounds, a pound of pepper and cumin, a bow, a pair of gilt spurs, 100 silver shillings, wood for his fires, and a salmon spear.

10. The Duchy of Cornwall covers 51,885 hectares across the south of England. Not all of it is in Cornwall and a large part is on Dartmoor in Devon.

fields.headline: Police complaints procedures
fields.standfirst: As home secretary Jack Straw prepares to announce a review of complaints procedures against police officers, Julian Glover examines existing rules and explains the debate that has been raging since the Stephen Lawrence inquiry
fields.trailText: As home secretary Jack Straw prepares to announce a review of complaints procedures against police officers, we examine existing rules and explain the debate that has been raging  since the Stephen Lawrence inquiry
fields.body:
Why are police complaints procedures in the news?
Jack Straw has decided that the existing system of handling serious complaints against police officers is not up to scratch. He is to announce new proposals in a speech this morning to the Police Federation conference in Brighton, shortly before the publication of a consultation paper on the subject.

How does the complaints system work at the moment?
Members of the public can complain if they think a police officer has behaved incorrectly or unfairly. They can make a complaint about the conduct of a police officer towards them or can complain on someone else's behalf with their written authorisation. Recently the level of proof required in an investigation has changed from the criminal standard of "beyond reasonable doubt" to the lower standard of the "balance of probabilities", in line with normal employment practice. Allegations of assault, neglect of duty, breaches of the police and criminal evidence codes of practice and incivility are the most common complaints. Allegations of corrupt practice are, in contrast, relatively low.

Why are there calls for change?
Under the present system, reformed in the wake of the1981 Brixton riots, police forces respond to complaints by setting up an internal investigation, under the supervision of the independent Police Complaints Authority. But only in very serious cases are officers drafted in from other forces to assist. Critics say that this approach lacks rigour and want a more transparent system to be introduced. They argue that there is a risk that officers won't really push to find out the truth when they are investigating their own colleagues.

Why's this issue on the agenda now?
Last year's MacPherson inquiry into the way police officers handled the murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence called for a review of the existing system of handling complaints. In response, Mr Straw appointed consultants KPMG to consider changes. They have backed reform and in today's speech the home secretary will aim to take the process forward, to take into account the many people who no longer trust the present system.

What changes will be made?
Independent civilian investigators will be introduced to examine issues such as deaths in custody, shootings and allegations of corruption. This could pave the way for investigators from the customs, inland revenue, serious fraud office and the legal profession to take charge of inquiries, although police could retain responsibility for some investigations. The aim is to produce a system which everyone accepts as impartial.

What do the police think about this?
Most police officers think that the existing system has merits. They claim that police officers are already subject to tight regulation and argue internal investigations provide the best way for forces to learn from their mistakes. Nonetheless, senior police figures say they will back the changes. They accept that reform is the only way for the police to win back public trust and also welcome the possibility that the new system will relieve hard-pressed police budgets of the cost of funding investigations.

fields.bodyText: Why are police complaints procedures in the news? Jack Straw has decided that the existing system of handling serious complaints against police officers is not up to scratch. He is to announce new proposals in a speech this morning to the Police Federation conference in Brighton, shortly before the publication of a consultation paper on the subject. How does the complaints system work at the moment? Members of the public can complain if they think a police officer has behaved incorrectly or unfairly. They can make a complaint about the conduct of a police officer towards them or can complain on someone else's behalf with their written authorisation. Recently the level of proof required in an investigation has changed from the criminal standard of "beyond reasonable doubt" to the lower standard of the "balance of probabilities", in line with normal employment practice. Allegations of assault, neglect of duty, breaches of the police and criminal evidence codes of practice and incivility are the most common complaints. Allegations of corrupt practice are, in contrast, relatively low. Why are there calls for change? But only in very serious cases are officers drafted in from other forces to assist. Critics say that this approach lacks rigour and want a more transparent system to be introduced. They argue that there is a risk that officers won't really push to find out the truth when they are investigating their own colleagues. Why's this issue on the agenda now? fields.trailText:
Tidy Britain Group/Going for Green

Elizabeth House

The Pier

Wigan

WN3 4EX
fields.body:
Tidy Britain Group/Going for Green

Elizabeth House

The Pier

Wigan

WN3 4EX

The Guardian article on Landfill Tax, sub-headed, "Going for Green and Tidy Britain Group" (Website 25th April) raised many questions about our funding - yet based all its assumptions on out of date information and contained a number of inaccuracies.

The article begins by claiming that we were criticised in 1999 for funding activities "outside the statutory authority under which the grant had been paid." In fact, there was some criticism of DETR (not ourselves) for not giving specific guidelines on what our grant should be spent on. No blame at any time was apportioned to Tidy Britain Group/Going for Green on how we were spending public money.

The article then says that Tidy Britain Group "spends more on fundraising than any other charity in Britain" - a claim built on figures published in our 1996/97 accounts. The 98% quoted actually refers to the cost of staging major national campaigns and publishing information sheets, as well as fundraising. This year fundraising has been shown separately in the annual accounts - and is less than 4% of the contributions received.

Finally, Going for Green's £1 million pound sponsorship deal with Tesco/Biffaward is listed as missing from our annual accounts of 1997/98. The first instalment of this income was not in fact received until 1998/99 and is fully recorded in our accounts of that year.

Tidy Britain Group/Going for Green believes that improving the environment is an all inclusive mission and therefore prides itself on having an open-door policy to the public. That includes having its funding scrutinised. But if our accounts are going to come under the spotlight, can at least the most recent report be looked at and the organisation given the chance to qualify its position?

Surely that is not too much to ask.

Alan Woods

Chief Executive

Tidy Britain Group/Going for Green

webTitle: Arsenal offer stay-away fans their money back

fields.headline: Arsenal offer stay-away fans their money back
fields.trailText: Arsenal have offered supporters on the club's official trips to tonight's Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen a full refund if they do not wish to attend the match following the stabbing of a Gunners fan.
fields.body:
Arsenal have offered supporters on the club's official trips to tonight's Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen a full refund if they do not wish to attend the match following the stabbing of a Gunners fan.

The club made the offer in a handwritten note given to every supporter as they checked in this morning to catch one of their official flights to the Danish capital.

Some fans opted to stay in England, but the vast majority decided to attend the game in the Parken Stadium. The note, which had been written on Arsenal's headed paper and was handed out by club officials, said: "The club can confirm that during a disturbance in the early hours of the morning, an Arsenal supporter was stabbed and has been detained in hospital. "Fortunately his condition is not life-threatening. If any supporter travelling on an official club trip does now not wish to travel to Copenhagen, the club will give a full refund."

The injured supporter, who was knifed in the back outside a bar during clashes between rivals sets of Galatasaray and Arsenal fans, is in a comfortable condition in the city's Central Hospital.

However Uefa claim there is little they could have done to prevent the violence. A spokeswoman said: "It's very unfortunate when things like this happen, but it has nothing to do with football really or the match itself because it happened on the night before in the city's streets.

"We are responsible for security and safety in the stadium on match day, but it's impossible for us to control everything the night before."

fields.headline: Stop blubbering, Kapil
fields.trailText: Kapil Dev's involvement in this filthy business is a shock. He must be condemned for his unpardonable offence. It was behaviour totally unbecoming a national superstar, the Michael Jordan of India no less. I still cannot believe he did it. But in a stroke he fell from grace, from hero to zero. No, he should never have blubbered on screen.
fields.body:
Kapil Dev's involvement in this filthy business is a shock. He must be condemned for his unpardonable offence. It was behaviour totally unbecoming a national superstar, the Michael Jordan of India no less. I still cannot believe he did it. But in a stroke he fell from grace, from hero to zero. No, he should never have blubbered on screen.

What was Kapil thinking of? Blubbering on television is always either suspicious or amusing. He could have blubbered on plenty of other occasions this year and got away with it. It would have been seen as contrite when his Indian team was being pulverised in Australia. What about when Courtney lurched past his world record of Test wickets? It was also an instant option after Inderjit Bindra named him as the missing man from Manoj Prabakhar's tale. When he did blubber, however, he didn't even have the decency to confine his outburst to a low-ratings cable channel. Instead, Kapil, like a true star, chose maximum exposure and the BBC.

I once cried, too, over cricket. I had just lost the final of our school single-wicket competition to an annoying kid with a slinging action; a shock result if ever there was one. I was 11. Apart from the fact that I missed out on a cheap plastic trophy, it took me a long time to lose my image as a blubberer, especially as my future brother-in-law witnessed my moment of shame. In fact, I have never blubbered over sport since (except when John McEnroe lost to Bjorn Borg at Wimbledon), not even when our opening batsman ambushed me, fists flailing, in our dressing room after I had run him out earlier in our innings, à la Inzamam. That was my reward for top-scoring that day, but I had learned my lesson: when you are at the pinnacle of your sport you just do not blubber.

Remember Nick Faldo's tears after he was fined for slow play at the British Open? Highly amusing, I thought at the time, though some commentators pointed out that the fine was a huge blow to his reputation. Maybe crying on television over a few quid was good for his image then. Not in the world I live in.

There is one saving grace for Kapil: blubbering on cue is an Asian attribute, most evident at weddings and funerals. Sadly, the ones that blubber the most are often the most insincere. This is not to say that Kapil's tears were a front, but more that they did him no good. He is not the only star player to be rubbished by the match-fixing rumours, but he certainly seems to be protesting more than anyone. One minute he insists on India's withdrawal from one-day internationals, the next he says that Bradman's final dismissal for a duck would have raised eyebrows if he had been playing today.

Kapil is manic. This non-stop babbling is in danger of turning a national icon into a laughing stock. He should focus on coaching the national side and leave the rest to his lawyers. And, please, please, avoid blubbering again - until after the verdict.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is editor of the Bulletin of the World Health Organisation. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.

webTitle: Hoorah for Bollywood as Birmingham gets multiplex screens dedicated to Indian films

fields.headline: Hoorah for Bollywood as Birmingham gets multiplex screens dedicated to Indian films
fields.trailText: Warner Village is to become the first big cinema chain in Britain to cater for the Bollywood market by dedicating screens in a Birmingham multiplex that opens in July.
fields.body:
Warner Village is to become the first big cinema chain in Britain to cater for the Bollywood market by dedicating screens in a Birmingham multiplex that opens in July.

Ralf Ludemann of Warner Village said yesterday that six out of 30 screens would show exclusively Indian-made films. His company was able to do this only because of a clampdown on pirated videos of Bollywood films, he said. "Until bodies like the Federation Against Copyright Theft toughened up on piracy recently, it was not feasible for multiplexes to compete with smuggled videos.

"Without the videos, there are fewer avenues to see these films, so people will come to the Warner Village."

Bollywood is the popular term for the film industry based in the city of Bombay which makes 600 films a year, worth £750m worldwide. The UK is Bollywood's biggest export market, but audiences of the three-hour musicals have been restricted to videos, satellite TV or independent cine mas. There is one eight-screen Asian cinema in Birmingham's centre that seats 1,000, and another cinema in nearby Smethwick. But multiplex chains only occasionally hold screenings in places such as Wolverhampton, Leicester or Bolton.

Warner Village said the Birmingham screens would be marketed specifically among the Asian community. In inner city Birmingham 70% of the population is black or Asian, and in the city as a whole there are more black and Asian under-18s than there are white under-18s.

Mr Ludemann said: "It's hard to tell if white audiences will come to the films on the back of mainstream hits like East is East.

"Bollywood films are subtitled and very long, with at least six dance intervals. But, if there is a demand, we will increase the number of Bollywood screens."

Inderjit Dehal is director of the Birmingham Race Action Project,which campaigns for institutional change in the city. He said the multiplex was important for Asians. "Birmingham will be Britain's first black city, but its infrastructure has stagnated, and blacks and Asians are sidelined from many leisure activities. This type of commercial initiative should set an example for a better ethnic balance in other areas like health and education."

Raj Kaushal, editor of Snoop, an Asian monthly specialising in Bollywood, said the screens were good news if there was a sustainable market. "Last year at least three Bollywood films entered the UK top 10.

"I'm all for Bollywood entering the mainstream, but it is tedious when fickle commercial ventures jump on the 'Asian cool' bandwagon. "Next week the new thing could be 'Japanese cool'."

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.trailText: What is the highest number of different countries represented by the starting 22 players in a Premiership match? asks Phil Brown
fields.body:
What is the highest number of different countries represented by the starting 22 players in a Premiership match? asks Phil Brown

The highest total we've found so far is 14. According to Lars Kollveit, when Coventry played Chelsea at Highfield Road on the 4th of January the following countries were represented:

England (Telfer, Williams, Froggatt, Palmer, Wise), France (Desailly, Deschamps), Italy (Di Matteo, Zola), Ireland (Breen, Keane), Morocco (Chippo, Hadji), Holland (De Goey), Spain (Ferrer), Nigeria (Babayaro), Uruguay (Poyet), Norway (Flo), Brazil (Thome), Sweden (Hedman) Scotland (McAllister), Belgium (Roussel). Can anyone else do better?

Has there ever been the Saturday night score announcer's all-time dream result: East Fife 5, Forfar 4? There's AU$20 riding on it asks Hugh McGinley.

Nearly but not quite. The Fifers visited Station Park during the 1963/4 campaign in the old Scottish Second Division and scored four. Sadly, their hosts still won, the final score being... Forfar 5, East Fife 4.

I was asked to name four English teams who have had three managers who won European Cup medals as players. The first three are Blackburn, Manchester City and Newcastle, but who are the fourth team? asks Stefan O'Connor.

The club in question is Preston. Three members of Manchester United's famous 1968 side went on to warm the Deepdale manager's chair: Bobby Charlton (1973-5), Nobby Stiles (1977-81) and Brian Kidd (1986).

Just for those who don't know: Blackburn's European Cup-winning managers were Kenny Dalglish (Liverpool 1978, 1981, 1984 - manager 1991-5), Brian Kidd (1998-9) and Graeme Souness (Liverpool 1978, 1981, 1984 - manager 2000-); City's were Billy McNeill (Celtic 1967 - manager 1983-6), Phil Neal (Liverpool 1977-8, 1981, 1984 - manager 1996) and Frank Clark (Nottm Forest 1979-80 - manager 1996-8); and Newcastle's were Kevin Keegan (Liverpool 1977 - manager 1992-7), Dalglish (1997-8) and Ruud Gullit (AC Milan 1989-90 - manager 1998-9).

In addition, the Toon have also had two World Cup winners at the helm in Jack Charlton (1984) and Ossie Ardiles (1991-2). But where has it got them?

Which club has won the FA Cup the most times? asks Andy Frame. Is it Tottenham Hotspur, Manchester United or Arsenal?

It's Manchester United. They've won the FA Cup ten times (1909, 1948, 1963, 1977, 1983, 1985, 1990, 1994, 1996, 1999) while Tottenham have won it eight times and Arsenal seven.

Hello! Who is responsible for the nutty situation that means that Heathrow Airport lacks any football memorabilia? Last December I made a stop-over (from Amsterdam to Montreal) and tried to get some Manchester United items. Alas, not one store carried anything from MU, or from any other football club for that matter. Doesn't England know how to honour its heroes? asked an enthusiastic Jesse Vorst last week.

Unfortunately rather than help Jesse out, many of you used his letter to take cheap shots at Manchester United instead. Hang your head in shame Nigel Kennedy, who wrote, "Dear Jesse, Many thanks for the tip. It seems you have inadvertently stumbled on the one spot on the planet that is a red-free zone. I may just take my holidays there."

So thank goodness for honest folk like Julian Smith, who suggests that Jesse should take a trip to the Far East - where Manchester United memorabilia can be picked up for 'next to nothing' and you can buy 'safe in the knowledge that your hard earned is not going to line the pockets of Rupert Murdoch.' Failing that, as Justin Steed points out, 'United have a commanding presence at Manchester Airport, being well-represented in both WH Smiths and the Duty Free shop in Terminal One'. Apparently Gatwick airport sells United merchandise as well.

Last week we mentioned that six cities that have had two different teams in the European Cup semi-finals (Milan, Glasgow, Dundee, Moscow and Madrid and Belgrade).

But we missed out two more, Bucharest and Vienna. As Tim Burgis points out, Steaua won the European Cup in 1986, while Dinamo got to the semi-finals in 1984 (where they lost to Liverpool). As for Vienna, Rapid reached the semi-finals in 1961 (losing to Benfica) while Austria lost at the same stage to Malmo in 1979. Thanks to John Foulis for that spot.

However those of you that argued that Prague should also be included are just wide of the mark. Although Dukla were defeated by eventual winners Celtic in the 1967 semi-finals, Sparta Prague only reached the quarter-finals in 1992.

Can you help?

Why was the May 1968 FA Cup Final televised in colour, but not the European Cup Final a few days later, although both were at Wembley? There must be someone in the world who knows the answer reckons Alan Sheridan.

Why do the English press keep referring to Jerrel Hasselbaink as "Jimmy Floyd" Hasselbaink? asks John Askew. In Holland Jerrel is his given name. I spoke to a Dutch Guy recently about this and he couldn't understand where "Jimmy Floyd" came from. Any ideas?

Unfortunately rather than help Jesse out, many of you used his letter to take cheap shots at Manchester United instead. Hang your head in shame Nigel Kennedy, who wrote, "Dear Jesse, Many thanks for the tip. It seems you have inadvertently stumbled on the one spot on the planet that is a red-free zone. I may just take my holidays there." So thank goodness for honest folk like Julian Smith, who suggests that Jesse should take a trip to the Far East - where Manchester United memorabilia can be picked up for 'next to nothing' and you can buy 'safe in the knowledge that your hard earned is not going to line the pockets of Rupert Murdoch.' Failing that, as Justin Steed points out, 'United have a commanding presence at Manchester Airport, being well-represented in both WH Smiths and the Duty Free shop in Terminal One'. Apparently Gatwick airport sells United merchandise as well. Last week we mentioned that six cities that have had two different teams in the European Cup semi-finals (Milan, Glasgow, Dundee, Moscow and Madrid and Belgrade). But we missed out two more, Bucharest and Vienna. As Tim Burgis points out, Steaua won the European Cup in 1986, while Dinamo got to the semi-finals in 1984 (where they lost to Liverpool). As for Vienna, Rapid reached the semi-finals in 1961 (losing to Benfica) while Austria lost at the same stage to Malmo in 1979. Thanks to John Foulis for that spot. However those of you that argued that Prague should also be included are just wide of the mark. Although Dukla were defeated by eventual winners Celtic in the 1967 semi-finals, Sparta Prague only reached the quarter-finals in 1992. Can you help? Why was the May 1968 FA Cup Final televised in colour, but not the European Cup Final a few days later, although both were at Wembley? There must be someone in the world who knows the answer reckons Alan Sheridan. Why do the English press keep referring to Jerrel Hasselbaink as "Jimmy Floyd" Hasselbaink? asks John Askew. In Holland Jerrel is his given name. I spoke to a Dutch Guy recently about this and he couldn't understand where "Jimmy Floyd" came from. Any ideas?

fields.headline: Top dogs for net shorts
fields.trailText: Some of the world's leading directors have signed up to make a collection of short films on the subject of time, that will be screened on the internet
fields.body:
Directors Bernardo Bertolucci, Jim Jarmusch, Nicolas Roeg, off-the-wall French director Chris Marker and Finnish helmer Aki Kaurismaki have all signed up to make a collection of short films that will be screened on the internet by webcaster and short films company Atomfilms, reports Screen Daily.

They are the first of 15 leading directors who have committed to make a ten-minute film on the subject of time, under the banner Ten Minutes Older.

The films will begin shooting in August and September of this year for delivery in spring 2001. It has yet to be decided whether the films will premiere on the net, on TV or in cinemas.

webTitle: 17 May: In brief, and the latest casting news

fields.headline: 17 May: In brief, and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Far from Saintly behaviour at Cannes, Brosnan's wedding plans delayed, Harry Potter is late already, and a fresh approach to the Three Musketeers
fields.body:
 More action from Cannes, but not in its expected filmic form: as we reported yesterday fighting broke out at the launch party of the All Saints' new film Honest on Monday night. Proceedings got so wild that riot police had to be called in to quell the brawl, which involved the use of bottles and chairs at the exclusive Palm Beach nightclub. The incident followed the screening of the film, which is directed by Eurythmics' Dave Stewart. Ten people were injured, but it was thought that All Saints had already left when the incident occurred. Phew.

 Pierce Brosnan has been forced to delay his wedding to journalist Keely Shaye-Smith because of his son's poor health. No new date has yet been set for the ceremony which was due to take place in Ireland this weekend at Ballintubber Abbey, in Co Mayo. Sixteen-year-old Sean has not yet recovered from a recent car crash in which he suffered a broken pelvis and ruptured spleen when a car he was in plunged 200 feet over an embankment in California last month.

 The LA truck driver accused of stealing 55 Oscar statuettes from a loading dock less than a week before the awards ceremony was ordered yesterday to stand trial for grand theft. Lawrence Ledent's lawyer says his client unknowingly drove off with the Oscars, valued collectively at $17,000.

 Another postponement today this time comes from Warner Bros which has officially moved the release date of its Harry Potter adaptation of JK Rowling's story of the schoolboy wizard. Insiders said the studio will move the film, directed by Chris Columbus, to November because the date is more realistic given the project's slow start.

Casting couch

 Gary 'Hannibal' Oldman, Mena 'American Beauty' Suvari and Justin Chambers are reported to be in final negotiations to star in the $42m action drama D'Artagnan, to be directed by Peter Hyams (End of Days). Touted as a fresh approach to the Three Musketeers yarn, it will feature D'Artagnan on a quest across Europe to avenge his parents' deaths. The film, scripted by Gene Quintano (Sudden Death), is to begin production in August in Belgium, Luxembourg and France.

fields.headline: Name of the game
fields.standfirst: How do you define precisely who or what is a social worker? Kendra Inman reports on an academic approach to end the confusion
fields.trailText: How do you define precisely who or what is a social worker? Kendra Inman reports on an academic approach to end the confusion
fields.body:
At the moment, anyone can call themselves a social worker, whatever their training or expertise. But soon the job title could become a protected term used only by staff who have completed a degree in professional social work. The proposal, part of a push to raise standards, is contained in a document outlining benchmark academic targets designed to shape the future of socia work degree courses.

The quality assurance agency for higher education (QAA), proposer of the benchmarks due to be implemented later this year, says the setting up of a general social care council (GSCC) and statutory regulation of some social care staff may lead to "the terms social work and/or social worker becoming protected titles".

There are currently only 60,000 qualified social work posts out of a social care workforce of more than a million. Don Brand, of the National Institute of Social Work, says the move would end public confusion about who is qualified to act as a social worker. When things go wrong, he says, "anyone in the care field is referred to as a social worker. Newspaper headlines refer to social workers even when they're talking about unqualified care staff."

The publication of the benchmark standards has also re-ignited the debate over whether social work training should be university based or whether there should continue to be a range of routes into the profession.

Would-be social workers can currently take a diploma in social work (the professional qualification), a first degree orpostgraduate degree in the subject. The diploma - currently under review by the government - is not linked to a specific level ofacademic achievement. Brand says: "There is an acceptance that only two years of social work training isn't sufficient to equip people for the job today. It is likely that the minimum training will be extended to three years, and it would make sense to set it atdegree level."

But there are some fears that a protected title could lead to elitism in a field that has traditionally relied on staff from a broad range of backgrounds. As one social work trainer says: "Of the social care workforce, 80% is unqualified, so local authorities have traditionally 'grown their own' social workers. This approach has been particularly important for ethnic minority staff who haven't been able to gain access to higher education."

Employers struggling to recruit new staff worry that restricting entry to graduates could discourage many good applicants from entering the field. The British Association of Social Workers is keen to prevent academics from "hijacking" professional training. The organisation was disappointed that it was neither invited to join the academics in drafting the benchmarks nor formally asked to respond. Ian Johnston, the BASW director, says they would be happy to see the title protected but would be concerned if entry into the profession is restricted to those who have had an academically based training. "We would like it to be a protected title, otherwise it is a recipe for confusion," he says. "But what needs to be clear is what you need to do in terms of practice and knowledge. There could be many ways of meeting the level of expertise, but we must be clear about what knowledge and skills are needed to practise."

The QAA says it is not in the business of setting out what makes a social worker competent to practise, but that this should be done in conjunction with other stakeholders in social care, such as employers. "I wouldn't want the professional qualification to become too academic and discourage people with a range of life experiences from coming into the field," says Johnston.

Brand says that fears of elitism are misplaced. He believes the government is committed to maintaining flexible routes into social work, even if the diploma does become a degree. Distance learning and modular degree courses are already available for many subjects. Two-thirds of the degree could take place while students are employed in social care.

Liz Wulff-Cochrane, of the social work training council, says Scotland and Wales is likely to settle on an inclusive register open to staff working in social care. England, on the other hand, is likely to restrict initial registration to those holding recognised qualifications.

Legislation to enable the establishment of a GSCC is making its way through parliament as part of the care standards bill. The future of social work will be largely determined by what form the register takes.

fields.headline: Mandelson reopens cabinet euro split
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson last night reopened divisions in the cabinet over the euro when he upstaged Tony Blair's keynote speech to British industry by openly admitting that the government was virtually powerless to protect exporters against the high level of the pound unless Britain joined the single currency.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson, Larry Elliott  and Michael White
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson last night reopened divisions in the cabinet over the euro when he upstaged Tony Blair's keynote speech to British industry by openly admitting that the government was virtually powerless to protect exporters against the high level of the pound unless Britain joined the single currency.

In a speech to the pro-single currency GMB union in Belfast, which was not cleared by No 10 or the Treasury, the Northern Ireland secretary suggested that euro membership was the only permanent way of preventing sterling being buffeted by currency fluctuations.

"I fully accept that the pound is overvalued and the euro is undervalued," Mr Mandelson said, adding: "The fact is that, as long as we are outside the euro, there is little we can do to protect industry against destabilising swings in the value of sterling as they affect Europe - the largest market where we have to earn our living."

The Treasury moved immediately to distance itself from Mr Mandelson's remarks.

One political source said: "Everybody knows that the two people who decide government policy on the euro are Tony Blair and Gordon Brown. Peter Mandelson is doing an excellent job as secretary of state for Northern Ireland."

Although both the prime minister and the chancellor have admitted in recent days that the pound is overvalued, neither is prepared to put at risk economic stability by adopting quick fixes, such as currency intervention or stating a clearer intention to join the euro.

Last night Mr Blair used a speech at the annual dinner of the Confederation of British Industry to restate the government's intention to put macroeconomic stability first.

"My own belief is that we cannot try artificially to devalue the currency," he said. "We have to hold to the tight fiscal and sensible monetary policy that is the best guarantee over time of the stability we all want."

The prime minister emphasised that government policy on the euro was unchanged. "We remain in favour of joining in principle; in practice, the economic conditions must be met. The policy on the referendum and timetable remain the same."

With opinion polls showing strong opposition to membership of the euro, William Hague seized on Mr Mandelson's remarks.

"Peter Mandelson has let the cat out of the bag and has revealed Tony Blair's secret agenda to join the euro as soon as possible in defiance of all the evidence," he said.

"Yet again it shows that Mr Blair is becoming more and more out of touch with the people of this country."

The prime minister's assertion that there was no realistic alternative to the government's economic policies was also challenged from the opposite point of view by the CBI's pro-single currency president, Sir Clive Thompson.

While accepting that intervening on the money markets would not work, Sir Clive said a tighter fiscal policy in the last Budget might have helped.

He sympathised with Mr Mandelson's views by saying that a clear British commitment to the single currency might have encouraged closer convergence between the pound and the euro.

The CBI president also warned against the introduction of more red tape. Complaining that industry had been subjected to the "biggest and most damaging overhaul" of labour market regulation for 20 years since Labour came to power, Sir Clive said more job protection laws would backfire by increasing unemployment.

Taking a dig at Mr Blair and his wife, now expecting their fourth child, he added: "Everyone understands and sympathises with the call for paid parental leave and a right to part-time work for returning mothers. But the nature of work in the future will be insecure and needs for its very existence to be unprotected."

The prime minister hit back over business regulation, saying the working time directive - providing a maximum 48-hour working week for some employees - "could have been implemented better".

But he went on: "Britain still has one of the most lightly regulated labour markets in the world."

The prime minister urged business to work with government and praised industry leaders as "the key not just to enterprise but to fairness, too". "Let us work together, admit the problems, cooperate on the solutions," he told them.

The TUC general secretary, John Monks, said Sir Clive's fears about new employment legislation were misplaced.

"Sir Clive Thompson should understand that the rules of a civilised society cannot stop at the workplace door," he said.

"Good employers have nothing to fear from sensible new measures to help people at work."

webTitle: Europe wins battle for £5bn military deal

fields.headline: Europe wins battle for £5bn military deal
fields.standfirst: Missile and airbus package follows intense lobbying
fields.trailText: Huge arms and military aircraft deals worth £5bn were unveiled by the government yesterday in a move with far-reaching implications for European defence cooperation and Britain's ability to intervene in conflicts such as the one in Sierra Leone.
fields.body:
Huge arms and military aircraft deals worth £5bn were unveiled by the government yesterday in a move with far-reaching implications for European defence cooperation and Britain's ability to intervene in conflicts such as the one in Sierra Leone.

In a package defence companies say will create or safeguard nearly 5,000 British jobs, the government intends to spend £3.5bn on a new European "military airbus" and £1bn on missiles for the Eurofighter aircraft.

The package, announced after months of intense lobbying - including the personal intervention of President Clinton - combines heightened commitment to Europe with short-term reliance on the US.

The European Meteor missile and the A400M military airbus - to which other European countries have yet to commit - will not be ready until the end of the decade. In the meantime the RAF will lease four giant Globemaster aircraft from the US company Boeing at a cost of £500m. It will also buy a number of shorter-range missiles from the US company Raytheon for the Eurofighters due to enter service in 2002.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, hailed the deals as "of great importance for the armed forces and for our defence capability for several decades to come.". They were also welcomed by BAe Systems, a leading partner in the Meteor and airbus projects.

The missile deal is a setback for Raytheon, which persuaded Mr Clinton to write twice to Tony Blair on its behalf. In one letter the US president underlined the words "I feel strongly" about the forthcoming decision.

President Jacques Chirac of France and the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, also wrote to the prime minister urging the government to choose the Meteor over its US rival. "Cher Tony", Mr Chirac began, ending with a handwritten message: "This business therefore appears to be of great importance."

Mr Hoon said the cost of the rival bids and the number of missiles the government had bought for the RAF's promised 232 Eurofighters remained classified. He described the Meteor as a "vital component of the Eurofighter's ability to dominate the skies". It is de signed to engage a number of enemy targets at the same time, at long distance, day or night.

The Meteor will be built by a European consortium led by BAe and Matra of France and including German, Spanish, and Swedish companies. The contract will create or sustain 1,200 jobs at Stevenage, Herts, Bristol and Stanmore, north-west London, according to BAe.

The prospects for the military airbus, which BAe says would create more than 3,000 jobs in Filton near Bristol, Broughton in north Wales, Prestwick in Scotland, and Warton in Lancashire, is less certain.

Britain is the only European country to commit itself to the proposals. Mr Hoon said yesterday he was confident that other countries would sign up though he told MPs Britain could buy the US Globemasters as an alternative.

A cut-price bid by Air Foyle, a private company, to offer the large Antonov aircraft was dismissed on the grounds that Russia and Ukraine - where the planes are built - could not ensure long-term reliability.

Mr Hoon said Britain planned to buy 25 of the proposed European large aircraft. From next year the RAF would be able to lease the four Globemasters which, he said, "will deliver vital early support to our new joint rapid-reaction forces".

Europe's inability to transport large numbers of troops and equipment quickly was demonstrated in the Kosovo conflict. Air Marshal Sir Peter Squire, the chief of the air staff, said yesterday that with the new planes, British troops would have been able to fly directly to Sierra Leone.

In the Commons, the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, welcomed the deals but told Mr Hoon: "Given the way that President Clinton has been lobbying the prime minister over the last few weeks and months, I just wonder to what extent this is a case of the Foreign Office giving you another load of bad advice."

fields.headline: Ex-MI5 chief to publish memoirs
fields.standfirst:
Spymasters who silenced Shayler may let Rimington go into print
Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: MI5 was plunged into disarray last night after the disclosure that its former head, Dame Stella Rimington, has written her memoirs about her experience in charge of the security service.
fields.body:
MI5 was plunged into disarray last night after the disclosure that its former head, Dame Stella Rimington, has written her memoirs about her experience in charge of the security service.

The disclosure could not have come at a worst time for MI5. It is embroiled in a series of legal battles against the media, including the Guardian and Observer newspapers, to prevent publication of its activities.

David Shayler, the renegade MI5 officer now living in Paris, is certain to seize on the disclosure to press his demands that he should be allowed to return to Britain to reveal his allegations of malpractice against the agency.

The government is also trying to clamp down on revelations about the activities of army intelligence units in Northern Ireland during Dame Stella's time in the security service.

The Home Office said last night that the former MI5 chief had submitted a text of her memoirs "according to the rules" earlier this year. A spokeswoman said both Dame Stella and the government were concerned that nothing should be published that would damage national security. The Home Office denied reports in the Sun newspaper that a court injunction was being drawn up preventing her from publishing the book.

The Home Office was unable to comment on reports that government lawyers were scrambling to stop the disclosure of any secrets with a high court injunction, amid reports that Dame Stella could make as much as £1m from her memoirs.

"The government's overriding concern is that nothing should appear that is damaging to national security," the spokeswoman said. "I understand that Dame Stella shares that view and that is why she submitted the text in accordance with the rules and it is being considered.

"Obviously if there is material in the text which is damaging, the government will be talking to her and telling her that."

Later the Home Office said: "There are no plans for a high court injunction. It would be inappropriate to talk about legal action when discussions are ongoing under the normal procedures."

Dame Stella told reporters: "Yes, I am writing a book. I have written a draft which I have submitted to the relevant government authorities.

"It is a personal memoir. It is not my intention to disclose any information of a sensitive nature."

The last time a former MI5 chief published his memoirs was in the 1950s when Percy Sillitoe wrote Cloak Without Dagger. In the 80s the Thatcher government spent millions of pounds in a vain attempt to prevent a former MI5 officer, Peter Wright, from publishing his memoirs, Spycatcher.

Dame Stella and MI5 will be open to the charge of hypocrisy if it allows her memoirs to be published when the security service is trying to suppress information about its workings.

The spymaster ran MI5 during the height of the terrorist threat from the IRA. She was the first woman to be appointed head of MI5 and was also the first to be photographed and officially named.

In retirement she earns an estimated £60,000 a year from her directorships of Marks and Spencer and British Gas. She also draws a sizeable government pension based on the £90,000-a-year salary she earned at MI5.

News of her proposed book follows a stream of similar publications by men holding sensitive positions.

The Gulf war commander, General Sir Peter de la Billière, published a book relating to SAS operations during the 1991 Gulf war. SAS sergeant Andy McNab also caused controversy when he wrote his best selling book Bravo Two Zero about the exploits of his patrol behind enemy lines during the same conflict.

webTitle: Experienced teachers earn as much as other graduates

fields.headline: Experienced teachers earn as much as other graduates
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: An international comparison of teacher salaries left a union leader last night "pleasantly surprised", for once, by the situation in Britain.
fields.body:
An international comparison of teacher salaries left a union leader last night "pleasantly surprised", for once, by the situation in Britain.

The UK was one of five industrialised countries where the average salaries after 15 years teaching were the same or better than those of other university graduates, according to an OECD report.

Teachers in England with 15 years experience earned an average of $34,087 in 1998. Scottish teachers earned $32,679. That put them 6th and 7th in the OECD rankings.

British teachers were also among the hardest-working.

Scottish primary teachers had to cope with 975 compulsory teaching hours compared with 760 in England and an OECD average of 700.

At secondary level, Scottish teachers of children up to 16-years-old ranked third (917 hours), while teachers in England were eighth.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of teachers' union NAS/UWT, said he was "pleasantly surprised".

fields.headline: Lack of sport stops Grandstand
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC has cancelled this weekend's edition of Grandstand, its flagship sports programme, because it has no decent sport to show.
fields.body:
The BBC has cancelled this weekend's edition of Grandstand, its flagship sports programme, because it has no decent sport to show.

After a 42-year tradition broken only by annual festive periods and the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, the programme has finally fallen victim to the corporation's catastrophic loss of sports rights.

So while ITV rakes in the ratings with the FA Cup final, and Channel 4 scoops up the rest of the sports viewers with the opening Test between England and Zimbabwe at Lord's, viewers of BBC1 will have to make do with My Fair Lady and a repeat of 'Allo, 'Allo.

The situation is an embarrassment for Greg Dyke, the BBC's director general, who has pledged to claw back some of the losses of the past few years. He has regained Test Match Special for radio, but Sky is the favourite to retain the rights to Premiership football, ITV has Champions League football, and Channel 4 holds the rights to Test cricket. ITV has poached the BBC's top sports presenter, Des Lynam, who launched the channel's coverage of Euro 2000 yesterday

The BBC said yesterday that it would still be broadcasting sporting events this Saturday. It will show racing from Newbury on BBC2 while Radio 5 Live will broadcast live commentary of the FA Cup final between Aston Villa and Chelsea. A spokeswoman said last night: "The reason Grandstand isn't appearing on BBC1 on Saturday is that unlike in previous years, there is no major alternative sporting event available."

ITV was jubilant yesterday about securing a top line-up of pundits to front its coverage of the European Championships: Terry Venables and Ron Atkinson will join Lynam. The BBC, which is sharing coverage of the tournament, boasts Gary Lineker, Martin O'Neill and Alan Hansen.

Lynam said that he hoped many of his fans would switch from BBC to ITV for the coverage: "I have done it before on the other side, it always worked rather well for the BBC and this time I hope it will go well for ITV."

webTitle: Britain tops US in degree league

fields.headline: Britain tops US in degree league
fields.standfirst:
University student numbers soar, but spending at primary and secondary level lags behind rivals

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The rapid expansion of higher education means that Britain is now producing proportionately more graduates than the United States, according to a survey by the organisation for economic cooperation and development.
fields.body:
The rapid expansion of higher education means that Britain is now producing proportionately more graduates than the United States, according to a survey by the organisation for economic cooperation and development.

And the organisation finds that the number of such students increased by 76% in Britain between 1990 and 1996.

But spending per student is lower than the average of other industrialised nations for universities and schools, and the UK is falling behind at GCSE level, the OECD says.

The rise in higher education student numbers represents a faster growth rate than any of the 28 OECD countries except Portugal. At the start of the 1990s the UK's graduation rate (the percentage of students graduating with a first degree at typical graduation age) was under 20%, and in the US around 30%. But in 1998 it was 35.2% in the UK and 32.9% in the US, with an average for the OECD of 23%. Only Norway (38.3%) has more people finishing degrees.

The numbers of students grew by more than 20% in all but five countries in the OECD from 1990 to 1997, and in eight countries by more than 50%.

The report shows that British university courses have a bigger "survival rate" than others, excepting those in Japan. In the UK more than 80% of students complete their first degree courses; in Italy the level is 35%. The UK has the third highest graduation rate at masters level, after the US and New Zealand.

Andreas Schleicher, principal administrator in the OECD's statistics department, acknowledged the university drop-out rates, but said comparatively they were more serious in many other countries.

British higher education, the OECD also says, is attractive to foreign students - 16% of those in OECD countries who study abroad go to the UK and one in 10 degree students in Britain is foreign.

But the report, Education at a Glance, shows spending at all levels has not kept pace. Spending has increased, by about 50%, but as numbers of students have risen the outlay per student has dropped. Britain spent less than the OECD average in 1997 on primary and secondary education; and, for secondary level, about half the amount spent by Switzerland.

The report found that, as a proportion of GDP in 1997, Britain's public expenditure on educational institutions was 4.6%, compared with an OECD average of 4.8%.

Figures for the number of pupils attaining an "upper secondary education" - in Britain, classified as those getting five or more A to C grades at GCSE - suggest the country is falling behind. The rate of 55- to 64-year-olds with an upper secondary qualification (53%) is above the OECD average. Among 25- to 34-year-olds in Britain, 63% have an upper secondary qualification, but that is lower than the average - of 73%. In Germany, Japan, Korea, Norway, Switzerland, the Czech Republic and the US, 88% or more in this age group have equivalent qualifications.

Although the number of people getting five or more A-Cs is increasing, the rise is happening more slowly than in many other OECD countries.

The report shows that those who do not achieve five A-Cs or the equivalent, find they are penalised in jobs markets. Female graduates aged 30-44 earn 90% more than women with an upper secondary qualification, and men earn 57% more.

Britain also has a large student-staff ratio of 16 pupils to seven staff, compared with an average of 14 to nine at lower secondary level in 1998. At primary level only Ireland, Korea and New Zealand had higher ratios. But the education minister, Estelle Morris, said that since the OECD figures had been compiled class sizes for infants had plunged.

Other findings reveal that a bigger proportion of people in Britain aged 25 to 64 participate in training or education compared with any other OECD country.

Pupils in England, Scotland and Spain are the most enthusiastic for science at the age of 13. In Korea and Japan enthusiasm for science more than halves between ages of nine to 13.

The OECD is at present working on a way of comparing countries for value for money in education.

webTitle: BBC told to show files in race case

fields.headline: BBC told to show files in race case
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC has been told to hand over documents relating to nine years of job promotions at the World Service, in a case brought by a journalist accusing the corporation of race and sex discrimination.
fields.body:
The BBC has been told to hand over documents relating to nine years of job promotions at the World Service, in a case brought by a journalist accusing the corporation of race and sex discrimination.

An employment tribunal has ordered disclosure of papers relating to appointments for every job applied for by Sharan Sandhu, a journalist at the World Service headquarters at Bush House in London.

It rejected an application by her lawyers to disclose correspondence relating to an inquiry into appointment procedures at the BBC by the commission for racial equality. The corporation had opposed the application, saying it was a "fishing expedition". Ms Sandhu may now attempt to obtain the CRE correspondence by applying to the tribunal for a witness order.

Ms Sandhu, 49, from west London, claims that when promotions were not made through the BBC's board system they always went to white candidates, and there was "widespread concern" among non-white and senior white staff about the poor representation of ethnic minorities. The BBC contests the claims, and said yesterday it was considering the tribunal's ruling on disclosure of personnel files: it has the right of appeal.

webTitle: Israel halts land handover in wake of riots

fields.headline: Israel halts land handover in wake of riots
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli leader Ehud Barak, after agreeing to the transfer of the village of Abu Dis to Palestinian control, has abruptly reversed the decision, insisting that the handover must wait until peace is restored in the West Bank and Gaza.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Ramallah, West Bank
fields.body:
The Israeli leader Ehud Barak, after agreeing to the transfer of the village of Abu Dis to Palestinian control, has abruptly reversed the decision, insisting that the handover must wait until peace is restored in the West Bank and Gaza.

The US envoy, Dennis Ross, met the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, yesterday to discuss a peace process which has yielded almost no material gains and which is now the principal source of the frustration which is fuelling the clashes.

In Ramallah, Israeli soldiers trained machine guns over geraniums in the window boxes of the City Inn hotel yesterday; uninvited guests staring down hundreds of rioters who had ignored calls from the Palestinian leadership to end the violent protests.

Three Palestinians were killed and at least 320 injured, and 15 Israeli soldiers were wounded on Monday, which saw the worst explosion of violence in nearly four years.

Israeli forces resorted to live ammunition in pitched battles with Palestinian protesters - and with the police, who were under instructions to stand aside while people vented their anger.

At an Israeli enclave in Palestinian-run Bethlehem, police formed a cordon to force back the stone throwers. "Down with the olive branch, long live the rifle," protesters chanted as they withdrew.

Yesterday, however, Mr Ross warned that the peace talks have no hope of advancing unless peace is restored. "Both sides are working hard to calm the environment, and that is the key to restoring calm," Mr Ross said. "It is also a key to being able to move this peace process forward."

Israeli officials are fond of accusing Mr Arafat of manipulating street protests as a means of putting pressure on the negotiations. But as yesterday's protests underscored, popular anger can not be switched on - or off - at will.

Although Palestinian leaders were more anxious to rein in demonstrators after Monday's venting of rage, the protesters at Ramallah yesterday were in no mind to heed them.

"We don't follow orders from anyone," said Ali Abu Khader, 19, who was catching his breath between rounds of stone throwing. "Mr Arafat wants to protect people but he doesn't understand that this is a popular revolution.

"When my brother is killed or in prison how can I obey orders?"

Outside the City Inn hotel, scene of the worst clashes on Monday, hundreds of Palestinian police were called out yesterday to do just that. But their efforts were desultory at best.

From the first floor conference room, which was fortified with sandbags, and reinforced with coffee urns and tea cakes, the Israelis regularly lobbed sound grenades and tear gas and fired rubber-coated bullets. From time to time, the Palestinian police would step in, ambling down the hill to the stone-throwing youths and leading them away by the elbows.

Marwan Barghouti, a Fatah leader and a member of the Palestine legislative council, admitted the police had little stomach for keeping order - especially when several of their number had been shot and wounded by Israeli soldiers on Monday.

He also justified Monday's exchange of fire with soldiers, saying the Palestinian police were providing "moral support" for the demonstrators in their battle with Israeli security troops.

Other Palestinians say the forces propelling the protesters to violence are more complicated. They argue that much of the anger vented on Monday and yesterday was against Mr Arafat's corrupt and incompetent authority, which has disappointed Palestinian aspirations, both in the peace process, and in domestic governance.

"These people believe they should start a new intifada," said Kanaan al-Jamal, who works for the Palestinian negotiations department.

"People now realise they must be a part of the peace process, and that if they throw stones it might strengthen the negotiations."

webTitle: Angry Charles warns scientists of disaster

fields.headline: Angry Charles warns scientists of disaster
fields.standfirst:
Religion in the UK: special report
GM food: special report
Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles's simmering anger with the direction of some modern science will tonight blow into a philosophical storm as he argues that the only way to avoid environmental catastrophe is for humankind to rediscover an urgent "sense of the sacred".
fields.body:
Prince Charles's simmering anger with the direction of some modern science will tonight blow into a philosophical storm as he argues that the only way to avoid environmental catastrophe is for humankind to rediscover an urgent "sense of the sacred".

In a Reith lecture, to be broadcast on Radio 4 tonight, he will confront scientific materialism, politicians and business leaders to argue that it is because of humanity's "inability or refusal to accept the existence of a guiding hand that nature has come to be regarded as a system that can be engineered for our own convenience and in which anything that happens can be fixed by technology and human ingenuity".

He will add: "We need to rediscover a reverence for the natural world, irrespective of its usefulness to ourselves, to become more aware of the relationship between God, man and creation."

The lecture takes swipes at biotechnology, the government's modernising zeal, and economic globalisation - and warns that it is only by employing "both the intuitive and rational halves of our own nature that we will live up to the sacred trust that has been placed in us by our creator".

He asks: "If literally nothing is held sacred anymore, what is there to prevent us treating our entire world as some 'great laboratory of life' with potentially disastrous long-term consequences?"

But the prince is careful to build bridges between modern science and the sacred. "We need to restore the balance between the heartfelt reason of instinctive wisdom and the rational insights of scientific analysis. Neither is much use without the other. Only by rediscovering the essential unity and order of the living and spiritual world and by bridging the gap between cynical secularism and the timelessness of traditional religion will we avoid the disintegration of our environment."

The Prince of Wales has weighed into the debate over genetically modified foods before, but this time his attack on the scientific approach is broader and deeper. Some of his critics are likely to interpret his remarks as an assault on the whole medical and agricultural revolution being ushered in by the new era of genetics.

His fears over GM crops may have inspired his criticism, but his lecture is a cry against excessive scientific rationalism in general. His belief that tampering with nature is an affront to God, whom he refers to throughout his lecture as the creator, is spelled out more explicitly than in previous statements.

The 22-minute speech draws on green gurus including Fritz Shumacher and Rachel Carson, natural theologians including Philip Sherrard, and radical economists such as Herman Daly, formerly of the World Bank. Last night it was well-received by British environmental leaders, who are increasingly at odds with what they see as the fundamentalism of some modern science.

Peter Melchett, director of Greenpeace, said: "It's long overdue that someone pointed out how bereft and barren of humanity are those people who claim they are acting on the basis of 'sound science'. They say in effect that culture, society, values and religion don't exist."

Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth, said the speech would be a wake-up call to politicians and business leaders who thought nature was "a piece of machinery".

"He is reminding us that nature is something wondrous and beautiful and that we have to learn that humility to develop a truly sustainable relationship with nature," he said.

fields.headline: It's Prince forever (so he says)
fields.trailText: The artist formerly known as Prince informed a grateful public yesterday that he has a new name: Prince.
fields.body:
The artist formerly known as Prince informed a grateful public yesterday that he has a new name: Prince.

The hyper-productive musician, whose name has commanded more interest in recent years than his music, told a crowded news conference that henceforth there was no need to grapple with pseudonyms such as the Symbol, the Hieroglyph or the Artist.

His interminable dispute with the record industry, which at one time had him taking the stage with the word "slave" written on his arm, is at an end.

It would seem that he has felt free for some time to revert to being Prince, but revealed it only after allowing four-and-a-half months for the realisation of freedom to sink in.

"On December 31 1999, my publishing contract with Warner-Chappell expired, thus emancipating the name I was given before birth - Prince - from all long-term restrictive documents," the artist, 41, said.

"I will now go back to using my name instead of the symbol I adopted to free myself from all undesirable relationships." He did not make clear if this included his relationship with his wife, Mayte.

He took the opportunity also to announce a week-long party in Minneapolis under the banner of Prince: A Celebration. His recording studio there will be open for shows between June 7 and 13, and will include one by himself on the final day.

A new song, Cybersingle, will be available on his web site, as will be a modified version of his last album, Rave In2 the Joy Fantastic. The return to the name Prince after seven years ends the dispute with Warner Bros, whom he accused of exercising too much control over his music.

"Will I be changing my name ever again?" he asked himself. "No, I won't have to, because I won't be under any restrictive long-term contract again."

fields.headline: Ecstasy can dull the brain
fields.trailText: New medical evidence has debunked the myth that small amounts of ecstasy and cocaine are safe after two studies published today found that even moderate doses of the drugs have serious and long lasting mental or physical side effects.
fields.body:
New medical evidence has debunked the myth that small amounts of ecstasy and cocaine are safe after two studies published today found that even moderate doses of the drugs have serious and long lasting mental or physical side effects.

Researchers at Aachen University in Germany found regular ecstasy users performed far worse in mental tasks than non-users. They concluded that the effects may be "cumulative and irreversible".

The results, published in the Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery and Psychiatry, showed ecstasy users got significantly worse scores in complex memory tests.

Researchers at the Pittsburgh University medical centre who monitored the heart rates and blood chemicals of 14 young people for two hours after they took a small dose of cocaine found the drug slightly increased heart rate and blood pressure, with a more significant increase in chemicals aiding the formation of clots.

Their findings appear in the journal Heart.

fields.headline: Settlement for sacked train driver
fields.trailText: A train driver who claimed she was sacked for her union activities today accepted a £16,000 payment in settlement of her case.
fields.body:
A train driver who claimed she was sacked for her union activities today accepted a £16,000 payment in settlement of her case.

Sarah Friday, 35, will not be reinstated by South West Trains after an employment tribunal in Croydon ruled that she was 66% responsible for her dismissal; it dismissed her claim of discrimination and victimisation, but decided she had been unfairly dismissed.

A SWT spokeswoman said: "We believe £16,000 is a small price to pay to bring this episode to an end." A spokesman for the Rail Maritime and Transport union said: "The settlement is a victory for her and for the union."

The sacking of Ms Friday, who lives in Gravesend in Kent, led to strikes at Waterloo earlier this year.

fields.headline: Virgin radio fined for bias
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Virgin radio was fined £75,000 by the radio authority yesterday for a "flagrant breach" of broadcasting rules when its star presenter, Chris Evans, said during the London mayoral campaign that he backed Ken Livingstone for the post.
fields.body:
Virgin radio was fined £75,000 by the radio authority yesterday for a "flagrant breach" of broadcasting rules when its star presenter, Chris Evans, said during the London mayoral campaign that he backed Ken Livingstone for the post.

The fine, the largest handed out by the authority, was imposed after Mr Evans twice supported Mr Livingstone - who later won the position as an independent candidate - on air weeks before the election.

He pledged £200,000 to the Livingstone campaign, although he did not hand over any money.

Richard Hooper, chairman of the authority, which licenses and regulates commercial radio, said Virgin was guilty of a "critical failure".

It is the fifth time that Virgin has been fined by the authority since it began broadcasting in 1993.

Mr Evans did not comment yesterday, but Virgin said it accepted the decision. It pointed out, however, that the rules on political broadcasting had been altered only recently, and said the mistake had been due to a misunderstanding.

In its ruling yesterday the authority said that Mr Evans had breached the rules governing broadcasters' impartiality during his breakfast show on March 21.

Mr Evans first aired his support for Mr Livingstone "at length" after the 8am news and again an hour later, the authority said.

Mr Hooper said: "This broadcast was a flagrant breach of the long-standing rules surrounding political impartiality, made worse by the fact that the broadcast took place in the run-up to that most sensitive of political events, an election."

The authority said that the fine would have been greater had Virgin not immediately apologised after the event.

Virgin confirmed yesterday that Mr Evans had not yet met his cash pledge to Mr Livingstone's campaign.

A meeting has been arranged for next Tuesday with Mr Livingstone's staff to discuss how Mr Evans might be able to support the mayor in future.
