webTitle: Prince courts controversy as he places the nature of God above the god of science

fields.headline: Prince courts controversy as he places the nature of God above the god of science
fields.standfirst:
Religion in the UK: special report

GM food: special report

Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles's twin ambitions to cast himself as defender of the natural world and defender of Britain's many faiths have long been an open secret. But in tonight's Reith lecture, to the dismay of scientists and unease of some within the religious mainstream, he explosively brings the two ambitions together.
fields.body:
Prince Charles's twin ambitions to cast himself as defender of the natural world and defender of Britain's many faiths have long been an open secret. But in tonight's Reith lecture, to the dismay of scientists and unease of some within the religious mainstream, he explosively brings the two ambitions together.

He declares that love of nature and faith in an unspecific deity he calls the "creator" or "sustainer" are one and the same thing, and that over-dependence on scientific rationalism has become the enemy of the nature-god.

In a phrase which will have his detractors fizzing that he has plunged deeper into obscure mysticism, the prince argues that the best guide to what is right for the planet is not rational thought but "a wisdom of the heart a faint memory of a distant harmony, rustling like a breeze through the leaves".

The spread of genetically modified foods is clearly the spur for the prince's concern, but the lecture comes across as an attack on science in general.

Although he says that science is vital, the overall picture the lecture conveys is of a harmonious natural world created by God, nourished by the faithful, and betrayed by progress-loving rationalists.

The scientific community was quick to respond yesterday. "I am saddened by Prince Charles's lecture, the more so because he is so obviously a very nice man and very well-meaning. What person of goodwill could disagree that our primary concern should be with long term stewardship, with the welfare of the whole planet?" said Richard Dawkins, the zoologist and writer.

Neo-paganism

"But how grieving that Prince Charles should tie this enlightened view to a wholly unnecessary hostility towards scientific rationalism. Worse, that he should link it to a championing of traditional religious world views. What have they ever done for the long term welfare of the planet?"

The prince's nature-god beliefs are unlikely to be greeted with enthusiasm by all traditional religions. Protestantism, with its traditional acceptance of capitalism, and Catholicism, with its abhorrence of birth control, have not been traditionally environmentally friendly.

The prince's religious views seem closer to a blend of Buddhism, Islam and Orthodoxy, with a strong streak of neo-paganism.

John Polkinghorne, a retired Anglican priest and scientist who sits on the government's Human Genetics Commission, was ambivalent about the lecture. "We, of course, are also part of nature, and though we must act responsibly, we have, as part of nature, the right to change it. Agriculture has been doing that for thousands of years," he said.

"I'm sympathetic with his general drift, but it's regrettable he's quite so suspicious of current science although he says we need both rational and intuitive he's obviously much warmer about the intuitive."

Last year the prince accused supporters of GM foods of using "emotional blackmail" to put their case, and questioned the lack of independent scientific research into the safety of GM crops.

In other comments down the years, he has honed his complex views of God, faith and spirituality, hinting that when he inherits his mother's title of Defender of the (Anglican) Faith, he would like to be seen as defender of all Britain's many religious faiths.

In tonight's lecture, Prince Charles says humankind should be careful "to use science to understand how nature works - not to change what nature is, as we do when genetic manipulation seeks to transform the process of biological evolution into something altogether different".

But the issue goes beyond GM foods. Some scientists and sufferers from genetic diseases are talking about altering the "germ line" of human beings, creating genetic alterations that would be passed on from generation to generation, to cure illnesses such as cystic fibrosis.

There was resentment among scientists, many of whom are proud of their personal green credentials, that the prince should seek to portray them as violators of nature. "I have a lot of sympathy with some of the things he's saying. It's just that they get taken to extremes," said John Sulston, who heads the British end of the multinational project to sequence the human genome.

Commerce, not science, was the problem, he said. "There seems to be a very strong tendency generally to equate scientific rationalism with a sort of desecration of the earth. But that's because human beings take every single scientific advance and try to make as much money out of it as they can, as quickly as possible.

"Scientific knowledge is neutral, or very often beneficial, because it leads us to a clearer understanding, free of superstition, of what's going on, but then it's up to the social structures to make it work.

"People were pretty good at destroying the earth before there was science. It's the scale that's changed. More than anything else, it's sheer human numbers which are destroying the earth."

John Durant, professor of public understanding of science at Imperial College in London, said he agreed with the prince that there had to be a proper balance between head and heart, between reason and moral intuition. The difficulty was, he said, in knowing whose moral intuition was right. "Implicit in the Prince of Wales's opinions is that it becomes immediately obvious, when you take the spiritual dimension into account, that certain things are wrong, as genetically modified crops. That's not obvious to me at all.

"In me, the balance of head and heart seems to have led me to judge that it's right to take heart valves from pigs and put them into human beings to save lives. If it's right to do that, which doesn't seem like going with the grain of nature, I think we need to look at other areas of science and technology and be very careful about ruling them out because we could be doing the world a great disservice."

The clash between the prince and scientists is an echo of the great ideological clash between Enlightenment rationalists and Romantics which began two centuries ago and has never quite died down. The rationalists wanted to tame nature and analyse the mechanics of the human mind. The romantics preferred nature, and human emotions, in their wild state.

The difference now, to the prince's alarm, is that science has become much more powerful - capable not simply of taming nature but of altering it.

Prof Dawkins said that whatever you thought of scientific rationalism, it had become an essential part of the fabric of human life. "Far from being demeaning to human spiritual values, scientific rationalism is the crowning glory of the human spirit," he said. "Of course you can use the products of science to do bad things, but you can use them to do good things too.

"Any person of goodwill who deliberately turns his back on scientific rationalism is playing into the hands of those who would use it for exploitative or evil ends."

Excerpts from the speech

 If literally nothing is held sacred any more - because it is considered synonymous with superstition, or in some other way 'irrational' - what is there to prevent us treating our entire world as some 'great laboratory of life', with potentially disastrous long-term consequences?

 Part of the problem is the prevailing approach that seeks to reduce the natural world, including ourselves, to the level of nothing more than a mechanical process

&#149 ;It is all too easy for us to forget that mankind is a part of nature, and not apart from it

 We should show greater respect for the genius of nature's designs, rigorously tested and refined over millions of years. This means being careful to use science to understand how nature works, not to change what nature is, as we do when genetic manipulation seeks to transform the process of biological evolution

 Do you not feel that, buried deep within each and every one of us, there is an instinctive, heartfelt awareness that provides - if we will allow it to - the most reliable guide as to whether or not our actions are really in the long-term interests of our planet and all the life it supports?

 It is only by employing both the intuitive and the rational halves of our own nature - our hearts and our minds - that we will live up to the sacred trust that has been placed in us by our creator

fields.headline: TV worsens global warming
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: The phasing in of digital television is expected to increase domestic power consumption in UK homes by 7% by 2010 and could add to global warming, according to research by Oxford University's environmental change unit.
fields.body:
The phasing in of digital television is expected to increase domestic power consumption in UK homes by 7% by 2010 and could add to global warming, according to research by Oxford University's environmental change unit.

Unlike computers, which have a less power-thirsty "sleep mode" when not in use, digital set-top boxes have to be left fully powered up all the time.

Tina Fawcett, one of the researchers who carried out a projection of domestic electricity consumption in the UK, Netherlands and Portugal, said: "One of the main causes of global warming is energy use. The more demand there is the more electricity you are going to have to generate, and digital TV is going to make a significant difference."

fields.standfirst: Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: A heavily-pregnant Cherie Booth yesterday proved herself a thorn in the government's side as she led an impassioned legal defence of the need to balance parenthood with working life.
fields.body:
A heavily-pregnant Cherie Booth yesterday proved herself a thorn in the government's side as she led an impassioned legal defence of the need to balance parenthood with working life.

In her last high court appearance before the birth of her fourth child, due next week, the prime minister's barrister wife declared on behalf of the TUC that government policy on parental leave was unlawful.

Ms Booth, who recently hinted strongly that she wanted her husband to take paternity leave when their baby arrived, spoke forcefully of "allowing parents to strike a balance between work and family rights" in a row over a new entitlement to parental leave.

The regulations, which last year brought an EU directive into British law, allow up to 13 weeks' unpaid leave to mothers and fathers of children under five.

But, under pressure from employers' organisations, the government restricted this right to parents of children born after December 15 last year.

The TUC, bringing its case against the trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers, claimed the privilege should also have been made available to all existing parents who had children under five on that date.

The legal battle highlights continuing tensions within Mr Blair's administration between the urge to keep business sweet and promoting family-friendly working. The government has also come under strong pressure, not least from its own female backbenchers, to provide some form of payment for parental leave amid warnings that few parents - particularly fathers - will otherwise take up the new right.

Ms Booth, appearing with a team of three women barristers "catering for any eventuality", said the government's restriction had the effect of cutting off 2.7m parents from claiming the extra time with their children that was theirs by right.

She said it created a "two-tier system of parental leave; those parents fortunate in having children born after December 15 and other parents with similar age children [born] before that".

Tony Blair chose this week to reveal that, while he would scale back his official workload, he would not be taking paternity leave for the birth of the couple's fourth child. Instead, he is expected to hop up and down stairs between home and office, cutting his working hours but by no means handing over his duties completely.

Yesterday Ms Booth told the court that it was impossible to put a price on the loss to parents who miss out on time with their children.

"What they are losing is the right to family life," she said. "That is very difficult to quantify in monetary terms." Similarly unquantifiable were "the benefits to employers of a family-friendly policy: a more contented workforce, a more committed workforce".

Ms Booth told Lord Bingham, the lord chief justice, and Mr Justice Morison - who are not expected to pass judgment for a week - that to include the parents of children under five born before December 15 would cost employers about £50m on top of the projected £42.18m over five years.

These figures were "small beer" compared with the £2.5bn cost of the minimum wage regulations, said Ms Booth. The cost to employees of taking unpaid leave would be £109m in lost income, much greater than the cost to employers.

The government's claim that the burden on employers was already excessive was an exaggeration, she said.

Jonathan Crow, counsel for the trade and industry secretary, said the EU directive referred to the right of workers to parental leave "on the grounds of the birth or adoption of a child".

Therefore the entitlement to leave was triggered by the specific event of birth or adoption, not by merely having responsibility for a child, he said.

The TUC is likely to appeal if it loses the case, and DTI sources indicated the government might do the same if defeated.

TUC campaigners fear a worst-case scenario which would see the decision passed to the European court of justice, effectively "kicking the whole thing into the long grass", according to one source.

fields.headline: Rail disaster rescue 'hampered'
fields.standfirst:
Survivors of Paddington crash tell public inquiry of frustration with inadequate emergency equipment

Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: Survivors of the Paddington rail disaster yesterday told how inadequate safety standards and emergency equipment hampered efforts to save the lives of horrifically burned passengers.
fields.body:
Survivors of the Paddington rail disaster yesterday told how inadequate safety standards and emergency equipment hampered efforts to save the lives of horrifically burned passengers.

First aider, Andrew Cowgill of Cirencester, Gloucestershire, said he could not find first aid equipment to help other passengers.

He told the public inquiry into the accident that there should be regulations to reduce the potential for serious injury by ensuring all passengers had seats.

Mr Cowgill, who was travelling in coach D of the first Great Western train last October, said: "On the day, it was very confusing but I would have expected to be able to find a first aid kit to treat casualties. I could not see any indication as to where the first aid kit was or about hammers to break the windows."

He described how he tried to comfort a semi conscious woman whose injuries were "among the worst" he had seen. "The burn injuries were terrible down her leg, into her torso and her head. She was very badly burned and her injuries were so great that she had difficulty understanding me. She was semi-conscious.

"There was very little that I could do. I had my hand on her head on one side and was trying to reassure and encourage her." The woman later died in hospital.

Safety hammers used to help passengers smash windows to escape from the twisted wreckage broke after a few strikes, the inquiry was told. Passenger Anthony Knox, of Reading, Berkshire, a senior lecturer in paediatric intensive care, said the first people off the train were "incredibly courageous" because they made sure that the dangling overhead electrical wires were not live before allowing anyone to leave.

When the emergency services arrived they seemed inadequately equipped, the inquiry heard.

Passenger Lee Tyack, a Swindon-based railway worker, said: "When the train came to a halt it was a scene that I can only describe as like going into a furnace. Flames were either side of the window and that was the only light to see by."

Fellow passenger Martin Brennan, a banker originally from Cheltenham but now working in Hong Kong, joined Mr Tyack and began to help three trapped passengers on the Thames train. He said he tried to smother the flames after hunting in vain for a fire extinguisher.

One victim spoke of her horror that her efforts to comfort a badly injured passenger led to her family wrongly being informed that she was dead.

Evelyn Crosskey, 28, of Long Wittenham, near Didcot, recalled how amid the chaos she gave her coat to Pam Warren, 33, of Reading, Berkshire, to sit on. First aider Mrs Crosskey, who works for Marks & Spencer, left Mrs Warren to see if she could help other victims unaware that her coat containing her work ID pass was taken to Charing Cross hospital in central London, with Mrs Warren. "That evening my parents had a visit from Thames Valley police to inform them that I had died."

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: We Finns are in demand
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Both the Irish and the British governments have asked Finns to help them in the peace process. The former president of Finland, Martti Ahtisaari, is involved in inspecting IRA arms dumps; the former prime minister, Harri Holkeri, took part in the talks that led to the signing of the Good Friday agreement. There are currently two Finns sitting on the International Decommissioning body.
fields.body:
Both the Irish and the British governments have asked Finns to help them in the peace process. The former president of Finland, Martti Ahtisaari, is involved in inspecting IRA arms dumps; the former prime minister, Harri Holkeri, took part in the talks that led to the signing of the Good Friday agreement. There are currently two Finns sitting on the International Decommissioning body.

What makes them so suitable for the job? For a Finn like me the answer is easy. Both countries' histories contain paradoxes that politicians like to forget.

Both the Republic of Ireland and Finland used to be part of a great eastern empire. When Finland declared independence from Russia in 1917 civil war broke out. In Ireland civil war came after the 1921 Irish Free State treaty was signed.

In Finland the civil war divided people into the rightwing Whites who won (helped by Swedes and Germans) and socialist Reds. (Backed by Russia). People whose ancestors supported the Whites call it Vapaussota [the Liberation war] and people whose ancestors supported the Reds call it Kansalaissota [the Citizen's war]. Similarly, in Northern Ireland if a person speaks about Ulster, the North, six counties, the North of Ireland, Northern Ireland, Derry or Londonderry, you can always pick up their political background, even if they haven't said a word about politics.

Every time Mika Häkkinen wins a formula one motor race you will see vast numbers of Finnish flags. But behind these visible signs of unity there were once many divisions. This too originated in the civil war. Until very recently, two organisations governed almost every single sport in the country. Those whose families had supported the Whites formed the bigger one and those whose families had supported the Reds ran the smaller one. Meanwhile in Ireland, Gaelic football clubs still don't allow Northern Ireland's security forces employees to join.

Sweden ruled Finland before Russia did, until 1809. Swedish speakers were a privileged minority and many of the country's biggest industries are still run by Swedish-speaking families. The republicans say the same about Protestants in Northern Ireland.

Almost all of the citizens of the island of Åland wanted to become part of Sweden. But, as a result of a 1921 League of Nations decision, the island remained part of Finland (even though the population speaks Swedish). Today Åland is a demilitarised zone and has autonomy, its own assembly and a member in Finland's 200-seat parliament.

A Republican mother, whose son was killed by the IRA after the Good Friday agreement was signed, recently told me how she trusts the RUC and fears the IRA. Yet even after she had told me this she still believed that the IRA should never give up its weapons. That would be a sign of weakness, a sign of surrender, like admitting that the whole war has been useless.

Strangely, this is easy for me to understand. I remember that when I was a kid - probably like most boys in Finland - old men showed me the old guns that they had kept as memorabilia. I can understand how big an insult it would be if someone forced them to hand over their weapons.

My father had to flee home at the age of five, when Russians started bombing the borders of Finland in 1939. My father's family were given half an hour to pack their belongings and leave. My grandfather was later killed during the Continuation war in 1944, and my grandmother never saw her home again.

The way my father speaks about the Russians is very similar to the way the republicans speak about the British. Their words are full of hate but that hate is rarely aimed against anyone in person. It is simply a hatred of unfair politics. Sadly, that hatred blinds people from seeing the positive side of their multicultural heritage.

After the war Finland had to pay a heavy price, establish a war crimes tribunal against it's own leaders and pay reparations to Stalin's Russia.

An Englishman sat on the war crimes tribunal which sentenced some of Finland's wartime leaders. Finland had to agree because Stalin claimed that the Finns had started the war. It was 50 years before Russia accepted its responsibility. Finland had to give up Karelia to Russia and one fourth of the country's population [400,000] became refugees.

In Finland it is popular to say: "In wars there are no winners." Northern Ireland has its unique history, but perhaps it is not as unique as the local politicians would like us to believe.

 The author is a Finn living in London

webTitle: Recreational drugs 'can have lasting side effects'

fields.headline: Recreational drugs 'can have lasting side effects'
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: New medical evidence has debunked the myth among recreational drug users that small amounts of ecstasy and cocaine are safe after two studies published today found that even moderate doses of the drugs have serious and long-lasting mental or physical side effects.
fields.body:
New medical evidence has debunked the myth among recreational drug users that small amounts of ecstasy and cocaine are safe after two studies published today found that even moderate doses of the drugs have serious and long-lasting mental or physical side effects.

German researchers discovered that ecstasy could reduce intelligence, while an American study suggested that taking a small amount of cocaine could cause blood clots and might explain the high rate of heart attacks among users.

Researchers at Aachen University found that regular users of ecstasy performed far worse in mental tasks than those who had never taken the drug. They concluded that the effects may be "cumulative and irreversible".

They tested the alertness, attention span, memory and general intelligence of 84 people - a third of whom were regular users of ecstasy and cannabis, a third regular users of cannabis and a third who did not take any drugs.

The researchers found that ecstasy users got significantly worse scores in complex memory tests, although their alertness was not affected.

The results, published in the Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery and Psychiatry, suggested that ecstasy could lead to a "cognitive decline" in otherwise healthy young people, particularly if combined with cannabis, by having toxic effects on brain cells, particularly those involved in the serotonin neurotransmitter system, which might be irreversible.

Researchers at the Pittsburgh University medical centre who monitored the heart rates and blood chemicals of 14 young people for two hours after the subjects were given a small dose of cocaine found that the drug slightly increased heart rate and blood pressure, with a more significant increase in the chemicals aiding the formation of clots.

William Wagner, who led the research published in the journal Heart, said: "The risk of thrombosis, similar to the risk of sudden cardiac death, is real and may affect even the first time user of small quantities of the drug."

webTitle: To the Millbank dreamers: lay off the fairy dust

fields.headline: To the Millbank dreamers: lay off the fairy dust
fields.standfirst:
Sketch: Simon Hoggart

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A Labour MP handed me a plain white envelope yesterday morning. I won't say tears of mirth were rolling down his cheeks, but he was certainly shaking gently with merriment.
fields.body:
A Labour MP handed me a plain white envelope yesterday morning. I won't say tears of mirth were rolling down his cheeks, but he was certainly shaking gently with merriment.

The envelope contained the official Labour analysis, sent to the party's MPs, of the local elections and the Romsey byelection. I mentioned this briefly last week, but nothing prepares you for the full text, the sheer bonkers, demented, mind-spinning lunacy of the whole document.

What is scariest is that the people who wrote this piffle almost certainly believed it. They must imagine that their weird view of events leads us to a higher truth, like a hot air balloon soaring skywards, untethered by mere reality, free from the ballast of facts.

Recall that in the elections Labour lost almost 600 council seats, a worse result than anyone had predicted, its candidate for mayor of London came a poor third, and because of tactical voting, the Labour candidate in Romsey lost his deposit.

So the analysis begins: "Yesterday's elections show that William Hague is dead in the water." (A bold opening, when you consider that his poll results are now better than ever before.)

"To lose Romsey is a disastrous result for Hague. The Tories have made no progress in London since the general election, and the local elections, with a record low turnout, are meaningless in general election terms."

Translated, this means: "The bad news for the Tories is terrible. The bad news for us doesn't count."

The analysis continues to pick at Romsey. "The Tories have lost their 51st safest seat by 3,300 votes. This is totally unprecedented and a disaster for William Hague.

"Now real questions have to be asked about his leadership and his political judgment. He attended Romsey three times, and it seems the more he is involved in an election, the worse the Tories perform. The alarm bells are ringing over his leadership."

No wonder, because according to Labour's version of events, "on this basis, in a general election the Tories would come third, William Hague would lose his own seat, and Michael Portillo would be left to lead a rump of just 11 MPs".

Clearly some political Puck has been scattering fairy dust in people's eyes at Millbank, turning donkeys into hunks. Apparently the London results, which, by the standards of normal people - people who can count, say - were terrible for Labour, were even worse for the Tories. They "have made no comeback from the disastrous result they got in the 1997 election".

In fact, Labour had an incredibly good night. "Labour won Welwyn and Hatfield, and has kept historic gains, including Trafford, Gloucester, Hastings and Exeter."

Like children rootling in a bran tub full of manure in the hopes of finding a sweetie, they start pulling out the tiniest victories. "Labour also held Longbridge ward!" they announce triumphantly.

Our political parties seem increasingly to resemble Japanese companies that demand total loyalty and mental subservience. Sales may drop, profits may collapse, new products can flop - all this must be ignored as the company's glorious past and future are constantly praised by its disciples.

When an organisation is as large and as tightly controlled as the modern Labour party, it requires bigger and bigger fabrications to hold itself together. None of the MPs who received this fax thinks one word of it is true, yet the party demands that they act and speak as if they do.

They do not have to believe the lie, but they are obliged to publicly embrace it.

webTitle: Diabetes breakthrough may end insulin injections

fields.headline: Diabetes breakthrough may end insulin injections
fields.standfirst: Breakthrough may end insulin jabs
fields.trailText: A British surgeon has announced a breakthrough in the treatment of diabetes, holding out the prospect of an end to insulin injections and strict diets and a return to a normal life for the millions around the world who suffer from the condition.
fields.body:
A British surgeon has announced a breakthrough in the treatment of diabetes, holding out the prospect of an end to insulin injections and strict diets and a return to a normal life for the millions around the world who suffer from the condition.

James Shapiro, based at the University of Alberta in Canada, told transplant surgeons in Chicago yesterday that he has successfully transferred human pancreatic islet cells, which generate insulin, into eight patients who once had chronic diabetes but are now living ordinary lives.

Richard Moore, the clinical director of the transplant centre at University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff, predicted "enormous" demand for the procedure. Speaking after the meeting, he said: "This really is something - a breakthrough.

"Diabetes mellitus is a very severe disease and most diabetics would jump at a chance to have a normal diet, avoid a regime where they need several injections a day and constant monitoring of blood sugar levels."

Mr Shapiro told 3,800 delegates at the joint conference of the American Society of Transplants Surgeons and the American Society of Transplantation that he had extracted the cells from the pancreas of dead donors. They were kept alive and purified by fellow surgeon Jonathan Lakey and then injected into a main vein, called the portal vein, connected to the liver.

The cells were carried in the bloodstream into the liver where they "nested". Even though they were in a different organ, they produced sufficient insulin to allow the patients to live for the first time without daily insulin injections.

The eight, aged 29 to 53, had very severe diabetes from their youth, needed up to 15 injections of insulin a day and often suffered blackouts without warning. "They were crashing their cars, falling off horses or burning themselves while cooking," Mr Shapiro said.

After undergoing the transplants on average 11 months ago, Mr Shapiro said they showed "complete control" of a chemical marker which signals damage from high blood sugar.

"There has been clear and dramatic improvement in quality of life for the patients and no evidence of rejection," said the surgeon.

The only problem he foresaw was meeting the expected demand from diabetics for the transplant, which is a simple procedure involving injection of the cells into the vein and does not need to be done by a surgeon. It will involve at most an overnight stay in hospital, he said.

He acknowledged that getting a sufficient supply of islets was a problem, but said he thought it could be overcome in about five years by cloning techniques.

Until now, surgeons have unsuccessfully focused on trying to transplant the entire pancreas into a diabetes patient.

Mr Shapiro said a new anti-rejection drug called Rapa mune, which became available in the US last year, had been crucial to the new treatment. "The drug regime is extremely well tolerated and the patients do not have the moon faces associated with steroids," he told the meeting.

Patients receiving the cells have to remain on anti-rejection drugs for life, but Mr Moore said taking low doses of Rapamune, which appears not to have some of the side-effects of other such drugs, "was a very good trade off".

The quality of life of at least a million diabetics in Britain was often poor, he said. They were at risk of heart disease, blindness, strokes and loss of limbs through blood vessel deterioration.

Transplant centres in the UK and France are about to try to duplicate Mr Shapiro's work. If they succeed, there is likely to be huge demand for the treatment and initially at least the cost implications will be high.

Rapamune will cost at least £5,000 per patient per year once it is licensed in the UK, Dr Moore said.

fields.headline: Straw's fury at obscenity verdict
fields.trailText: Jack Straw, the home secretary, threatened a shake-up of Britain's obscenity laws after a landmark high court ruling yesterday that the film censors were wrong to ban the sale of double X explicit hardcore porn videos in licensed adult sex shops in Britain.
fields.body:
Jack Straw, the home secretary, threatened a shake-up of Britain's obscenity laws after a landmark high court ruling yesterday that the film censors were wrong to ban the sale of double X explicit hardcore porn videos in licensed adult sex shops in Britain.

Mr Justice Hooper dismissed the test case brought by Andreas Whittam Smith's British Board of Film Classification, saying that the risk of the seven videos involved being seen by and causing harm to children was, on the present evidence, insignificant.

The BBFC last night refused to comment in detail on its defeat but when it started the case last September, Mr Whittam Smith said that failure would have "fundamental implications" for all its decisions on classifying videos and films, including those involving unacceptable levels of violence.

The judgment reinforces the legal view that adults should not be prevented from access to explicit material just because it might be harmful to children if it fell into their hands.

As TV "decency" campaigners claimed that the decision would "open the floodgates to hardcore pornography", Mr Straw said he would, if necessary, bring in new legislation to sort out the current "shambles" of the obscenity laws.

"The home secretary believes that the situation is un satisfactory and it will be considered carefully whether additional steps can be taken to protect children from exposure to this sexually explicit material. Any such changes may require legislation," a Home Office statement said.

Mr Straw made clear his anger at the decision and said that he had personally intervened to replace the BBFC acting president, Lord Birkett, with Mr Whittam Smith to stop the licensing of such "stronger" videos to be sold in adult sex shops.

The target of his anger is the 1984 Video Recordings Act, introduced as a private member's bill to curb the alleged excesses of "video nasties".

The case centres on a decision by the independent Video Appeals Committee to overturn the BBFC's refusal to give a special R18 certificate to seven "hardcore" videos produced by Sheptonhurst Ltd and Prime Time (Shifnal) for restricted sale in Britain's 80 licensed sex shops.

The committee, which is chaired by John Wood, a former deputy director of public prosecutions, includes the novelist Fay Weldon.

The film censors said the seven videos - called Horny Catbabe, Nympho Nurse Nancy, TV Sex, Office Tart, Carnival International Version (trailer), Wet Nurses 2 Continental Version and Miss Nude International Continental Version - should not be licensed unless "all shots of penetration by penis, hand or dildo as well as shots of a penis being masturbated or taken into a woman's mouth" were removed.

Lord Lester of Herne Hill, for the BBFC, told the high court that if the videos were allowed to be sold all hardcore material would have to be licensed unless it was criminally obscene or could be shown to cause "devastating harm to more than a minority of children and young people".

But Mr Justice Hooper said the assessment by the Video Appeals Committee that the risk to children was insignificant was a reasonable conclusion.

Greg Hurlstone, a director of Prime Time, said he was delighted but insisted his US-made videos were double X rather than triple X productions, as they featured consensual penetrative sex without close-ups and no ejaculation or illegal practices.

Last night Clive Sullivan, a consultant to Sheptonhurst, insisted that the decision would not unleash a flood of European triple X hardcore films: "There are still limits which will be applied," he said.

But John Beyer of the National Viewers and Listeners' Association called for new legislation to clamp down on porn. "This will open the floodgates to hardcore pornography," he said.

fields.headline: Terra to snap up $10bn Lycos
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A new powerhouse in the internet market was created last night when Spanish service provider Terra Networks agreed a $10.6bn (£6.5bn) deal to acquire Lycos, the American web company.
fields.body:
A new powerhouse in the internet market was created last night when Spanish service provider Terra Networks agreed a $10.6bn (£6.5bn) deal to acquire Lycos, the American web company.

Terra, which is controlled by Spain's former state telephone company Telefonica, is already the largest internet business in Europe and the deal creates a strong competitor to the headlining US internet firms.

Some estimates said the combined group would be one of the four largest internet operations in the world.

The deal is the latest in the rapid consolidation of the still fledgling internet industry as businesses seek to establish dominant positions. Terra plans to offer about 1.7 shares for each in Lycos, valuing it at $96.70 a share.

Established in 1998, Terra has attracted millions of Spanish and Portuguese-speaking internet users in both Europe and Latin America.

Analysts said the deal with Lycos would open doors in the US, which has an estimated 35m Spanish speakers with an average income well above that of their counterparts south of the border. Terra has a market capitalisation of around €19bn.

Lycos shares climbed $15 to over $75 in early trade on the New York markets.

webTitle: We're not selling BMW, family insists

fields.headline: We're not selling BMW, family insists
fields.standfirst:
Shareholders queue to enter the BMW annual meeting in Munich

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: BMW yesterday promised its shareholders an independent future after the disposal of the bulk of the Rover car business to the Phoenix consortium, and pledged itself to growth without the need for "mergers and diversifications".
fields.body:
BMW yesterday promised its shareholders an independent future after the disposal of the bulk of the Rover car business to the Phoenix consortium, and pledged itself to growth without the need for "mergers and diversifications".

The Munich-based group also confirmed that a £500m loan to Phoenix was interest free and was to be repaid from future profits.

In a special intervention at the annual shareholders' meeting yesterday, the chairman of the supervisory board, Volker Doppelfeld, said he had been asked by the Quandt family - which speaks for almost half the shares in BMW - to make it clear that it had no plans to sell the holding.

There has been persistent speculation that the family would be prepared to sell, clearing the way for one of the world's leading car makers to take over.

Volkswagen, Ford and General Motors are said to be interested. But Mr Doppelfeld insisted: "Speculation about the sale [of the stake] is off the wall. The Quandt family fully supports BMW. Anyone who argues to the contrary is not telling the truth."

Though the family's spokesman has consistently denied the Quandts were prepared to sell the stake, the decision to raise the issue formally at the annual meeting is likely give the "not for sale" message additional force.

Both the family and the executive board came under fire from small shareholders for being too late with the decision to dispose of Rover - dubbed "the English patient" by the German media.

Chief executive Professor Joachim Milberg defended the decision to dismember Rover and to sell the Longbridge car plant - home of the Rover 25 and 45 and the MGF sports car and to which production of the Rover 75 is to be switched.

"Our decision to give up Rover was absolutely essential in the interest of the overall future of the BMW group. The group will continue to grow in future under its own power, without requiring mergers or diversification," he said.

BMW expects this year's net profits to be significantly higher than the €663m (£398m) earned fro last year, before provisions of €3.15bn for the disposal of Rover.

The group is planning to make 800,000 BMWs this year - against 750,000 last year - though analysts note that the bulk of the group's sales are of its 3-series model, which is positioned in an increasingly competitive sector of the market.

However, the Munich car maker is planning to introduce a smaller BMW which it said yesterday will be launched in 2004.

The group's future model line-up will also include the new Mini as well as a new Rolls-Royce, once BMW assumes control of the marque at the beginning of 2003.

webTitle: Premier League bets on online jackpot

fields.headline: Premier League bets on online jackpot
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The Premier League is demanding a share of revenues from online betting and other interactive services run by the media company which wins the main rights to broadcast live matches from the 2001-2 season.
fields.body:
The Premier League is demanding a share of revenues from online betting and other interactive services run by the media company which wins the main rights to broadcast live matches from the 2001-2 season.

A copy of the tender document adds a clause to the package of 66 live matches which requires the bidder to include projections of how much revenue it hopes to generate through the exploitation of interactive services enabled by digital television.

The Premier League also wants the broadcasters to outline the percentage they would hand over to the game's officials plus the size of a non-returnable advance each season.

Different deals on interactive revenues will subsequently be agreed between the league and each platform that agrees to carry the live games. Similar demands are made on bidders for the pay-per-view package of 40 live games.

"It's sensible of the Premier League to look at the interactive element and try to write something into the agreement," said Nick Batram, sport and leisure analyst at broking firm Granville Baird. "Whether deals end up being structured in that way is a different issue."

The 23-page document forms the basis for what is expected to be the most expensive broadcasting deal in sport. The growing number of broadcasters jostling for position in Britain has prompted estimates on the amount that will be generated by the process to soar as high as £2bn. Anyone winning the main live rights will have to pay 7.5% of the fee on offer immediately.

Initial bids were lodged with the league last week and offi cials are now meeting broadcasters to flesh out their proposals. Channel 5 is understood to be at the league's offices this morning. Around 75 tender documents were sent out to interested broadcasters and all the mainstream TV firms in Britain are expected to feature including BSkyB, NTL, Telewest, OnDigital and the ITV companies.

Speculation is growing that the key bidders may agree between themselves which set of rights they will bid for in the hope of keeping the price as low as possible.

The tender document says the league will either draw up a shortlist of a maximum of five bids for each package of rights on offer or move to recommend a single bid straight away. The process will then move to either sealed bids or an auction. A number of clubs are believed to favour the auction method.

Under the current deal, hatched on the eve of Euro 96, BSkyB paid £670m for five years with the BBC winning a highlights package for £73m.

In the current bidding process there are two free-to-air highlights packages and clubs will have rights to screen their own matches on their own channels or websites on a delayed basis.

The contract length for the new set of broadcast rights has been reduced from five to three years.

webTitle: This time hackers have the whole internet to play with

fields.headline: This time hackers have the whole internet to play with
fields.standfirst:
Chatroom: Dan Atkinson

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: He's back - and he's bigger and badder than ever. The computer hacker, big business's top bogey of the 1980s, is tap-tapping at the keyboard once more, and this time round he has the whole of the internet to play with.
fields.body:
He's back - and he's bigger and badder than ever. The computer hacker, big business's top bogey of the 1980s, is tap-tapping at the keyboard once more, and this time round he has the whole of the internet to play with.

Suddenly everyone is on the alert. Yesterday the financial services authority (FSA), the chief City regulator, announced a new crackdown on dubious make-money schemes on the net.

And today London solicitor and leading fraud expert Steven Philippsohn will present a paper containing figures on computer crime that will startle even the most grizzled fraud-watcher.

Central to the hacker's mummy-like lurch from the grave are two new developments: "netspionage" and cyber terrorism, Mr Philippsohn will warn.

The bill for these activities already runs to billions of pounds annually, and failure to control the e-crime explosion could push the cost into the higher realms of mathematics.

Currently, it is netspionage - defined by Mr Philippsohn as "theft of confidential information" - that is racking up big losses for large western corporations.

Almost $20bn (£13bn) in costs had to be swallowed last year by copyright owners as hackers helped themselves to all types of intellectual material, ranging from computer codes to auction bids on the internet.

But cyber-terrorism - including what may be termed "e-extortion" - is closing fast. Visa, the credit card company, was recently faced with a £10m demand from "a group of British hackers" who claimed the ability, using stolen "source codes", to crash the world's biggest payment system.

Faced with the possibility of losing tens of millions a day should the threat be carried out, Visa showed its mettle by ringing the police.

But, Mr Philippsohn will claim, others have caved in. A British bank "paid a ransom of £12.5m after blackmail threats", a British broker paid £10m for similar reasons and, most worryingly from the state's point of view, "a British defence firm [paid] £10m in ransom."

Both netspionage and cyber-terrorism mark a major shift from the computer hacker of yesteryear, not least because the available technology has expanded greatly.

Whereas theft of copyright material from computer bases would have required, a decade or so ago, a certain patience and determination, today, according to Mr Philippsohn, one tool used to steal secrets is Tempest (Transient electromagnetic pulse emanation surveillance technology), that allows a scanner to read the output from a computer up to a kilometre away.

"It is non-invasive and virtually undetectable," he says.

Put another way, computer hacking no longer has the decency to be confined to people who are good with computers. Any fool can, it seems, collect valuable material with about as much knowledge as it takes to operate a microwave oven.

In the 1970s and 1980s, the hacker was either a friendless loner or a super-cynical computer expert as played by Hywel Bennett in The Consultant. Today the hacker could be anybody.

In fact, as the anti-fraud section of computer group Unisys warned last October, today's computer fraudster most closely fits the profile of someone a big computer company would most like to hire.

fields.headline: National Power tidies up
fields.trailText: National Power yesterday cleared the way for the planned demerger of its British and international operations by announcing exceptional charges totalling £1.37bn.
fields.body:
National Power yesterday cleared the way for the planned demerger of its British and international operations by announcing exceptional charges totalling £1.37bn.

The value of interests in Pakistan, Australia, Spain and Thailand have been written down by £246m to bring them in line with market conditions.

It has written down the value of a long-term electricity contract by £200m after the fall in electricity prices and also reduced the book value of older generation assets.

webTitle: Less a disaster, more a widow's mite

fields.headline: Less a disaster, more a widow's mite
fields.standfirst:
Notebook Employers count cost of ruling
Midland Bank
fields.trailText: Are we to pity the country's employers, now facing a ruinous £17bn bill for the pensions of hundreds of thousands of part-time workers all the way back to 1976?.
fields.body:
Are we to pity the country's employers, now facing a ruinous £17bn bill for the pensions of hundreds of thousands of part-time workers all the way back to 1976?.

Midland Bank, one of the worst affected by yesterday's European court ruling, thinks so. It likened the ruling to back-dating the motorway speed limit to 60mph and then fining everyone who had exceeded it prior to the law change. The Institute of Directors was hardly pleased either. How could employers run their businesses when courts can land them with huge back-dated liabilities?

But do such numbers really stack up? First, the biggest "victim" of the ruling is the government, ultimate employer of the legions of supply teachers and part-time NHS workers. So a large chunk of the £17bn will not fall on the private sector. So, at worst, the bill for private employers is in the single-figure billions. Even this is probably an enormous over-estimate, however. Britain has around 6m part-time workers, but high staff turnover suggests that few will have had many years' service with any one employer. Around three-quarters stay for less than two years - and therefore fall outside the scope of the ruling.

Part-timers need to have put in a claim for pension rights within six months of leaving employment but most have not done so. Knock off a few more noughts.

And for those whose company's scheme was a contributory one, they will have to stump up a cash payment in lieu of what they would have contributed. Since the vast majority of part-timers are low paid, the likelihood they will have treasure stashed away is remote. More money off the employers' bill.

The final total could be as little as £100m says William Mercer, one of the biggest company pension advisers. Or to put it another way, around 0.01% of the £850bn invested in UK company pension schemes. Some of yesterday's gnashing of teeth looks premature.

Hopes go east

After a decade of "transition" to free markets, the bulk of the economies of central and eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union are smaller than they were at the beginning of the process, according to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

The EBRD estimates released yesterday show only Poland, Slovenia and the Slovak republic recording increases in gross domestic product in real terms between 1989 and 1999 - though Hungary is within a whisker of its old level and Albania and the Czech republic are close. In the former Soviet Union the picture is bleak. Moldova's economy is now less than a third of its former size, while that of Ukraine and Georgia are barely better.

A couple of caveats. Official figures from the days of Soviet control routinely overstated performance. By contrast the latest figures understate activity as they do not include the often vigorous black economies. Even so, the EBRD acknowledges that the position is disappointing.

There is some good news. Give or take the odd percentage point, the forecasts suggest that the economies of all 26 of the bank's countries of operation will show growth this year. Indeed the re gion as a whole has shown surprising resilience in the face of the setback caused by the Russian default in 1998 and the conflict in Kosovo.

But a note of caution. The reform process in central and eastern Europe is linked to countries' hopes of being allowed into the European Union. Further east, recovery is being pushed on by a recovering oil price and currency devaluations. The risk of setbacks remains considerable.

Compass askew

Granada chairman Gerry Robinson is said to be spitting tacks at the way in which the final deal of his career has slipped prematurely into the public arena, only to be met with a coordinated raspberry from the markets.

Knee-jerkers in the Square Mile have assumed that a nil-premium takeover of catering group Compass means exactly what it says, and even yesterday there was no recovery in Compass stock after Monday's 15% beating - the price slipping another couple of pence to 768.5p.

But followers are missing a key fact here: according to the best over-the-shoulder document readers on Moorfield's High Walk, some sort of "sweetener" is in store for Compass shareholders when the deal - on current plans - is announced tomorrow morning.

Inflation game

Fed chairman Alan Greenspan is worried about inflation, hence yesterday's half-point rise in interest rates. But, according to reports from the US last night, Goldman Sachs' influential market strategist Abby Cohen believes the worst of the inflation years is already past. For the gurus it's game on.

fields.headline: A good man in Africa
fields.standfirst:
The government says our troops in Sierra Leone are there just to evacuate westerners. But the man in charge on the ground has other ideas. Chris McGreal in Freetown and Richard Norton-Taylor on the maverick in charge of the biggest British taskforce since the Falklands

Sierra Leone: special report

Interactive: what is happening in Sierra Leone?
Read Geoff Hoon's statement in full
fields.trailText: The government says our troops in Sierra Leone are there just to evacuate westerners. But the man in charge on the ground has other ideas.  Chris McGreal  in Freetown and  Richard Norton-Taylor  on the maverick in charge of the biggest British taskforce since the Falklands
fields.body:
Brigadier David Richards shoots from the lip. In an army not known for its openness in a situation so sensitive the Foreign Office has shrouded its mission in semantics, he is one of a kind. He is comfortable with the press, he speaks in moral as well as military terms and he talks with the authority of a man in charge of a growing number of troops.

He flew to Sierra Leone last month as head of a 15-man "technical assistance" team. Now he is commander of the biggest British taskforce since the Falklands war. He talks of his "great affection" for Sierra Leone, calls the rebels "murdering bullies" and freely admits that he is interpreting the army's mission there "liberally".

He gives good soundbite; now he is giving his colleagues a headache. Fellow soldiers are constantly trying to save him from himself in case he blunders into a diplomatic minefield. And Foreign Office officials are frustrated by his determination to interpret their orders to suit his moral agenda.

But while civil servants in Whitehall express caution about the role of British troops in Sierra Leone, Richards keeps yomping over delicate diplomatic territory.

Take last week. In London the ministry of defence repeatedly insisted the task of 700 British paratroopers was strictly limited to securing key areas of Freetown and Lungi airport. Meanwhile, Richards was sending out very different signals. Asked by Sierra Leone's Radio Democracy whether his evacuation force's mandate was changing, he replied: "There is discussion of that. But because I have personally a great affection for Sierra Leone and the people and all that you have been through - as has my government - that mandate is being liberally interpreted."

Quite where this insubordination comes from is not clear. The length of time he has served in the army suggests he must have towed the line at some stage. Brigadier Richards has been a soldier for 29 years, serving in Northern Ireland, the Far East and the Rhine Army. He was commissioned into the Royal Artillery in 1971. He is married with two teenage daughters, describes himself as a "student of military history" and lists "occasional riding" among his recreations. Compared with others of his rank he is affable, but he does not suffer fools gladly.

His passion is not reserved for Sierra Leone. Last September he commanded the British contingent of the UN forces in East Timor with similar flair. "It's really a matter of sucking and seeing and keeping your fingers crossed. We are prepared for the worst, but hope for the best," he said as he went in. A few days later, after refugees began to return to Dili, the capital, he spoke of a "red letter day for the people of East Timor".

Standing in a village square, he told the refugees: "I have come to tell you that it is safe for you and your people to come back down to Dili."

But the plight of the people of Sierra Leone does seem to have had a particular effect on him, producing forthright and partisan comments. "This is not a war to equate with other wars," he said yesterday. "This is really about a bunch of bullies who go around carrying out murders so they can keep their diamonds."

Among local people his somewhat maverick nature has proved popular. He is well on the way to occupying the same appeal in Freetown as the former British ambassador Peter Penfold. Penfold was recalled after he was accused of complicity in allowing mercanaries to break the UN arms embargo on the country. His departure sparked huge demonstrations in Freetown demanding his return.

Richards may not only enjoy the same popularity but may suffer the same fate. The Foreign Office is trying to distance itself from him for fear that his enthusiasm inflames the situation. Brigadier Richards said that he had been given "pretty wide discretion" to decide on how to help the mainly Nigerian forces fight Sierra Leone's rebels who last week came close to toppling president Kabbah. But if he gets it wrong he will be on his own. Foreign Office sources in London have already ruled out a direct role in combat for British servicemen. "He can employ the movement of assets as he decides. It is not something for London," said a senior British defence source.

Only yesterday, Richards told the BBC that the commander of the UN force had sanctioned a more offensive role against the rebels. UN soldiers would move out from Freetown into the rebel-held countryside.

"He (the UN commander) is orchestrating a move forward, back into the country," said Richards.

Asked whether that was a major development of strategy on the UN's part, he replied: "I think it is, in terms of a plan. It is definitely . . . a move east and to some extent south . . . towards the RUF heartland."

Richards added that as many as six extra battalions of UN troops, rather than the expected two, might be on the way to Sierra Leone.

But it is unclear whether this had been agreed or was an attempt kick into action those governments providing the bulk of the UN peacekeepers - India, Jordan, and Bangladesh - who have so far firmly resisted any change in their mandate.

The increase in the number of troops under him certainly gives him the opportunity to make a serious impact. He is in charge of 700 paratroopers deployed in and around Lungi airport and Freetown, and 40 SAS soldiers engaged in surveillance and intelligence missions deep in the Sierra Leone countryside.

They also include an amphibious group led by the helicopter carrier, HMS Ocean - with an artillery battery and 600 Royal Marines on board itching for action - and the aircraft carrier, HMS Illustrious, with Harrier strike bombers.

As such he is one of the new breed of senior British officers engaged in what the government calls "defence diplomacy" - backing up diplomatic activity and military advice with an effective deterrent force.

By all accounts, he has succeeded in his key mission in Sierra Leone - to restore the confidence of the Kabbah government and the multinational UN force. He might be a loose cannon, but so far his aim has been true.

webTitle: Relief as NHS waiting lists fall

fields.headline: Relief as NHS waiting lists fall
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Hospital waiting lists have finally fallen by more than 100,000 since the last election, in accordance with Labour's most intractable election pledge, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, will announce today.
fields.body:
Hospital waiting lists have finally fallen by more than 100,000 since the last election, in accordance with Labour's most intractable election pledge, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, will announce today.

Mr Milburn will attribute much of the cut in both in-patient waitings lists - 35,000 down in March compared with a year earlier - and out-patient lists - 50,000 down - to reforms in procedures introduced by Labour since 1997.

But ministers, who have struggled harder than expected to turn round what former health secretary Frank Dobson called the "NHS supertanker", are avoiding triumphalism.

"The war on waiting must be sustained. These are very en couraging figures, but this is still very much a work in progress. There will be no crowing," one official said.

Mr Milburn's caution will be justified next month when the waiting lists for April are published. Easter holidays for NHS staff and their patientswill push the figures higher again, at least for the month. But ministers believe they are on the right track now that hospitals are responding to peer group pressure to do as well as the best hospitals do.

Today's figures will take the in-patient waitings list a clear 100,000 below the 1,158,004 in March 1997, just before the 1997 election and at a time when waiting lists were rising. But it will remain above 1m.

With medical critics and opposition MPs complaining that the Labour "early pledge" exercise has backfired by mis-directing resources, ministers will take comfort from the parallel fall in out-patient waiting lists.

It had been widely assumed there would always be a trade-off with patients moved from one list to another and easier cases tackled before more serious and time consuming ones. But ministers say the parallel fall shows they are on the right track.

They will cite such examples as revised guidance on how to handle urology cases - from GP to the operating theatre - adopted by the Central Middlesex hospital in central London. "It's not rocket science, but waiting lists are at an all-time low at this hospital,"said one Milburn aide.

At Thurrock hospital the use of nurses to do endoscopy - examining patients internally with micro cameras - rather than doctors, has similarly improved productivity.

webTitle: Liberty surrenders Tudor trappings to Marylebone

fields.headline: Liberty surrenders Tudor trappings to Marylebone
fields.standfirst: Liberty
fields.trailText: Liberty, famous for its paisley print scarves and mock-Tudor London store, yesterday surrendered 125 years of family ownership through a £72m agreed deal from a property group.
fields.body:
Liberty, famous for its paisley print scarves and mock-Tudor London store, yesterday surrendered 125 years of family ownership through a £72m agreed deal from a property group.

The takeover by Marylebone Warwick Balfour follows a long period of boardroom wrangling and brings a £15.2m windfall to the family led by Elizabeth Stewart-Liberty.

The property group, which is also active in hotels, offered 300p per share for Liberty, around the level of the share price two years ago before it plunged to 100p. It has recovered on bid speculation and last night the shares had risen 23p to 288p.

Marylebone is creating a company - Retail Stores - in which the business of Liberty will be incorporated. Retail Stores will be listed on Aim.

The retail side of Liberty will be consolidated on the Tudor building site while the other half of the premises is developed for leasing. Most of the 600 designers, marketing executives and sales assistants are expected to be kept on.

The new owners plan to exploit the Liberty brand for e-commerce and will offer concessions to other department stores while building more joint ventures, particularly in the far east.

Richard Balfour-Lynn, chief executive of Marylebone, said said that it would take up to three years for the business to break even.

fields.headline: Prescott awaits ruling over flat as Tories accuse him of breaching code
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott was at the centre of a fresh row with the Tories last night over whether he has broken ministerial rules by using a flat provided by the RMT union, which lobbies him on transport issues.
fields.body:
John Prescott was at the centre of a fresh row with the Tories last night over whether he has broken ministerial rules by using a flat provided by the RMT union, which lobbies him on transport issues.

The deputy prime minister will today face a report from the Commons standards and privileges committee on whether he has broken the rules as an MP by not declaring the flat in Clapham, south London in Parliament's register of interests.

But the Tories are furious that the prime minister and Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, have declined to rule on whether Mr Prescott is in breach of the separate ministerial code.

Archie Norman, shadow secretary for the environment, said yesterday: "The crucial issue is not the report by the standards committee. It is a flagrant breach of the ministerial code by receiving a financial benefit from a transport union, when he has ministerial responsibility for trans port." The Tories are asking Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life to investigate.

Mr Prescott's aides deny he has any financial benefit from the union because they say the £220 per month rent on the flat is set as " fair rent " by the independent rent service. Mr Prescott's ministry does however set maximum rents for these properties. The Tories add that comparable market rents in Clapham vary between £1,200 and £2,000 a month.

As well as the Clapham flat - now used by his son, a freelance journalist - Mr Prescott has use of a flat in Admiralty House in Whitehall, and Dorneywood in Buckinghamshire, Gordon Brown's grace and favour residence which the chancellor does not use. He also has a large home in his Hull constituency.

Mr Prescott's aides said last night that Mr Blair was waiting for publication of the standards committee report before deciding to investigate whether the deputy prime minister was in breach of the ministerial code.

webTitle: QXL takes lead in race to dominate Europe online

fields.headline: QXL takes lead in race to dominate Europe online
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: QXL.com yesterday upped the ante in the race to dominate the European online auction sector by agreeing a £668m all-share takeover of Germany's Ricardo.de.
fields.body:
QXL.com yesterday upped the ante in the race to dominate the European online auction sector by agreeing a £668m all-share takeover of Germany's Ricardo.de.

The acquisition was QXL's fifth since floating last October and was seen by analysts as a move made to head off the threat posed by US group Ebay, which is expanding aggressively in Europe.

QXL is now expected to go head to head with E-Bay, and try to use its highly rated paper to buy French online auction house E-Bazar. Both are relatively weak in the market and need to consolidate.

"I'd be lying if I said we had not been talking to virtually everyone in the market - it's that sort of business - but we have no concrete intentions at the moment," said Stan Laurent, QXL's senior vice-president for sales and marketing.

"We're planning to create a major European player pitched against our US rival and develop a consumer brand that will perhaps encompass more than just auctions."

Mr Laurent added that with Ricardo's executives locked into the deal, QXL had the management strength to look beyond Europe and towards Asia. Ricardo already has an interest in Similian, a Singapore based joint venture with Lycos Asia and others.

QXL shares, which have been some of the hi-tech sec tor's most volatile, closed down 4.4% at 171p amid fears that it may have overpaid.

The offer values each Ricardo share at €127, a premium of approximately 27% on Monday's close price, but that fell to 21% after the slide in QXL's price.

Peter Misek, internet analyst at Chase H&Q, said: "I can't believe the shares have reacted in this way. This was an unbelievably positive deal for QXL, a 'must do' deal if they were going to head off E-Bay.

"In a single move they have doubled their gross auction value and significantly increased their revenues. There are also significant cost-saving synergies. QXL is now big enough to compete with E-Bay on a pan-European scale."

The combined group, which is expected to be named QXLricardo and be listed in London and Germany, will have a registered user base of 1.17m.

During the last quarter QXL made a loss of £10.7m on revenues of £1.6m.

In March it agreed to pay £347m to take over its Scandinavian competitor, Bidlet AB. That deal followed successful bids for rivals in Norway, Denmark and Poland.

Analysts believe that QXL is trying to mimic the strategy of American companies such as Cisco - which moved swiftly after its flotation to build dominant market positions through acquisitions.

webTitle: Rising star  Booming Bookham heads for FTSE

fields.headline: Rising star  Booming Bookham heads for FTSE
fields.trailText: The seemingly relentless rise in the share price of stock market newcomer Bookham Technology continued apace yesterday after the fibre optics company released its first figures since floating last month.
fields.body:
The seemingly relentless rise in the share price of stock market newcomer Bookham Technology continued apace yesterday after the fibre optics company released its first figures since floating last month.

Shares in the Oxford-based company - priced at £10 on flotation - climbed nearly 10% to a record high of £39.12 after it announced a 22% rise in first quarter revenues to £2.5m and an 80% increase in product shipment. However, net losses widened to £5.6m, with further heavy investment in product development, staff and manufacturing centres expected.

The latest share price increase values Bookham at £4.6bn and places it in pole position to move into the FTSE 100 when the next quarterly changes are determined on June 7.

Based on Monday's closing price, Bookham would take the place of either Baltimore Technologies, Thus or Kingston Communications, which have suffered from the sell-off of technology shares since entering the index in March.

Bookham chief executive Andrew Rickman, above, speaking publicly about the group's financial prospects for the first time, predicted future trading would be "strong" with several new product launches boosting second-half figures.

He also reiterated his aim to build an "optical Intel".

Bookham has a dual Nasdaq listing and the rules of the US Securities and Exchange Commission have forbidden Mr Rickman from commenting publicly on the flotation.

He and his wife own al most 25% of the company, a stake that is valued at about £1.1bn.

The startling performance of Bookham shares has been driven by investor demand for a technology that uses light to transmit data, catering to the needs of high-speed internet and telecoms networks.

It uses what it claims is a "unique" manufacturing technique to build fibre-optic cables.

webTitle: Popular Mowlam gloomy about voter interest

fields.headline: Popular Mowlam gloomy about voter interest
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam, the most popular member of the Labour cabinet, yesterday refused to rule herself out for a high profile role as party chairman, but suggested her popularity may be connected to a decline in voter identification with traditional political parties.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam, the most popular member of the Labour cabinet, yesterday refused to rule herself out for a high profile role as party chairman, but suggested her popularity may be connected to a decline in voter identification with traditional political parties.

Speaking a day after a Guardian/ICM poll gave her a 58% approval rating, the highest of any minister, Ms Mowlam asked aloud: "Why am I so popular? I don't know. Is it because I have had an operation? Is it because of Northern Ireland? I wonder how strong party identification is."

The Cabinet Office minister also revealed that many of her colleagues were so disturbed by the low voter turn-out in recent elections, they were advocating a move to compulsory voting.

Re-emerging into the spotlight after a period of relatively few media appearances, Ms Mowlam said the polls "were far from good, but mid-terms have never been good, and it is no worse than any other government". Nevertheless she conceded that many backbench MPs felt displaced, Labour had not covered itself in glory over the London mayoral elections and "people don't perceive we are listening as a government". She added that the fall in Tony Blair's popularity had been caused by press "caricatures" of his personality and leadership style.

Ms Mowlam was speaking after Labour's former party general secretary Tom (now Lord) Sawyer called for a strong party chairman to unite the competing factions in the party and government.

Besides Ms Mowlam, the name of the education secretary, David Blunkett, has also been canvassed. But Downing Street insists the appointment of a party chairman is not being discussed.

Speaking at the Commons launch of an academic research project into the decline in voter participation and identification with political parties, Ms Mowlam conceded there was a worrying long-term fall in interest in party politics. She personally was opposed to compulsory voting, but said, on the basis of informal discussions with MPs: "I have to say there are many different points of view, and there may not be many on my side."

Ms Mowlam suggested there was a long-term decline in voter identification with political parties, especially among younger voters, and pointed to the recent victory of Ken Livingstone in London.

webTitle: Yes TV cuts float price by 30%

fields.headline: Yes TV cuts float price by 30%
fields.trailText: Yes Television yesterday reduced the offer price of its shares by 30% after delaying its planned stock market flotation last month.
fields.body:
Yes Television yesterday reduced the offer price of its shares by 30% after delaying its planned stock market flotation last month.

The video on demand company had a stormy run-up to its proposed listing five weeks ago which saw relations sour between the company and two of its key partners.

Yes TV's updated prospectus yesterday said it had terminated its agreement with Hull's Kingston Communications. It avoided mention of an agreement to supply video on demand services to cable company NTL - which has also fallen apart.

Dealing in the shares is now back on track to begin next Monday, with the price set at 175p, against the original range of 225p to 275p a share. The revised offer price will give Yes TV a market capitalisation of some £560m and raise proceeds of £126m.

The head of marketing at Yes TV, Steve Garvey, said: "We accept that there has been some turbulence, but if you set NTL and Kingston against deals we have subsequently signed in France and Norway and the extension of our agreement with BT then I think we are slightly up on balance.

"I wouldn't say we are pleased with what has happened, but we are satisfied."

The agreement with BT to pilot a service in west London has been extended from June until September, and discussions are under way for a co-project in Cardiff to replace the NTL trials.

Yes TV has ordered 15,000 ADSL lines in Cardiff which upgrade copper telephone wires for broadband use.

From next year media companies will be permitted to offer full broadcast services over the BT network.

Pilot services are also being launched by Yes TV with Telenor, the Norwegian telecoms company and Skyline, a French media business.

Mr Garvey said the price cut reflected the market decline since the beginning of April. "It has been a very tough market to sell into but fund managers have been positive," he added.

The opening up of BT's networks and the arrival of ADSL technology has prompted a new generation of media companies hoping to offer interactive services. Yes TV rival Filmgroup has already outlined plans to float, while Video Networks is also expected to join the market.
