fields.headline: Wot, no codpiece?
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Last night's TV: It was a night of deception. Of women tricked by those who claimed to love them so dearly.
fields.body:
It was a night of deception. Of women tricked by those who claimed to love them so dearly. In the case of Anna Karenina (C4) the real cad was television, who'd duped Anna into thinking she was going to receive an honest adaptation. Like Madame Bovary, a strange thing happened on the way to the small screen. Events had conspired to turn a complex, proto-feminist icon into Queen Bitch. From one of literature's most intriguing cyphers into a spoilt rich cow from Notting Hill.

Alas, literary adaptations are no longer Paul Eddington in breaches and pointy helmet hamming up the Duke Of Pumpernickel. They must be "relevant" to Clerkenwell. In other words, look like This Life 2. Out go the codpieces. In comes steel-blue lighting with out-of-focus humping. Thankfully, Anna K held true to some old-fashioned ham: manly bear-hugs ("I want to hear all about zee hunting trip, Har Har!"); heaving breasts at the piano recital; and the obligatory Mr Darcy moment: a wet blouson dripping stormy passion on the doorstep. Count Vronsky put the beast out of its misery with a blurry gun.

Murder In The Family (C4) promised blood-drenched soap and delivered a girl looking out over the sea: documentary short-hand for poignancy. Sam's parents were A1 aircraft designers ("a small world"). Their trick was the standard parental ruse of making their kids believe the sickest dysfunctionalism is normal. Which it is, of course.

A single photo told the story: daddy standing with his arm locked proprietorially around mummy. A 15 quid agency pic with a bunch of dead Daffs and dappled peach wall. Except mummy kneeled submissively at his feet.

Daddy loved his little rituals: the 400 "bow-downs" to kiss his shiny shoes. Force-feeding the daughter. Kicking the dog to death. Faking his own death. Just another day in Bournemouth, that living hell with a 40 foot drive.

Daddy found sadism addictive. But how far would he take it? Getting the daughter to keep look-out as he screwed the mistress on the marital bed. Was she making it up, we wondered? Was it really that bad or that different? Neglected, unloved, but aren't we all, à la Larkin? She reeked of abuse, and tragically, it made the viewer hate her too.

When I Get Older (BBC2) was made of tougher stuff. Because it was a gem. Jan, a beautiful old woman from Copenhagen, was moving to Oxford to be near her family. "I'd prefer to live in Denmark, but to die in England", she said acidly.

The film followed Jan as she packed her boxes and moved into a granny-flat: that quaint name for a box shaped slightly differently from a coffin. Her so-called family had talked Jan out of living alone because they said she couldn't cope anymore. Not, as it transpired, because they cared for her, or even liked her, but simply because they wanted to control Jan.

"We're practical people, sensible people, boring if you like", said her sister-in-law. "Maybe it's because we're Christians, we know that we're here to be used." Except the only person being used was Jan. To call her family her family at all was a misnomer. They were strangers, playing a cruel trick.

In Denmark, Jan had entertained with her sparkling wit and a fridge-full of champagne. She'd lent a fur-trimmed dress to Vivian Leigh and befriended Joan Crawford. She was leaving all this to be near what? A fur-lined kettle.

Six months after moving, the family stopped visiting, the good Christians that they were. Jan's loneliness was deafening in that flat. She wanted to go back to Denmark, but we knew she'd never make it. This sharp little film made you embarrassed to be English. What do we do with our old? Put them in hutches and wait for them to die. With their thick, bullying, zealous, hectoring stupidity, the Christians pointed to a wider truth about the caring, sharing family. You wanted to kill them for killing Jan.

In Reputations (BBC2) Olga Korbut moved across the floor like a mechanical butterfly. Days before her Olympic debut, her trainer had raped her. They say that you hurt the ones you love, and Renald Knysh had all the love in the world for Olga. That day (score: 9.89) she had the face of a 40-year-old woman on the body of a 14-year-old girl. We knew something was wrong, maybe that's why we loved her so much.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: British brewing and leisure group Whitbread is to sell its Swallow Inns and restaurants to Enterprise Inns for £119m. The consideration is to be in cash, minus an adjustment for net working capital of around £4m, and is likely to be effected in June.
fields.body:
Whitbread sells Swallow estate
British brewing and leisure group Whitbread is to sell its Swallow Inns and restaurants to Enterprise Inns for £119m. The consideration is to be in cash, minus an adjustment for net working capital of around £4m, and is likely to be effected in June. The estate comprises 183 pubs, which were put up for sale in February. In the financial year to September 1999, the business had sales of £64.4m with an operating profit of £14.6m.

The dot.com prince
Saudi Arabian prince Alwaleed bin Talal said yesterday that he had invested $1bn in 15 US companies, including six internet firms and two telecoms companies. The prince's Kingdom Holding Company put $50m each in Amazon.com, eBay, Internet Capital, Priceline.com, InfoSpace Inc and Doubleclick, as well as Coca-Cola, Pepsi, McDonald's, Walt Disney, Ford, Gillette and Procter & Gamble.

The new investments raised the value of the prince's technology, media and telecommunications portfolio to $7.8bn.

Rolls wins £80m US order
British aero-engine maker Rolls-Royce has won a $120m (£80m) order for its Trent engines. The engines were ordered by US-based International Lease Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of American International Group, and will power three Airbus Industrie A340-600 aircraft. Deliveries are scheduled to begin in June 2002.

ILFC is the largest of several companies which supply aircraft to airlines on lease. The order brings the total number of firm and optional orders for Trent-powered A350-500 and 600 aircraft to 129 globally, and the total value of Rolls-Royce orders announced this year to nearly $5.5bn. $1bn more for BCCI creditors.

Creditors of the collapsed Bank of Credit and Commerce International (BCCI) were repaid another $1bn (£625m) yesterday, taking total compensation since the bank's collapse in July 1991 to about 60p in the pound.

Liquidators Deloitte and Touche said 70,000 creditors - including those who deposited funds with BCCI - may receive 75% of what they were owed, although the final settlement will depend on various legal actions, including a £1bn-plus case against the Bank of England.

Specie substitute

Charles Darwin, the Victorian originator of the doctrine of the survival of the fittest, is to feature on new £10 notes, the Bank of England announces today. Darwin's portrait will replace that of his contemporary, Charles Dickens, on the notes, which will be similar to the new £20 notes in incorporating extra security devices to combat counterfeiting.

The dot.com prince Saudi Arabian prince Alwaleed bin Talal said yesterday that he had invested $1bn in 15 US companies, including six internet firms and two telecoms companies. The prince's Kingdom Holding Company put $50m each in Amazon.com, eBay, Internet Capital, Priceline.com, InfoSpace Inc and Doubleclick, as well as Coca-Cola, Pepsi, McDonald's, Walt Disney, Ford, Gillette and Procter & Gamble. The new investments raised the value of the prince's technology, media and telecommunications portfolio to $7.8bn. Rolls wins £80m US order British aero-engine maker Rolls-Royce has won a $120m (£80m) order for its Trent engines. The engines were ordered by US-based International Lease Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of American International Group, and will power three Airbus Industrie A340-600 aircraft. Deliveries are scheduled to begin in June 2002. ILFC is the largest of several companies which supply aircraft to airlines on lease. The order brings the total number of firm and optional orders for Trent-powered A350-500 and 600 aircraft to 129 globally, and the total value of Rolls-Royce orders announced this year to nearly $5.5bn. $1bn more for BCCI creditors. Creditors of the collapsed Bank of Credit and Commerce International (BCCI) were repaid another $1bn (£625m) yesterday, taking total compensation since the bank's collapse in July 1991 to about 60p in the pound. Liquidators Deloitte and Touche said 70,000 creditors - including those who deposited funds with BCCI - may receive 75% of what they were owed, although the final settlement will depend on various legal actions, including a £1bn-plus case against the Bank of England. Specie substitute Charles Darwin, the Victorian originator of the doctrine of the survival of the fittest, is to feature on new £10 notes, the Bank of England announces today. Darwin's portrait will replace that of his contemporary, Charles Dickens, on the notes, which will be similar to the new £20 notes in incorporating extra security devices to combat counterfeiting.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Pick of the day
fields.body:
Villains: Kentucky Teenage Vampires

(Steve Rose)

9pm, Discovery

After The Blair Witch Project, it's difficult to know when you're being had these days, but this is supposedly a true story. Welcome to Murray, Kentucky, home to a number of vampire cults. These trench-coated goths take drugs, drink each other's blood and mutilate the occasional pet, but unwarranted attention came their way when breakaway member Rod Ferrell committed a double murder in 1996. Ferrell, his mother, fellow vampires, and upstanding townsfolk all contribute to this fantastic tale.

Goodfellas

(Martin Scorsese, 1990)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Scorsese at his brilliant best, back on the mean streets with an assured and crunchy tale of ugly, vicious people. Co-writer Ray Liotta plays real-life Italian-Irish gangster Henry Hill, who after years of murder and mayhem turned state's witness. The wiseguys he first admires, then fears, are Joe "You think I'm funny?" Pesci, an evil little monster; Paul Sorvino, the godfather who orders Hill to make up with wife (Lorraine Bracco) for the good of the Family; and most fearsome, Robert De Niro's Jimmy, a man steeped in casual violence.

City Of Angels

(Brad Siberling, 1998)

10.05am, 6pm, Sky Premier

A loose reworking of Wim Wenders's Wings Of Desire, Siberling's sweet romance has Meg Ryan as a down-to-earth surgeon being wooed by Nicolas Cage's angel: he's one of many roam ing Los Angeles doing good deeds, but now he's prepared to hand in his wings for love. Intelligent and appealing, despite the pedestrian climax.

Starman

(John Carpenter, 1984)

9pm, 3.15am, Carlton Cinema

Another otherworldly romance, and a surprising subject for Carpenter. Jeff Bridges (pictured) is the space visitor who changes his appearance to that of Karen Allen's late husband and creates an intergalactic love affair. All very charming, although the snappy bits of conflict show what Carpenter does best.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: Sin Pattenden spoke to boys in Cookham, Berkshire.
fields.trailText: What boys sitting in the sun are watching on TV
fields.body:
Clark, 13: "I don't like TV. My dad sits and watches it all the time, or he gets videos out - some rubbish. He sits and eats his tea and swoons over Julia Roberts who I think is an old cow. Last thing I watched? Probably the snooker. I love it, man, I can watch it for hours and hours. My mum likes it, but my dad doesn't. He gets really narky. Do I watch Art Zone on BBC2?? Nah, what's that? I did see some programme about this girl who draws stick pictures in the nude, she was not what I thought an artist was."

Matt: "I watch everything. I like EastEnders, Top Gear or any car programme. I want to get a Mazda or a Porsche when I get some money. I love cars. My dad's got a Mini Cooper and I hate it, it's a crap car. I want a babe magnet, something page-three girls will want to sit in. Any more TV programmes? I watched that thing with Michael Barrymore in it, and I thought it was crap. I thought it was going to be funny."

Dean: [Kicking football] "Ali G's my favourite. I like it when he makes the drugs references and all that, I think he's spot on. Right on it. Wicked. I like the football and I like a bit of motor racing. Costume drama? Nah, who do you think I am? A bird? [Kicks football onto a child's head] Oh, sorry mate. Sorry. Lee here's going to be on telly [Lee giggles]. On the Channel 5 late night show, hahahahah. He's a porn star."

Lee: "No I'm not. I want to be a TV presenter like Johnny Vaughan. I got the gift of the gab. Wouldn't want to work with Lisa Tarbuck though, I'm more of a Van Outen bloke myself."

Ashley: "I don't watch TV, I play football or doss about here with my mates. We go around at night and swim in the river. I think TV's rubbish, loads of cookery and girls' things. Yeah, I think so. My auntie knew Jill Dando."

fields.headline: Manhattan transfers
fields.standfirst: Salman Rushdie likes it so much he's moving there. Martin Amis fell in love with it long ago. What is it about Brits and New York?  Amanda Foreman  , who commutes between London and Manhattan, on the complex allure of a city that worships success
fields.trailText: Salman Rushdie likes it so much he's moving there. Martin Amis fell in love with it long ago. What is it about Brits and New York?  Amanda Foreman  , who commutes between London and Manhattan, on the complex allure of a city that worships success
fields.body:
It is easy to see why Salman Rushdie, Martin Amis and a host of other writers have fallen in love with New York. Like a femme fatale, it is irresistably compelling. With every generation comes a new wave of hopefuls: small-town escapees, European refugees, disaffected Londoners. Once here, few are not entranced. Suddenly the rest of the world seems like an unbearable backwater. After a year of living here while researching my next book, I still look around me with a sense of wonderment. I think I understand what a citizen from ancient Athens must have felt when seeing the might of Rome for the first time.

The New Yorker writer, EB White, once compared the city to a poem, "whose magic is comprehensible to millions of permanent residents - but whose full meaning will always remain elusive". But the magic is by no means pure. The energy that New York exudes is as much the light of extinguished souls as it is the spark of individual enterprise. And while the full meaning of the city may prove elusive, all New Yorkers are painfully aware that it remains an intractable mass of contradictions. It is not just the extremes of wealth and poverty living side by side. It is as though every condition is locked in a struggle with its opposite, fixing New York in a state of permanent tension. Tolerance vies with racism, social mobility with elitism, sophistication with insecurity, efficiency with corruption, philanthropy with excess. Neither will yield to the other which is one reason New York defies definition.

It might sound strange to describe New Yorkers as insecure when they delight so much in the cult of success. The display of wealth here, especially new wealth, is indeed wonderfully frank, from the super-long limousines which clog up the roads, to the voluptuous fur coats that adorn both men and women. LA has the Oscars once a year, but it's Oscar night every night in New York. Even something relatively unimportant like a black tie gala at the New York Metropolitan Opera House means couture ball gowns and real jewellery.

I went to one for the American Ballet Theatre last week and saw two society hostesses almost have a heart attack because the designer had made them the same dresses. The "pink dress affair" buzzed through the audience like a 19th century scandal. In New York, appearance is a form of currency, or at the very least a calling card. One must look wealthy in order to be recognised as a person of worth.

In a sense the whole city is an an audience and, from time to time, someone will stand up and announce, "Last year I made $1,000,000, but this year I'm going to make $10,000,000," while every body applauds, each drawing hope and inspiration from the example. New York magazine, the weekly bible for Manhattanites, features a hilarious real estate section whose sole purpose is to spotlight very rich people buying very expensive homes.

However, the cult of success is inextricably linked to its malevolent doppelganger, the cult of celebrity. The two combined have had an insidious affect on social mores such as courtesy, fairness and inclusion. To be a celebrity here is to enjoy the most craven and undisguised fawning. Unlike the British press, American newspapers handle literary figures with kid gloves, as if they were national treasures. In general, these manifestations of mass sycophancy are so crude that it almost makes the British envy of success seem attractive. Life is vastly different for the celebrity. Restaurants will always find a table, most services become free or ridiculously cheap, there is no such thing as a wait, invitations to anything and everything pour in. No one is ever rude or says no to a celebrity. A successful hairdresser told me recently that he barely breaks even because he dare not charge his more famous clients. Interestingly, celebrity is relative and highly local in New York. A famous person from another country counts for nothing unless he or she also succeeds here. I once saw Robin Cook, the Foreign Secretary, try in vain to catch his waiter's eye while film stars Alec Baldwin and Kim Basinger nearby were mobbed with attention.

Just a couple of blocks away from my apartment, there is a restaurant called Moomba. I am told the food is so-so, and from the outside the decor looks distinctly ordinary. Its chief attraction is the VIP room where celebrities can dine in their own little corner, safely tucked away from the gawping hoi-polloi. A bouncer stands outside in front of a velvet rope, presumably to deter pushy nobodies.

I can't understand why anyone except a masochist with a desire to be humiliated would frequent such a place. I suppose a certain celebrity might go to have his or her ego boosted but in a normal world we would feel sorry for such people and hardly admire them. In New York one man's fame stems from another's mortification.

The consequence of this adoration of the celebrities is that to be ordinary is to be treated at times as though less than human. My fiancé once joined a group of friends in a live audience in front of David Letterman. Not only were they herded about like cattle, they were talked to as if they were cattle. Such contempt simply for being ordinary.

It is said that LA welcomes unknowns because today's unknown is tomorrow's discovery. New York, on the other hand, regards them as pests who won't go away. Both perceptions are probably exaggerated. However, I remember when I first arrived in New York, having an interview with a senior editor at a literary magazine which ended in farce. It was a boiling hot day and I arrived for a lunch appointment dishevelled and unnerved by the intense humidity. The editor looked up at me from his desk, smiled distantly, and said that he was too busy for lunch and it would have to be rescheduled. He then carried on writing and, humbly, I left.

Yet New Yorkers not only revel in the status quo, they participate in their own humiliation. The clubs, naturally, have rules; some will accept Jews, blacks, and self-described homosexuals, some will not. But many of the co-ops, which constitute the majority of affordable and attractive New York housing, are also segregated. A co-op is a residential building owned by all the lessees; it is run by an elected board who have the right to determine who can buy an apartment. It is so routine for buyers to be rejected by boards that no one complains. Snobbery reigns supreme. I did not believe the stories about covert racism or social black-balling until I saw it for myself. For brief time, my fiancé and I toyed with the idea of buying a place, so I contacted Stephen, the broker we had used for our rented flat. We wanted to live downtown, I told Stephen, in a pre-war building.

He was disarmingly honest about the co-op process, and even went so far as to list which buildings accept Jews and non-whites, and which do not. "But you won't have a problem getting past the board," he said, "because you are Wasps." I am in fact Jewish. We decided to rent after that.

As far as I know, such naked exclusionary tactics do not exist in London, my other home town. Nor is there the same frenzy of consumption and self-congratulation. It may be that the worst is yet to come, and London is merely catching up to New York's excesses. But then it is not ruled by the City to the same extent that the stock exchange powers New York. "Believe me," said an editor at New York magazine, when I told him that everybody wants to move to New York. "If the Nasdaq or the Dow Jones dropped 500 points, Salman Rushdie and Martin Amis would move elsewhere."

Such impermanence is the great irony and, of all New York's contradictions, perhaps the biggest. What seems to be creative energy is often just feverish activity inside a ballooning bubble. New York is like a Potemkin Village, its inhabitants mere imports for the day. VS Pritchett despised the deracination of New Yorkers. "There is no place where newness is so continuously pursued," he wrote. "The past is a shame. It must be wrong. New York lives in the present because it is real estate. It has been more for sale than any other city I can think of."

However, the real threat to New York's predominance is not the instability of its wealth, but the momentum of its own success. The city is in danger of becoming the Monaco of America. The more New York attracts the famous and the established, and celebrates the successful at the expense of the striving, the more it poisons its own creative pool. If the pendulum continues to swing in favour of the have-it-alls, the extraordinary tension which sustains this city will collapse.

. . . and the Americans who love London

Warren Hoge, London bureau chief, New York Times

"London appeals to New Yorkers with a certain interest in creative life, in cities. For me, the attraction is built around theatre: I used to come each fall to see whatever the new David Hare play was. As for the underground - well, I grew up on the New York subway system, and this is Valhalla compared to that. When people ask if I miss New York, I say: I'm a real New Yorker, but the one place I don't miss New York is London."

Harriet Gugenheim, Film company executive

"I can't see myself leaving now. I enjoy visiting America, but it's very small-minded. I like the access to the rest of the world you have in Europe - and the feeling that you don't have to worry about being mugged. The one thing that makes me want to leave London? Property prices."

Rafael Lago, President, American Intercontinental University

"They say the British can be unwelcoming, but it's all to do with attitude: if you're determined to find people unfriendly, they will be unfriendly. There's also a feeling of safety in London that is unlike any other city I've visited. Eventually I guess I'll have to go back but if right now I were to receive a call telling me I had to return, I'd be very disappointed. I've fallen in love with this city."

Jennifer Waddell, Graphic designer

"I'm attracted to the ease of living in London. Transport is convenient - it makes the pub more enjoyable when you don't have to drive home afterwards. It seems generally safer here as well. Some people find Londoners unfriendly; I like that they generally keep to themselves. But then again, it's expensive and dirty."

fields.headline: No: 1637 Ned Kelly
fields.trailText: Appearance: Bequiffed, mean streets WG Grace lookalike
fields.body:
Appearance: Bequiffed, mean streets WG Grace lookalike

Status: Bush ranger, outlaw and Australia's greatest folk hero.

Gosh, the competition for that title must be intense. A cheap and unjust slur on the nation that produced Olivia Newton John.

What did he do then, apart from ranging the bushes? Stole horses, robbed banks, killed a lawman or two. The usual outlaw stuff.

Why is he so famous? Many Australians say he was a working class hero, waging a war on bourgeois society and the trappings of property.

So he was a thief, like you said. What else? Well, his popularity might also have something to do with the Iron Mask.

Hang on, that's France, surely? Ned had clearly read Alexandre Dumas ( père ) before making his last stand. His outlaw gang was tracked down to a hotel in the town of Glenrowan. Determined never to surrender, our hero emerged sporting a comical mask and suit fashioned from what looked like a coal scuttle and a bucket.

Sounds more Blue Peter than Dumas. Either way, it didn't do him much good. He was wounded, caught and hanged, although he managed to kill a policeman before they nabbed him.

Sounds pretty clear cut - the man's a murderer. Ah, but did he get a fair trial? This week, 120 years after his death, Kelly will have another chance. Two top QCs are set to argue the case at Melbourne supreme court. And, in a twist of which Kelly might have approved, the public will decide on his guilt or innocence.

So his head is on the block again? It would be, if his skull hadn't vanished from the Kelly Museum in 1978. A farmer in north-western Australia claims to be holding it ransom until he is sure it will get a Christian burial.

Do say: A timely reconsideration of the reputation of an important socialist icon.

Don't say: Olivia Newton John: Guilty or not guilty?

Not to be confused with: Shergar.
fields.bodyText: Appearance: Bequiffed, mean streets WG Grace lookalike Status: Bush ranger, outlaw and Australia's greatest folk hero. Gosh, the competition for that title must be intense. A cheap and unjust slur on the nation that produced Olivia Newton John. What did he do then, apart from ranging the bushes? Stole horses, robbed banks, killed a lawman or two. The usual outlaw stuff. Why is he so famous? Many Australians say he was a working class hero, waging a war on bourgeois society and the trappings of property. So he was a thief, like you said. What else? Well, his popularity might also have something to do with the Iron Mask. Hang on, that's France, surely? Ned had clearly read Alexandre Dumas ( père ) before making his last stand. His outlaw gang was tracked down to a hotel in the town of Glenrowan. Determined never to surrender, our hero emerged sporting a comical mask and suit fashioned from what looked like a coal scuttle and a bucket. Sounds more Blue Peter than Dumas. Either way, it didn't do him much good. He was wounded, caught and hanged, although he managed to kill a policeman before they nabbed him. Sounds pretty clear cut - the man's a murderer. Ah, but did he get a fair trial? This week, 120 years after his death, Kelly will have another chance. Two top QCs are set to argue the case at Melbourne supreme court. And, in a twist of which Kelly might have approved, the public will decide on his guilt or innocence. So his head is on the block again? It would be, if his skull hadn't vanished from the Kelly Museum in 1978. A farmer in north-western Australia claims to be holding it ransom until he is sure it will get a Christian burial. Do say: A timely reconsideration of the reputation of an important socialist icon. Don't say: Olivia Newton John: Guilty or not guilty? Not to be confused with: Shergar.

webTitle: Hospitals look to China to ease nurses crisis

fields.headline: Hospitals look to China to ease nurses crisis
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The NHS is turning to China in a desperate attempt to recruit nurses for Britain's short-staffed hospitals.
fields.body:
The NHS is turning to China in a desperate attempt to recruit nurses for Britain's short-staffed hospitals.

In the first initiative of its kind, the head of the NHS recruitment division will this month lead a delegation of hospital trusts to China to discuss the official secondment of nurses on short term contracts.

About 100 Chinese nurses have already arrived in Britain and are undergoing adaptation training and assessment before being considered for professional registration.

The NHS is short of about 17,000 nurses, even though the government has created 4,000 extra training places and helped generate a 73% increase in applications for nursing diploma courses.

Individual trusts have increasingly resorted to overseas recruitment, mainly from Australia, New Zealand and the Philippines.

But this the first government backed drive to bring nurses from abroad.

Last November the government banned poaching from developing countries - particularly South Africa and the Caribbean - unless their governments gave consent.

The Department of Health said yesterday that the China venture was strictly at the invitation of its government, which wanted its nurses to gain experience elsewhere.

"The NHS team will be finding out more about nursing and health provision in China in order to decide whether to accept the Chinese authorities' request for cooperation in enhancing the education and skills of Chinese nurses," a department statement said.

"The purpose of the initial visit is to gather information to enable the trusts to decide whether they wish to participate in this initiative and offer a period of employment to some nurses.

"The Chinese authorities have been very keen to encourage the NHS to employ Chinese nurses, but has made it clear that it would be essential for any staff employed to return to China at the end of the contract."

Five trusts will be represented on the delegation, to be led by David Amos, head of the NHS Executive recruitment and retention unit. Among the five are believed to be St Mary's hospital in Paddington, west London, and Brighton Health Care.

A health department spokeswoman said the trip was being paid for by the NHS "on a minimum basis" and would last a matter of days.

The United Kingdom Cen tral Council, nursing's regulatory body, meanwhile disclosed that some 100 Chinese nurses had already arrived in Britain. About half had come direct and the others had moved on from jobs in other countries - mainly Saudi Arabia, the US and Canada.

A council spokesman said the nurses were typically working as health care assistants while undergoing a period of adaptation, being tested especially on their mastery of English.

"Our understanding is that they have been trained to standards we would recognise. The big factor is language: not just being able to find your way around in a tourist kind of way, but more about being able to communicate with patients."

A spokesman for the Royal College of Nursing said: "We welcome the experience and skills of nurses around the world, but overseas recruitment should not be seen as a long term solution to nurse shortages.

"The RCN is supportive of recruitment under the new ethical guidelines, which take account of the workforce needs of the origin country. To address nurse shortages, we need to continue to raise the value of nursing as a career to attract UK recruits and to retain experienced nurses."

fields.headline: Concentrating minds
fields.standfirst:
Labour's dwindling lead may have its uses

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Whether you take ICM in yesterday's Guardian (Labour seven points ahead) or ICM for the Conservative party (Labour eight points ahead) or Gallup in the Telegraph (Labour ahead by 16) one thing is clear: the gap is narrowing.
fields.body:
Whether you take ICM in yesterday's Guardian (Labour seven points ahead) or ICM for the Conservative party (Labour eight points ahead) or Gallup in the Telegraph (Labour ahead by 16) one thing is clear: the gap is narrowing.

It begins to look just about possible that the next election might be a meaningful contest after all. That is great news for William Hague. Yet it could, paradoxically, be good news for Labour too.

For nearly three years after the Labour landslide, politics were becalmed. The Conservatives were an irrelevance. When they tried to challenge the government, it sounded like nothing more than the squawks of the dispossessed.

But now, as the Labour lead dwindles, there is the sense at last of an opposition in action, doing the new Blairite politics some damage. And one step behind that, should this trend continue, will come the apprehension that we might just have a Conservative government next time.

That could bring uncommitted voters to ask themselves, as they have not had to do until now, what a government under William Hague might be like. Contemplating the leader's recent pronouncements on law and order, asylum seekers and so on, many former Conservative voters who defected in 1997 may relish the prospect.

But those who have drifted away from Labour because they believe that nothing fundamental has changed may now be bought back, however reluctantly, to their 1997 allegiance by the awakening fear of four years of Hague. They may start to ask themselves if they really want to entrust the British economy to a party still entangled in twin commitments to spend as much as Labour on health and education, while cutting taxes.

They may note that Mr Hague, congratulating his shadow cabinet colleagues and himself on the way their campaigns on crime and race have caught the public mood, went on to say they must now develop vote-winning strategies on health and education. That comes rather late in the day, you may think.

However disturbed they may be at the government's failure to find more than 75p a week for them, Labour doubters may start to ask themselves whether pensioners would be better served by the Tories, who first broke the link between pensions and wages.

Though disheartened that Labour has not done more for the poor or to close the gap between men's wages and women's, they may too reflect on what the figures revealed in last week's report on social inequality tell us about the effects of four terms of Tory government. Would a fifth have been different? Is there any reason to think Mr Hague would do better?

At the same time those upset by Stephen Byers's handling of the crises at Longbridge and Ford may ask themselves: would things have been any better if Angela Browning had been in charge?

They may also begin to wonder if the Tories are any better placed to handle the issues of Europe than they were last time round; and whether the mean and opportunistic Tory response to Britain's involvement in Sierra Leone suggests a party ready for government or one which expects - and deserves - a decade of opposition.

To list all that - and there could be much more - is not to subscribe to the view often promulgated by Blairites that there is only one valid choice in politics: New Labour, as they invented it, or many more years of the Tories.

Should Labour have done better over the past three years? Certainly. Should it have been more brave, more true to itself? Undoubtedly. But does any of that make a case for restoring the Tories? No way.

fields.headline: Can Mr Barak deliver?
fields.standfirst:
Palestinian hopes for peace are fading

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: This week's explosion of violence in the West Bank and Gaza - which (so far) has left three dead, hundreds wounded, and brought direct exchanges of fire between Israeli troops and Palestinian police - is not difficult to explain, though much harder to justify.
fields.body:
This week's explosion of violence in the West Bank and Gaza - which (so far) has left three dead, hundreds wounded, and brought direct exchanges of fire between Israeli troops and Palestinian police - is not difficult to explain, though much harder to justify.

Promised that the new millennium's opening year would finally bring a lasting settlement, Palestinians have watched with growing frustration as US-expedited "fast-track" talks have reverted to the old, familiar, stop-go two-step.

Staged Israeli territorial hand-overs have come late, in bits, or not at all; 1,650 political prisoners remain behind bars; refugees languish in Lebanon and elsewhere, their right of return as uncertain as ever; and new Jewish house-building, tunnels and road schemes inexorably extend and deepen Israel's grip on the land Palestinians deem their own.

While the outside world focuses on the more salient drama of a Lebanon withdrawal under fire, on the grim harvest of Syria's displeasure, and on a vengeful Hizbullah's vow to pursue its war beyond the pale, the dream of Palestine reborn is again obscured. Even significant developments, like prime minister Ehud Barak's now delayed attempt to transfer the village of Abu Dis to Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's control, are intrinsically dismaying in their implications.

Abu Dis, mooted as a base for a Palestinian government, overlooks the Al-Aqsa mosque, Islam's third holiest shrine. It is very close to Jerusalem. But it is very far from being the Arab east Jerusalem capital which Mr Arafat seeks. A recent survey showed that 71% of Palestinians still support the peace process. But only 13% now believe Mr Barak can deliver the framework for a September agreement, or indeed any agreement at all.

The Palestinians are not alone in questioning the Israeli leader's capabilities. Divisions within his coalition on domestic policy, and voter concerns about jobs and taxes, have reduced his room for manoeuvre in the (unrelated) peace talks. In less than a year, his approval rating has fallen below 40%. Suddenly the shine is off. But political obituaries are premature.

If Israelis are serious about peace being the top priority, Mr Barak remains their best bet. He must do better, faster, particularly in the talks with Mr Arafat; and they must support him. Some speculate about a comeback by ex-prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu. To use the current Palestinian term, that really would be risking nakba (catastrophe).

webTitle: Trimble losing grip on wavering party

fields.headline: Trimble losing grip on wavering party
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The British and Irish governments were last night facing defeat in their struggle to restore devolution to Northern Ireland on Monday, with the Ulster Unionists in rudderless disarray.
fields.body:
The British and Irish governments were last night facing defeat in their struggle to restore devolution to Northern Ireland on Monday, with the Ulster Unionists in rudderless disarray.

David Trimble, their leader, appeared isolated within his party in his wish to return to government with Sinn Fein. Even his assembly team, the party's most liberal element, was yesterday opposed.

Mr Trimble still clings to hopes of another government concession, but is expected to have to decide tomorrow whether to press ahead with Saturday's meeting of his 858-strong ruling council.

No matter what he decides, his five-year leadership looks to be under serious threat.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, is trying desperately to entice the Ulster Unionists on board. He has infuriated the SDLP and Sinn Fein with concessions to Mr Trimble on RUC reform and on the controversial issue of flags, but his concessions appear so far to have been insufficient.

As well as last minute decisions to reserve powers to name the police and to rule on which flag flies over government buildings, Mr Mandelson has sent Mr Trimble a lengthy letter to reassure him on other issues that include electoral fraud, prisoner releases and punishment beatings.

Nationalists were outraged. Republican sources suggested that the IRA initiative would be withdrawn if unagreed concessions continued.

Sinn Fein said that the Ulster Unionists' list of demands proved they were more interested in blocking progress than in solving the decommissioning issue. Trimble loyalists said the questions were instead about winning cover before the party council meets.

Seamus Mallon, the deputy SDLP leader, lambasted Ulster Unionists for attempting to re-negotiate the deal which all other parties say was agreed at Hillsborough Castle 12 days ago. He warned the government that drip-feeding concessions would strangle the political process.

Danny Kennedy, Ulster Unionist assembly member, replied: "It is time for the SDLP, who have had little or no pain to endure, to make up their minds as to whether they want the Belfast agreement to work. They come to us with their sympathy but offer nothing for the pro-Union people."

Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's chief negotiator, pleaded with Mr Trimble to face face down his party opponents. He said: "The question is, when are those people going to wise up for once and for all and join the rest of us in giving our people a real future?"

Northern Ireland Office sources said that the aim must be to re-focus on the IRA's offer, which will allow some of its dumps to be inspected regularly, and thereby encourage Mr Trimble to take the biggest gamble of his career.

The government again appealed to John Taylor, Mr Trimble's deputy, to stop backing away from a deal he had resoundingly endorsed.

Anti-agreement unionists (who privately concede that the IRA's statement is highly significant) were yesterday in the ascendancy after having been put on the back foot last week, and they stepped up a well-organised campaign aimed at wooing the middle third of the council. One anti-agreement Ulster Unionist MP said: "Trimble gave us a chance. Had he moved in and sold the deal early last week, we were lost."

webTitle: Hope for men's health in soaps and net

fields.headline: Hope for men's health in soaps and net
fields.trailText: Soap operas and the internet could be used by government to persuade men to look after their health, in an attempt to narrow the gap between their life expectancy and women's.
fields.body:
Soap operas and the internet could be used by government to persuade men to look after their health, in an attempt to narrow the gap between their life expectancy and women's.

Professional women are living on average 10 to 12 years longer than men with low incomes. But much of men's ill-health is preventable. The Men's Health Forum, presenting a report on health inequalities yesterday, said 250 men a day were dying from smoking-related diseases, while 1,500 men a year committed suicide.

Yvette Cooper, minister responsible for public health, said at the report's launch that the government wanted ideas from the public and organisations on ways of getting the message through to men during the current consultation exercise for the NHS modernisation plan. The website is www.nhs.uk/nationalplan

Ian Banks, chairman of the Men's Health Forum, suggested that soap operas could be persuaded to incorporate men's health problems in storylines. Another hope was the internet; the website for NHS Direct was well used by men.

webTitle: Police suspect shot men died in gang war

fields.headline: Police suspect shot men died in gang war
fields.trailText: Two men found shot dead in Leeds could have been victims of a gangland feud in Manchester, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Two men found shot dead in Leeds could have been victims of a gangland feud in Manchester, police said yesterday.

The bodies of Clifton Junior Bryan, 29, and Denis Wilson, 38, were discovered in a car early on Monday morning in Harehills, Leeds.

Two other men have been killed and six seriously injured in shootings in Leeds in the past two months; one of these latter was Mr Bryan, who in March had been put under police guard after being wounded in the back and stomach.

Yesterday Detective Chief Superintendent Grahame Bullock, who is leading the murder inquiry, denied that the streets of the city were descending into lawlessness. On Monday the chairman of the Police Federation told its conference in Brighton that parts of London, Manchester, Liverpool and Leeds were no go areas because of violence and a lack of police presence.

"We are not in the middle of anarchy on the streets of Leeds," said Mr Bullock. "Sometimes comments like that can be unhelpful.

"We've had a number of targeted attacks on known individuals - that doesn't suggest anarchy to me."

Detectives knew Leeds was not the scene of the double shooting, he said, and Manchester would be investigated. He did not rule out drugs playing a role in the murders.

webTitle: Pensions ruling will cost employers dear

fields.headline: Pensions ruling will cost employers dear
fields.trailText: About 60,000 part-time workers yesterday won the right to pension benefits backdated to 1976 in a victory at the European court of justice in Luxembourg which could cost employers between £10bn and £17bn.
fields.body:
About 60,000 part-time workers yesterday won the right to pension benefits backdated to 1976 in a victory at the European court of justice in Luxembourg which could cost employers between £10bn and £17bn.

The ruling means a potential multi-billion pound bill for the government, which is the principal employer involved.

The workers, backed by private and public sector unions, won a ruling in 1994 that excluding part timers, who are mainly women, from pension schemes constituted sex discrimination and a breach of European law on equal pay.

Employers, most of whom denied part timers access to occupational schemes, were forced to let them join, but it was unclear how far back those denied access could claim backdated contributions from employers. Unions fought up to the House of Lords and in the European court to establish 1976 as the date, rather than the two years' backdating allowed under UK equal pay law.

They lost in the industrial tribunal, employment appeal tribunal and court of appeal, but the House of Lords sent the question to Luxembourg for a ruling. Yesterday, the court ruled in 22 test cases, representing 60,000 applicants, that they can date pension scheme membership back to 1976, or when they started working part time if later. Britain at present has 6m part-time employees.

Employers hardest hit by the ruling include banks, the NHS and local education authorities, which all employ large numbers of part-time workers.

Workers whose employers run contributory pension schemes will have to put in the contributions they would have paid had they belonged to the scheme. But those working in some sectors, such as banking, where schemes are non-contributory, will get a large windfall without a contribution.

The National Union of Teachers said a typical teacher with 25 years' service who worked part time for 12 years of that time, retiring on a salary of £24,000, would get £1,800 a year additional pension and an extra £5,400 lump sum.

The NUT's general secretary, Doug McAvoy, said: "The government could have saved a fortune by accepting its responsibilities rather than fighting against women's rights. We have been arguing the case for our members since 1994. At last [part-time] teachers will be able to press their claims."

Many people who would have benefited have died while awaiting resolution of this case, and surviving spouses are extremely unlikely to receive a penny.

The case will now go back to the House of Lords for a decision on how to take the claims forward. The lords will also have to decide whether workers who filed claims more than six months after leaving their job will be able to claim.

Aside from the 60,000, there are hundreds of thousands of others who could benefit. Unions will be pressing the banks and public sector employers to extend the backdating of pension benefits, irrespective of whether a claim was lodged within six months of leaving employment, to all part-time workers since 1976 as a matter of equity.

The ruling means a potential multi-billion pound bill for the government, which is the principal employer involved. The workers, backed by private and public sector unions, won a ruling in 1994 that excluding part timers, who are mainly women, from pension schemes constituted sex discrimination and a breach of European law on equal pay. fields.headline: The mind of the leader
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair is not rattled by drops in his popularity rating. The first term is but a prelude to greater things

New Labour in power: special report

Imagine him standing there at the window, a prime minister gazing out over the roof tops far beyond Downing Street. To his blind eye is a telescope as he says, "Polls? I see no polls". (What Nelson actually said was, "I have a right to be blind sometimes. I really do not see the signal."). Metaphorically, Nelson's telescope hangs by this window for every prime minister and they all use it sooner or later. It might be a sign of admirable single-mindedness, steering full speed ahead for a great Trafalgar. Or it might be a sign of impending doom as used by Mrs Thatcher when the poll tax was sailing full at her - all guns blazing - and she refused to see it coming. Great leadership or the madness of the bunker - how is the leader himself to know the difference? Whether through strength or self-deception, deliberate blindness seems to be Tony Blair's current state of being. Tough it out, no lurching, keep calm.

The third poll in a week has Labour plummeting, now only seven points ahead of the Conservatives who are creeping upwards. He who once had 93% approval now has a statistically insignificant number, more people thinking he's doing a good job than think he is not. Outside, the rabble grows as more dissenting voices from within the party beg him to change course, to trim, to think again on all manner of issues.

Tom Sawyer, one of the architects of New Labour, is only the latest in a growing army of anxious, friendly critics, beseeching and warning. IPPR's Matthew Taylor, Labour's former director of policy, joins the clamour in Prospect: everyone everywhere is whingeing, he notes. And he warns of the Queensland experience, when an attractive Blair clone was leading by 15% but victory was snatched by a clever campaign from the right to "Put Labour Under Pressure". The opposition won, even to the surprise of those who'd voted for them just to give Labour a fright. Could it happen here, he asks?

Tony Blair's big tent is flapping vacantly in the wind. The third way big top that was built to bring all the enemies inside, inclusive, protective, a bit like a gospel preacher's tent on a big salvation drive now looks deserted as the dome. Many of those who once declared themselves born-again New Labour are now (to use Lyndon Johnson's crude reference to skunks), pissing in. The old enemies were first to skulk out of the tent - the rightwing press, far happier back in the pissing party where they belong. Where they lead, some of their readership was always bound to follow. The worry is that no hot enthusiasts remain.

Downing Street has a glib reply to all doubters. Look at Margaret Thatcher, they say. Consider how little she achieved in her first term. All the policies for which she became famous didn't happen until her second - the anti-union laws and the privatisations which she discovered almost by accident. By comparison Blair has achieved far more. A hundred years ago Keir Hardie laid out three main goals - and Blair has done them all already: devolution, the minimum wage and abolition of the hereditaries (almost). Add in all the rest and you have huge NHS spending to come, education already measurably improving, more money for the poor than ever before, taxes higher, while the economy gushes like a fruit machine.

Critics reply that history is a flexible friend in Downing Street's hands. Thatcher was astoundingly brave in her first term, in the midst of appalling recession producing the most radical (if horrible) budget and fighting the most (foolhardy) risky solo war in the Falklands. Where compared with that is Blair's bravery? He's had nothing but luck - a huge majority, untold wealth and dead calm waters. Maybe you make your own weather but his has been better than he can reasonably expect again. In this best of all possible worlds is this as good as it will ever get? If so, it's disappointing. Consider the tragedy of Clinton's third way failure as he leaves office, nothing much done.

The restless natives in the party have a growing list of grievances. Pensions is certainly the loudest cry of pain from the doorsteps of the local elections, arousing folk memories of lone parent benefit cuts. The europhiles despair of Blair's intent on the euro. Industrial heartlands fear for further collapse of jobs. Where is his promise of PR to create a social democratic coalition to keep the Tories out for a century? Women see his foot-dragging on all the work/life balance directives. The liberal intelligentsia is foaming at the mouth - prisons, freedom of information, asylum seekers demonised wickedly as "bogus".

Above all, where are the visible signs of genuine Labour improvements in public services? Still neither NHS or education feel better. Why is public transport worse? Add in whatever else you will to this litany of woe: from Worksop to Islington there are scant good words for him. Even in her darkest hours Margaret Thatcher had her passionate advocates, her loud claque of admirers. From taxi-drivers to weak-kneed aristos with a taste for handbagging, there were always adorers. Wonderful woman! Where are the worshippers crying Wonderful Man?

It's a puzzle that people are quite so cheesed off. Grumbling you expect, but why this great cacophony when things are certainly better than for decades? Number 10 researchers think political times have changed. Volatile voters now want instant political gratification - newer, fresher, faster, cooler, now. The slow pace of politics, of laws, amendments, budgets and implementations no longer satisfy short attention spans and mercurial moods that move as fast as the click of a mouse.

The prime minister remains relaxed, cool even. Maybe he has greater things on his mind: new babies keep things in proportion. He is not rattled, but surprisingly sanguine. No trimming, no u-turns, no blenching. Ignoring the polls, he is not giving an inch. There'll be no gestures to appease the mob, no coins tossed from the window to them, let them eat cake. Or rather, let them wait for their cake. It'll be there. He always said the first term was for groundwork, for a solid economy, prudence and the first steps. The second term is when the real radicalism begins. Wait and see, the manifesto will herald a second term of great ambition. All things will be well, all manner of things - or at least that's the message.

But will they? The polls show victory is no longer a certainty. Is this good leadership, playing bowls with statesmanlike sang-froid while all about him panic? Or is he stubbornly refusing to see the crucial signals that he is getting it all badly wrong? Even his own closest people seem to veer from one view to the other, bombarding him with anxious advice from every side. He may be right, but it would be reassuring to see him bend a bit, to say nothing of admitting the odd mistake: a few small acts of contrition would be welcome. But up there alone on his deck, for now he seems to think leadership demands a steadfast refusal to be blown off course - Captain Bligh or Captain Hornblower according to taste.

webTitle: British jets seconds from disaster at Heathrow

fields.headline: British jets seconds from disaster at Heathrow
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Air accident investigators have been brought in after two British passenger jets came within 30 metres of colliding at Heathrow, it emerged yesterday. It was described as the closest near-miss in the 30 years since jumbo jets began flying to Britain.
fields.body:
Air accident investigators have been brought in after two British passenger jets came within 30 metres of colliding at Heathrow, it emerged yesterday. It was described as the closest near-miss in the 30 years since jumbo jets began flying to Britain.

A crash between the British Airways Boeing 747 and British Midland Airbus 321 was averted only when air traffic controllers realised the jumbo was descending towards the runway where the commuter plane was waiting to take off, and radioed the pilot to take evasive action. He aborted the landing and later landed safely.

Yesterday it was alleged that a controller who was undergoing training had authorised the near-fatal manoeuvres.

Chris Yates, aviation safety and security specialist at Jane's Transport, said that with up to 450 people on board the 747 and just under a hundred on the Airbus, it could have been the biggest aviation accident in British history, rivalling the world's worst disaster in Tenerife in 1977, when 582 people died after two jumbo jets collided.

The Heathrow incident, on April 28, has been deemed so serious that the air accident investigation branch, which normally investigates only crashes, has begun an inquiry. Normally the civil aviation authority would investigate near-misses.

This one has lent weight to the arguments of campaigners against the government's plan partly to privatise air traffic control services. "This is a clear demonstration of just why we must not move towards any form of privatisation," Gwyneth Dunwoody, MP for Crewe and Nantwich and one of 46 Labour MPs who last week voted against the plan, said last night.

Martin Salter, MP for Reading West and a fellow rebel, said the incident highlighted "just what a life and death service is provided by air traffic controllers. This is the last service we should be destabilising."

Full details will not emerge until the AAIB's report is published in a few months, but the near-miss occurred in murky conditions at 3.06pm as British Midland flight BD151, carrying 89 passengers and seven crew, waited on a runway to take off for Brussels.

The plane, running 26 minutes late, had been cleared by air traffic control, which deals with 1,340 takeoffs and landings each day at Heathrow. British Airways flight BA006 from Tokyo, which had already circled the runway once and was flying low because of the weather, had also been given clearance to land.

An industry source said last night: "We believe the controller was a trainee. It would appear that the Airbus didn't take off quite as fast as was expected. They were very close indeed - just seconds away from disaster."

A Heathrow pilot speculated that the near-miss was "a simple air traffic control cock-up: they forgot the Airbus was waiting at the start of the runway". He said the airport was using both runways because the murky weather meant planes coming in to land had to fly farther apart and so were running out of fuel. "The nub of the problem is runway capacity. There simply isn't enough, and with controllers working at full throttle, mistakes are going to be made."

Iain Findlay, aviation officer at the Institution of Professionals, Managers and Specialists, the union that represents 3,500 air traffic controllers and believes privatisation will compromise safety, said controllers handled a record 1.9m flights in 1999, up 7% on the previous year. There was little margin for error. "Controllers are the buffer between commercial pressures and safety, and any further pressure on [them] would be going too far."

webTitle: Minister pledges support for cash-hit post offices

fields.headline: Minister pledges support for cash-hit post offices
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is planning to pour cash into inner city and rural post offices to protect them from the impact of a huge loss of revenue caused by the automation of benefit payments.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is planning to pour cash into inner city and rural post offices to protect them from the impact of a huge loss of revenue caused by the automation of benefit payments.

The post office minister, Alan Johnson, yesterday outlined the main findings of a report on the network by the No 10 performance and innovation unit, which includes a plan to turn the post office into a universal bank, aimed at the estimated 4m people without bank accounts.

Hundreds of post office branches close each year as they lose custom. Many rural and inner city post offices rely heavily on benefit cash payments for revenue. All benefit payments, including pensions, are due to be automated by 2005.

Mr Johnson said the No 10 report would also propose that post offices could become places for many customers to order and pay for goods over the internet, and collect orders. He also held out the possibility of post offices becoming the central point to apply for government services.

He added: "In urban deprived areas post offices play a special role, especially when there are few other shops around. We are considering ways to provide special assistance for their outlets which would allow them to improve the quality of both the post office and the retail sides of their business."

fields.headline: Accountable cops
fields.standfirst:
The police should stop investigating themselves. An independent body would be the best way forward

Macpherson report - one year on: special report
Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: Today the government unveil proposals to change the way complaints against police officers are handled. We hope that for the first time we will see proposals to set up an independent body to investigate such complaints.
fields.body:
Today the government unveil proposals to change the way complaints against police officers are handled. We hope that for the first time we will see proposals to set up an independent body to investigate such complaints.

For years there has been concern about lack of independence in the system. The police hold a unique position, with powers to interfere in the lives of the public, and responsibilities to act independently to uphold the law. Inevitably at times this places them in positions of conflict, and will lead to complaints, including allegations of criminal conduct.

Accountability is vital both for public confidence and for the effectiveness of policing, so that the police can be seen to be subject to fair and open scrutiny.

If citizens are to have confidence in the police service as a whole, they must feel that when they complain about individual instances of police misconduct their allegations will be investigated thoroughly and impartially.

The key to achieving this is a complaints system which can demonstrate independence and openness at every stage.

The history of the complaints system in England and Wales is littered with attempts at reform. We have been waiting too long. As early as 1929 there were proposals for independent investigation.

The 60s, the 70s and the 80s all saw inquiries set up where independent investigation was considered, but on each occasion proposals were rejected in favour of compromise solutions. These compromises have not stood the test of time.

The current system includes independent supervision by the police complaints authority of police investigations in some of the most serious cases. It was set up after the recommendation for independent investigation by the Scarman inquiry into the riots in the 80s. But concerns have continued. There have been a series of high profile cases where there has been criticism of police "investigating themselves".

Liberty has long held that the rights of the public and police officers can be properly protected only by a truly independent system, including independent investigation. In fact this has also been the position of the police federation since 1981 and even police management, the association of chief police officers, are likely to support a practical and workable model.

Most recently the reports of the Commons home affairs committee and the Lawrence inquiry recognised that there is now widespread support for the introduction of independent investigation.

Sir William Macpherson in the Lawrence report stated: "Investigations of police officers by their own or another police service is widely regarded as unjust, and does not inspire public confidence."

Over a year ago, therefore, the government commissioned a feasibility study into the practicality of a mechanism for independent investigation of police complaints, by consultants KPMG. It is to be published today alongside an independent report by Liberty.

Because complainants are not happy with the complaints system more and more of them are seeking to sue the police in the civil courts and more and more of them are winning substantial damages. A better complaints system would result in fewer legal cases.

Ironically in those civil actions the statements taken by the police where there has been a previous complaint are revealed. Unfortunately the evidence is then that all too often the investigation of police by other police officers is not as robust as it should be.

We also know that there is a problem with the system because, despite successful civil actions against police officers in the courts, few officers suffer disciplinary sanctions as a result.

Although the police complaints authority has an "independent" role in supervising investigations in serious cases, they are reliant on police officers doing the investigations and taking the statements.

This does not work and the members of the PCA have too little time to carry out detailed supervision of every single case.

We need an independent body that does the investigation itself. This would help to root out malpractice in the police more effectively. There would be other advantages of course. People who think they have been badly treated by the police are much less likely to accept their complaint being dismissed if the investigation was carried out by another police officer. But complainants are much more likely to accept this if the complaint was independently investigated.

The system would have advantages for the police too. No police officer, having been "cleared" following a complaint, wants the public to believe that he or she "got away with it" because a colleague investigated the case.

The problem with allowing the police to investigate themselves is clear. What we need now is an alternative model. After Liberty and KPMG publish their proposals today, it is the responsibility of Jack Straw, the home secretary, to make sure a new body is set up now rather than waiting for the next scandal to occur.

John Wadham is director of Liberty.

Over a year ago, therefore, the government commissioned a feasibility study into the practicality of a mechanism for independent investigation of police complaints, by consultants KPMG. It is to be published today alongside an independent report by Liberty. Because complainants are not happy with the complaints system more and more of them are seeking to sue the police in the civil courts and more and more of them are winning substantial damages. A better complaints system would result in fewer legal cases. Ironically in those civil actions the statements taken by the police where there has been a previous complaint are revealed. Unfortunately the evidence is then that all too often the investigation of police by other police officers is not as robust as it should be. We also know that there is a problem with the system because, despite successful civil actions against police officers in the courts, few officers suffer disciplinary sanctions as a result. Although the police complaints authority has an "independent" role in supervising investigations in serious cases, they are reliant on police officers doing the investigations and taking the statements. This does not work and the members of the PCA have too little time to carry out detailed supervision of every single case. We need an independent body that does the investigation itself. This would help to root out malpractice in the police more effectively. There would be other advantages of course. People who think they have been badly treated by the police are much less likely to accept their complaint being dismissed if the investigation was carried out by another police officer. But complainants are much more likely to accept this if the complaint was independently investigated. The system would have advantages for the police too. No police officer, having been "cleared" following a complaint, wants the public to believe that he or she "got away with it" because a colleague investigated the case. The problem with allowing the police to investigate themselves is clear. What we need now is an alternative model. After Liberty and KPMG publish their proposals today, it is the responsibility of Jack Straw, the home secretary, to make sure a new body is set up now rather than waiting for the next scandal to occur. John Wadham is director of Liberty. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Tougher Hague silencing Tory whisperers
fields.standfirst:
Central office treats talk of a Conservative recovery with caution. But MPs on right and left of the party have taken heart at recent events

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague surprised a group of "wet" Tories at Westminster this week when he confided to them that he will never win the next general election if he limits himself to the sort of rightwing speeches he has recently made on asylum seekers and crime.
fields.body:
William Hague surprised a group of "wet" Tories at Westminster this week when he confided to them that he will never win the next general election if he limits himself to the sort of rightwing speeches he has recently made on asylum seekers and crime.

In an attempt to allay the concerns of one nation Tories, who fear a relentless lurch to the right, Mr Hague told the group that he appreciated the need to appeal to a much broader base if the Conservatives are to stand any chance in the general election.

MPs at the meeting said Mr Hague still stood by every word of his recent provocative interventions on asylum and on crime which were widely criticised in the run-up to the local elections. Mr Hague will return to the law and order theme tomorrow when he calls for the abolition of the "double jeopardy" rule, seen as one of the cornerstones of British justice, which means a defendant cannot be tried twice for the same crime.

But the wets were heartened to hear that Mr Hague will now try to position himself on the centre ground by speaking about his commitment to Britain's public services, saying that, as a comprehensive boy, he is better placed to talk about state education than the prime minister. Mr Hague also surprised the wets by pointing out that he relies entirely on the NHS and has no private health insurance.

Mr Hague's briefing came amid signs that the relentless whispering campaign against him in Tory circles may be ending. MPs on the left of the party, who have been exasperated by his hardline stance on Europe, and MPs on the right, who have been critical of his failure to unsettle the prime minister, are saying that Mr Hague is at last establishing his credentials. The Hague camp hopes that critics have been silenced by the Tories' impres sive showing in the local elections, when the party regained just under 600 seats, and by the Conservatives' stronger showing in recent opinion polls.

Tory strategists are treating the poll figures with caution, a sensible position given the humiliation of losing one of their safest seats in the Romsey byelection on the same night.Despite such gloomy signs, Central Office believes that the overall outlook is encouraging, thanks to a carefully planned four-point strategy launched by Mr Hague after he became Tory leader nearly three years ago.

In the first stage, Mr Hague attempted to distance the party from the sleaze of the Major years by implementing huge internal reforms. Mr Hague believes he has done well here, although his dependence on Michael Ashcroft as party treasurer and his slowness in blocking Jeffrey Archer's mayoral bid count against him.

Within a year of taking over as leader, Mr Hague launched the second stage when he held a party-wide ballot to endorse his hardline stance on the euro, which he won. By positioning himself so adamantly against the euro, he placed himself in a strong position in last year's European elections when the Tories beat Labour into second place. Although there was a derisory turn-out, his victory served as a personal boost.

Buoyed up by his victory, Mr Hague embarked on the third phase at last year's Tory conference when he launched his Common Sense Revolution, with initiatives such as the tax guarantee, in which he pledged to reduce taxes as a proportion of GDP. The fourth phase of the Hague strategy, in which he was meant to "roll out" the Common Sense Revolution in a series of speeches, came badly unstuck in the autumn. Jeffrey Archer's downfall, closely followed by Shaun Woodward's defection to Labour, diverted Central Office. As the party entered the new millennium, the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, overturned the party's opposition to the minimum wage and appeared to question the tax guarantee.

It is only in the past few months that Mr Hague has found his stride again, dominating the political agenda with his asylum and crime speeches. However, one senior Tory source insisted that there was no room for complacency. "We are under no illusions about the task facing us because our defeat in 1997 was the worst the party has suffered since 1832. It was like having an army where half your troops are killed and then you have to face an army which is more than twice as big. We are therefore doing well now that people are beginning to think there is an outside chance that William could be the next prime minister."

Mr Hague will be encouraged that former critics on the backbenches believe he is at last making a mark. One former minister, a Portillo admirer, said: "There is evidence that something is happening out there in the undergrowth. William has discovered that if you take a robust line people will listen." One wet said he believed that Mr Hague has broken through a "psychological barrier".

However, he still does not command his party in the style of Tony Blair. This was brought home last night when Tory rightwinger, David Davis, rounded on Mr Hague's plans to abolish the "double jeopardy" rule, saying that such a move would be a "body blow for justice". Mr Hague will find it difficult to shake off such criticism. "If Davis is complaining about civil liberties, something must be up," one wag said.

webTitle: Negative speeches foster cynicism, claims Labour

fields.headline: Negative speeches foster cynicism, claims Labour
fields.standfirst:
ICM rating shows Hague as unpopular as ever

Tories in opposition: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The cabinet last night unleashed a personal attack on William Hague for deliberately fostering public "cynicism" about politics just as this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll confirmed that voters still see the Conservative leader as an electoral liability to his party.
fields.body:
The cabinet last night unleashed a personal attack on William Hague for deliberately fostering public "cynicism" about politics just as this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll confirmed that voters still see the Conservative leader as an electoral liability to his party.

Although the gap between Labour and the Tories slipped to 7% last month - the narrowest lead since the election - and Tony Blair's rating has slumped in the past year from +34 points to +1, the prime minister is still a long way ahead of the Conservative leader.

This month's ICM survey shows that only 35% of voters believe Mr Hague is doing a good job, while 46% are dissatisfied, giving him a net rating of -11 points compared with -10 points he recorded in a similar poll in January.

This shows that despite high profile speeches on asylum and law and order Mr Hague has made little progress personally in the affections of the electorate in the past five months.

Labour is determined to capitalise on these doubts. Downing Street last night gave official blessing to a hard-hitting speech today by Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons.

She will directly accuse Mr Hague of cynicism in seeking to persuade voters that none of the improvments in their lives reflect any credit on governments. "Everyone says William Hague is opportunistic and has poor short-term judgment, but he does more harm to the country than to the Conservative party. I have come to the conclusion that what he does is not accidental, but is cynical," Mrs Beckett said last night.

This week's Guardian/ ICM poll confirms ICM's recent private polling for the Tories themselves that the Conservatives are making some modest progress in the eyes of the electorate.

When voters were asked when they thought the Conservatives would be returned to power the proportion saying they will get back in at the next election has doubled from the 10% recorded in the immediate aftermath of the 1997 Labour landslide to 20% now.

There has been little change among the 41% of voters believe the Tories will get back in at the general election after next, but those who believe it will take at least three general elections before they return to power has more than halved from 31% in 1997 to 14% now.

This shift in the perception of the Conservatives' chances of re-election give some perspective to Labour's falling poll lead. Although a lead of only seven points sounds vulnerable it is clear that the overwhelming majority of voters firmly believe that Labour will win the next general election.

The issue on which Mr Hague plans his biggest election campaign gamble, the single European currency, still shows all the signs of running in his favour.

The ICM monthly tracking question, asking how people would vote if a referendum were held tomorrow on whether Britain should join the euro, shows 60% would be against (down 3); 27% would vote to join (unchanged) and 14% said they did not know (up 3).

The slight rise in the don't knows suggests that the impact of a high pound on the British car industry has at the least raised doubts in some voters' minds about the cost of staying out of the euro.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,003 adults aged over 18 by telephone on May 13-15. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.
