fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Pregnancy case doctor cleared
fields.body:
Pregnancy case doctor cleared
A doctor who failed to spot a 15-year-old's pregnancy, which led to her death, was yesterday cleared of serious professional misconduct by the General Medical Council. Barbara Thomas did not carry out pregnancy tests on the Welsh teenager, who went from 8st to 12st 6lbs before her death after a stillbirth in December 1995.

Jury split over child 'cruelty'
The jury in the trial of a nursery owner accused of cruelty to children in her care was discharged at Merthyr Tydfil crown court in south Wales yesterday after failing to reach a verdict. Margaret Price, 58, had denied 13 charges of ill-treating children at her Playtime Nursery in Brecon. She was cleared on one cruelty charge. Geoffrey Gibbs

Lottery winner in court
A lottery winner charged in connection with the seizure by customs of 21.3m cigarettes was bailed until August 15 by Rotherham magistrates yesterday. Rossiano Rossi, 34, of Barnsley, South Yorkshire, was one of 11 men arrested in Operation Camelot, a national campaign against tobacco smuggling. He won £1.96m three years ago.

Tenth drug user dies in Glasgow
An unknown illness among Glasgow drug users has claimed its 10th victim after a man died in hospital yesterday. There have been 20 known cases with a number of addicts still being treated in hospital. The outbreak began just over two weeks ago. Press Association

GPs urge NHS ageism inquiry
More than three in four GPs say elderly people face health care rationing, a survey has suggested, and almost two-thirds support a call by the charity Age Concern for an inquiry into ageism in the NHS. David Brindle

fields.headline: Brothers to test coroner's powers
fields.trailText: Two brothers who only found out that their mother had died after a postmortem examination had been carried out will ask the high court in London today for a judicial review of the coroner's powers.
fields.body:
Two brothers who only found out that their mother had died after a postmortem examination had been carried out will ask the high court in London today for a judicial review of the coroner's powers.

Neither John nor Jeremy Holtom were contacted by the GP, the police nor the coroner to tell them of their mother's death, they say.

They found out three days later, when John Holtom went to his mother's flat in Oxford to find out why she had not been answering phone calls.

Jeremy Holtom said that his brother had feared the worst, but was not prepared for what he discovered when he arrived at the flat.

"He found the flat had been broken into. There was no note on the door with a number to contact. He had no idea whether she had been in an accident or been burgled or was dead. Eventually he went to the next door neighbour, who broke the news to him.

"He then set about trying to find out what had happened. Nobody seemed to know or care. Eventually someone at the police station was helpful and he found out about the postmortem."

The brothers are angry that a postmortem was carried out on their mother, a staunch orthodox Jew who would have opposed such a thing, they say. They believe there was no need for a postmortem, because their 67 year-old mother, Jane Holtom, had a medical history which made her death from a heart attack unsurprising - she was overweight and had late-onset diabetes and heart disease.

They find it hard to understand why nobody tried to contact them in the three days between her death on Friday December 3 and the postmortem at 8.30am on Monday morning. "I was on holiday, but if they had contacted my office they would have been given a number and my brother was available," said Jeremy Holtom, a businessman living in Northamptonshire.

"When my brother eventually got into my mother's flat, he found her address book lying by the phone. It was open at the page with her family's numbers and addresses on it. Nobody bothered enough to read it."

Their application for a judicial review today centres on the discretionary power of the coroner, who must decide whether a postmortem is necessary, and on the human rights convention which guarantees respect for family life.

The brothers' case has been taken on by a prominent human rights barrister, Danny Friedman. It will be argued the coroner should ensure the family is informed of a death.

webTitle: Threat to Sierra Leone hostages splits UN

fields.headline: Threat to Sierra Leone hostages splits UN
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report

Human Rights Watch: Sierra Leone
UN Mission in Sierra Leone
Sierra Leone - MoD site
fields.trailText: There is growing political pressure on British commanders in Sierra Leone to rein in the military assault against the Revolutionary United Front because of new threats against almost 500 UN peacekeepers held hostage by the rebels or semi-hostage by the president of neighbouring Liberia.
fields.body:
There is growing political pressure on British commanders in Sierra Leone to rein in the military assault against the Revolutionary United Front because of new threats against almost 500 UN peacekeepers held hostage by the rebels or semi-hostage by the president of neighbouring Liberia.

Concern over the fate of the abductees has heightened following reports that some of the 124 UN personnel released by the rebels into Liberia at the weekend were badly tortured and in "a terrible state".

The Liberian president, Charles Taylor, has admitted that 30 or 40 of the hostages have bullet wounds. He has so far blocked UN officials from meeting them and warned that the war against the RUF must be halted or it could harm the remaining abducted UN personnel.

Mr Taylor, the RUF's principal foreign backer, has also confined 15 former hostages - including the only Briton among the 124 - to a hotel for the past three days.

The fate of the hostages has led to a split within the UN in Sierra Leone, with its military commander in Freetown backing the assault against the rebels while Kofi Annan's special representative is pressing for a ceasefire. The Freetown government is strongly opposed to any let-up in the war.

Mr Taylor's warning came as the British officer coordinating the campaign against the rebels, Brigadier David Richards, claimed that the Sierra Leone Army (SLA) is making headway.

"We have definitely got over the worst of it in Freetown. The RUF is pulling back to Makeni. It's quite a rap on the knuckles for them. If there's one change to the plan it's that the SLA is doing better than we expected. We want it to keep pushing eastwards, without pausing," he said.

Brig Richards disowned a report on the BBC Today programme that claimed he had said UN forces are to go on the offensive against rebels. Peacekeepers will instead be used to hold areas already taken by the SLA.

"What I've got the UN to do is move up and fill the gaps behind the Sierra Leone army. The UN was a bit iffy about that but I persuaded them. The key to success now, my priority, is to get the SLA to keep going and keep fighting," he added.

But there are problems. Frontline government troops have been short of food, although Brig Richards says that problem is being addressed. The question of ammunition is more sensitive. The chief of Britain's defence staff, General Sir Charles Guthrie, who was in Freetown earlier this week, is returning home with a list of requirements for Sierra Leonean forces, including ammunition and possibly guns.

Whether they are supplied is a political decision, and there is concern that British weapons could fall into rebel hands if the tide of war turns.

The SLA and the UN are heavily reliant on the British in matters of strategy and logistics. A British officer is now running the Sierra Leone defence headquarters.

But Brig Richards says the various parties, including the UN and military factions now united to fight for the government, are at one on the need to take the war to the RUF's heartland.

The real test will come in the next few weeks as government forces launch an assault on the diamond areas that provide the rebels' financial lifeline. Russian helicopter gunships will back up the attack.

Charles Taylor's attempts to curb the SLA offensive are, in part, a bid to forestall an attack on the diamond mines, which have also proved profitable for the Liberian president.

The British army has also been trying to mend relations with the Nigerian military after one of its senior commanders warned that his men might shoot white troops.

Brig Richards described the incident as a "little local difficulty" at the international airport where the British took over responsibility for security for the Nigerians.

"One British soldier was told by a Nigerian soldier 'if you don't tell us what you are doing you will end up getting shot'. I'm confident this is a non-problem. It was not 'we will shoot you'," he said. "We have told the Nigerians what we are doing but it had not got down to the soldier level.".

But the Nigerian officer who made the remark, Lieutenant Colonel Ginda Usman, said the members of the Parachute Regiment had humiliated his men by detaining and disarming them on suspicion of being rebels. "They [the British] sometimes deployed right behind our positions and some of my soldiers were disarmed by them," Lt Col Ginda said.

"They said RUF rebels had captured UN uniforms and they couldn't be sure if my men were rebels in stolen uniforms. The paras even used to check me at the airport and I'm the commanding officer.

"I pointed out that there are white mercenaries working for the RUF and if we didn't know who you were then we could mistake them for mercenaries. And what do we do to mercenaries? We shoot them."

The British can ill afford to annoy the Nigerians. Their 3,000 troops are the largest contingent in the peacekeeping force.

More importantly, they have considerable experience of fighting in Sierra Leone and detest the RUF for atrocities it has committed against captured Nigerians.

Peacekeepers will instead be used to hold areas already taken by the SLA. "What I've got the UN to do is move up and fill the gaps behind the Sierra Leone army. The UN was a bit iffy about that but I persuaded them. The key to success now, my priority, is to get the SLA to keep going and keep fighting," he added. But there are problems. Frontline government troops have been short of food, although Brig Richards says that problem is being addressed. The question of ammunition is more sensitive. The chief of Britain's defence staff, General Sir Charles Guthrie, who was in Freetown earlier this week, is returning home with a list of requirements for Sierra Leonean forces, including ammunition and possibly guns. Whether they are supplied is a political decision, and there is concern that British weapons could fall into rebel hands if the tide of war turns. The SLA and the UN are heavily reliant on the British in matters of strategy and logistics. A British officer is now running the Sierra Leone defence headquarters. But Brig Richards says the various parties, including the UN and military factions now united to fight for the government, are at one on the need to take the war to the RUF's heartland. The real test will come in the next few weeks as government forces launch an assault on the diamond areas that provide the rebels' financial lifeline. Russian helicopter gunships will back up the attack. Charles Taylor's attempts to curb the SLA offensive are, in part, a bid to forestall an attack on the diamond mines, which have also proved profitable for the Liberian president. The British army has also been trying to mend relations with the Nigerian military after one of its senior commanders warned that his men might shoot white troops. Brig Richards described the incident as a "little local difficulty" at the international airport where the British took over responsibility for security for the Nigerians. "One British soldier was told by a Nigerian soldier 'if you don't tell us what you are doing you will end up getting shot'. I'm confident this is a non-problem. It was not 'we will shoot you'," he said. "We have told the Nigerians what we are doing but it had not got down to the soldier level.". But the Nigerian officer who made the remark, Lieutenant Colonel Ginda Usman, said the members of the Parachute Regiment had humiliated his men by detaining and disarming them on suspicion of being rebels. "They [the British] sometimes deployed right behind our positions and some of my soldiers were disarmed by them," Lt Col Ginda said. "They said RUF rebels had captured UN uniforms and they couldn't be sure if my men were rebels in stolen uniforms. The paras even used to check me at the airport and I'm the commanding officer. "I pointed out that there are white mercenaries working for the RUF and if we didn't know who you were then we could mistake them for mercenaries. And what do we do to mercenaries? We shoot them." The British can ill afford to annoy the Nigerians. Their 3,000 troops are the largest contingent in the peacekeeping force. More importantly, they have considerable experience of fighting in Sierra Leone and detest the RUF for atrocities it has committed against captured Nigerians.

webTitle: 40 monitors to be sent to election in Zimbabwe

fields.headline: 40 monitors to be sent to election in Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The Commonwealth secretary-general promised yesterday to send more than 40 observers to monitor next month's parliamentary election in Zimbabwe.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum in Harare and Ewen Macaskill
fields.body:
The Commonwealth secretary-general promised yesterday to send more than 40 observers to monitor next month's parliamentary election in Zimbabwe.

Amid concern over delays to the long-awaited report from the country's electoral boundary commission, Don McKinnon said: "I believe it's possible to have free elections here".

Despite the fact that 20 opposition supporters have been killed by supporters of the ruling Zanu-PF party, he said he believed there could be free and fair elections on June 24 and 25.

"President Mugabe gave his assurances that he would like to see a de-escalation of the political violence," said Mr McKinnon, adding: "We would like to see the violence go down."

Mr Mugabe cancelled his meeting with Mr McKinnon on Monday, then made him wait for hours yesterday.

John Makumbe, a political science lecturer at the University of Zimbabwe, said 40 is a significant number for the Commonwealth because it often sends just 20 monitors.

Mr Makumbe said 15,000 Zimbabwean monitors are being trained, but in several cases war veterans and Zanu-PF youths have beaten people attending the training.

Harare has been flooded with people from rural areas who are fleeing beatings and killings from members of the Zanu-PF and war veterans.

fields.headline: One we made earlier
fields.standfirst: The Clangers, Bagpuss, Ivor the Engine. Why are we all buying videos of the television shows we remember from our childhood? It's because the old ones really are the best, says  Nicholas Barber
fields.trailText: The Clangers, Bagpuss, Ivor the Engine. Why are we all buying videos of the television shows we remember from our childhood?
fields.body:
If you went to university between the mid-80s and early 90s, you may sometimes wonder what undergraduates ever talked about before children's television was invented. From my experience, a whole generation of stand-up comedians and student union drunks would have been silent if they hadn't had cartoons and puppetry for the under-10s to fuel their reminiscing.

And now this very generation is being encouraged to revisit the programmes that helped it through Freshers' Week. Children's videos are being sold to adults. One company, Kult Kidz, has even adopted a knowing slogan for the stickers on its video boxes: "Relive Your Wasted Youth".

"Kult Kidz is all about children's programming firmly aimed at adults", says Andrew Wishart, the product manager. Their first release was Bod in 1998. "Initially we thought that parents were buying it for their kids", says Wishart. "But from the number we sell through places like Virgin and HMV we can tell that actually they're self-purchases. We sell them for £4.99, so people will go in to get the latest Farscape video and then pick up Hector's House as an impulse buy."

The company's packaging is becoming more adult-orientated accordingly. Fingerbobs, says the box, "practically coined the term minimal chic with its pared-to-the-bone production values". Crystal Tipps And Alistair's Yellow Submarine-ish visuals were "seemingly created in a psychedelic haze.

The classic designs of Hilary Hayton are now ultra-hip - this is real flower-power and influenced an entire generation of children to be groovy, man." Earlier this year Kult Kidz manufactured its first DVD, a depiction of "a highly patriarchal society... a textbook model of the type of family that the Conservative Family Campaign is trying to recreate in Britain". The Flumps, of course.

It's shrewd marketing: retro children's TV videos, not just the Kult Kidz' ones, are ideal for post-pub and post-club viewing. The Clangers and Ivor The Engine will have you conducting entire conversations in whistling and "pssh-de-coof" noises, while Mr Benn's need for a frequent fix of out-of-body travel is open to interpretation.

Roobarb is the most fast-moving and funny of the bunch, especially once you spot how similar Custard the Cat's voice is to Ken Livingstone's. And for full-on what-the-Hell-was-that-about psychedelia, there is no substitute for Bod - hypnotic stuff from John Le Mesurier's nonchalant narration and Derek Griffiths' beatnik music to Bod's weird resemblance to the alien creature in Area 51. Maybe Kult Kidz should rearrange their slogan to "Relive Your Youth, Wasted".

On the other hand, there is something slightly condescending about the insistence that these programmes are "kult" and "ultra-hip" and "groovy". Some of them are wonderful creations: to turn them into kitsch icons is to degrade series which no adult should need a smirking, postmodern excuse to watch.

Generation X may not have much world-class culture to call its own, but at least we can say we were there for the golden age of animated British children's television, the late 1960s and early 1970s. Any youth spent watching it wasn't wasted.

For a start, these programmes were national events. They were broadcast in the brief period when every household had a television, but when there were only three channels on it. Before VCRs, before computers and Playstations, a couple of hours of children's TV after primary school was a ritual. As for the programmes, they were made before Star Wars turned so much of children's entertainment into extended merchandising commercials.

George Lucas is probably responsible, too, for opening the 1980s market for swords and heavy artillery. He-Man and Thundercats tried to preach peace and friendship while attracting children with images of humungously-muscled men stabbing each other.

Apart from the rather pedagogic Mary, Mungo And Midge ("Careful of the fire, Midge, you might get burned"), the golden age programmes give off not a whiff of a focus group or a committee. To quote Kult Kidz' blurb, in Bod "simple charm blends with the theatre of the absurd and strongly surreal elements underpin the classic characters". By the 1980s, Willo The Wisp's wackiness seemed a tad too deliberate compared to the childlike unself-conscious creativity of the liberal decade before.

The golden age was a transitional phase between the years when adults would sit in chairs and read out stories to the camera and the years when cartoons took over. Each series still had a narrator, and the visuals were the idiosyncratic work of one or two people rather than a studio of animators.

The masters of the craft were Oliver Postgate and Peter Firmin, makers of Bagpuss. This multi-media extravaganza topped a BBC poll as the most popular children's TV programme ever, and Postgate and Firmin also created Ivor The Engine and The Clangers - which other kids' script would ever mention a "calm, serene orb, sailing majestically among the myriad stars of the firmament"?

Irony has got nothing to do with it. Firmin's paintings and models were things of beauty, Postgate's stories were gently whimsical and unpatronising.

But you wouldn't sell many videos to adults if you put a review like that on the box.

Kult Kidz website is at: www.kult-kidz.co.uk

fields.headline: Court Circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Well, it's a welcome return to this column for old-school favourite Bobby Brown, sometime r 'n' b star and spouse of the hapless Whitney Houston (herself the subject of recent tabloid tittle-tattle over her alleged recreational activities).
fields.body:
Well, it's a welcome return to this column for old-school favourite Bobby Brown , sometime r 'n' b star and spouse of the hapless Whitney Houston (herself the subject of recent tabloid tittle-tattle over her alleged recreational activities).

To wit, it seems the long arm of the law is only getting longer, with Brown being picked up at Newark Airport late last week for a probation violation dating back to summer 1998. It is, as you might imagine, a long story: having been convicted of drink-driving back in '96 - after crashing Whitney's Porsche - the lascivious trouper then fouled up on the terms of his release two years later when traces of cocaine were discovered in a urine sample.

With the original charge having only been a misdemeanour, prosecutors unsurprisingly failed to go after a warrant for Brown's arrest, only to pounce (for no discernible reason) as he returned from a holiday in the Bahamas last Thursday. Denied bail, the errant vocalist can be found sitting in Broward County Jail, Fort Lauderdale until next Monday, at which point he faces a preliminary trial hearing.

Meanwhile, Drew Barrymore 's famously singular mother Jaid has also been entertaining the cops of late, getting herself nicked in downtown Manhattan over the weekend on an illegal firearms rap.

The details, sadly enough, saw the elder Barrymore being interrupted by the NYPD as she stood on a Manhattan street flyposting for a rock band at 2am on Saturday morning. But things only got worse when a subsequent search of her handbag yielded a loaded and unlicensed .357 Magnum.

Booked for weapons possession and criminal mischief, she was later released on bail pending a court appearance in late July. All of which is unlikely to endear her to her estranged daughter, still - predictably - put out by mom attempting to auction her old baby clothes on the internet last summer.

fields.headline: Stars 'demanding up to $30m a film'
fields.standfirst:
Veteran actor Gregory Peck recalls simpler times in the movies and warns cash hungry players to focus on producing quality pictures

www.filmunlimited.co.uk
fields.trailText: Film stars are now demanding as much as $30m (£19.9m) a movie, one of Hollywood's most influential agents revealed last night.
fields.body:
Film stars are now demanding as much as $30m (£19.9m) a movie, one of Hollywood's most influential agents revealed last night.

Jim Wiatt of the William Morris agency, which represents most of the box office "bankers" such as Leonardo DiCaprio, Bruce Willis and John Travolta, disclosed that several stars are now demanding fees of $25m a movie plus perks amounting to $5m.

Until recently, for instance, Travolta would only agree to do blockbusters if a private Lear Jet was put at his disposal, fuelled and ready for take-off 24 hours a day.

He has since bought his own Boeing 707. Even Kim Basinger - who is not the draw she once was - demands $100,000 for her personal hairdresser. Most have entourages which also have to be paid for.

Wiatt, speaking at a conference at the Cannes film festival, said, however, most stars were prepared to take a cut in pay for the right script, like Jim Carrey did recently for Man on the Moon.

Uma Thurman - who can command at least $15m a movie - admitted she did the new Merchant Ivory film, the Golden Bowl, which was premiered at Cannes, for less than $1m.

Wiatt denied that agents like him were to blame for the greed, but Amir Malin, of Mel Gibson's company, Artisan, warned that if fees continued to spiral at least one of the big Hollywood studio could go under.

Their comments came as Nick Nolte, who was himself one of the big action movie earners until the mid-1990s, condemned the star system and urged actors to use their power to make sure the public saw better films. "The star system sucks," he declared in Cannes at the weekend.

"The big studios have boiled Hollywood down to four male leads ... it's not creative. They get the stars before they get a script."

As if to prove the point that talent will always win out over special effects, Gregory Peck put younger stars to shame when he was mobbed at the festival yesterday.

Peck, 84, who is mesmerising in the new Barbara Kopple documentary Conversation, charmed the festival's most crowded press conference with his wit, wisdom and an hour of cracking good yarns.

Asked if it was morally correct for actors to be paid $30m a movie, he replied: "All I can say is I was born too soon." But Peck, the most venerated liberal in Hollywood who has always defended workers' rights, had a warning for actors who chased big pay days.

"It is not the fame but the work that matters in the long term," he said. "All the rest will be forgotten. In my case there's a few good pictures and my family to look back on."

Reminiscing about a movie career which started in 1944, he said the part he most identified with was Atticus Finch, the lawyer in To Kill A Mocking Bird who defends a black man wrongly accused of raping a white woman in the Deep South during the depression, for which he won a best actor Oscar in 1963.

Peck's daughter, Cecilia, who worked on the documentary, confirmed that "Atticus was the nearest character to the real him. Like every family, we have occasional disagreements ... but he is a very rare human being, a noble spirit, with a huge open heart."

"Is that all?" joked Peck, who was quite embarrassed at being portrayed as a "superman".

Peck also recalled Hollywood in the 1950s when he whistled as he drove to work. He said Ava Gardner turned heads on the set every morning and Elizabeth Taylor - who is due in Cannes tomorrow for a party for her Aids charity - went to work with a chipmunk on her shoulder. He also revealed how he nearly died when he was cast adrift in the Irish Sea on an 85ft rubber whale while filming Moby Dick.

Peck, who was playing Captain Ahab in John Huston's 1956 classic, said he feared for his life when the weather turned and he went "into a fog bank riding this huge rubber whale piercing him with my harpoon and cursing him. It got very choppy, and I felt if I slipped into the water I was a goner.

"I didn't know which way to swim. Should I swim towards Ireland or Wales, the south pole or the north pole? I was completely disorientated so I began to shout 'Ahoy there!' and 'Help'. Eventually the camera boat found me and I was glad to slide off that rubber whale."

Meanwhile, the action sequences in the new Ang Lee film, the martial arts movie Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon - a world way from his recent Jane Austen adaptation, were greeted with gasps and applause from critics, a rarity in Cannes.

The new Darren Aronofsky film, Requiem For A Dream, which is about various forms of drug addiction, also went down well with the critics.

Useful links:
 www.festival-cannes.fr/

webTitle: Hoorah for Bollywood as Birmingham gets multiplex screens dedicated to Indian films

fields.headline: Hoorah for Bollywood as Birmingham gets multiplex screens dedicated to Indian films
fields.trailText: Warner Village is to become the first big cinema chain in Britain to cater for the Bollywood market by dedicating screens in a Birmingham multiplex that opens in July.
fields.body:
Warner Village is to become the first big cinema chain in Britain to cater for the Bollywood market by dedicating screens in a Birmingham multiplex that opens in July.

Ralf Ludemann of Warner Village said yesterday that six out of 30 screens would show exclusively Indian-made films. His company was able to do this only because of a clampdown on pirated videos of Bollywood films, he said. "Until bodies like the Federation Against Copyright Theft toughened up on piracy recently, it was not feasible for multiplexes to compete with smuggled videos.

"Without the videos, there are fewer avenues to see these films, so people will come to the Warner Village."

Bollywood is the popular term for the film industry based in the city of Bombay which makes 600 films a year, worth £750m worldwide. The UK is Bollywood's biggest export market, but audiences of the three-hour musicals have been restricted to videos, satellite TV or independent cinemas. There is one eight-screen Asian cinema in Birmingham's centre that seats 1,000, and another cinema in nearby Smethwick. But multiplex chains only occasionally hold screenings in places such as Wolverhampton, Leicester or Bolton.

Warner Village said the Birmingham screens would be marketed specifically among the Asian community. In inner city Birmingham 70% of the population is black or Asian, and in the city as a whole there are more black and Asian under-18s than there are white under-18s.

Mr Ludemann said: "It's hard to tell if white audiences will come to the films on the back of mainstream hits like East is East.

"Bollywood films are subtitled and very long, with at least six dance intervals. But, if there is a demand, we will increase the number of Bollywood screens."

Inderjit Dehal is director of the Birmingham Race Action Project,which campaigns for institutional change in the city. He said the multiplex was important for Asians.

"Birmingham will be Britain's first black city, but its infrastructure has stagnated, and blacks and Asians are sidelined from many leisure activities. This type of commercial initiative should set an example for a better ethnic balance in other areas like health and education."

Raj Kaushal, editor of Snoop, an Asian monthly specialising in Bollywood, said the screens were good news if there was a sustainable market. "Last year at least three Bollywood films entered the UK top 10.

"I'm all for Bollywood entering the mainstream, but it is tedious when fickle commercial ventures jump on the 'Asian cool' bandwagon.

"Next week the new thing could be 'Japanese cool'."

Ralf Ludemann of Warner Village said yesterday that six out of 30 screens would show exclusively Indian-made films. His company was able to do this only because of a clampdown on pirated videos of Bollywood films, he said. "Until bodies like the Federation Against Copyright Theft toughened up on piracy recently, it was not feasible for multiplexes to compete with smuggled videos. "Without the videos, there are fewer avenues to see these films, so people will come to the Warner Village." Bollywood is the popular term for the film industry based in the city of Bombay which makes 600 films a year, worth £750m worldwide. The UK is Bollywood's biggest export market, but audiences of the three-hour musicals have been restricted to videos, satellite TV or independent cinemas. There is one eight-screen Asian cinema in Birmingham's centre that seats 1,000, and another cinema in nearby Smethwick. But multiplex chains only occasionally hold screenings in places such as Wolverhampton, Leicester or Bolton. Warner Village said the Birmingham screens would be marketed specifically among the Asian community. In inner city Birmingham 70% of the population is black or Asian, and in the city as a whole there are more black and Asian under-18s than there are white under-18s. Mr Ludemann said: "It's hard to tell if white audiences will come to the films on the back of mainstream hits like East is East. "Bollywood films are subtitled and very long, with at least six dance intervals. But, if there is a demand, we will increase the number of Bollywood screens." Inderjit Dehal is director of the Birmingham Race Action Project,which campaigns for institutional change in the city. He said the multiplex was important for Asians. "Birmingham will be Britain's first black city, but its infrastructure has stagnated, and blacks and Asians are sidelined from many leisure activities. This type of commercial initiative should set an example for a better ethnic balance in other areas like health and education." Raj Kaushal, editor of Snoop, an Asian monthly specialising in Bollywood, said the screens were good news if there was a sustainable market. "Last year at least three Bollywood films entered the UK top 10. "I'm all for Bollywood entering the mainstream, but it is tedious when fickle commercial ventures jump on the 'Asian cool' bandwagon. "Next week the new thing could be 'Japanese cool'."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The whole of Radio 3's evening is devoted to Organ Night, lasting for five hours from 6.55pm.
fields.body:
The whole of Radio 3's evening is devoted to Organ Night, lasting for five hours from 6.55pm. The programme includes live relays of Gillian Weir playing an all-Bach programme in Copenhagen, Olivier Latry offering a French 19th-century repertoire from Truro Cathedral, and David Goode performing a specially commissioned piece by Francis Grier at Christ Church, Oxford. The recitals are interspersed with discussions about the instrument and the challenge it now faces from digital alternatives.

It's one of life's oddities that most coronaries happen in the morning, while severe asthma tends to strike at night, a phenomenon now under study by chronobiologists. As Peter Evans explains in Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4), years of research paid off in 1997 with the location of a gene to control the bio-rhythms of everything from blue-green algae to humans. Now scientists are investigating whether, if our internal clocks are reset, we may offset some of the more dangerous side effects.

fields.headline: Diary Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: Not for the first time, mystery enshrouds the activities of Jesus's friend Jonathan Aitken, whom the Express has revealed stashed £508,000 (from the sale of a house) in a Monaco bank to avoid paying his creditors, including us (and you should see the state of this place, we really could use the money).
fields.body:
Not for the first time, mystery enshrouds the activities of Jesus's friend Jonathan Aitken, whom the Express has revealed stashed £508,000 (from the sale of a house) in a Monaco bank to avoid paying his creditors, including us (and you should see the state of this place, we really could use the money). Just when we all began to believe that he'd changed ... Well, it's very hard to take, that's all I can say, upon my soul it is. What is so confusing is that just when he needs all the religion he can get, Jonathan seems not to be honouring a commitment he gave last year, in a bankruptcy proceeding, that he would spend January to September of this year at Wycliffe Hall, Oxford, preparing for his BA course in theology starting in October. When we call the college, no one will say if he is there. But if he's not there, where is he ... and what is the crooked swine up to now? Very odd. Very odd indeed.

The Independent reserves a chunk of its front page (a space normally reserved for news in most papers) for revelations that the six lead actors in Friends are to be paid $750,000 per episode in the next series of the smug New York sitcom. The one baffling element here is why the story didn't have the word "exclusive" above the headline. Simple modesty, I guess. Whether or not this was because other papers ran it on Monday is beside the point.

Would you Adam and Eve it? According to our ICM poll yesterday, my old friend Mandy Mandelson is the third most popular minister. Trailing only our most beloved Mo Mowlam and, curiously, Margaret Beckett, Mandy is 14 times more popular than Mr Tony, and seven times better liked than weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown. Leading psephologists such as Professor Anthony King source the genesis of this miraculous turnaround directly to two events - the night he invited himself to dinner at my house, and the day this column broke the story of Bobby, the Andrex puppy. You hardly need to be a genius to work out whose pulling the strings on the image front here. Let us just hope that Mandy remembers this when the first invitations to Chevening go out soon after the next election.

The annual conference of the Communications Workers Union begins on June 4, but the unsettling news is that the standing orders committee is indulging in some heavy-handed censorship. The committee has ruled out various conference motions this year, but the most scandalously disallowed of all came from the Norwich and Cambridge clerical branch. The branch's instruction to the incoming telecoms and financial services executive that "fraternising socially with senior BT management is not big and is not clever" has been ruled inadmissible, we gather, because of its lack of a clear instruction. Very New Labour. Very Millbank.

The time always comes to bid farewell to even the fondest of friends, and today it's a poignant goodbye and God bless to www.ruthgledhill.com, inaugural Web Site of the Month. We have learnt so much about the Times's religion correspondent ... her talent for dancing; her relationship not only to Basil Rathbone but also Celtic king St Caedwalladr, Joseph of Aramathea and Adam; how her "burgeoning assets" popped out at her 16th birthday party; and so much more. While the site never became quite the pan-global cult we hoped, the number of visitors shot up from 7055 to 8401. We wish Ruth well, and will be popping back from time to time.

Home Office minister Charles Clarke tries so hard - perhaps too hard - to impress. In a written reply recorded by the Hansard of May 10, Mr Clarke points out that Nato is an acronym for Northern American Treaty Organisation. Thank you, Charles, but I think that's something we've all known for a very long time.

fields.headline: Cannes review
fields.standfirst:
Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
****
Director: Ang Lee
fields.trailText: If you're not familiar with the pace, grace and elegance of the best of the chop-socky movies, you're likely to be knocked out by Ang Lee's first effort in the genre. It looks a treat, has star performers who know exactly what they are doing and fight sequences that make you gasp and laugh at the same time. There is an occasional tongue-in-cheek quality that never descends into parody, and only the slightly excessive two-hour length (which actually makes it short in relation to this year's Cannes competition) slightly spoils full enjoyment.
fields.body:
If you're not familiar with the pace, grace and elegance of the best of the chop-socky movies, you're likely to be knocked out by Ang Lee's first effort in the genre. It looks a treat, has star performers who know exactly what they are doing and fight sequences that make you gasp and laugh at the same time. There is an occasional tongue-in-cheek quality that never descends into parody, and only the slightly excessive two-hour length (which actually makes it short in relation to this year's Cannes competition) slightly spoils full enjoyment.

Set during the Ching dynasty - and thus a period piece, where costumes and decor matter, and even the scenery becomes important - the film tells its melodramatic story with all the cliches intact, as if Ang Lee were determined to do as well by the genre as he did by Jane Austen in Sense and Sensibility. In other words, he respects the source material while twisting it a little way here and there to allow us to see it in a fresh light.

The story, for instance, is audacious in that it chiefly concerns two women, both dab hands at the fight game. One of them has given up her constrained aristo lifestyle for crime; the other falls in love with a bandit after affirming that justice and honour are all that matter. They are, of course, sisters under the skin, and their destinies lead them to the usual climactic showdown.

Made in China but bankrolled by Warner Brothers, the film gives Ang Lee the chance to let his hair down in a big way after The Ice Storm and Ride With the Devil. But it's not easy to mix it in a genre that requires technique of the highest order. So the film's success is a distinct feather in his cap.

Chow Yun-Fat, Michelle Yeoh, Zheng Pei-Pei and Zhang Zi-Yi are the principals, and you can't do much better than that.

Useful Links:

 www.festival-cannes.fr/
 www.filmunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • An article headed Cutting through the myths, Society, page 9, May 3, dealing with the subject of self-harm, should not have been published in the form in which it appeared. The author of the piece had told the Guardian of concerns expressed about the article but her message unfortunately was overlooked and not acted upon. Furthermore, Equinox and Tulip have asked us to say that they did not approve or authorise publication of the article. The Guardian regrets any distress the publication of the article has caused.
fields.body:

The author of the piece had told the Guardian of concerns expressed about the article but her message unfortunately was overlooked and not acted upon. fields.headline: Poor, poor, pitiful me
fields.standfirst: Warren Zevon has all the makings of a rock legend. His father was a gambler, he used to be an alcoholic, and he wrote beautiful songs about drugs and death. So why has he been through such a tough patch?
fields.trailText: So your new album's all about old age and disease, then? Warren Zevon waits several moments before replying. "I think it has more to do with death," he decides, in his gravelly baritone. " 'Timor mortis conturbat me.' You know that poem?"
fields.body:
So your new album's all about old age and disease, then? Warren Zevon waits several moments before replying. "I think it has more to do with death," he decides, in his gravelly baritone. " 'Timor mortis conturbat me.' You know that poem?"

Er, no.

Zevon gives a ferocious leer, flashing two rows of evenly spaced, impossibly white teeth. Just because he doesn't sell many records these days, that doesn't mean he can't afford deluxe California-style dental care.

"It's a medieval Scottish poem by William Dunbar. It means, 'The fear of death just fucks me up.' " His face creases up and he emits a deep, leathery laugh.

Warren Zevon's latest album is called Life'll Kill Ya, and it's a record he didn't expect to make. After the blistering career-best brilliance of his 1987 disc Sentimental Hygiene, Zevon spent the 90s subsiding gradually into a quicksand of popular indifference. It didn't matter that 1991's Mr Bad Example was beyond the wildest dreams of the average singer-songwriter, nor that 1995's Mutineer, though not a masterpiece, deserved far better promotion than it got. Logic led Zevon to the conclusion that he was, to all intents and purposes, retired.

He concocted his latest batch of songs without a recording contract, and feeling no particular urge to find one. He made up his own demo tapes to play in his car. "Jackson Browne and I were having dinner and driving around Santa Monica and I was playing him the new songs, and he asked me what I was going to do. When I told him I had no idea, he suggested calling Danny Goldberg - he's known not to be allergic to artists over 30 or 40 or 50."

Goldberg, something of a rockbiz legend in his own right and Nirvana's former manager, heard Zevon's tapes and promptly offered him a deal with his new record label, Artemis. It seemed churlish to refuse. Somewhat to his bemusement, the 53-year-old songwriter found that his career had spluttered into life again.

Life'll Kill Ya is a fine addition to the Zevon canon, all the better for its stripped down and frequently acoustic arrangements. In the past, Zevon has occasionally been guilty of LA sludge-rock bluster, but these songs flash back to the rough simplicity of his original inspiration, Bob Dylan. Despite the morbid tone of the title tune, or I Was In The House When The House Burned Down, and the terror of medical crises that palpitates through My Shit's Fucked Up or Don't Let Us Get Sick, Zevon's black, ironic delivery manages to suggest that there are still a few more twists left in these tales. His unexpected cover of Steve Winwood's Back In The High Life Again suggests both the painful transience of fame and Zevon's indifference to it.

But doesn't he get angry that people don't buy his records? "Uhhh, not really," he answers. "I wish they'd buy a few more - it would help in many ways. Doesn't seem to be much I can do about it. But I love it when the cult kind of artists say, 'Well, I could change to sell records.' This from, like, a 58-year-old man. 'Yeah, I know how to make a commercial record, but I won't.' " Zevon roars with malicious laughter. "Like they ever knew how in the first place. Or if anybody knows how."

It's disorientating to recall the rocket-assisted ascent of Zevon's career in the mid-70s, when he became the toast of the West Coast with his albums Warren Zevon and Excitable Boy. The cream of the Los Angeles session-man elite queued up to work with him, and Linda Ronstadt covered his songs Poor Poor Pitiful Me and Hasten Down the Wind. Zevon was signed to David Geffen's Asylum label, the centre of California soft rock, and even had a hit single with the deranged Werewolves of London.

Geffen founded Asylum as a tasteful boutique label and once boasted that he never wanted to sign more artists than could fit into the sauna in his home. "I was never in David Geffen's sauna," says Zevon firmly. "Geffen wasn't particularly hands-on with my career. He was gracious enough. You'd play him a new song and he'd encourage you, but I'm not a great intermingler. It's not an accident that I'm a solo performer at the age of 53. I'm a deeply anti-social person. So the fact that I've had a few sustaining friendships over the fullness of time is the anomaly, not the rule. And remember, I was also dead drunk for 27 years, so although I had a sauna, I wasn't in as many saunas as some."

Yet he was rubbing shoulders with some of the biggest acts of the era. A more calculating artist would undoubtedly have hustled his way into multi-platinum heaven alongside them.

"I remember Glenn Frey from the Eagles calling me, and he said, 'You got a shitload of those songs like Hasten Down the Wind?' I thought I would have, and then Linda Ronstadt covered it, and it was a good time. But I didn't know all those people as well as popular myth would have you believe. I knew Jackson Browne and John David Souther better than anybody."

A hard drinker who drank even harder when he was hired as musical director to the Everly Brothers in the early 70s, Zevon was sucked into alcoholism. He later detailed his rehab experiences in his song Detox Mansion.

Zevon has always viewed the world more as a film-maker or crime novelist would (several of his eclectic circle of friends are writers, and, as Jackson Browne puts it, Zevon "is the first exponent of song noir"), and the role of drunken loner sat well with the caustic observations of his writing.

To his disgust, the Philadelphia Enquirer once described him as "the Woodstock Liberace", presumably having overlooked the drugs, death and decapitated mercenaries that rampage through his songs. The fact that his father was a gangster and a gambler adds more fuel to the Zevon psychodrama. "My father was a wonderful guy," says Zevon. "But I can't imagine him going to a therapist, which is the premise of that TV series The Sopranos. A gangster at the therapist? I don't think so." He leans forward menacingly. "Sensitive gangster? Just a little oxymoronic, I think."

Yet having dragged himself free of addiction (he looks startlingly bronzed and fit) he can detect no difference in his approach to songwriting. "It's exactly the same," he rumbles. "Writing a new song is like making a little movie or something. There has to be some kind of deal, and the deal is I get the idea, I hear it in the air and I say, OK, that's gonna be my next song. Am I gonna have to go on location? Will I have to shave my head? How am I gonna make enough sense out of this song to write it?

"I don't like talking about it I'm ashamed to say this, but I even declined to speak at my daughter's college about this. I don't want to take it apart. I think it's a journalist's thing sometimes. They want to take the mechanical sculpture apart and see which way the spring is wound. And I don't know."

Zevon obviously takes little interest in the fleeting picture-show of pop. "As Penderecki, the Polish modernist composer who writes spectacular two-hour requiems, said, 'I'm in the fine art business.' That's what I say." And we should encourage him to keep saying it.

 Life'll Kill Ya is on Artemis Records. Warren Zevon plays Shepherds Bush Empire, London W12 (020-7771 2000), on Friday.

Geffen founded Asylum as a tasteful boutique label and once boasted that he never wanted to sign more artists than could fit into the sauna in his home. "I was never in David Geffen's sauna," says Zevon firmly. "Geffen wasn't particularly hands-on with my career. He was gracious enough. You'd play him a new song and he'd encourage you, but I'm not a great intermingler. It's not an accident that I'm a solo performer at the age of 53. I'm a deeply anti-social person. So the fact that I've had a few sustaining friendships over the fullness of time is the anomaly, not the rule. And remember, I was also dead drunk for 27 years, so although I had a sauna, I wasn't in as many saunas as some." Yet he was rubbing shoulders with some of the biggest acts of the era. A more calculating artist would undoubtedly have hustled his way into multi-platinum heaven alongside them. "I remember Glenn Frey from the Eagles calling me, and he said, 'You got a shitload of those songs like Hasten Down the Wind?' I thought I would have, and then Linda Ronstadt covered it, and it was a good time. But I didn't know all those people as well as popular myth would have you believe. I knew Jackson Browne and John David Souther better than anybody." A hard drinker who drank even harder when he was hired as musical director to the Everly Brothers in the early 70s, Zevon was sucked into alcoholism. He later detailed his rehab experiences in his song Detox Mansion. Zevon has always viewed the world more as a film-maker or crime novelist would (several of his eclectic circle of friends are writers, and, as Jackson Browne puts it, Zevon "is the first exponent of song noir"), and the role of drunken loner sat well with the caustic observations of his writing. To his disgust, the Philadelphia Enquirer once described him as "the Woodstock Liberace", presumably having overlooked the drugs, death and decapitated mercenaries that rampage through his songs. The fact that his father was a gangster and a gambler adds more fuel to the Zevon psychodrama. "My father was a wonderful guy," says Zevon. "But I can't imagine him going to a therapist, which is the premise of that TV series The Sopranos. A gangster at the therapist? I don't think so." He leans forward menacingly. "Sensitive gangster? Just a little oxymoronic, I think." Yet having dragged himself free of addiction (he looks startlingly bronzed and fit) he can detect no difference in his approach to songwriting. "It's exactly the same," he rumbles. "Writing a new song is like making a little movie or something. There has to be some kind of deal, and the deal is I get the idea, I hear it in the air and I say, OK, that's gonna be my next song. Am I gonna have to go on location? Will I have to shave my head? How am I gonna make enough sense out of this song to write it? "I don't like talking about it I'm ashamed to say this, but I even declined to speak at my daughter's college about this. I don't want to take it apart. I think it's a journalist's thing sometimes. They want to take the mechanical sculpture apart and see which way the spring is wound. And I don't know." Zevon obviously takes little interest in the fleeting picture-show of pop. "As Penderecki, the Polish modernist composer who writes spectacular two-hour requiems, said, 'I'm in the fine art business.' That's what I say." And we should encourage him to keep saying it.  Life'll Kill Ya is on Artemis Records. Warren Zevon plays Shepherds Bush Empire, London W12 (020-7771 2000), on Friday.

fields.headline: All about my mother
fields.standfirst: Frank McGuiness won a Tony for his translation of A Doll's House.  But now he is back with a new play of his own.
fields.trailText: I first clapped eyes on Frank McGuinness at the Gate Theatre in Dublin. He was hard to ignore. A reeling bulk of red hair, he was collapsing in instalments towards the bar. There were bits of yesterday's dinner still in his beard and his mickey was taking the air through the gaping front of his raggedy trousers. Even manky drunk, he had a certain odd decorum about him, and a curious vulnerability that reminded me of Bert Lahr, the lion in The Wizard of Oz.
fields.body:
I first clapped eyes on Frank McGuinness at the Gate Theatre in Dublin. He was hard to ignore. A reeling bulk of red hair, he was collapsing in instalments towards the bar. There were bits of yesterday's dinner still in his beard and his mickey was taking the air through the gaping front of his raggedy trousers. Even manky drunk, he had a certain odd decorum about him, and a curious vulnerability that reminded me of Bert Lahr, the lion in The Wizard of Oz.

There are lots of stories about McGuinness. The drink, the tears, the awkward passes, the jokes, and the turn of phrase that can stop traffic. He isn't fearful of failure. He went out on a limb with his 1989 play Lizzie and Mary, based on the illiterate Irish sisters Engels kept as lovers. With Mutabilitie - which transplanted a gay Shakespeare to Ireland to spar with the imperialist Edmund Spenser - he watched a play "12 years in the brooding" die from over-ambition. These were mad risks for a writer accustomed to praise for Baglady, the hostage drama Someone Who'll Watch Over Me and a host of masterly translations, including A Doll's House, which won him a Tony award when it appeared on Broadway starring Janet McTeer.

McGuinness is 50 this year and, having done battle with the "great, scarifying European classics", is ready to strike out again into the unknown on his own. "Working on Ibsen, Chekhov and Strindberg teaches you how to write. Ibsen was a fecking Viking. You have to be fearless, to juggle with alligators, and to do that you have to master your skill so you can go places where you haven't a clue where you'll end up."

The fraught relations between Ireland and England are often in his work. McGuinness decommissioned minds with Observe the Sons of Ulster Marching Towards the Somme, the most dazzling piece about men preparing to die you are ever likely to see. His sexuality is also central to his work, though you won't often hear that in Ireland. In Carthaginians, he gave Ireland her first openly gay hero in Dido Martin, while Innocence, his Caravaggio play, dared to slander a Catholic church then busy covering up the child abusers in its ranks.

It can't have been easy growing up in Buncrana, a small seaside town in beautiful but backward Donegal hard by the border with Derry. "Let's just say I kept my head down,' McGuinness says. "All I thought about was doing well enough for that grant to university." There was no other way out: his father was a breadman and his mother worked in the shirt factories. TV, rock music and Dusty Springfield kept him sane.

He went to school in an old cinema, a far-flung outpost of the same church school that produced two Nobel prize winners in Seamus Heaney and John Hume, and where Brian Friel and Seamus Deane were also "taught lessons in fear," as McGuinness puts it. The priests, however, have been coy about claiming him. "It is not a role that I would want. They don't really talk about me, and I don't talk about them, and I admire them for their reticence." There's venom in his words. "We'll say nothing." What Frank won't say is that the local clergy got their revenge for his "filthy" Caravaggio by slighting him at his mother's funeral.

We'll say nothing about his wardrobe either. There are tramps in Dublin who make it a point of pride to be better turned out than Frank McGuinness. Today, though, he is wearing a shockingly stylish coat: it must be the influence of Kate Moss, whom he met through his friend and "guiding star" Marianne Faithfull.

We are on a windswept Buncrana beach, where his new play, Dolly West's Kitchen, is set. It is raining, and he is striding into the gale, sucking a cigarette to death and expounding on why he wanted to put "everything but bestiality" into the script. Which is a surprise, because Dolly West's Kitchen is a lyrical homecoming piece, not dissimilar to the kind done so well by Brian Friel, who lives down the road, and whose fictional Ballybeg ("small town" in Irish) hovers in the hills above Buncrana. Gentle Ireland, Friel's early take on homosexuality, was the first play McGuinness saw and it was obviously an influence. Not that Friel went in much for Irish mammies bringing beautiful transvestite American GIs home for tea to meet their sons.

Nor has Friel ever created a character like Rima, the earthy matriarch who sets her world to rights in the strangest of ways before she dies. When she goes, you feel bereaved. "I meant that to happen," says McGuinness. "I wanted the audience to feel they had been cast into oblivion. Because you are. I may as well admit it, Rima is my mother. Let me tell you, she took no prisoners." McGuinness lost both his parents within a short space of time a few years ago. "It was a devastating experience. Every first night I would ring and she would calm me by telling me that it was only a play. They were proud of what I did but they were afraid of it as well. They came to the first few plays but after that they thought I could manage on my own. She had a much more realistic view of writing than I ever had. In a way they would have liked it if I had been more like Daniel O'Donnell [a camp country and Irish star who has a strange effect on Irishwomen of a certain age]. In another way, they would have killed me if I was."

Dolly West's Kitchen is about acceptance and a paean to a mother who practised it. Like McGuinness's wonderful first play, Factory Girls, it is also a love letter to his home town. When I ask him why Buncrana doesn't seem keen to claim him, he goes very quiet. I ask him again a few minutes later. "It's not that kind of town," he says, angry with me for goading. And then I remember what he had said the previous night about writing every play he had ever written in a Buncrana accent. "I slept every night of my life till I was 18 in Buncrana. When I left, it was like going into exile. I couldn't go through that again."

 Dolly West's Kitchen opens at the Old Vic, London SE1 (020-7369 1722), tonight.

fields.headline: The hills are alive
fields.standfirst: For its latest trick, Glasgow company NVA is going to bring the Himalayas to the Highlands.
fields.trailText: Can you keep a secret? In more ways than one, that is the question being posed this week by Glasgow-based arts company NVA. Firstly, the location for their new, typically ambitious project, The Path, is shrouded in mystery and may remain so even after the event. This is a night-time happening on a giddily grand scale, with access by shuttle bus only. The 5,000 visitors NVA hopes to attract over three weeks may never know quite where they have been or what exactly they have seen. The event is unclassifiable, with music, lighting, performance and art set against dramatic surroundings.
fields.body:
Can you keep a secret? In more ways than one, that is the question being posed this week by Glasgow-based arts company NVA. Firstly, the location for their new, typically ambitious project, The Path, is shrouded in mystery and may remain so even after the event. This is a night-time happening on a giddily grand scale, with access by shuttle bus only. The 5,000 visitors NVA hopes to attract over three weeks may never know quite where they have been or what exactly they have seen. The event is unclassifiable, with music, lighting, performance and art set against dramatic surroundings.

When I visit the site to meet Angus Farquhar, the creative force behind NVA, I'm asked not to pass on details of the location (and I won't, except to say it is deep in Perthshire's glorious countryside). Rather romantically, the area has no mobile phone coverage.

In 1998, NVA presented The Secret Sign, a spectacular twilight "environmental animation" of a river gorge near Loch Lomond. "At the end," explains Farquhar as we stroll the old peat path that will form the two-hour walk, "I realised we had achieved something special - a new, heartfelt way of exploring our relationship with nature."

Two years on, The Path is to be a millennial celebration of a classic Scottish Highland landscape, the horseshoe-shaped route rising 1,500ft and passing rock-falls, ancient trees and a flowing burn with deep pools.

Farquhar is adamant that The Path isn't simply a homage to West of Scotland traditions. Its focus comes not from the local culture, or even from Farquhar's urbanite understanding of the Highlands (NVA evolved from Test Department, known for interventions in derelict city spaces). Instead, he says, the event will attempt an "elemental comparison", with one of the world's other great highland cultures, the Himalayas. NVA has brought singers and sherpas from Nepal for a Buddhist perspective on the Perthshire landscape.

For all its huge scale, The Path is a deeply personal project, reflecting Farquhar's passion for climbing and his interest in Buddhism following a life-changing trek in Nepal. He points out that "Nepal is still an 85% rural community, whereas our indigenous rural culture has largely been destroyed. And in the Himalayas, people have a completely different relationship to the mountains: there are no roads, only paths - you walk everywhere, and life expectancy is short. There is poverty and lack of education, but they do have a living faith in Buddhism, whereas in the west, we practise periscope religion - it only pops up when someone gets married or dies."

NVA could be accused of a periscopic flirtation with Buddhism. There is a strong suggestion that you should walk The Path alone - as though this is some path to self-knowledge - and it is hard not to smile indulgently at the little details that slip out: there will be "exquisite mantras", sacred cairns, "helping hands" and singing bowls in concert. But going into the hills at night, with lighting designed to sculpt the already imposing landscape, should knock any cynicism out of visitors. "There is a spiritual quest underpinning my involvement," says Farquhar, "but you're not press-ganged into a particular response. On the mountain in the dark, you're in a heightened state - your senses come alive. This is profoundly experiential work, propelling yourself up and down hills at night." And then, after all the propelling, keeping it a secret.

The Path will take place in a glen in Perthshire from Friday to 4 June (except Mondays).
Further details: 0141-204 3346 or www.nva.org.uk.
Tickets can be booked on 0115-912 9246/01786 461081.

fields.headline: Yesterday bad day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Labour MP Bob Blizzard, who won a battle to avoid paying his former secretary £1,071 for 129 hours overtime. A court ruled Mr Blizzard need not pay up because Sheena Fisher submitted her claim more than a year after resigning from her £11,000 job at the backbencher's Lowestoft office. Ms Fisher said she would never trust a politician again.

Bad day

An inquiry was launched into how a convicted Northern Irish loyalist terrorist was allowed to work as a contractor at the Welsh assembly building in Cardiff. The man, jailed in the 1980s for posessing firearms and explosives, was part of a team installing a new air conditioning system. The building was sealed off for 48 hours and searched.

Today

Commons: Northern Ireland questions. PM's questions. Lords: Debate on law and order.

fields.headline: Ethiopia-Eritrea arms ban call
fields.trailText: The United States and Britain were last night pushing for a United Nations arms embargo on Ethiopia and Eritrea in response to the renewed outbreak of war between the two east African neighbours.
fields.body:
The United States and Britain were last night pushing for a United Nations arms embargo on Ethiopia and Eritrea in response to the renewed outbreak of war between the two east African neighbours.

The move at the security council was opposed by Russia and China, but the two western allies were engaged in horsetrading to persuade them to abstain rather than vote against an embargo.

"We think we can get this," a source close to America and Britain said.

Ethiopia restarted the border conflict with its former ally by invading Eritrea last Friday, overrunning first world war-style trenches across a wide front. Casualties were heavy.

The Ethiopians claimed to have punched a hole in the front at Mereb-Setit. Eritrea disputed this and claimed to have shot down two planes. But both sides accepted that there had been heavy losses - one Eritrean spokesman described the battleground as like a "massacre site".

The Eritrean government was scathing about the US-British initiative, dismissing it as limp. A spokesman said: "We don't expect anything of the United Nations any more. They are following a policy of appeasement."

Russia described the sanctions as premature, given that hostilities had only broken out last Friday, and said an oppor tunity should first be given for a resumption of negotiations.

A vote on the US-British resolution was not expected until today at the earliest.

The deputy US ambassador, Nancy Soderberg, said an arms embargo should be imposed regardless of whether the fighting stopped, because "we hope to degrade their ability to carry on this war".

The draft resolution also sets out to punish the Ethiopian leadership, but not the Eritreans, by imposing a ban on visas to prevent them travelling abroad. The only exception would be for travel to peace talks.

fields.headline: Working on the future
fields.trailText: I read with interest the article by John Gray and Fernando Flores (A wing and a prayer, May 16) based on yet another report, Entrepreneurship and the Wired Life, proclaiming that the career is now dead. Entertainment value high, factual basis zero.
fields.body:
I read with interest the article by John Gray and Fernando Flores (A wing and a prayer, May 16) based on yet another report, Entrepreneurship and the Wired Life, proclaiming that the career is now dead. Entertainment value high, factual basis zero.

As the TUC's own recent report Future of Work showed, permanent employee jobs remain the bedrock of the UK labour market - over 80% of all those in work. This figure has not changed significantly since the mid-1980s. Nor has the average length of time people spend in a job changed much.

The US labour market, which some see as a predictor of tomorrow's labour market, has even more people in permanent employee jobs than the UK - and fewer people working as self-employed or in small firms.

The new forms of employment beloved of the wired world brigade - portfolio working, homeworking, teleworking - are marginal and likely to remain so for the foreseeable future.

There are important changes going on across all industrialised economies and in the world of work. The nature of careers is changing. But any serious analysis has to be based on facts, rather than assertion. The death of the career is exaggerated.

John Monks General secretary, TUC

 Gray and Flores are mistaken if they think that it is only middle-class people who are affected by the demise of the concept of a career. Many working-class people, like myself, grew up in a world in which jobs, whether in the blue or white collar sectors, were secure, pay was based on the rate for the job, hours were set, and employment conditions were determined by trade unions collectively bargaining with the employers.

All the changes Gray and Flores outline have been imposed upon employees in wide areas of both the private and public sectors. It is, however, sadly typical of our Demos writers that they try to put a gloss on this process by pointing to all the wonderful things our new breed of socially aware entrepreneurs are apparently doing.

Frankly speaking, it is no compensation for employees if their employers are oh so caring about the Amazonian rain forest when at the same time they refuse to recognise unions, and insist upon performance related pay, short term contracts, etc, etc.

Socially aware entrepreneurs are little different from the Victorian sweatshop owner who salved his conscience by putting a few bob in the charity box at Christmas.

Paul Flewers

London

hatchet.job@virgin.net

The US labour market, which some see as a predictor of tomorrow's labour market, has even more people in permanent employee jobs than the UK - and fewer people working as self-employed or in small firms. The new forms of employment beloved of the wired world brigade - portfolio working, homeworking, teleworking - are marginal and likely to remain so for the foreseeable future. There are important changes going on across all industrialised economies and in the world of work. The nature of careers is changing. But any serious analysis has to be based on facts, rather than assertion. The death of the career is exaggerated. John Monks General secretary, TUC  Gray and Flores are mistaken if they think that it is only middle-class people who are affected by the demise of the concept of a career. Many working-class people, like myself, grew up in a world in which jobs, whether in the blue or white collar sectors, were secure, pay was based on the rate for the job, hours were set, and employment conditions were determined by trade unions collectively bargaining with the employers. All the changes Gray and Flores outline have been imposed upon employees in wide areas of both the private and public sectors. It is, however, sadly typical of our Demos writers that they try to put a gloss on this process by pointing to all the wonderful things our new breed of socially aware entrepreneurs are apparently doing. Frankly speaking, it is no compensation for employees if their employers are oh so caring about the Amazonian rain forest when at the same time they refuse to recognise unions, and insist upon performance related pay, short term contracts, etc, etc. Socially aware entrepreneurs are little different from the Victorian sweatshop owner who salved his conscience by putting a few bob in the charity box at Christmas. Paul Flewers London hatchet.job@virgin.net

webTitle: The press watchdog that fails to bite

fields.headline: The press watchdog that fails to bite
fields.trailText: Matt Wells's excellent piece about Piers Morgan's share-buying (It's been a terrible week for newspapers, Media, May 15) goes only part of the way, since it fails to take on board the potential of a DTI investigation. In the same edition, Roy Greenslade tells how a corrosive press stitched up Alastair Campbell and Philip Gould.
fields.body:
Matt Wells's excellent piece about Piers Morgan's share-buying (It's been a terrible week for newspapers, Media, May 15) goes only part of the way, since it fails to take on board the potential of a DTI investigation. In the same edition, Roy Greenslade tells how a corrosive press stitched up Alastair Campbell and Philip Gould.

In your columns the previous week, Jeremy Paxman revealed the sick reporters who make up stories, and this week too we have had the unsatisfactory Press Complaints Commission "adjudication" on the Sunday Times and the buying of Jonathan Aitken's allegedly important-to-the-nation memoirs.

Editors of major newspapers may well despair at the fraught times they have when complaints are lodged against them, but the answer to their difficulties is to get it right in the first place and fire staff who consistently fail to report the truth.

The much vaunted "political" nous of Lord Wakeham is, in my view, counter-productive, especially as I spent some years sitting on the PCC and witnessed its inability to grapple with the heart of the problem - the fact that it has no serious sanctions as a watchdog other than the proverbial slap on the wrist. No wonder our television compatriots complain when they face huge fines for getting it wrong. No wonder nobody wants to change anything and maintain the present cosy code of conduct system.

All that will probably change when European legislation kicks in later this year, and our judges enter the fray. Editors then may well find themselves testing the traditional cry for press freedom to the limits when they face punishments more likely to fit the crime. What the industry refuses to recognise is that the inherent failure of the PCC lies in the fact that many people and organisations who have wholly legitimate grounds for complaining about the press simply refuse to do so - because they believe it is a total waste of time.

Unless that situation is rectified - and the public have a fair and just watchdog they believe in - editors will continue to smile contritely for a day or so. A few sleepless nights are a small price to pay if you can still be free to play havoc with people's private lives and cynically distort the truth.
Gerald Isaaman
London

fields.headline: Use and abuse of porn
fields.trailText: Dare an inveterate heterosexual endorse Peter Tatchell's enthusiastic case (Letters, May 12) for the modern global porn industry, and its superiority to the expensive bother of dating, condoms, STD risks, matrimony, parenthood etc?
fields.body:
Dare an inveterate heterosexual endorse Peter Tatchell's enthusiastic case (Letters, May 12) for the modern global porn industry, and its superiority to the expensive bother of dating, condoms, STD risks, matrimony, parenthood etc?

As someone who started masturbating at nine years of age half a century ago, when this harmless and beneficial activity was reprehended as morally evil, and you had to make do with some "artistic" monochrome photo of Diana Dors' nipples, or Pamela Green's high heels from an old copy of Lilliput, I find it gratifying indeed to see the abundance of fantasies catering for every taste, and giving employment to so many beautiful young females in every conceivable pose .
Alfred Tamer
Edinburgh

• Yes, human beings fantasise and masturbate - and not only those seeking less risky sexual behaviour or the old, ugly and disabled. However, the reality of pornography, as opposed to erotic material, is that it limits and distorts our sexuality and imagination for profit. Perhaps Tatchell should listen to the testimony of the women and children who have been raped or sexually abused and the part pornography played in their abuse.
Joan Skinner
Edinburgh

fields.headline: Jobs column
fields.body:
I just want to say that it was the proudest moment of my journalistic career to find that Hugo Young - whose books I used to read at school! - has consecrated almost an entire column (No rightist could be the right person, May 16) to a meditation on whether I might be a fitting candidate for a job no one has asked me to do, for which I have not applied, and which I have not the slightest interest in doing. Tomorrow in my Telegraph column: Why Hugo Young Must On No Account Succeed Janet Street-Porter At The Independent On Sunday.
Boris Johnson
Editor, The Spectator
