fields.headline: On art's little treasures
fields.trailText: Madeleine Bunting laments the apparent failure of contemporary art to address matters political and economic (No politics, we're Briitsh, May 15). Well, just because it ain't in the Tate Modern doesn't mean it ain't happening. There is much that is happening, political or otherwise, that is not represented there.
fields.body:
Madeleine Bunting laments the apparent failure of contemporary art to address matters political and economic (No politics, we're Briitsh, May 15). Well, just because it ain't in the Tate Modern doesn't mean it ain't happening. There is much that is happening, political or otherwise, that is not represented there.

The new monolithic temple to importance at Bankside, magnificient as it is, merely represents the kind of post-Duchampian correctness of thought now rampant amongst the curatorial elite. A hit parade of cultural cool, it is a partisan, not a comprehensive view.

There are a few of us seeking to address the issues Madeleine Bunting speaks of, but you have to look a little harder, through the fog of self-congratulation and media hype.

John Keane

London

 Hostility towards children as expressed by Luke Tredinnick is unfortunately only too common in this country (Letters, May 16). I've lost count of the places to which I've been where my children - and therefore I - have been made to feel unwelcome, or have been refused admittance.

He asks: "What do you expect them to get from it anyway?" They may not be able to "appreciate" art in the chin-clasping, head-nodding way that he would obviously like to see. But, with parents who help to engage their children, they will learn about shape, form, colour, size, materials, and so on. They will also feel included, and learn how to behave in a socially acceptable way in a shared environment. And, who knows, they may even learn the tolerance of others that seems to have eluded Luke Tredinnick.

Stephen Potter

St Leonards on sea, E Sussex

 As the infantile impulse has long been a source of inspiration in modern art, it seems highly appropriate that those who still have these skills should visit art galleries to see the work of the adults for whom they act as guru.

Christopher Bamford

London

 As the mother of a two-year-old son, I am ashamed to say that I still have the same interests and need for social interaction as I had when childless.

I know that, for some people, it is a crime but I enjoy eating out, checking out the new galleries and mingling with people from all walks of life, childless or otherwise.

I usually don't have any option but to take my son along with me when I go to these forbidden places, as there are precious few neighbours or family members around to take him off my hands while I pretend not to be a parent for a few hours.

I've considered the alternatives, but I've found it rather limiting sitting at home, day in, day out, locked in a mothers' ghetto and enjoying endless conversations about nappy brands and potty training.

My abiding memory of childhood, back in the good old days when children were still seen and not heard, is the feeling that there was an exciting adult world enjoyed by my parents from which my brother and I were completely excluded. I don't want my son to grow up feeling the same way.

Lindsay Wright

London

lindsay.wright@ncvo-vol.org.uk

 Stephen Cox (Letters, May 16) is wrong to decry the lack of baby changing facilities in Tate Modern. If he leaves the soiled nappy in the middle of the gallery floor, Charles Saatchi is bound to snap it up, and next year's Turner prize will be a virtual certainty.

Jon Keen

Hook, Hampshire

jgk@ndirect.co.uk

fields.headline: Seascape with quoits
fields.standfirst: People who cruise mostly enthuse
fields.trailText: Cruising - to judge from figures out yesterday - has become highly popular. Worldwide, it is attracting new millions.
fields.body:
The difference between a transitive and intransitive is all. If you were to cruise Tangier - or Naples or Piraeus for that matter - flesh would probably be your object. If, however, you were to go cruising to one of those Mediterranean ports, flesh (fried or lightly grilled) might be part of the package but the object would more likely be deep draughts of ozone with occasional trips ashore, wining and dining at the captain's table and body shaking in the several on-board discos.

Cruising - to judge from figures out yesterday - has become highly popular. Worldwide, it is attracting new millions. Some 70 new cruise ships are on order, costing £14bn. And still to come is the American sea monster on which - so it is projected - entire families will live, work and take their leisure for months on end.

A type of holiday once reserved for the old, rich and tired is attracting both many more and much more diverse customers. Cruising is increasingly popular among Britons. Holiday sailors are getting younger. Perhaps the growth is a reflection of growing affluence. Most cruisers, so to speak, come from London and the south-east. Of the English regions East Anglia takes fewest cruises: perhaps the sight of boating on the Broads has put them off life on the ocean waves.

Cruising these days is a more active pursuit. The Caribbean remains a favoured destination where, one imagines, shipboard tourists loll by the pool, occasionally stirring to play deck quoits and buy the odd trinket from traders in bumboats. But there has been a notable increase in trips up and down the rivers Nile, Rhine and Danube, the pleasures of which lie mostly on shore in museums, vineyards and concert halls.

It is the Med, though, which attracts most Brits to the poop deck. Either they are moved by some collective memory of Horatio or assured by the fact you cannot sail far across that inland sea without losing sight of land.

fields.headline: Baroness Wharton
fields.standfirst: Animal rights campaigner who fell victim to CJD
fields.trailText: Baroness Wharton, known as "Ziki", who has died of sporadic CJD aged 66, was a photographer and animal lover who became vice- president of the RSPCA in 1997 and joint secretary of the all-party parliamentary group for animal welfare. She was described as a "very lively, bubbly kind of person" and a "brilliant photographer" by fellow photographer Austin Mitchell, the Labour MP who shared with her the chairmanship of the all-party media group.
fields.body:
Baroness Wharton, known as "Ziki", who has died of sporadic CJD aged 66, was a photographer and animal lover who became vice- president of the RSPCA in 1997 and joint secretary of the all-party parliamentary group for animal welfare. She was described as a "very lively, bubbly kind of person" and a "brilliant photographer" by fellow photographer Austin Mitchell, the Labour MP who shared with her the chairmanship of the all-party media group.

Wharton was a crossbench peer who sought, unsuccessfully, to remain in the Lords in their November 1999 election, following the government's constitutional reform that removed hereditaries' voting rights. She had spoken often on animal welfare since 1990, when she revived the family title, which had fallen into abeyance on her mother's death in 1974.

Although the form of CJD from which she died has not been linked to BSE, Wharton spoke about the disease in the May 1991 debate on the hygienic disposal of horses' carcasses, which were being abandoned on wasteground in the wake of the BSE scare.

She also strongly supported Lord (Douglas) Houghton's dog control and welfare bill in 1993, sharply attacking "sub-standard" puppy farms in Wales. She sought to restore discretion to the courts, without which allegedly dangerous dogs were locked up for years on end.

She told their lordships: "I would like to see the sale of pets from shops ended altogether. If one wants a pedigree dog, then why not buy it from a reputable breeder, whose establishment has been checked, or, preferably, from a dogs' home, thereby giving an abandoned dog a chance of a decent life?"

Wharton had a very practical approach to legislation, guessing that she would have been arrested for aggravated offence after the 1991 Dangerous Dogs Act came into effect.

As she told the Lords: "I answered my front door to an extremely unsavoury character, who promptly put his foot inside the door and started to push it open. My dog was lying on the floor behind me. On impulse, I pulled the door wide open and shouted to my dog: 'Get him!' That docile labrador leapt up, chased the man down the drive, caught his leg and tore his trousers. My dog was protecting me. I believed that I was in danger."

In February 1994, Wharton utilised the experience of her other principal interest, photography, to criticise Lord Harmar-Nicholls's harshly-worded bill to curb the activities of the paparazzi. She warned him against imposing too harsh a ban on intrusive photographs, and pressed, instead, for sanctions to be aimed at the publishers of offensive photographs rather than the photographers.

"People in the public eye, be they in the entertainment industry or politicians, are well aware that in public places they are liable to be photographed by professionals and amateurs alike," she said. "They are of interest to the public. That is what much of photo-journalism is about. Indeed, many such people have publicity agents, whose job it is to keep their names and faces before the public.

"Having said that, I agree that some restrictions need to be imposed upon the continual abuse of someone's privacy which, of course, is not in the public interest."

Wharton was the daughter of David George Arbuthnot and Elizabeth Dorothy, the 10th Baroness Wharton. She was educated at the Herschel school for girls in Clarement, Cape Province, South Africa.

"When I lived in South Africa, I felt proud of all things British," she told the Lords in February 1995. "I can still hear 'This is London calling', followed by the chimes of Big Ben. My favourite programme then was Much Binding In The Marsh."

In 1958, Wharton married Henry Macleod Robertson, of Elgin, Morayshire, by whom she had three sons (including twins) and one daughter. Her husband predeceased her; the heir to her title is her son, Myles.

 Myrtle Olive Felix 'Ziki' Robertson, Baroness Wharton, hereditary peer and animal rights campaigner, born February 20 1934; died May 15 2000

fields.headline: Experts try to untangle knotweed
fields.trailText: Scientists are to fly to Japan in search of predators to control a concrete-cracking superweed described as the country's most invasive plant.
fields.body:
Scientists are to fly to Japan in search of predators to control a concrete-cracking superweed described as the country's most invasive plant.

They want to see if biological controls can defeat the Japanese knotweed, which has cost millions of pounds in short-term control measures. Beetles and fungi which control its growth in Japan will be researched in UK quarantine. The Department of the Environment will have the final say on whether the method is used.

The knotweed, which can grow 12ft in as many weeks, was introduced as an ornamental plant in the early 19th century. It pushes through concrete and road surfaces, chokes river banks, invades homes and blights development sites.

South Wales is Britain's blackspot. The battle against the weed is being led by Dick Shaw, a scientist from CABI Bioscience of Ascot, Berkshire. Fourteen organisations, including the environment agency, Railtrack, the National Trust and the Welsh development agency, have joined him in the fight.

fields.headline: Letters:  Joe Kenyon
fields.trailText: Clare Jenkins writes: Joe Kenyon (Obituary, May 12), who I interviewed for the BBC's oral history project, The Century Speaks, was a gift to a radio producer, having a vivid memory, an ability to paint pictures in sound, and iron in his soul hardened by anger at the (continuing) mistreatment and oppression of the northern poor.
fields.body:
Clare Jenkins writes: Joe Kenyon (Obituary, May 12), who I interviewed for the BBC's oral history project, The Century Speaks, was a gift to a radio producer, having a vivid memory, an ability to paint pictures in sound, and iron in his soul hardened by anger at the (continuing) mistreatment and oppression of the northern poor.

That anger came from his own life's tragedies. His father's back was broken in a pit accident - his colleagues had to carry him home in a wheelbarrow, and one of them later committed suicide. An aunt was scalped in a textile mill in Halifax.

Because Joe's mother could not afford to pay a £3 fine, the bailiffs took away the furniture, and she and her seven children had to sleep on the bare floor. Joe kept himself from starving by digging up tree roots and scavenging birds' eggs, though he always left two in the nest.

As a miner himself, he saw enough awful deaths - men reduced to dust in a matter of seconds - to decide to tackle the issue head on. Hence his involvement in health and safety issues. Even in his 80s, and suffering badly from pneumoconiosis, he was still battling for improved benefit rights for pensioners, and for an improved NHS. He doubtless went down fighting.

Kevin Ward writes: Your obituary of Joe Kenyon rightly highlights his welfare rights advocacy role. His ability both to fight individual cases, and draw out their wider im plications, was unmatched. There were many senior officials of the then DHSS who were not fully appreciative of Joe's intimate knowledge of legislation, and his adoption of what they perceived as his intimidatory tactics.

One manager of a social security office was highly aggrieved when he realised that Joe had taped one of their disputatious interviews and sent it to ministers and senior civil servants. He continued to utilise similar tactics throughout his life.

fields.headline: General Sir Martin Farndale
fields.standfirst: Innovative army commander whose leadership qualities took him to Malaya, Northern Ireland and Nato
fields.trailText: General Sir Martin Farndale, who has died aged 71, was unquestionably the most distinguished gunner officer of his generation. He had an outstanding career both in command and on the staff, but was never more at home than when among soldiers in the field. He was an example of what can be achieved with a combination of leadership, intellect, personality, charm and dedication.
fields.body:
General Sir Martin Farndale, who has died aged 71, was unquestionably the most distinguished gunner officer of his generation. He had an outstanding career both in command and on the staff, but was never more at home than when among soldiers in the field. He was an example of what can be achieved with a combination of leadership, intellect, personality, charm and dedication.

He was born in Alberta, Canada, and educated at Yorebridge school, Yorkshire. He joined the Indian army in 1946 and, in 1947, transferred to the British army, went to Sandhurst and was commissioned into the Royal Artillery in October 1948.

He served in several gunner regiments, but his heart lay with the 1st Regiment, Royal Horse Artillery, with whom he served on and off for 21 years. He saw service in the UK, Aden and the British Army of the Rhine and, in 1964, took command of the Chestnut troop, the senior battery.

In 1969, to his immense pride, Farndale assumed command of the regiment and, during this period, took it to Northern Ireland, the first gunner regiment to serve there in an infantry role. Later, he became the first honorary colonel of the regiment. His infectious enthusiasm, his encouragement to those who needed a helping hand, his sense of humour and his oratory skills made him a legend within the regiment in his lifetime.

Farndale would, I feel sure, see himself first and foremost as a commander. He was at ease with soldiers and they, in turn, followed him without hesitation. Nevertheless, he was an equally brilliant staff officer. After passing out from the Camberley staff college in 1959, he served for two years in HQRA 17th Gurkha Division, where he saw active service during the final phases of the Malayan campaign, followed by a spell in military operations at the Ministry of Defence. He became an instructor at Camberley in 1966.

After two years on the defence policy staff, he returned to Germany to command 7th Armoured Brigade at Soltau. This was followed by two years as director, public relations, at the MoD, and a further two years as director of military operations. He then commanded the 2nd Armoured Division in Germany for three years.

Farndale's grasp of the complexities of the all-arms battle, allied to his inspirational leadership qualities, led to his being appointed to command the 1st (British) Corps. Life was always exciting for those serving with him during this period, as he was a constant source of innovative ideas that kept all concerned on their toes. His success led to promotion to commander, Northern Army Group, and commander-in-chief, British Army of the Rhine.

As a Nato general, Farndale earned the respect and loyalty of the national corps under his command from Germany, Holland and Belgium, as well as the 1st British Corps. This was fully tested on Exercise Certain Strike in 1987, the largest exercise of its type in Europe since the second world war. Here, Farndale took under his command a fifth corps, 3 (US) Corps, and established a rapport with its commanding general that lasted the rest of his life.

In 1980, he was appointed colonel commandant, Army Air Corps, continuing a line of distinguished senior officers who had filled the post. This was a new area, and, some might have felt, an added burden to his already full and demanding military life.

But it was typical of Farndale that, without hesitation, he committed himself completely to his new role. He took a personal interest in every aspect of this small but rapidly developing corps, unstinting with his time and applying his huge capacity for work in an entirely selfless fashion. There is no doubt that the Army Air Corps flourished under his hand.

He retired in January 1988 after 42 years' service, and became a director and senior defence adviser to Short Brothers plc, and defence adviser to Deloitte Touche. He kept his links with the army, and particularly the Royal Regiment of Artillery, when he assumed the appointment of master gunner, St James's Park, on November 5 1988. During this period, he was also colonel commandant, Royal Horse Artillery, colonel commandant, Royal Artillery, honorary regimental colonel, 1st Regiment, Royal Horse Artillery, and honorary colonel, 3rd Battalion, the Yorkshire Volunteers.

Farndale was also a man of letters and a military historian of note. He wrote four books covering the history of the Royal Artillery, an undertaking he was still engaged in at the time of his death. He was chairman of the English Heritage Battlefields Panel and, from 1989-1993, chairman of the Royal United Services Institute for Defence Studies.

In his last years, Farndale threw his energies into safeguarding the heritage of the Royal Regiment of Artillery, particularly as president, and subsequently chairman and chief executive, of its regimental museum project at Woolwich. He was an inveterate and persuasive fund- raiser, to such an extent that some were said to be suffering from donor fatigue. Thanks to his drive, vision and determination to overcome manifold obstacles, the museum will open to the public next year.

Martin Farndale was an exceptional man, who lived an exceptional life. He was generous of spirit, an inspiring leader, a true comrade in arms and a firm friend. The world is poorer for his passing but his achievements will be remembered for many a year to come.

He was appointed CB in 1980 and KCB in 1983. He married Anne Buckingham in 1955; she survives him, with their son Richard. It was a source of great pride to Farndale that Richard too served in 1st Regiment, Royal Horse Artillery, his old regiment, to which he remained intensely loyal.

 Martin Baker Farndale, soldier, born January 6 1929; died May 10 2000

fields.headline: Kitty Macleod
fields.standfirst: Gaelic singer renowned for reviving a dormant musical tradition
fields.trailText: Kitty Macleod, the doyenne of Scottish Gaelic singers and one of the first to bring the music's traditional style to the attention of an international audience, has died at the age of 85. In the notes to an album reissued last year, the folklore collector Alan Lomax described her as being "generally regarded as the finest stylist among Gaelic folk-singers".
fields.body:
Kitty Macleod, the doyenne of Scottish Gaelic singers and one of the first to bring the music's traditional style to the attention of an international audience, has died at the age of 85. In the notes to an album reissued last year, the folklore collector Alan Lomax described her as being "generally regarded as the finest stylist among Gaelic folk-singers".

For many years, Macleod virtually turned her back on the commercial music industry, which she believed to have been exploitative towards both the music and the people who performed it. However, her much-broadcast early recordings on Parlophone from before the second world war, and the memory of concert appearances in her heyday, ensured that she retained an enormous amount of professional and public respect.

From being an outstanding singer within her own linguistic community, Macleod moved to a wider stage, partly as a result of the single event that subsequently grew into the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. In 1951, as a response to the perceived elitism of the festival itself, Hamish Henderson and the late Norman Buchan organised the People's Festival Ceilidhs, which provided a showcase for more popular forms of Scottish culture.

Singing with her sister, Marietta, who had trained as an actress and worked with the Unity theatre, Kitty took the opening session by storm. Audiences which had hitherto been familiar with only the more stylised forms of Gaelic song, almost invariably with piano accompaniment, were exposed to the raw musical meat of the Hebridean tradition. Her wider reputation continued to grow, and the songs she sang that night were recorded by Lomax in the United States on a Columbia Masterworks recording entitled The Highlands And The Lowlands.

Macleod was born at Kasauli, a hill station on the southern slopes of the Himalayas, near the British army HQ at Simla. Her mother had gone to India shortly before the start of the first world war to be with her husband, then serving with the Seaforth Highlanders. He was captured at the siege of Kut, in Mesopotamia, and was pronounced "missing in action, believed dead".

Mrs Macleod took her baby daughter back to the Isle of Lewis. Two years later, Kitty's father turned up in a military hospital in Alexandria, unable to speak his own name. He was brought back to Britain, and his faculties were restored after his daughter had visited his bedside. The family settled in Lewis, where music was an important part of their lives, in what was then a largely monolingual society.

Kitty won a scholarship to Edinburgh University, where she was an outstandingly brilliant student in the early 1930s. She developed her Gaelic interests under the great Celtic scholar, Dr WJ Watson, and won the Elizabeth Hamilton prize for the best woman student in philosophy. All the time, she was singing, and, in 1936 at Inverness, she won the gold medal of the National Mod, the premier Gaelic music festival.

At this time, Gaelic music, as far as the wider Scottish society was concerned, was largely perceived through the arrangements and translations of distinguished non-Gaels like Marjorie Kennedy Fraser and Sir Hugh Roberton. Except through the radio, there was little contact with the true music of the Gaelic-speaking communities in which Kitty had grown up. She was also an avid collector, and in 1938 visited the island of Barra to learn many of the songs with which she later became identified.

Film buffs will recognise her from two cameo appearances as a Gaelic singer. In the early 1940s, she featured in a picture about the work of Hebridean women during wartime, The Western Isles. In 1953, she and Marietta sang some show-stopping mouth music in Rob Roy: A Highland Rogue, starring Richard Todd, Glynis Johns and James Robertson Justice. This led to screen tests for the part of Flora MacDonald in a David Niven film, Bonnie Prince Charlie, but the producers decided that they needed another big name - Margaret Leighton - rather than an authentic Gael. The film bombed.

In her professional life outside music, Macleod was a teacher in Manchester, the Gorbals, and, latterly, East Lothian. After retirement in 1974, she became one of the prime movers in creating the United States's own National Gaelic Mod. As her recordings became accessible once again, her reputation was further enhanced.

Her death marks the end of a fascinating era within a fragile, but immensely rich, minority culture. She is survived by her second husband, Dr Ernest Gregson.

fields.headline: RAF airlifts sick QE2 passenger
fields.trailText: RAF crewmen yesterday airlifted a dangerously ill 80-year-old from the QE2 passenger ship, 250 miles off the west coast of Ireland.
fields.body:
RAF crewmen yesterday airlifted a dangerously ill 80-year-old from the QE2 passenger ship, 250 miles off the west coast of Ireland.

Falmouth coastguard launched the mission after the ship's medical officer diagnosed the American man as needing urgent hospital treatment. "The vessel was about 800 miles out in the Atlantic and way out of helicopter range," said a coastguard spokesman.

The liner was diverted from her transatlantic course to head towards Ireland at 28 knots while the Coastguard alerted RAF Chivenor in Devon where a Sea King helicopter left for Cork to wait for the ship to sail within range. An RAF Nimrod reconnaissance aircraft from Kinloss, in Scotland, located the ship and co-ordinated the air-sea rescue.

The crew of the Sea King, which reached the QE2 after 2 and a half hours, winched the patient up amid strong winds early yesterday morning. The coast-guard spokesman said the helicopter reached a hospital in Shannon just after 5am after plans to go to Cork had been scrapped because of the bad weather.

The QE2 yesterday resumed its passage to Southampton. A spokeswoman for the regional hospital in Limerick said the man should recover fully.

fields.headline: Oops, was that a camera?
fields.standfirst:
Stars who have no shame
Why the BBC can't win with the Windsors
Potato shock
fields.trailText: There is one great comic moment in Madonna's documentary about herself, In Bed with Madonna. A doctor inspects the singer's worn throat and then asks whether she would like to discuss the matter off camera. There is an explosion of laughter from Warren Beatty, her consort of the time, who has been lurking in the background, hiding behind a pair of dark glasses: "She doesn't want to live off camera," he says. "Much less talk. Why would you say something if it's off camera. What point is there existing?"
fields.body:
There is one great comic moment in Madonna's documentary about herself, In Bed with Madonna. A doctor inspects the singer's worn throat and then asks whether she would like to discuss the matter off camera. There is an explosion of laughter from Warren Beatty, her consort of the time, who has been lurking in the background, hiding behind a pair of dark glasses: "She doesn't want to live off camera," he says. "Much less talk. Why would you say something if it's off camera. What point is there existing?"

But that was 1991 and Beatty's bafflement now seems like ancient history. What indeed is the point of existing off camera?

You are Will Carling. You become a national hate-figure when the woman you left your wife for - and with whom you had a child - discovered you were leaving her through reading a draft version of an article you had written for the Daily Mail. Now, two years on, you want more access to your son. You start legal proceedings that end up in the High Court this week. But that's not enough. You need to send a message. So you allow yourself to be photographed playing with your child and then give an interview to go with the pictures which appear in the Sun. "Now Carling fights for his son" was the headline that dominated the front page along with the photograph of the little tot attempting to kick a rugby ball. How could the horrid judge resist giving him what he wanted?

I don't want to be pious about this. It's not as if I haven't on occasion used my own life, and indeed my own children, as material for articles. In fact, I suspect I could probably concoct an autobiography the length of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire out of my yellowing cuttings from this paper's Parents page, various magazines and my column in the New Statesman. But even so, there are right ways and wrong ways of doing things. Do gentlemen permit themselves to be photographed with their two-year-old son as a weapon in a custody dispute?

As is usually the case with weapons, the main damage here was done to the man wielding it. You have to admire the Sun's lack of gratitude for its exclusive story. The sub-heading on the front page read: "Love rat takes ex Ali to court." Inside, Will Carling gave an interview in which he defended himself, saying it was all right for him to walk out on Ali Cockayne and their child because he had had no intention of marrying her: "I was not in love with her. And selfish as it may sound, I couldn't go through the charade of pretending I was." As a rebranding exercise - Old Will the cad relaunched as Cuddly Will, the doting dad - this was not a complete success. Is this the man who gives lectures to businessmen? The Sun's own follow-up story described Carling as "the love rat - who famously left tearful Ali holding the baby two years ago".

Carling could say he was only using little Henry as politicians have always used their children. Remember John Gummer feeding a hamburger to his daughter Cordelia to prove that British beef was safe. Has anything been seen of her since? Is she all right?

But Will Carling is like Greta Garbo compared with Les Dennis, the host of the game show Family Fortunes. Guardian readers may have missed the very public collapse of his marriage to actress and ex-Blind Date contestant, Amanda Holden. She was photographed having a tryst with (but of course) Men Behaving Badly star Neil Morrissey. Bad. Then he was photographed falling over in a tequila bar, shouting: "Neil's a bastard. How can Amanda do that with him?" Very bad. But then, when she moved out of the house this week, instead of hiding under the covers with the curtains drawn, as any sane person would do, he carried her bag out to the car in front of all the photographers, tried to smile and engage her in conversation before finally being refused a kiss as she shut the car door and drove away. Are these people mad?

There are only two explanations for all of this. One is that Will Carling, Les Dennis and other celebrities are producing a post-modern comedy show for Channel 4 as some surreal revenge on the media. The other is that there is a category of people for whom the idea of "off camera" and the concept of embarrassment no longer exist. And no doubt before the decade is over Charles and Camilla will be touring regional venues performing the transcript of the Squidgygate tape.

Auntie and the royal curse

I know where I stand on the supposed controversy about the BBC's refusal to provide live coverage of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday tribute. I still have the "Stuff the Jubilee" badge I wore in 1977. Admittedly, the regime at my school was oppressive enough that I had to wear it behind the lapel of my blazer, but at least I knew it was there.

As for the BBC, it may be a case of three times bitten, finally getting shy. Maybe the corporation felt that the massive live coverage given to the weddings of Anne, Charles and Andrew had been a sort of curse. Then there was the experience of the death of Diana. All channels were cleared to reflect the national feeling of mourning; there was nothing on TV but men wearing black ties talking to each other about how sad they felt. Then in the middle of the afternoon the nation perked up and started ringing in to ask if it was really necessary for the EastEnders repeat to be cancelled.

At this point, the BBC began to reconsider its plan for the death of the Queen Mother, which had been designed years before, apparently on some Soviet model that involved about a week of nothing but solemn music and Dimblebys dressed in black and speaking in low voices. It has now been scaled down, probably to a 30-second tribute from Carol Vorderman after the Isthmian League football results.

In any case, the most impressive tribute to the Queen Mother has already been paid. The pageant may be the second-rate show you'd expect for something that had to be paid for by flogging corporate boxes - but it has been scheduled to take place six weeks after her birthday. What greater compliment could you give a 99-year-old?

The truth about spuds

For a moment I was shocked by the finding of a survey carried out this week by the British Potato Council which showed that half of children aged between six and nine believe that potatoes grow on trees. But only for a moment. First, I cheered up immediately simply having learned that something called the British Potato Council exists. Second, I've long been accustomed to discovering that every interesting fact I know is actually wrong - that far from having 200 words for snow, the Inuit have only three. And third, it was only when I moved to the country a year ago that I discovered that Brussels sprouts don't grow like little cabbages on the ground. Instead they perch on stupid sticks, looking for all the world as if they've been stuck on for an April Fool. My own six-year-old is already glumly taking her Sats at a time when she can barely hold a crayon. Am I now meant to sit her down and tell her where potatoes come from?
fields.bodyText: There is one great comic moment in Madonna's documentary about herself, In Bed with Madonna. A doctor inspects the singer's worn throat and then asks whether she would like to discuss the matter off camera. webTitle: Blue blooded meat:  Duchess opens farm shop

fields.headline: Blue blooded meat:  Duchess opens farm shop
fields.trailText: The toffs of Belgravia no longer have to leave London for a taste of the country, writes James Meikle .
fields.body:
The toffs of Belgravia no longer have to leave London for a taste of the country, writes James Meikle .

The Duke and Duchess of Devonshire have opened a farm shop in south-west London offering home-grown beef, lamb, pork, game, dairy products, cakes and pates.

The couple's first shop, on their Chatsworth estate in Derbyshire, opened in 1977 and now has a turnover of £2.5m and a staff of 65.

"All meat is either our own or from tenant farmers," said the duchess yesterday. "It's delivered to London three times a day, and game is hung properly - things almost impossible to find in London."

She had noticed some difference in buying habits. "People here buy more high quality cuts than in the country. I don't think families in Eaton Square tend to sit down to Irish stew."

fields.headline: Drama aid doubled for students
fields.trailText: A second round of scholarships to enable potential stars to study at top dance and drama colleges was announced by the government yesterday.
fields.body:
A second round of scholarships to enable potential stars to study at top dance and drama colleges was announced by the government yesterday.

It will raise from 835 to 1,560 the number of students supported by the scholarships from September, Lady Blackstone, the education minister, said. Total funding is rising from £6.1m this academic year to £11.9m.

At a presentation at the Almeida theatre in Islington, north London, Lady Blackstone said the government had ended the funding "lottery" inherited from the Conservatives in which financial help from local education authorities was discretionary and determined by where a student lived.

Now talent would be "put before postcodes", she said. "Instead of paying fees of up to £8,000, award winnners pay at most £1,050, in line with university students."

The actress Prunella Scales said she had won a scholarship to train at the Bristol Old Vic. "British performers are lucky to work in a widely understood language and in one of the richest literary and dramatic heritages in the world. I am delighted that a government has at last realised the importance of investing in this heritage."

Sarah Matthews, head of dance at the Central School of Ballet in London, said one of her students, Ben Weeratunge, 19, had found his scholarship a "huge help", although he still needed a bar job to make ends meet.

 Lecturers in the Association of University Teachers yesterday rejected a "full and final" pay offer of 3%. The association had called for a substantial rise to redress a 30% decline in salaries and for better starting pay.

fields.headline: UK's £200m aid for dam stalled
fields.standfirst: Controversial Turkish project which would flood Kurdish heartland now unlikely to get support
fields.trailText: The government has cooled its support for a dam project in Turkey which would drown the Kurdish heartland.
fields.body:
The government has cooled its support for a dam project in Turkey which would drown the Kurdish heartland.

The controversial Ilisu scheme, which had been backed personally by the prime minister, is now unlikely to get £200m of British aid because the government has set conditions that Turkey will probably not accept, forcing the project to be postponed.

In a reply to severe criticism from the Commons trade and industry select committee, the government accepts the export credit guarantee would be in breach of international law unless Turkey consulted and agreed with the downstream countries, Syria and Iraq, about the use of the waters of the Tigris. Turkey has already said it will not do so.

Syria and Iraq have protested to the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, that the Turks refuse to talk to them.

Turkey must also shift its position in respect of properly compensating local Kurdish people whose homes and land would be submerged. The project would flood 52 Kurdish villages and 15 towns, including centuries-old Hasankeyf, a centre of Kurdish culture.

The export credit has been delayed until June at the earliest because the Turkish government has failed to produce a resettlement plan. Britain regards this issue as "of particular concern".

The export credit was about to be rubber stamped by civil servants at the export credit guarantee department of the Department of Trade and Industry until the issue was high lighted by the Guardian a year ago. The plan was seen to be in breach of the government ethical foreign policy and eventually was considered at cabinet level. Tony Blair gave the scheme his personal backing.

Yesterday the government conceded for the first time that failure to consult ministers in the first place had been a mistake.

"ECGD has now introduced an environmental screening process to enable sensitive cases to be identified at an earlier stage," it said.

The government rejects crit icism that it was lax and behind every other credit agency in Europe and North America in putting conditions on government backing for overseas business. The reply claims that the DTI does consult other departments on ethical and environment issues and does not just consider the business case.

The careful reply to the committee still leaves the government open to support the deal if the Turks have a change of heart and are prepared to meet the stringent conditions now placed upon them.

The government is already clearly embarrassed by a legal opinion commissioned by Friends of the Earth which says Turkey is already in breach of international law for not consulting the downstream states, Syria and Iraq. By supporting the scheme Britain too is in breach, the opinion says.

Tony Juniper, policy and campaigns director of FoE, said: "The government has got itself into a very tricky situation support for this dam will cause tremendous political damage."

webTitle: Hollywood dames  Julie and Liz collect their gongs

fields.headline: Hollywood dames  Julie and Liz collect their gongs
fields.trailText: It was her crowning moment and movie star Elizabeth Taylor  wished she could have   shared it with the love of her life, Richard Burton.
fields.body:
It was her crowning moment and movie star Elizabeth Taylor wished she could have shared it with the love of her life, Richard Burton.

"I miss him so much," she said, after receiving the insignia of a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire from the Queen yesterday. "I wish he was here."

Sharing the limelight at Buckingham palace was the newly invested Dame Julie, who said: "This is the greatest honour of my life."

fields.headline: Arsonist killer sent to Rampton
fields.trailText: An unemployed disc jockey was yesterday given unlimited detention in the secure hospital, Rampton, for the killing of seven in a house fire.
fields.body:
An unemployed disc jockey was yesterday given unlimited detention in the secure hospital, Rampton, for the killing of seven in a house fire.

Richard Fielding, 21, of Walthamstow, east London, pleaded guilty to manslaughter, on grounds of diminished responsibility, of the Day family. His pleas of not guilty to murder were accepted by the prosecution at the Old Bailey. The Recorder of London, Judge Michael Hyam, said he was satisfied that Fielding was mentally ill.

Outside court, Kelly Himpfen, 21, the mother of three children who perished, said: "It shows you can get away with murder."

Judge Hyam said psychiatrists agreed the defendant had a severe mental illness, probably schizophrenia.

The court heard that Fielding poured petrol in the letter box of the Days' home in Chingford, east London, in March last year. He admitted killing Kathleen Day, 76, her daughter-in-law Sandra Day, 50, Sandra's son Lee, 22, his daughters, Maddison and Rhiannon, both three, and son Reece, two, and his girlfriend Yvonne Colverhouse, 17.

Orlando Pownall, prosecuting, said that Fielding had said it was revenge against Lee Day, an old school friend. "The prosecution agonised before accepting the [defendant's] pleas. We understand our decision will not be met with unreserved support from those whose lives have been devastated."

fields.headline: Cricketer arrested in assault case
fields.trailText: The cricketer Peter Roebuck has been arrested and questioned by Avon and Somerset police about allegations that he spanked a young South African batsman.
fields.body:
The cricketer Peter Roebuck has been arrested and questioned by Avon and Somerset police about allegations that he spanked a young South African batsman.

Roebuck, 44, now a cricket journalist, was released on police bail to reappear at Exmouth police station in Devon next month. Police said he was arrested at his home in Exmouth on suspicion of two assaults occasioning actual bodily harm.

The investigation is believed to centre on claims by the South African, 19, that Roebuck beat his buttocks with a cane or bat while he was sharing his home in Taunton, Somerset, last year.

The batsman, who came to Britain to be coached by Roebuck, alleged that the beatings were punishments for poor performance.

Devon and Cornwall police said the case was in the hands of Avon and Somerset police.

Roebuck, who captained Devon in the Minor Counties championship for six years until last summer, moved from Taunton to a villa in Exmouth after the allegations became public last year.

The former pupil of Millfield public school still plays for Budleigh Salterton in Devon. He skippered Somerset for several years and was in charge when Ian Botham, Viv Richards and Joel Garner left the county amid acrimony.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Missing victims
fields.body:
Missing victims

Hundreds of people are still unaccounted for after the fireworks explosion in the Dutch town of Enschede on Saturday, officials said yesterday.

Fifteen bodies have been recovered and the authorities predict an eventual death toll of 20, but said that between 200 and 400 were unaccounted for. They stressed that many were likely to be staying with friends.
Reuters, Enschede

Student slain

South African police opened fire yesterday with rubber bullets on protesting students, killing one, following several days of violence over student fees at the University of Durban-Westville.

Riot police were sent in after students went on the rampage.
AP, Durban

Stormy flight

The leader of France's National Front, Jean-Marie Le Pen, and the black rap singer Stomy Bugs had a slanging match on a flight between Paris and Strasbourg on Monday, police said yesterday.

The European parliament later decided to allow Mr Le Pen to keep his seat in its forum pending his appeal against a French state decree that stripped him of his seat after he assaulted a a woman politician in 1997.
Reuters, Paris

fields.headline: Japan divine, claims PM
fields.trailText: The gaffe-prone Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, has kicked off an unholy row by claiming that Japan is a divine land with the emperor at its core.
fields.body:
The gaffe-prone Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, has kicked off an unholy row by claiming that Japan is a divine land with the emperor at its core.

Opposition politicians say the comments are a disturbing throwback to the country's militaristic past, when the state Shinto religion propagated the belief that the emperor was a living god.

Mr Mori, whose past slip-ups include discriminatory references to Aids patients and "communist teachers", made the comments in a speech on Monday at a gathering of parliamentarians working to promote Shinto beliefs.

"Japan is a country of the gods with the emperor at its centre," said the prime minister, who has been a member of the Shinto parliamentarians' group since its inception in 1970. "We have been working for 30 years to have people firmly acknowledge that."

According to the beliefs of Shinto, the indigenous religion, Japan is a land of countless kami (gods) and the emperor is a direct descendant of the sun goddess, Amaterasu. However, this creed is no longer officially state-sponsored.

During the meeting, Mr Mori boasted that he and his predecessor, Keizo Obuchi, had rekindled interest in Shinto by creating a national holiday to mark the birth of the last emperor Showa (better known in the west as Hirohito), and by organising celebrations - the scale of which were unprecedented - for the 10th anniversary of the reign of the current emperor, Akihito.

He also promised a greater role for Shinto shrines in education, despite the legal prohibition of religious teaching in state schools.

Yukio Hatoyama, the leader of the opposition Democratic party, slammed the remarks as a worrying echo of the pre-war system. He said Mr Mori had contradicted the constitution, which makes the people sovereign and the emperor merely a symbol of the nation.

Mr Hatoyama also said Mr Mori had offended neighbouring nations, many of which suffered under occupation by Japan's Imperial army in the 1930s and 40s. "The impact this will have on other countries, especially other Asian countries, is extremely serious," he said.

The prime minister's comments appear to have arisen more from political expediency than religious dogma. With a general election set for June 25, Mr Mori needs the support of the Shinto lobby.

But with the exception of elderly people educated before the war and a handful of die-hard rightwingers, very few Japanese people give a second thought to the emperor, let alone worship him.

"[Mr Mori's} words are very dangerous," said one man who was interviewed on television. "Japan went into the second world war in the belief that this is a divine nation. I'm worried that we are heading in the same direction again."

webTitle: Repeat criminals could go to jail for minor crimes

fields.headline: Repeat criminals could go to jail for minor crimes
fields.trailText: Plans for minor criminals who repeatedly offend to be jailed for the weekend or given "9am to 5pm" daytime prison sentences were last night floated by the home secretary, Jack Straw.
fields.body:
Plans for minor criminals who repeatedly offend to be jailed for the weekend or given "9am to 5pm" daytime prison sentences were last night floated by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

In yet another "get tough" move, Mr Straw indicated he was now prepared to tear up the liberal 1991 Criminal Justice Act of the former Conservative home secretary Douglas Hurd, which said that sentencing should be based on the "just deserts" principle that the punishment should fit the crime rather than the criminal's past record.

The home secretary said yesterday that he believed it was time to close the "revolving door" that allowed habitual criminals to return repeatedly to a life of crime after serving a community penalty or a short prison sentence.

He said the 1991 act did not deal adequately with such repeat offending - especially where the offences were not considered serious enough to justify a prison sentence.

"The system is failing to protect the public from the activities of those repeat offenders, whose level of criminality remains constant but, because of the rigidities in the current system, do not progress properly through the system and keep returning to the courts," said Mr Straw.

The home secretary said he believed the courts needed a new sentencing framework which made the punishment fit the criminal rather than the crime, even if it meant that a habitual milk thief went to jail for the 12th time he stole a bottle off the step.

He said the idea that there was a fixed penalty, or "price tag", for certain crimes no matter how many times they were committed was an idea with which he profoundly disagreed.

Mr Straw also announced that he intended to consider new forms of prison sentences which do more to take account of how convicted criminals behave during their time in custody.

They could include "custody plus" which combined a fixed period in jail followed by time in the community which would be subject to sanctions, such as tagging, depending on the prisoner's behaviour. Other ideas being looked at were "day custody", which would require offenders to be at a secure day centre for fixed periods, so keeping them off the streets, and weekend jail which would enable convicted offenders to keep their job during the week.

But the plans brought ridicule from the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdicombe: "The idea seems to be verging on the lunatic, because he is effectively saying he will lock offenders up during working hours and make it impossible to make a lawful living, then release them at night, when most burglaries take place. Who is he going to put in 'nine to five' jail, unless there are some criminals who don't need to make a living that he knows about?"

However, Paul Cavadino of the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders said there was no point in jailing more offenders only to produce a less effective penal system.

He said there was a danger that the "progression in sentencing" proposals would lead to disproportionate sentences for persistent but petty offenders. "Automatic sentences always cause injustice because they prevent the courts taking into account individual circumstances," he said.

fields.headline: 'Communist spy file' of ex-dissident minister
fields.trailText: The Czech Republic's foreign minister, Jan Kavan, has come under fire following the publication of a book which claims to document his work as a secret agent in Britain during the communist era in his country.
fields.body:
The Czech Republic's foreign minister, Jan Kavan, has come under fire following the publication of a book which claims to document his work as a secret agent in Britain during the communist era in his country.

Mr Kavan, who befriended many politicians in the current British government during his 20-year exile in Britain, is accused of cooperating with Prague's former secret police, the StB, during his student days in London between 1969 and 1970.

Embarrassingly for the Social Democratic government, the book, Kato: Story of a True Man, referring to his alleged StB code name, Kato, has appeared in Prague bookshops two weeks after Mr Kavan was put in charge of coordinating the Czech intelligence services.

Written by two former dissidents, the 530-page book claims to contain his file from the archives of the communist secret police and has photographs of alleged meetings between Mr Kavan and StB agents in Prague during the 1989 revolution.

It alleges he met StB case officers 31 times, during which he informed on his British friends, officials at the Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation and Czechoslovak students who were considering emigrating to Britain.

Formerly a prominent dissident, Mr Kavan, whose mother was British, left Czechoslovakia after the 1968 Soviet-led invasion and spent two decades in exile in London. During those years he supplied information about Czech dissidents and the Charter 77 movement, spearheaded by the future president Vaclav Havel - to the British media and kept up secret links with opposition groups in Czechoslovakia.

He returned to Prague for good after the 1989 revolution and was elected to parliament as a member of the Civic Forum, a broad democratic alliance founded by Mr Havel.

The book's publication is the latest saga to have plagued Mr Kavan in London and Prague.

In 1981, Mr Kavan went to the Broadcasting Complaints Commission (BCC) accusing the British journalist Julian Mannion of falsely stating that a van with banned material sent secretly to Prague by Mr Kavan and seized by the Czech secret police had contained a list of dissident names and addresses.

The BCC found against Mr Mannion. But in 1992, the judgment was reversed after documents were released from the secret police's archives. Mr Kavan was accused of "misleading" the commission by withholding important information. His defence was that he was trying to protect underground contacts.

In 1991, while serving as a deputy in the Czechoslovak parliament, he went to court in Prague to fight accusations that he was an StB agent. The court cleared him in 1996.

In the foreword to the book, its authors, Premysl Vachalovsky and John Bok, say they hope it will shed light on the reportedly "unconscious" collaboration of Mr Kavan with the StB.

Mr Kavan responded in a statement yesterday, saying: "I consider the publication of the file not only extremely unethical, but also a violation of law. This publication cannot change the fact that I was one of the most efficient opponents of the former regime and one of the most efficient collaborators with the domestic opposition."

The Czech prime minister, Milos Zeman, condemned the book: "This is the publication of documents from a criminal organisation, which the StB undoubtedly was. And to some extent it's comparable to the publication of Hitler's works."

webTitle: Hollywood's internet madam jailed for three years

fields.headline: Hollywood's internet madam jailed for three years
fields.trailText: The Hollywood madam who was said to have numbered many of America's rich and powerful among her clients was jailed yesterday for three years. Her lawyer attacked the sentence, claiming that the real offenders were all men and none had stood trial.
fields.body:
The Hollywood madam who was said to have numbered many of America's rich and powerful among her clients was jailed yesterday for three years. Her lawyer attacked the sentence, claiming that the real offenders were all men and none had stood trial.

Jody "Babydoll" Gibson, 42, was sentenced at Van Nuys superior court after being convicted on three counts of "felony pimping" last month. Her request to be released on $100,000 (£62,500) bail was turned down by Judge Lloyd Nash.

Ms Gibson, who originally came to Los Angeles hoping to make it as a country-and-western singer, was arrested last year by LA's vice squad for running an international prostitution ring. She was alleged to have a contact book of more than 400 clients who would pay between £330 and £2,000 for the women she provided.

Three of the women who worked for her gave evidence in the case, claiming that they paid 40% of their earnings to Ms Gibson.

Before the case came to court the names of her clients in her "trick book" had been blacked out by the prosecution, fuelling rumours that politicians, show business names and athletes had been protected from public scrutiny. One client was alleged to have been a wealthy businessman who asked Ms Gibson to fly women to Kuwait to help him close a deal.

"Bottom line is, when you put it in a pot and boil it all down, this was a case that was put on the books by men, investigated by men, crimes committed by men and a conviction and jail term served only by a woman," said Ms Gibson's lawyer, Gerald Scotti. "There are no victims here. This is not a bad person. There is no one who could say 'she hurt me' or 'my life is worse because of her'."

An animated Mr Scotti had asked the jury during the trials: "Is it fair in a case like this that they don't bring in a single 'John' [client]?"

Using the name Sasha, Ms Gibson had employed the internet to recruit clients, which is how the police became aware of her activities. But she claimed she had been able to continue operating because she had had an affair with a Beverly Hills detective who was investigating the escort business.

She was said to have taken over part of the market vacated when Heidi Fleiss, the legendary Hollywood madam, was convicted in 1995 for running a celebrity prostitution ring. Ms Fleiss was also jailed for three years, which she has now served.

Sentencing Ms Gibson, the judge told the court: "This is a tragedy. The women appear to be tragic and pathetic individuals and Ms Gibson appears to be tragic and pathetic."

His comments prompted Mr Scotti to say that the judge should have kept his personal opinions to himself. The defence counsel also said his client's operation was much smaller than the one run by Ms Fleiss.

Part of the evidence in the case was a manuscript for a proposed book written by Ms Gibson which the prosecution alleged was an admission of guilt. In the manuscript, she wrote of her irritation with the police and suggested that prostitution should be legalised. "They should just tax it, [and] give 1% to the homeless," she said.

Ms Gibson, who attracted attention by attending her trial in spectacular outfits, suggested that the escort business started when she was running a talent agency and models on her books asked if she knew any "sugar daddies".

"It just all came together and fell on my lap," she said in the manuscript, which she claimed in court was a work of fiction.

fields.headline: Red Brigades suspect arrested
fields.trailText: Italian police yesterday arrested a suspect in the assassination of Massimo D'Antona, a government adviser on labour law reform who was shot in a Rome street just under a year ago in the first killing claimed by the leftwing terrorist Red Brigades for 11 years.
fields.body:
Italian police yesterday arrested a suspect in the assassination of Massimo D'Antona, a government adviser on labour law reform who was shot in a Rome street just under a year ago in the first killing claimed by the leftwing terrorist Red Brigades for 11 years.

Police identified the suspect as Alessandro Geri, a 27-year-old trade union employee, and said they believed he was the person who called a newspaper to claim responsibility for the murder in the name of the Red Brigades for the Construction of the Fighting Communist party.

Mr Geri was identified through the evidence of a 10-year-old boy who allegedly spotted him at the phone box in Rome used to call in the claim on May 20 1999.

Investigators identified the serial number of the prepaid phone card used to make the call, tracking subsequent calls made with the same card.

Details of the the inquiry were leaked to the Rome daily La Repubblica at the weekend, forcing investigators to tighten the noose around a group of suspected Red Brigades sympathisers they had been keeping under surveillance.

Yesterday police raided numerous premises in Rome and charged Mr Geri with complicity in murder, membership of a subversive organisation, theft of two vans used in the terrorist attack and illegal possession of a firearm.

D'Antona was not a public figure. An academic and consultant to the then labour minister, Antonio Bassolino, he was responsible for devising a legal framework for labour relations in the public sector.

A 28-page document justifying the attack accused him of playing a key role in the government's reforms, encouraging part-time and temporary work and curtailing the right to strike of public servants.

It also condemned "Nato aggression" - the alliance was in the midst of the Kosovo bombing campaign at the time.

In an interview published yesterday by La Repubblica, D'Antona's widow, Olga, voiced doubts about the motives of her husband's killers and said they may have been serving conservative forces opposed to change.

"My husband was responsible for very important reforms: of public administration, trade union representation, strikes in the transport sector, employer-trade union negotiations," she said.

"It's clear he was a source of irritation to many. How can I be sure that someone didn't try to resolve the problem by removing the man who was at the centre of these projects?"

fields.headline: Collar bomb
fields.trailText: Colombia's Marxist guerrillas rigged a bomb around the neck of a woman who rebelled against their systematic campaign of extortion, killing her and a policeman hours later when the bomb exploded as he struggled to prise the collar loose. Three security force members were maimed by the blast.
fields.body:
Colombia's Marxist guerrillas rigged a bomb around the neck of a woman who rebelled against their systematic campaign of extortion, killing her and a policeman hours later when the bomb exploded as he struggled to prise the collar loose. Three security force members were maimed by the blast.

Police and army spokesmen said the bomb marked an unprecedented act of terror in a conflict that has claimed more than 35,000 lives in the last decade.

They said rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) used a silicone adhesive to glue the collar bomb around the neck of Elvira Cortes Gil, 52, after breaking into her home in Boyaca province on Monday. The pressure-release device exploded more than six hours later as police and an army bomb squad struggled to disarm it.

President Andres Pastrana yesterday reacted to the atrocity by suspending the next round of the peace process, planned for the end of May. It is the first time in the 18-month peace process that the government has called off talks with Farc.

The army said Cortes Gil, a dairy farmer, was singled out for the "atrocious experiment" because she had recently stopped paying extortion money. Farc recently threatened to "tax" individuals and companies worth more than $1m (£625,000).

fields.headline: French markets reject EU clean-up
fields.trailText: Street markets, a mainstay of the Gallic way of life as quintessentially French as the baguette and the bidet, are at risk from strict EU hygiene regulations that stallholders fear will drive them out of business.
fields.body:
Street markets, a mainstay of the Gallic way of life as quintessentially French as the baguette and the bidet, are at risk from strict EU hygiene regulations that stallholders fear will drive them out of business.

"It's a real threat to France's national identity we're talking about," said Pierre Ribaut, a fromager at the colourful rue Mouffetard market in Paris. "It's about a genuine concern for good fresh food; it's about sights, sounds and smells that people these days come half way round the world to see."

The rules require electricity and running water to be in stalled at every point of sale, toilets at every market, and fish, meat and dairy produce to be kept in refrigerated cabinets - on pain of a £1,000 fine. The directive finally came into force yesterday after being delayed for five years by the government.

Defenders of the 20,000 street markets in some 6,000 towns and villages around the country argue that the rules will knock the soul out of a cherished institution and could bankrupt merchants who cannot afford the £25,000 for refrigeration equipment.

"I've been selling cheese like this for 41 years," Mr Ribaut, 63, said. "I've never had a problem, not one, and now they tell me I have to stop displaying my cheeses on straw, because it breeds microbes, and put everything in a case that will keep it at 8C, like a supermarket. I haven't got the money and it will ruin most of the cheeses."

Campaigners who have gathered 50,000 signatures against the change estimate that as many as half of all stallholders will find themselves in financial difficulty.

"Does Europe take any account of regional variety and beauty?" asked Damien Boileau, a member of the 250-strong market defence committee in the picturesque southern town of Uzes. "Our market's appeal is in its mix. You go from handicrafts to the fishmongers to the flower stall to the goat's cheese. With this law, all the food will be around water and power points - the charm will be gone."

The government insists that the measures are necessary to safeguard health, and points out that it has provided millions of pounds worth of grants and loans to help councils and stallholders adapt. But so far only 61% of markets have installed water and power points.

"We can no longer afford to have two sets of hygiene regulations for two kinds of retailer," said a spokesman at the economic affairs ministry, which will enforce the rules.

webTitle: Day eight: Screaming success at the scaffold

fields.headline: Day eight: Screaming success at the scaffold
fields.standfirst: Lars Von Trier's latest movie extravaganza polarised critics, but Fiachra Gibbons loved it. He reports exclusively from Cannes
fields.trailText: Lars Von Trier's latest movie extravaganza polarised critics, but Fiachra Gibbons loved it. He reports exclusively from Cannes
fields.body:
In Scandinavia they referred to Breaking the Waves as Breaking the Wives, and film-maker Lars Von Trier is at it again with Dancer in the Dark, putting his women through the full range of physical and psychological horror with such an unwavering gaze that at times it's hard to sit there and watch. This will be the film that goes down in history for its heroine singing from a scaffold. The final, almost unbearable scene in which Björk's blind criminal is marched the 107 steps from the condemned cell to the gallows makes for the movie's most bizarre and gut-wrenching song and dance number. When she cannot stand up, she is strapped to an upright board where she sings - or, more accurately, Björks - while we wait to hear whether the authorities will allow a blind woman to be hanged without a hood because "she just can't breathe with one on".

Boasting a motif from The Sound of Music, Dancer in the Dark is the most unusual, extraordinary feel-good musical ever made - but you may have guessed that already. The critics in attendance at the screening were either visibly moved or not so much booing as hissing or bellowing with rage. Never have I seen a reaction like this to a film, and never have those reactions been so shockingly divided.

Björk - who Von Trier had branded a 'mad woman' only a fortnight ago after she tried to block its screening because of cuts to her score - refused to appear alongside him and her co-star, the legendary French actress Catherine Deneuve, to answer questions. However, she did attend last night's gala screening in Cannes.

Björk's spokeswoman said she was "too frightened" by the attention he performance had attracted, and Deneuve disclosed that she was so traumatised by the experience of playing the part of Selma, a Czech immigrant in fifties America, that she may not be able to talk about it for another 10 years.

Von Trier, who has admitted to being a tyrant, made no attempt to play down their rift, which culminated in her storming off the set for four days. She is also said to have tried to eat her costume in a fit of rage.

Asked what it was like to work with Björk, he replied, "It has been terrible but the results have been incredible. Björk is not an actor. What was a surprise for me is that she seemed like a professional but she really isn't. She is not acting in this film but feeling everything, which is extremely hard on her and everyone else too. It was like being with a dying person. She was really feeling it all the time. I was in the awkward position of being the hangman who was pushing her towards her death. But it is the only way it could have been done."

Van Trier, who is so scared of flying he drove from Denmark in his camper van, said despite their differences he admired her performance. "I am extremely fond of the work she has done and I would like to thank her for it."

Deneuve, who formed a close bond with Björk during the filming, and spent New Year in Iceland with her, did not deny the tension with Björk on the set. "But it would be very perverse with such a very special film to give such importance to something behind the scenes. Nothing that is really worth it goes without difficulties, without tension, without crying," she said. "The more difficult and intense a film the more painful it is. Björk is very special. She cannot really act, she can only feel. Some of the situations in the film are so hard, and she was in so much pain, she could not recover from one day to the other. Those things made her behave sometimes like a child, like a human being who couldn't take it anymore. Like a child running out of school, sometimes she would run away. But when you compare that to the level of her performance in the film those things become so little."

She said it was most the most 'extreme' experience of film-making she had ever been through, but she found it "worth every minute. It was incredible what has been done."

Von Trier, who founded the Dogma style of simple, pared back film-making, and is regarded as a major force in world cinema, joked that he hoped to cast Deneuve, who famously played a prostitute in Belle du Jour, in his next project, a porn film. "She knows many things about the world that I don't," he said. "For the first time in my life, I feel empty."

Despite the movie's torrid production, Björk is a revelation as Selma, a Czech immigrant with failing sight, a kind of innocent, who goes to her death to save others and in particular her son. In a supporting role, Catherine Deneuve has never looked more human, while the song-and-dance sequences - which owe a lot to the Eastern European musicals of the 50s and 60s - are beautiful. As with the other key Von Trier pictures (Breaking the Waves, The Idiots), you are left with the sense that you are either in the presence of genius or have been manipulated by a cruel and cynical con-man.

From the ecstatic ovation given to Von Trier at a press conference afterwards, it is clear that many critics will be angry if the film does not win the Palme d'Or, although with opinions so divided they may also be protests if he does.

 Security in Cannes, already extremely tight, with hundreds of riot police and gendarmes deployed all over the town, has been stepped up even further after a series of muggings and break-ins in the backstreets behind the beachfront Croisette where most of the star-studded parties are held. Local police admitted that gangs of thieves had descended on the resort for the festival. Two British women, two Swedes and an American were all mugged on Tuesday evening and there had been 'opportunist' thieves working the main hotels too.  Meanwhile, Derek Malcolm, who has written for the Guardian for 35 years, was yesterday presented with a medal - for his services to cinema - by the retiring Cannes president Gilles Jacob. He said Malcolm was "one of the world's most distinguished critics".

webTitle: Beekeepers seek GM halt after honey contamination

fields.headline: Beekeepers seek GM halt after honey contamination
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Bees are making honey containing traces of genetically modified crops, it was claimed yesterday as the £210m-a-year bee industry demanded a temporary halt on further trials of the new technology.
fields.body:
Bees are making honey containing traces of genetically modified crops, it was claimed yesterday as the £210m-a-year bee industry demanded a temporary halt on further trials of the new technology.

Tests on two samples of honey bought from shops near a trial site used last year were said to reveal GM pollen although seven others showed no signs of GM engineering.

The results, announced by the strongly anti-GM Friends of the Earth, were given a cool reception by Aventis, the biotech company involved in the trial, and by the government, which said they indicated no risk to humans. Honey producers would not have to label their products as containing GM ingredients since they would be unlikely to have more than the 1% threshold allowed for accidental contamination by the European Union.

However, they caused consternation at the Bee Farmers Association which has already advised members to move their hives at least six miles from the nearest GM site - the distance organic farmers have been advised by the Soil Association to consider "safe" from contamination.

Such measures could soon prove difficult to adopt. If crops get commercial approval in three years' time, the location of farms using GM crops will not have to be publicised.

Sales of honey are worth more than £10m to commercial beekeepers, who also have lucrative contracts worth up to £200m with farmers who need to pollinate traditionally-grown fruit and other crops each year.

The potential effects of GM crops on bees, butterflies and ladybirds have all been raised by scientists recently while there is widespread evidence of consumer resistance to GM ingredients in food even if it has been passed safe.

Last year FoE found GM pollen in traps outside beehives more than 2.5 miles from a GM site. This time it went further and bought honey made by a bee farmer living near a test site for GM oilseed rape, whom it refused to identify, and sent them to researchers working for a company in Vienna owned by the Austrian government. The lab oratory identified the presence of GM components in two of them but said the tests used could not measure the extent of contamination.

FoE demanded an immediate ban on the outdoor testing of GM oilseed rape and maize, saying liability for contamination had not been established. By potentially forcing beekeepers to pull out of areas near GM test sites, damage could also be caused to fruit and vegetable farmers who often need their help because a destructive parasite is ravaging the British bee population.

Pete Riley, FoE senior food campaigner, said: "Honey is seen as a pure and natural product. The public has already made it clear that they don't want GM food."

The public would not be happy if the government allowed GM trials to threaten their honey, he added.

The Bee Farmers Association said there had been no pro-active consultation by government and no offers to compensate members for moving hives or other consequences of contamination. It said the FoE example was "an isolated incident", and there was no proven evidence that such a tiny amount of GM material could be harmful.

The biotech industry is supervising a three-year programme of trials designed to establish whether there are potential threats to the environment from GM crops, but government advisers have already ruled they are safe enough to plant in the open. A spokeswoman for the Department of the Environment said: "The minute amounts of GM pollution found in honey poses no risk to human health."

She repeated assurances that separation distances between GM and traditional crops - 50 metres for oil seed rape and 200 metres for maize - would be reviewed if there was any evidence of cross pollination.

Aventis said it could not comment in detail until it had seen the methods used in the tests. But a spokesman said the results "run diametrically contrary to everything we have to do to date with bees". Much of the work it had submitted to government over the years had concerned the impact on wildlife.

webTitle: The best job interview scene:  Boiler Room

fields.headline: The best job interview scene:  Boiler Room
fields.trailText: Long Island. At brokerage firm JT Marland, Seth Davis (Giovanni Ribisi) sits at a conference table in the midst of a "group interview" for potential employees. Senior broker Jim Young (Ben Affleck), a sharply dressed man in his mid-twenties, strides into the room. He leans over a candidate.
fields.body:
Long Island. At brokerage firm JT Marland, Seth Davis (Giovanni Ribisi) sits at a conference table in the midst of a "group interview" for potential employees. Senior broker Jim Young (Ben Affleck), a sharply dressed man in his mid-twenties, strides into the room. He leans over a candidate.

"Sorry man, that's my chair."

Panicked, the would-be broker swiftly swaps seats.

"Shit, sorry."

"No, don't worry about it."

Another candidate eyes his errant colleague-to-be with scorn.

"Dumb-ass."

Young spins on his heels.

"Get the fuck out of here."

"What?"

"Don't talk to me, don't look at me. Just pick your ass up out of that Italian leather chair and get the fuck out of this room right now. Come on, let's go - out!"

The loud-mouthed candidate shuffles out of the room. Young faces the remaining job applicants.

"We expect everyone here to treat their co-workers with a certain level of respect. OK, I'm not here to waste your time, and I certainly hope you're not here to waste mine. So I'll keep this short. Become an employee of this firm and you will make your first million within three years. I'm going to repeat that. You will make a million dollars within three years of your first day of employment at JT Marland. You think I'm joking?"

He grins.

"I am not joking."

See also: Trainspotting, Out Of Sight, The Hudsucker Proxy, Some Like It Hot

Don't see also: Working Girl

Pointless trivia: Ben Affleck owns a vintage Pac Man arcade machine.
